docs.title: Chum Knowledge Base
docs.text:
Welcome to the wiki for Chum, a web serial set in an alternate-history Philadelphia where superpowers emerged in 1981 and reshaped every aspect of human civilization.

The story follows Samantha "Sam" Small, a 15-year-old Jewish girl from Tacony who becomes the vigilante Bloodhound — and the investigative team she builds to take on a conspiracy that reaches from the streets of Northeast Philly to the halls of Congress.

docs.title: Aaron McKinley
docs.text: A fire-manipulating villain and former gang leader who waged a prolonged campaign of violence against Sam Small, ultimately sentenced to 38 years in Daedalus Correctional Facility.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Aaron McKinley Aliases The Coyote Date of Birth Unknown Age 20s Gender Male Ethnicity White (described as pale-skinned) Place of Birth Unknown Residence Philadelphia, PA (formerly); Daedalus Correctional Facility (current) Affiliation None (solo operative at time of arrest) Former Affiliations Tacony Coyotes (leader), Kingdom of Keys (associate), Philly Phreaks (temporary alliance) Occupation Criminal Status Incarcerated First Appearance Chapter 20 Last Appearance Chapter 148 (in person); mentioned through Book 12

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Aaron McKinley was the leader of the Tacony Coyotes, a local teen gang operating out of the area beneath the Tacony-Palmyra Bridge in Northeast Philadelphia. He was physically distinctive, described as pale-skinned with tattoos, cornrows, and wind chime earrings. His gang engaged in vandalism, drug dealing, and petty theft throughout the Tacony and Mayfair neighborhoods. Aaron possessed fire-ignition powers activated by his gaze, making him the only metahuman in the group and the source of his authority over the other members.

Aaron's criminal trajectory escalated dramatically after his first encounter with Sam Small and Jordan Westwood in September 2023, when the two young vigilantes confronted the Coyotes beneath the bridge. The fight ended with Sam biting into Aaron's shoulder and breaking his collarbone. Humiliated and injured, Aaron was subsequently summoned by the Kingdom of Keys, for whom the Coyotes had been running low-level operations. Faced with the threat of severe punishment for losing the Kingdom's money, Aaron was given an assignment: kill Bloodhound. He formed a temporary alliance with members of the Philly Phreaks, including Pumice and Deathgirl, and identified Sam's civilian identity by surveilling Tacony Charter Academy.

After his coordinated ambush on Sam resulted in her capture and torture — during which he removed her fingernails and broke her hand — Sam escaped by growing teeth from her wrists and knuckles, puncturing Aaron's throat and tearing eight jagged lines across his face. His subsequent alliance with the Phreaks collapsed when Chrysalis, Pumice, and Deathgirl confronted him at the docks. Pumice showed Aaron the damage Sam had inflicted on his stone face during her escape, and Chrysalis delivered a devastating character assessment before telling him he was "not worth the bullet." Aaron retreated from Philadelphia with injuries including a dislocated knee (reset by the vet with a splint) and a re-broken nose, spending time in Bucks County and surrounding areas while his fire powers evolved. He returned months later to conduct a calculated arson and stalking campaign across Tacony in February 2025, which ended with his arrest following a final confrontation with Sam at an abandoned house near Vogt Park. He was sentenced to 38 years at Daedalus Correctional Facility.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Fire Ignition (Gaze-Based) — Aaron's original power allows him to ignite flammable materials and generate fire through his gaze. Initial manifestation produced standard yellow-orange flames capable of setting objects and people on fire, weakening metal supports, and creating area denial.
  • Fire Color Spectrum (Evolved) — Over time, Aaron developed the ability to produce multiple types of fire with distinct properties. Yellow flames represent his baseline ability. Red flames are hotter and more focused. Blue flames produce toxic fumes. White flames represent his most advanced and volatile manifestation, sometimes appearing unexpectedly even to Aaron himself.
  • Smoke Generation — Aaron can produce thick smoke to obscure vision, create smokescreens for escape, and fill enclosed spaces. This ability became more pronounced as his powers evolved.
  • Fire Immunity — Aaron is unharmed by his own flames, as demonstrated when Jordan threw a burning cloak onto him during their initial fight and he remained unaffected.
  • Toxic Fume Tolerance — Through deliberate exposure to his own blue fire's toxic byproducts, Aaron built a tolerance to the fumes that would incapacitate others.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Gaze Dependency — Aaron's fire-ignition power requires his gaze, making it vulnerable to visual obstruction. Sam neutralized this during their first fight by spitting blood into his eyes.
  • Respiratory Damage — Prolonged exposure to his own blue fire's toxic fumes caused significant deterioration of Aaron's lungs, noted by the veterinarian who treated him.
  • Inconsistent Control — Aaron's evolved fire abilities, particularly white fire, sometimes manifested unpredictably, suggesting incomplete mastery over his more advanced powers.
  • Physical Limitations — Despite his metahuman fire abilities, Aaron possesses no enhanced durability or healing. He sustained severe injuries across multiple fights, requiring treatment from a criminal-affiliated veterinarian.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Street fighting experience as a gang leader, though lacking formal combat training.
  • Proficiency in psychological warfare and intimidation tactics, including orchestrating indirect threatening messages through chains of unwitting intermediaries.
  • Surveillance and stalking skills, demonstrated by his methodical tracking of Sam's movements around her school, home, and known locations.
  • Knowledge of accelerant placement and fire manipulation for arson, including sabotaging sprinkler systems.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Aaron is sadistic, vengeful, and fixated on dominance through pain and fear. He speaks with a cruel playfulness that masks deep-seated rage, and his approach to conflict centers on causing maximum suffering rather than achieving tactical objectives. His torture of Sam — selecting a claw hammer and delivering a monologue about his father's philosophy on pain and power — reveals someone who has internalized violence as a framework for understanding the world. When confronted by others about his methods, he responds with threats and escalation rather than reflection.

Beneath the aggression, Aaron is driven by humiliation and a desperate need to prove his worth. His repeated defeats by a teenage girl destroyed his standing among both the Kingdom of Keys and the Philly Phreaks, the latter of whom called him "unoriginal and uninspired" before abandoning him. Rather than retreating permanently, Aaron chose to isolate himself and develop his powers in pursuit of personal revenge, reframing every setback as a tactical repositioning. He declared himself the sole Coyote — "The Coyotes are dead. Long live the Coyote" — and pursued Sam with single-minded obsession, conducting extensive surveillance and an escalating arson campaign designed to terrorize her before a final confrontation.

docs.title: Arc Appearances
docs.text: Book Role Key Events Book 2: Keys Supporting Antagonist Introduced as leader of the Tacony Coyotes in Chapter 20. Sam and Jordan confront his gang beneath the Tacony-Palmyra Bridge. Aaron reveals fire-ignition powers, sets Sam's costume ablaze, and collapses part of the overpass. Sam bites into his shoulder, breaks his collarbone, and neutralizes his fire by spitting blood in his eyes. Jordan steals the gang's drugs and money. Book 4: Exorcism Main Antagonist / Interlude In Interlude AMK.1, Aaron recovers from his defeat. He seeks treatment from a criminal veterinarian, is summoned by the Kingdom of Keys where Mr. Polygraph breaks his nose and assigns him to kill Bloodhound. Aaron resets his own nose, declares the Coyotes dead, and allies with Pumice. He surveils Tacony Charter Academy and identifies Sam's civilian identity. He ambushes Sam with a crowbar after she leaves power testing (Ch. 50), initiating a brutal multi-phase assault. Pumice, Deathgirl, and Chrysalis join the attack. Sam is captured and tortured — Aaron removes her fingernails and breaks her hand with a hammer while monologuing about power. Sam escapes by growing teeth from her body, scarring Aaron's face in the process (Chs. 51-52). In Interlude AMK.2, the Phreaks confront him at the docks, criticize his leadership, and abandon him. Aaron retreats to an abandoned basement where he discovers a new blue fire ability that produces toxic fumes, damaging his lungs. The vet warns him about his deteriorating respiratory health. Aaron interprets advice to leave the city as a "tactical retreat" and departs Philadelphia. Book 8: Big Mentioned Aaron's former Coyotes gang members are revealed to be deceased, reportedly killed in a drive-by shooting. Fires matching Aaron's evolved abilities begin appearing in Bucks County, showing progression from yellow to blue to red fire. Book 9: Sheol Main Antagonist Aaron returns to Philadelphia and conducts a week-long arson and psychological warfare campaign targeting Sam. He sets fires in a pattern circling Tacony Charter Academy, sabotages sprinkler systems, sends a threatening nail salon gift card through unwitting intermediaries, breaks into the Music Hall, sets Sam on fire at school along with six other students, and is the presumed arsonist behind the fire at Kate Smith's house. Sam and Derek track him to his hideout under the bridge. After escaping that encounter, Sam uses Crossroads' precognition to locate Aaron at an abandoned house near Vogt Park. The final battle reveals his evolved multi-spectrum fire abilities. Sam defeats him in brutal close-quarters combat, and Aaron is arrested on February 22, 2025. Book 10: Plume Mentioned Sam provides deposition testimony regarding Aaron's arrest. The Auditors investigate his defense attorney Katherine Huang and law firm Tremont & Fairfax, uncovering connections to the Kingdom of Keys and Stheno Pharmaceuticals. Aaron's defense is funded by mysterious "concerned citizens for due process." Sam reflects on the stalled trial during her 16th birthday. Book 11: Alarm Will Sound Mentioned Katherine Huang appears on Argus Corps paperwork, further connecting Tremont & Fairfax to both Aaron's defense and the broader Kingdom network. The circumstantial link between T&F representing both Aaron and Argus Corps becomes evidence in the Auditors' investigation of Councilwoman Richardson. Book 12: Authorized Personnel Only Mentioned Aaron receives a 38-year sentence at Daedalus Correctional Facility. Sam reflects on the conclusion of his case as she enters a new phase of operations.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Aaron's physical description includes cornrows and wind chime earrings, details that helped Sundial's psychometric sketch confirm his identity during the Book 9 arson investigation.
  • His former Coyotes gang members were all found dead in what was reported as a drive-by shooting, though the circumstances remain unexplained.
  • The veterinarian who treated Aaron, Dr. Fontana, is referred to as "Doc" in AMK.1 and "The Vet" in AMK.2. He repeatedly advised Aaron that he was not suited for the criminal lifestyle.
  • Aaron's fire powers are functionally distinct from Alex Kirby's (Hellhound) pyrokinesis; Aaron's are described as chaotic and gaze-based, while Alex's involve pressurized flammable gas jets with more controlled application.
  • His arson campaign in Book 9 triggered a wave of copycat arsons across Philadelphia, making it difficult to determine which fires were directly his work.
  • Sam feels unexpectedly conflicted about Aaron's lengthy 38-year sentence despite their violent history.
  • Aaron's father apparently espoused a philosophy about pain and power that Aaron internalized and repeated during his torture of Sam.
  • The Kingdom of Keys funded his defense through Tremont & Fairfax, though Katherine Huang herself was genuinely unaware of the Kingdom connection.
  • During the Kingdom meeting in AMK.1, Mr. Polygraph initially threatened a Yakuza-style punishment -- cutting off Aaron's pinky finger -- before relenting and breaking his nose with a punch instead.
  • When explaining his defeat to the vet in AMK.2, Aaron fabricated the excuse that Sam had suddenly developed "knives for arms," which the vet dismissed.
  • The Phreaks' rejection of Aaron in AMK.2 centered not just on his tactical failures but on a comparison to their former leader Patches, who they said genuinely cared for the group's members -- something Aaron never did.
  • After his abandonment by the Phreaks, Aaron considered heading to Atlantic City or nearby counties, reframing the vet's advice to leave Philadelphia as a "tactical retreat" rather than admitting defeat.
  • Pumice referenced having a "secret weapon" when he and Aaron formed their alliance at the warehouse near the docks in AMK.1, foreshadowing Deathgirl's involvement in the ambush.

docs.title: Abigail Silverman
docs.text: Sam Small's journalist cousin and closest family confidante, who independently deduces Sam's identity as Bloodhound through investigative reasoning during a Rosh Hashanah gathering.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Abigail Silverman Aliases Abby Date of Birth Unknown Age Late teens to early twenties (college-age) Gender Female Ethnicity Jewish-American Place of Birth Unknown Residence Boston, MA (Emerson College) Affiliation Small family Former Affiliations N/A Occupation Student, Journalist / Activist Status Active First Appearance Chapter 68 Last Appearance Chapter 197 (mentioned)

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Abigail Silverman is Sam Small's first cousin, described as the closest thing Sam has to a sister. She is connected to the Small family through Pop-Pop Moe (Morris Small), who lists her as a granddaughter "by marriage, via niece/nephew." Her exact branch of the family tree -- whether she is Uncle Shelley's daughter or connected through another relative -- is not explicitly clarified. She is also referred to once as "Abigail Small" in the Book 7 arc summary, though "Silverman" is her predominant surname across all other sources.

Abigail is a journalist and political activist attending Emerson College in Boston. She is described as a "force of nature" with strong political tendencies and a willingness to challenge family norms. She has artificially straightened hair and appeared at Rosh Hashanah dinner in Book 7 with a bruised face from protest injuries, reflecting her direct involvement in activist causes.

Her most significant narrative contribution occurs during the Rosh Hashanah gathering at Pop-Pop Moe's house in Ventnor (Book 7, Chapter 108), where she independently deduces that Sam is Bloodhound through investigative reasoning during the Tashlich ceremony at the pier. She promises to keep the secret, making her one of the few civilians outside Sam's immediate team who knows her superhero identity.

docs.title: Powers & Abilities
docs.text: Abigail Silverman has no metahuman abilities. Her contributions are based on her investigative journalism skills, political activism, and personal courage.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Trained journalist with sharp investigative reasoning abilities, sufficient to independently piece together Sam's identity as Bloodhound from circumstantial evidence.
  • Active political organizer with experience in protest movements, as evidenced by her bruised face from protest injuries.
  • Engaged in theological and political debate, capable of challenging family members and navigating heated intellectual discussions.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Abigail is described as a "force of nature" -- politically engaged, intellectually aggressive, and willing to challenge established norms even within her own family. She initiates theological debates (such as the question of God hardening Pharaoh's heart as a test of free will versus determinism) and makes political comments that provoke discussion. Her activism is not performative; she shows up with protest injuries and claims to be "in the area" when visiting Sam in the hospital, though Sam suspects she traveled specifically to see her.

Despite her forceful personality, Abigail demonstrates genuine emotional warmth and loyalty. Her relationship with Sam functions as a sibling bond, and her promise to protect Sam's secret after deducing the Bloodhound identity reflects both her personal loyalty and her professional understanding of what that information could mean if exposed.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• The plot thread tracker classifies Abigail's knowledge of Sam's identity as an open thread (O27): "Another identity-knowledge leverage point." The thread analysis notes that if a civilian family member can independently deduce Sam's identity, others might too.
  • Her identity deduction during the Tashlich ceremony is one of several identity compromises Sam faces in Book 7, alongside Patriot discovering it when Sam's helmet breaks (Ch. 118) and federal agents having her file on record from congressional testimony (Ch. 114).
  • She is referred to as "Abigail Small" once (in the Book 7 arc summary character table) and "Abigail Silverman" everywhere else. The discrepancy likely reflects uncertainty about whether "Small" is her birth surname or "Silverman" comes from another parent.
  • Her proximity to the Boston Activation Incident while attending Emerson College creates a geographic connection to Claymore's story in Intermission 15.5: This Side Up, though the two characters have no known direct interaction.
  • Her artificially straightened hair is noted during the Passover Seder in Book 5.

docs.title: Akilah Washington
docs.text: Former leader of the Young Defenders turned private investigator, a telekinetic string user now operating under the alias Marionette.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Akilah Washington Aliases Puppeteer (former), Marionette (current) Date of Birth Unknown Age 20s Gender Female Ethnicity African-American Place of Birth Unknown Residence Philadelphia, PA Affiliation Chambers & Woo Investigations Former Affiliations Young Defenders, Delaware Valley Defenders (associated) Occupation Private Investigator, College Student Status Active First Appearance Chapter 5 Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Akilah Washington was a competitive gymnast on an Olympic-level trajectory before an accident during a routine caused her to break both ankles. During the fall, her telekinetic string powers manifested for the first time, saving her from breaking her neck. The injuries ended her gymnastics career, but she was recruited into superhero work by Liberty Belle and joined the Young Defenders, initially serving as second-in-command under the prior leader, Labyrinth.

Following Labyrinth's graduation from the team in 2021, Akilah ascended to the position of field leader. She led the Young Defenders through a turbulent period that included Liberty Belle's terminal illness and eventual death at the hands of Chernobyl. The pressure of leadership, compounded by underlying mental health issues, took a severe toll. Akilah had a confrontation with Sam Small in which she physically assaulted Sam using her strings, and was subsequently admitted to the Elysium Behavioral Health and Wellness Center for inpatient psychiatric treatment. During her stay, she was diagnosed with Narcissistic Personality Disorder and prescribed Quetiapine and Fluoxetine.

In 2023, Akilah stepped down as leader of the Young Defenders, citing mental health concerns and personality incompatibilities. She later resigned from the team entirely alongside Devonte Harris to pursue personal goals. Akilah adopted the new codename Marionette and transitioned into private investigation work at Chambers & Woo Investigations, where she and Devonte now assist with the ongoing investigation into the Kingdom of Keys. Her NPD diagnosis bars her from becoming a Registered Superhuman Entity, though she retains her LUMA and can operate as a licensed vigilante.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: Field Value Classification C6/SONIE/P/B Category Create Power Ranking 6/10 Control 9/10 Hostility 2/10 Collateral Damage 2/10 Threat Level 3/10

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Telekinetic String Creation — Generates up to ten invisible telekinetic strings from her fingertips, one per finger. The strings are approximately the thickness of a pencil and appear as a slight shimmer in the air. They can attach to and manipulate objects within range.
  • String Projection — Projects strings at approximately 200 meters per second. Upon impact, strings impart a slight arbitrary force of around 3 Newtons in the direction of travel. Unanchored strings retract at the same speed they are projected.
  • String Durability — Strings possess roughly the tensile strength of steel cable and are non-conductive to both heat and electricity. They can be sheared with force exceeding 50,000 PSI, which produces an extremely unpleasant sensation for Akilah.
  • Range — Maximum extension of 112 meters in clear conditions. Requires line of sight to the targeted attachment point and guides strings visually.
  • Manipulation and Retraction — Can manipulate each string individually with high precision. Retraction pulls objects toward her or propels her toward larger objects, operating on her own physical strength. Can create slack to form loops and knots.
  • Tactile Feedback — Receives sensory feedback through her strings, allowing her to feel the objects they are attached to. This feedback enables precise control but can be overwhelming if too many complex sensations occur simultaneously.
  • Enhanced Mobility — Uses strings for rappelling, grappling, and rapid traversal of urban environments in a manner comparable to Spider-Man.
  • Combat Applications — Employs strings as extended limbs to engage opponents at range, entangle objects, create barriers, use small objects as improvised meteor hammers, and has demonstrated knowledge of garrote techniques. Can also physically restrain and manipulate people.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Physical Strain — Extended or intensive use causes physical fatigue similar to rigorous exercise. Pulling force is limited to her own physical strength.
  • Mental Concentration — Requires significant concentration to maintain control, especially when manipulating multiple strings in complex patterns simultaneously.
  • Visibility — Strings can be detected by their shimmering effect against certain backgrounds or lighting conditions. Airborne dust, smoke, or similar particulates make strings more visible.
  • Environmental Interference — Chaotic environments with multiple moving objects impair targeting and control. Attaching to heavy mobile objects such as vehicles can drag Akilah unwillingly.
  • Line of Sight — Requires visual contact with the intended attachment point to project strings accurately.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Former Olympic-level gymnast, providing exceptional agility, spatial awareness, and body control even after her career-ending injury.
  • Trained in superhero field leadership and tactical coordination through years of leading the Young Defenders.
  • Professional investigation skills acquired through work at Chambers & Woo Investigations, including surveillance, evidence analysis, counter-surveillance protocols, and legal documentation.
  • Currently completing a college degree.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Akilah is precise, articulate, and deliberate in her word choice, carrying herself with a professional bearing that reflects both her therapy and her investigative career. She has a narcissistic streak that she is now self-aware about following her NPD diagnosis and treatment, and she channels that self-awareness into measured, careful interactions. She speaks with authority and expects competence from those around her.

Beneath the controlled exterior, Akilah struggles with the tension between her desire for significance and her understanding of her own flaws. She has demonstrated a capacity for genuine accountability, as shown by her formal apology to Sam Small after assaulting her. She maintains a love-hate dynamic with Devonte Harris, marked by constant banter that has settled into a comfortable rhythm over time. She represents a more mature, professional path through the superhero world, contrasting with both Sam's vigilantism and the government-aligned Argus Corps approach.

docs.title: Alex Kirby
docs.text: Sixteen-year-old pyrokinetic and member of the Auditors' mentorship program who adopted the vigilante identity "Hellhound" after warping Sam Small's retired Bloodhound mask.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Alex Kirby Aliases Hellhound Date of Birth Unknown Age 16 Gender Male Ethnicity White Place of Birth Harrisburg, Pennsylvania Residence Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (recently relocated) Affiliation Mentorship Program (Tacony Community Center) Former Affiliations N/A Occupation Student Status Active (Benched) First Appearance Chapter 215 Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Alex Kirby is a white teenager who recently relocated to Philadelphia from Harrisburg, Pennsylvania. His parents hold mid-level administrative positions in the Pennsylvania state government — not elected officials, but functionaries with enough standing that City Councilman Jamal Davis knows them professionally. It was this professional connection, rather than a referral from Dr. Jensen (who flagged the other mentorship candidates), that secured Alex's place in the pilot peer mentorship program spearheaded by Davis in the aftermath of the Shrike crisis.

Alex arrived at the first mentorship meeting at the Tacony Music Hall on November 11, 2025, the last of the four initial students to show up. He recognized Sam Small from the Harrisburg senate hearing, establishing an immediate connection to her public profile. During the group's power demonstrations, Alex produced a small flame in his palm, accompanied by a faint smell of propane and alcohol — the first indication of his pyrokinetic abilities.

Over the following months, Alex participated in regular mentorship sessions at the Parkway Central Library, Franklin Park, Pennypack Park, and eventually the Tacony Community Center. He trained alongside Zara Khan, Liam O'Connor, and Jasmine Walker under Sam and Maggie O'Brien's guidance, developing increasingly precise fire control. However, his desire for bold, decisive action clashed with the program's emphasis on measured development and restraint. In mid-January 2026, Alex revealed he had been conducting unauthorized solo reconnaissance on Kingdom of Keys operations for three weeks and intended to raid a distribution warehouse alone. Despite Sam's objections, she coordinated his operation remotely, during which Alex barely survived an encounter with the Kingdom enforcer Garbage Day. Sam subsequently benched him from all solo operations indefinitely. Alex created his "Hellhound" identity by warping Sam's old Bloodhound mask, declaring it his own.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Pyrokinesis (Torch-Style) — Generates pressurized jets of an anomalous flammable gas mixture and flash-ignites them. This is not true pyrogenesis; the process produces a chemical mixture that smells faintly of propane and alcohol. The mechanism is closer to a biological blowtorch than spontaneous fire creation.
  • Variable Flame Control — Can adjust output through muscle effort, narrowing to a focused hot jet capable of cutting through metal (melted a padlock and deadbolt during the warehouse infiltration) or widening to a dull, short flame suitable for warming or ambient light.
  • White-Hot Incandescent Beam — Upper limit of his power: a white-hot beam projected simultaneously from all ten fingers, effective as an oxy-cutting torch. Sustainable for only 10-20 seconds before he loses consciousness.
  • Flashbang Deployment — Can accumulate flammable gas at a location and then ignite it as a concussive flash, blinding and disorienting opponents. Used this technique to neutralize two armed guards during the warehouse raid.
  • Steam Explosion — Can direct a plasma-torch-intensity flame at snow or water to create a sudden burst of superheated steam, useful as a defensive or area-denial tool.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Alex is a baseline human outside of his pyrokinesis; he possesses no enhanced durability, regeneration, or secondary physical enhancements.
  • His maximum output (white-hot beam from all ten fingers) is sustainable for only 10-20 seconds before he passes out, leaving him completely vulnerable.
  • He was physically outmatched by Garbage Day during the warehouse raid, demonstrating that his fire is insufficient against opponents with high durability or structural manipulation powers.
  • He sustained serious injuries from conventional weapons during the warehouse operation: a bullet caught by his vest that cracked his ribs, plus two grazing gunshot wounds to his left thigh and left upper arm.
  • His fires produce a distinctive smell (propane and alcohol), which can potentially identify him or his presence at a scene.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Received power control training through the mentorship program under Sam Small and Maggie O'Brien, developing precision fire techniques and de-escalation awareness.
  • Conducted three weeks of independent surveillance and reconnaissance on Kingdom operations, producing hand-drawn maps and stolen distribution schedules — indicating aptitude for fieldwork and intelligence gathering.
  • Demonstrated tactical thinking during the warehouse raid, including using accumulated gas as a flashbang, disarming guards, and stripping and scattering their ammunition.
  • Expressed interest in business and drag racing during mentorship career discussions.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Alex Kirby is a romantic in the genre sense — he believes in grand gestures, dramatic action, and making a difference through bold moves. He is driven by a hunger for significance that his emotionally unavailable, career-focused parents fail to provide. He validates frustration and encourages action over patience, not out of malice but out of a deep conviction that heroism is the path to meaning. Mrs. Patterson, the community center's youth services veteran, identified the core of his behavior succinctly: he acts out not because he wants to break rules, but because he does not know who he is if he is not fighting something.

This romantic disposition makes Alex an interesting counterpoint to Sam Small's increasing cynicism and realpolitik tendencies. Where Sam has learned to think in terms of systems, leverage, and long games, Alex still believes in the power of a single dramatic act to change things. His unauthorized warehouse raid — three weeks of solo reconnaissance culminating in a one-man assault on a Kingdom distribution hub — is the clearest expression of this worldview. He is not reckless in the way of someone who does not think; he is reckless in the way of someone who has thought about it and decided the risk is worth the story. On Valentine's Day, he showed up at Sam's house at 8 AM with expensive chocolates and a rehearsed speech, was turned down gracefully, and accepted the rejection after about ten seconds — passing what Sam internally called "the test" of whether he would push back. His parting observation to Sam was pointed: the situation is not a cowboy movie or an action movie, but it is not a political thriller either, and she could stand to lighten up.

Possesses structural manipulation powers that made him physically immune to Alex's fire.

docs.title: Arc Appearances
docs.text: Book Role Key Events Book 14: Shelter in Place Supporting Introduced in Chapter 215 as one of four initial mentorship students at the Tacony Music Hall. Arrives last, recognizes Sam from the Harrisburg senate hearing. Demonstrates pyrogenesis during the power-sharing session, producing a small flame with a propane/alcohol smell. Participates in subsequent mentorship sessions at the Parkway Central Library and Franklin Park, developing fire control. Book 15: Severe Weather Warning Major Attends mentorship meeting at Sam's house during the Rogue Wave/Kingdom fallout period (Chapter 221), practicing powers in the alley behind the house. Trains at Pennypack Park in January (Chapter 222), using fire to warm the group during winter sessions. Participates in mentorship career discussions, expressing interest in business and drag racing. Briefly glimpsed by Sam fleeing the Rittenhouse Square consulting firm fire (Chapter 225/228), though Sam does not confirm his identity at the time. Reveals three weeks of unauthorized solo reconnaissance on Kingdom operations during the January 14 blizzard crisis (Chapter 229), presenting stolen distribution schedules and hand-drawn surveillance maps. Executes the warehouse raid in Interlude AK.1: infiltrates the Torresdale Avenue warehouse, photographs all 15 break-ins' stolen goods, is shot in the chest (vest saves him) and grazed twice, deploys a gas flashbang to neutralize guards, burns Kingdom records, barely survives Garbage Day's arrival, and limps three blocks to extraction. Debriefed by Sam in Chapter 230; benched from solo operations indefinitely. Sam inspects his injuries and delivers the ultimatum: "I'm not Belle. I'm not going to do to you what she did to me." Present during mentorship meetings in Chapters 229-231 while Sam navigates legal constraints. Book 16: Category Five Hurricane Supporting Present at the Tacony Community Center grand opening (Chapter 234), lurking near the cookies and watching Sam. Shows up at Sam's house on Valentine's Day (Chapter 235) with expensive chocolates, asks Sam out, is turned down, and accepts gracefully. Described as "incinerating cardboard" and being "very normal" at the community center that same day. Present during the Songbird attack on the community center (Chapter 240), pacing and furious, wanting to fight; Sam shuts him down. His parents do not come to pick him up -- they send a taxi. Sam explicitly addresses him in the de-escalation speech, warning that setting a Songbird on fire would destroy the narrative advantage of adults harassing children.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Alex's "Hellhound" alias is a deliberate derivation of Sam's "Bloodhound" identity, created by physically warping Sam's old mask. His explanation — "so it was mine" — encapsulates his need to claim significance through connection to established heroic legacy.
  • His fire is explicitly described as more controlled and utility-focused than Aaron McKinley's chaotic fire, positioning the two pyrokinetics as thematic opposites: one a tool user, the other a destroyer.
  • Alex was identified by the arc synopsis as representing the next generation of powered kids Sam is trying to prevent from becoming vigilantes. His unauthorized raid forced Sam to confront the limits of mentorship.
  • Sam explicitly invoked Liberty Belle when benching Alex: "I'm not Belle. I'm not going to do to you what she did to me."
  • During the Valentine's Day exchange, Alex told Sam: "That didn't stop Peter Parker." Sam's response: "I don't read comics."
  • His parents' absence during the Songbird attack — sending a taxi instead of coming themselves — is noted by the narrative as significant and "filed away" by Sam.
  • Alex entered the mentorship program through Davis's professional connections to his parents rather than through Dr. Jensen's referral system, making him the only member of the initial cohort who was not flagged through clinical or institutional channels.
  • Mrs. Patterson described Alex as "a romantic" who acts out because he does not know who he is if he is not fighting something — and noted the parallel to Sam herself.

docs.title: Amelia Li
docs.text: Fourth-generation Chinese-American metahuman with an intuitive mastery of textiles, serving as costumier and quartermaster for the Young Defenders and later the Auditors under the codename Gossamer.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Amelia Li Aliases Gossamer, Stingray (temporary villain persona) Date of Birth Unknown Age 19–21 Gender Female Ethnicity Chinese-American (fourth-generation) Place of Birth Philadelphia, PA (presumed) Residence Chinatown, Philadelphia, PA Affiliation Auditors Former Affiliations Young Defenders, Delaware Valley Defenders (associated) Occupation College Student, Superhero Quartermaster / Equipment Specialist Status Active First Appearance Chapter 5 Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Amelia Li is a fourth-generation Chinese-American who lives with her family in Chinatown, Philadelphia. She manifested a Brain-type power granting her an extraordinary intuitive understanding of textiles, weaving, and material science. Her parents have been reluctant to acknowledge her powers, and their disapproval of her superhero activities has remained a persistent source of tension throughout her career. Her initial PERKS assessment in 2018 noted her reticence about sharing personal details and a strong inclination toward people-pleasing, traits that have continued to define her interpersonal dynamics.

Following her activation, Amelia was approved for a JLUMA (Juvenile License for the Unsupervised Metahuman Activity) due to her negligible collateral damage potential. She joined the Young Defenders and adopted the codename Gossamer on the recommendation of a friend. On the team, she served primarily as the costumier and field medic, designing costumes and equipment for her teammates while providing first aid during operations. She also began contributing her skills to the adult Delaware Valley Defenders.

When anti-vigilante legislation passed in March 2025 and the Young Defenders faced dissolution, Amelia initially expressed a desire to leave superhero work and focus on civilian life. However, she reversed course and instead joined the Auditors, the independent team founded by Sam Small and Jordan Westwood. She set up a dedicated workspace at the Tacony Music Hall with medical supplies and equipment, officially becoming the team's quartermaster. Her JLUMA was upgraded to a full LUMA in 2023.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: Field Value Classification B4/S/M/R Category Brain Power Ranking 4/10 Control 10/10 Hostility 0/10 Collateral Damage 0/10 Threat Level 1/10

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Intuitive Textile Understanding — Possesses an innate, intuitive grasp of textiles, weaving, tailoring, and material science as it relates to fabric and clothing. This understanding is experiential and intuitive rather than theoretical; she cannot explain or teach the underlying principles to others.
  • Anomalous Muscle Memory — Her power provides exceptional muscle memory for complex textile-related tasks. She can perform intricate work without conscious planning or visual aid, and her muscle memory functions equally through any medium (needle and thread, sewing machine, or other tools) as long as at least one hand is on one of the objects being manipulated.
  • Structural Analysis (Textile-Analogous) — Her understanding extends to structures that behave like textiles or can be conceived of as thread-related or strands under tension, including ropes, steel cables, nets, sails, knots, suspension bridges, and bullwhips. She can assess load-bearing structures and identify structural weak points.
  • Medical Application — Can perform complex medical tasks analogous to weaving or tailoring, such as suturing wounds and tying tourniquets, with minimal instruction.
  • Anomalous Textile Creation — Has developed the ability to create textiles with properties that defy conventional material science, including self-repairing fabrics, fabrics that actively circulate air, and materials with designated weak points for tactical purposes. She does not fully understand how she produces these effects.
  • Whip Mastery — Has secretly trained herself to use bullwhips with remarkable precision, leveraging her intuitive understanding of structures under tension. She currently possesses four anomalous whips, including at least one that produces sparking effects.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Material Scope — Her powers apply only to threads, ropes, steel cables, fabrics, clothes, nets, sails, knots, and structures behaving like textiles. Rigid materials such as concrete, non-textile metals, plastics, glass, and electronic components are entirely outside her scope.
  • Contact Required — Physical contact or proximity to the material is necessary for her power to manifest effectively. She has limited capability in understanding patterns or structures through indirect means such as pictures or videos.
  • Non-Combative Origin — Her powers are not inherently offensive or defensive. Her combat effectiveness depends on equipment she has prepared in advance, particularly her whips and custom gear.
  • Inexplicable Mechanisms — She cannot explain how she creates her anomalous textiles, which limits her ability to replicate or teach her techniques. Her creations have been described as "microscope breakers" because their properties defy analysis.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• First aid and field medicine training, including bandaging, suturing, and CPR. Served as the Young Defenders' field medic during operations.
  • Skilled in boxing and sparring, having trained with teammates and corrected Sam Small's technique during recovery training sessions.
  • Proficient whip combatant, self-taught through her power's extension to structures under tension.
  • Experienced costume and equipment designer, having produced costumes and tactical gear for the Young Defenders, Delaware Valley Defenders, and Auditors across multiple years.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Amelia is methodical, detail-oriented, and somewhat maternal toward younger team members. She speaks with authority on technical matters related to her expertise but harbors vulnerability about the perceived inadequacy of her powers, questioning what value "super-tailoring" holds in a superhero context. She is compulsively people-pleasing, a trait that PERKS officers noted as early as her first assessment in 2018 and one that has only become more reflexive over the years. This tendency is rooted in a difficult relationship with her parents, who have never fully accepted her superhero activities.

Beneath her agreeable exterior, Amelia possesses a secret venomous side that she works hard to suppress. Sam Small, the narrator and her team leader, is completely unaware of this aspect of her personality. Amelia has grown increasingly confident in her abilities and her role on the Auditors, enjoying the opportunities to operate in the field and observing how her power continues to evolve with further understanding. She is capable of asking pointed, difficult questions when the moment demands it, as demonstrated when she challenged Sam for treating herself as merely a messenger rather than a leader.

Trains with Sam and provides emotional support. docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Her codename Gossamer was adopted on the recommendation of an unspecified friend.
  • Her PERKS interviewing officer, M. Reynolds, assessed her across six separate years (2018 through 2023) and consistently noted her people-pleasing tendencies, describing them as "almost reflexive" by 2022.
  • Her power assessment was conducted by Dr. Leonard Harris, the same specialist who assessed Akilah Washington's powers.
  • Her PERKS classification code B4/S/M/R indicates Brain-type, power level 4, affecting Self, Mental in nature, operating at Room-sized radius.
  • She had a romantic relationship with Devonte Harris (Playback) that ended because he would not have sex before marriage due to his Christian faith, and neither of them wanted to get married.
  • She designed the original Bloodhound costume that gave Sam Small her superhero identity.
  • Her anomalous textiles have been described as "microscope breakers" because their properties cannot be explained through conventional material science analysis.
  • She uses a scooter as her primary mode of transportation, which has served as the Auditors' extraction vehicle on multiple occasions.
  • Her temporary villain persona "Stingray" was used during an undercover operation against the Kingdom of Keys in Book 16.

docs.title: Andrew Mitchell
docs.text: Government-sanctioned superhero and member of Argus Corps who privately questions his team's leadership while secretly investigating Maya Richardson's ties to the Kingdom of Keys.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Andrew Mitchell Aliases Captain Devil, Captain Jersey Devil Date of Birth Unknown (approximately mid-1990s) Age Early 30s Gender Male Ethnicity Black Place of Birth Trenton, New Jersey Residence Philadelphia, PA (row home neighborhood) Affiliation Argus Corps Former Affiliations N/A Occupation Registered Superhuman Entity (government-employed superhero) Status Active First Appearance Interlude MR.4 (recruitment); Chapter 160 (public debut) Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Andrew Mitchell is a metahuman from Trenton, New Jersey, who gained his powers approximately ten years before the events of the main story during a solo camping trip in the Pine Barrens. Mitchell had been visiting the Pine Barrens since he was nineteen -- first with friends, then alone, then with his partner Diana when they began dating. He treated these solo trips as a periodic reset, something Diana understood he needed every few months the way she needed her sister weekends. On the night of his activation event, he detected a distant wildfire approximately two miles west and began breaking down camp. Before he could evacuate, the forest emptied around him: a deer crashed through his campsite clipping his cooler, followed by a fox, rabbits, squirrels, and a nocturnal raccoon waddling at maximum speed. Distant sounds resembling gunshots accompanied the exodus. A black bear, approximately three hundred pounds, charged through at a full sprint -- not hunting but fleeing in pure animal panic, trailing a cub behind it. Mitchell was directly in its path with no time to climb or run. He attempted to calculate which limbs he could sacrifice, thinking "Please. I have a fiance. Probably kids." The bear mauled him, leaving a significant scar on his chest that still itches when he thinks about the Barrens. The traumatic encounter served as his activation event, granting him a suite of powers loosely themed around the Jersey Devil of regional folklore: invisible telekinetic claws, echolocation, a fear-inducing aura, and toxic blood.

Following his activation, Mitchell spent a period learning to control his abilities, during which he accidentally killed a civilian. This incident left a lasting psychological mark and became a core motivator in his superhero career, driving him to seek redemption and reclaim his name through legitimate heroism. He adopted the identity of Captain Devil (sometimes Captain Jersey Devil), deliberately styling himself after tokusatsu heroes and dark justice archetypes from the anime and sentai media he loves. His signature look -- a domino mask, large red scarf inspired by Kamen Rider, and red beret -- reflects this aesthetic sensibility.

Mitchell was recruited to Argus Corps by Councilwoman Maya Richardson during a private meeting at a rented coworking space, where Richardson appealed specifically to his desire for redemption and the chance to rebuild his legacy. He was the last of the four founding members to arrive at the recruitment meeting and remained the most reserved and detached of the group. When Argus Corps was publicly unveiled at a press conference in late April 2025, Mitchell made a dramatic entrance as the team's newest member. He subsequently relocated to the Philadelphia area to serve on the team, commuting via SEPTA and maintaining a family home in a residential neighborhood.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Invisible Telekinetic Claws — Mitchell's primary power consists of two invisible telekinetic appendages positioned above his left and right shoulders. Each appendage has two talons approximately the size of a human arm. The claws lack fine gripping dexterity and are not sharp enough to pierce skin, but they are highly effective at destroying property, capturing and restraining people, and intimidating animals. Mitchell can only control them in broad sweeping gestures rather than precise movements. He has described them as sitting on his shoulders "like two invisible albatrosses." The claws are capable of damaging marble flooring and can clear smoke from his immediate path.
  • Echolocation — A secondary sensory ability that allows Mitchell to navigate and track targets in low-visibility conditions. During the Stheno Pharmaceuticals warehouse confrontation, he demonstrated the ability to track Soot through dense smoke where visual tracking was impossible.
  • Fear Aura — Mitchell passively emanates a supernatural sense of dread that affects those in his proximity. The aura is most effective against animals but also produces an instinctual fear response in humans. Sam Small experienced this effect firsthand during their encounters, describing it as an involuntary, gut-level terror distinct from ordinary intimidation.
  • Poisonous, Acidic Blood — Mitchell's blood is both toxic and corrosive, rendering him extremely dangerous to bite-based or blood-contact attackers. Sam discovered this limitation during their confrontation at Richardson's town hall event, realizing she could not safely use her tooth-based attacks against him.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• The telekinetic claws lack fine motor control and can only be directed in sweeping gestures, limiting their utility in precision tasks or situations requiring delicate handling.
  • The claws cannot pierce human skin, making them ineffective as cutting or stabbing weapons; their utility is primarily in blunt force, restraint, and property destruction.
  • Mitchell's fear aura appears to function passively rather than as a directed ability, and its effectiveness varies significantly depending on the target (strongest against animals, weaker and more variable against humans).
  • The acidic blood is a defensive trait rather than one Mitchell can weaponize offensively; it protects him from certain attackers but does not grant him ranged capability.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Experienced outdoorsman and hiker who has been visiting the Pine Barrens since age nineteen, with years of wilderness survival knowledge including campsite management, fire safety, weather assessment, wind direction analysis, and wildlife behavior interpretation. During the Pine Barrens incident, he correctly assessed the wildfire's distance (~2 miles), direction (east-southeast), and timeline (hours before reaching his position) and began orderly evacuation before the animal exodus changed the situation.
  • Competent hand-to-hand combatant, utilizing the heavy bag and training facilities at Argus Corps headquarters regularly.
  • Skilled investigator who pieces together intelligence from overheard conversations, meeting notes, and behavioral patterns to form conclusions about colleagues and targets.
  • Demonstrates strong interpersonal skills and institutional knowledge, maintaining relationships with support staff and civilians at Argus Corps headquarters.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Andrew Mitchell presents a striking contrast between his intimidating exterior and his genuine warmth. Tall and physically imposing, he cuts an intentionally fearsome figure as Captain Devil, but beneath the domino mask and flowing red scarf is a devoted father, an avid comic book nerd, and a man who makes a point of learning the names of support staff and asking about their families. He is an enthusiast of anime, tokusatsu, and Kamen Rider -- interests that remain relatively obscure in his world's timeline -- and his entire superhero aesthetic is built around the "dark hero of justice" archetype he admires from those media. He follows tokusatsu release forums in his downtime and debates whether he can justify the price of a new Kuuga figure.

Mitchell's approach to the dual-identity problem is deliberate and ritualistic: the scarf and beret go on in the elevator down to the hero level, and they come off and go into his bag when he leaves. Captain Devil stays in the car; Andrew Mitchell walks through the front door. He frames this separation as essential to protecting both the people he works with and the people he comes home to.

Mitchell operates under a persistent "just doing my job" mentality that functions as cognitive dissonance for the morally uncomfortable work Argus Corps requires. He would prefer saving lives defensively to fighting criminals proactively, and he struggles openly with assignments that pit him against people he believes are doing more good than harm -- such as the Kensington phase-walker who destroys pharmacy fentanyl supplies. The accidental killing of a civilian during his early career weighs on him heavily and informs his cautious, measured approach to confrontations. He gave Sam Small an opportunity to surrender peacefully before using force at the town hall, and he chose not to pursue Sam and Maggie once they escaped into a public area with civilians. He has been described as "really too nice for this team," and the growing contradictions between his moral compass and Argus Corps' direction are building toward a likely defection or resignation.

docs.title: Relationships
docs.text: Character Relationship Notes Jasmine Perez (Turbo Jett) Teammate / Investigative partner The two conduct a secret parallel investigation into Maya Richardson's potential Kingdom ties, sharing intelligence in corridors without working cameras (exploiting Jenkins's maintenance backlog). Jett is more impulsive -- she stole Patriot's unlocked phone during a bathroom break to read his browser tabs, prompting Mitchell to hiss her first name in exasperation. She returned it to Patriot's table within minutes. Her FBI contact revealed that Tremont & Fairfax's lawyer Huang handled both the firm's incorporation paperwork and Aaron McKinley's pro bono case, raising the question of why a New York megafirm would take pro bono defense of a minor Philly arsonist. They address each other by first name (Jasmine and Andrew) when off the record. Jett's parting advice about the Kensington phase-walker ("He's not wrong about the drugs") stayed with Mitchell all afternoon. Richard Johnson (Patriot) Teammate / Team leader Mitchell serves under Patriot's command and follows his operational assignments. He pieced together from overheard conversations and meeting notes that Patriot walked into Maya Richardson's office months ago and told her directly that a teenage vigilante (Bulldozer/McNulty) thinks she is Kingdom -- a disclosure Mitchell considers either incredibly stupid or "something else." Jett's theft of Patriot's phone revealed he was independently researching barokinesis, Richard Duvall, Councilman Silverstein, and two-year-old weather reports, suggesting his own parallel investigation that neither Mitchell nor Jett fully understand. Joshua Pleasants (Miasma) Teammate Mitchell finds Miasma cryptic and difficult to read, noting he has grown even more distant and impossible to interpret. Suspects Miasma knows more than he shares but cannot determine his true allegiance. Maya Richardson (Mrs. Zenith) Ostensible superior / Investigation target Richardson recruited Mitchell to Argus Corps by appealing to his desire for redemption. Mitchell now suspects she may be Mrs. Zenith of the Kingdom of Keys, placing a fifty-fifty probability on the assessment. He is investigating her quietly alongside Jett. Sean McNulty (Bulldozer) Indirect contact Mitchell believes Bulldozer's claim that Richardson is Kingdom, which was relayed through Patriot's team briefing. This intelligence forms the foundation of his secret investigation. Diana Mitchell Fiancee/Wife A pediatric clinic worker who wears light blue scrubs (pediatric ward) and tolerates Andrew's camping trips and nerd hobbies, sometimes buying him tokusatsu figures for Christmas despite rolling her eyes at the hobby. She reads his moods perceptively ("You're thinking too loud") and teases him as "Mr. Dark Hero of Justice." She leaves the front door unlocked despite Mitchell asking approximately eight hundred times, insisting "the neighbors watch out for each other." She accompanied him on Pine Barrens trips when they were dating and understands his need for periodic solo resets. She smells like hand sanitizer and floral lotion from the constant washing her clinic work requires. They have a warm, stable partnership built on mutual understanding of each other's separate lives. Malik Mitchell Son Ten years old, perfecting the dismissive older sibling routine. Sleeps with a tablet under his pillow. Resembles Diana when sleeping. Destiny Mitchell Daughter Seven years old, convinced that running is superior to walking. Takes after Andrew's side of the family. Firmly believes cartwheels should be a superpower. Sam Small (Bloodhound) Adversary (professional) Mitchell has pursued and fought Sam on multiple occasions as part of his Argus Corps duties, but conducts these confrontations with restraint and professionalism. He offered Sam a chance to surrender at the town hall and chose not to pursue her into a civilian area. Marcus (Security Guard) Colleague (support staff) Front desk security guard at Argus Corps headquarters. Mitchell makes a point of asking about Marcus's family; Marcus's daughter Tamika made the Dean's List at Temple University. Their brief daily exchanges reflect Mitchell's deliberate effort to maintain relationships with non-powered staff. Rosario (Dispatch) Colleague (support staff) Dispatch operator at Argus Corps headquarters. Reported a quiet overnight shift to Mitchell, including a kid practicing pyrokinesis in a Fishtown garage. Mitchell makes a point of learning support staff names and engaging with them personally. Jenkins (Tech Support) Colleague (support staff) Argus Corps tech support, often seen working on Jett's backup suit. Mentioned a maintenance backlog that left some corridor cameras non-functional -- a fact Mitchell and Jett exploit for their private conversations about the Richardson investigation.

docs.title: Arc Appearances
docs.text: Book Role Key Events Book 10: Plume Supporting Recruited by Maya Richardson during a private meeting (Interlude MR.4), where Richardson appealed to his desire for redemption. Arrived last and remained the most reserved of the four recruits. Publicly introduced as a founding member of Argus Corps at Richardson's press conference (Ch. 160), making a dramatic debut. Named in the confidential Argus Corps formation proposal as Andrew "Captain Devil" Mitchell (Interlude MR.5). Participates in the Argus Corps raid on the Stheno Pharmaceuticals warehouse (Ch. 163-164): his fear aura creates an instinctual terror response in Sam upon arrival, demonstrates the ability to clear smoke and track targets through obscured conditions using echolocation. Patriot orders the team to detain all capes present. The warehouse is ultimately destroyed by Soot's chemical chain reaction, and the Auditors escape. Discussed by the Auditors as they investigate the legal connections behind Argus Corps. Book 11: Alarm Will Sound Mentioned Referenced as part of Argus Corps' expanding operations during the post-Stheno period. The team's public prominence increases under Richardson's direction as they conduct anti-vigilante enforcement and drug-distribution raids across Philadelphia. Captain Devil is noted in the heavily redacted Argus Corps after-action report from the warehouse incident. Book 12: Authorized Personnel Only Supporting Present during the Argus Corps team briefing where Patriot reveals Bulldozer's accusations against Richardson (Chapter 182). Expresses "quiet concern" about the allegations while Jett dismisses them. Assigned to follow up on the Kensington phase-walker situation. Confronts Sam at Richardson's town hall event (Chapters 191-192), giving her an opportunity to surrender before engaging. Reveals his powers include invisible extendable talons and acidic blood during the fight. Pursues Sam through City Hall corridors, damaging marble floors with his claws. Knocked off balance by Maggie's force fields, allowing Sam to escape through a window. Chooses not to pursue once Sam and Maggie reach a public area with civilians. His near-capture of Sam marks the climax of the arc. Book 13: Burn After Reading Supporting Participates in Argus Corps operations during the escalating conflict between vigilantes, the Kingdom, and Rogue Wave. Maggie reports his rooftop position during the Richardson town hall event. Part of the team responding to the broader crisis in Philadelphia. Referenced in discussions about Argus Corps' growing public prominence and operational reach. Book 14: Shelter in Place Mentioned Argus Corps commits full resources to hunting the serial killer Shrike. Lily reports Argus Corps checkpoints throughout Northeast Philadelphia. The team is referenced operating at capacity during the crisis. Book 15: Severe Weather Warning Supporting Argus Corps confronts Sam with an arrest warrant (Chapter 222), though Patriot and Turbo Jett handle the direct confrontation. During the operation to capture Alice (the Kingdom shapeshifter), Captain Devil and Miasma evacuate the person they believe to be Maya Richardson to an unmarked car (Chapter 232/Interlude MaM.1), unknowingly delivering Alice directly into Miasma's custody. Participates in crowd control during the Remora and Stingray operation. Referenced as part of Argus Corps being "played" by Sam's strategic misdirection. Maxwell Martinez notes Argus Corps hitting three Rogue Wave distribution points in one week, identifying this as Maya's PR strategy to keep the team "visible." Intermission 15.5: This Side Up (AM.1) Main (Interlude) The focus character of Interlude AM.1, which provides the only extended first-person perspective of Mitchell's life. The interlude opens with a detailed flashback to his activation event in the Pine Barrens, depicting the wildfire, the mass animal exodus, and the bear mauling with its cub. Transitions to a full day in his current life: his SEPTA commute (checking tokusatsu forums, saving Diana's breakfast photo of the kids), the morning briefing at Argus Corps headquarters where Patriot assigns Jett to a Gray's Ferry ribbon-cutting, Mitchell to the Kensington phase-walker follow-up, and Miasma to narcotics coordination. The briefing also covers the Turnout armored car robbery pattern on I-95 (third robbery that month, same two exits, suggesting inside information) and a new drug called "Love Potion Number Ten" -- small glass corked phials of bubbling pink liquid producing heart-shaped smoke, allegedly inducing love for a day or two. Mitchell and Jett conduct their secret investigation in corridors without working cameras: Jett's FBI contact found Tremont & Fairfax to be aggressively cooperative but the Fairfax connection "boringly, aggressively clean," with the central question being why a New York megafirm took pro bono defense of Aaron McKinley, a two-bit Philly arsonist. Jett stole Patriot's unlocked phone during his bathroom break, revealing his research tabs: an American Institute of Dynology article on barokinesis, encyclopedia articles on Tyrannosaurus Rex and Richard Duvall, Duvall's high school yearbook, stock reports, two-year-old weather reports, and an article on Councilman Silverstein. Mitchell revealed he had deduced that Patriot told Maya Richardson about Bulldozer's accusations months earlier, right after McNulty brought them to him. The failed Kensington search (the phase-walker had varied his pattern, not hitting the same area twice) and the evening at home with Diana, Malik, and Destiny follow, ending with Mitchell's resolve to find the truth about Maya -- "non-violently, of course." Book 16: Category Five Hurricane Supporting Continues operating with Argus Corps. Investigating Maya Richardson alongside Turbo Jett, keeping their inquiry secret because he does not know who to trust. Believes Bulldozer's intelligence about Maya being Kingdom. The contradictions between his moral convictions and Argus Corps' direction continue to heighten. At the Argus Corps oversight transition meeting (MR.10), visibly checked out and on his phone -- a detail Maya notes, suggesting his disengagement from the team's official mission is becoming outwardly apparent.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• The interlude AM.1 opens with lyrics from the original Kamen Rider theme song and closes with lyrics from Foo Fighters' "My Hero," both reflecting Mitchell's character arc as an ordinary person trying to be heroic.
  • Mitchell follows a tokusatsu release forum and was debating the purchase of a new Kuuga figure during his Pine Barrens camping trip, placing his fandom squarely in the Heisei era of Kamen Rider.
  • His Cape name "Captain Devil" and alternate name "Captain Jersey Devil" are references to the Jersey Devil of Pine Barrens folklore, connecting his identity to the location of his activation event.
  • Diana's refusal to lock the front door is a running domestic friction point that Mitchell has raised "approximately eight hundred times."
  • Mitchell explicitly notes that he leaves the Captain Devil persona in his bag or his car and enters his home as Andrew Mitchell, maintaining a deliberate psychological separation between his two identities.
  • The character reference guide describes him as "really too nice for this team," a sentiment borne out by his consistent restraint in confrontations and his empathy for targets like the Kensington phase-walker.
  • He is one of at least three Argus Corps members independently investigating Maya Richardson as of Arc 16: Mitchell and Jett work together, Patriot investigates alone, and Miasma operates as a full mole. None of them are aware of the full scope of the others' inquiries.
  • Mitchell's children are named Malik (age 10) and Destiny (age 7). Diana works at a pediatric clinic.
  • His fear aura's effectiveness on animals is consistent with the Jersey Devil folklore, which traditionally describes a creature that terrorizes livestock and wildlife.
  • During the Pine Barrens flashback, Mitchell recognized the bear's intent was not predatory -- it was a mother fleeing with its cub -- and noted they were thinking the same thing in that moment: protecting their families. He was "just in the way."
  • The scar on his chest from the bear mauling itches when he thinks about the Pine Barrens, described as feeling like it "happened to someone else entirely" while also feeling like yesterday.
  • His neighborhood includes recurring background characters: the Hendersons who leave their Christmas lights up until March, and Mrs. Milkovich who walks an ancient beagle that has been "dying for approximately six years and shows no signs of actually doing it."
  • Diana's typical workday during the interlude included two ear infections, one broken arm, and a determined four-year-old who tried to convince her he needed a cast despite nothing being wrong with him. Dinner was leftover jollof rice.
  • The morning briefing in AM.1 introduced "Love Potion Number Ten," a rumored new drug sold in small glass corked phials of bubbling pink liquid that produces heart-shaped smoke when uncorked and allegedly induces love for a day or two. Patriot's concern was that someone would use it to "roofie Drexel sophomores." No confirmed cases existed at the time of the briefing.
  • Mitchell's closing thought in the interlude is a resolve to "wring the answers out of Maya myself. Non-violently, of course" -- the qualifier serving as both humor and a genuine reflection of his restraint-oriented character.

docs.title: Angela Perez
docs.text: Member of the Philly Phreaks with insectoid physiology, currently incarcerated at Daedalus Correctional Facility for her role in the courthouse attack.

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Angela Perez is a metahuman teenager who underwent a dramatic physical transformation resulting in an insect-like physiology. Her home life was violently abusive; her father kicked her out of the house and shot her. At some point she joined the Philly Phreaks, a gang of visually-apparent metahuman teenagers in Philadelphia led by Amira Irshad (Patches), who served as a surrogate caretaker and mother figure to the group's members.

Following Patches's arrest during the Phreaks' first confrontation with the Young Defenders on South Street, Chrysalis and the remaining Phreaks fell under the influence of Aaron McKinley, a fire-powered metahuman who attempted to assume leadership of the group. Chrysalis participated in the kidnapping and torture of Sam Small alongside Aaron, Pumice, and Deathgirl, though she expressed visible discomfort with Aaron's sadistic methods. After Sam escaped, Chrysalis led the Phreaks in severing ties with Aaron, delivering a cutting verbal assessment of his failures and abandoning him at the docks.

Chrysalis later participated in the courthouse attack during Illya Fedorov's trial, where the Phreaks distributed tainted Jump to a crowd of protesters, causing violent mutations and mass casualties. She was captured in the aftermath of the attack along with Pumice and Deathgirl, and was sent to Daedalus Correctional Facility, a metahuman prison in upstate New York. As of her PERKS assessment in August 2024, she has been placed in the general population ward and displays alternating manic rage and depression, manipulative tendencies, and an apparent lack of remorse for her involvement in the terrorist incident.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: Field Value Classification G4/S/P/T (Insectoid Physiology), E3/S/P/B (Sensory), G2/O/P/T (Apitoxin) Category Gigant, Employ Power Ranking 4/10 Control 5/10 Hostility 7/10 Collateral Damage 1/10 Threat Level 4/10

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Insectoid Physiology — Angela has undergone a full-body transformation resulting in an insect-like anatomy. Her skin is covered in green chitin armor that provides increased durability, though it is not impenetrable. She has clawed hands and feet that offer enhanced grip and the capacity for physical damage.
  • Wings — She possesses large insect-like wings sprouting from her back. The wings allow for controlled descent and limited hovering but are insufficient for true sustained flight.
  • Apitoxin Secretion — Her claws secrete a venom similar to that of a common bumblebee. The toxin causes swelling and a burning sensation comparable to bee stings, posing a minor threat to most individuals but a significant danger to anyone with existing allergies to apitoxins.
  • Enhanced Sensory Capabilities — Her antennae provide enhanced smell, hearing, and vibroreception in roughly a block-sized radius. Her modified compound eyes, which glow red, allow for control over light perception, including adjustable opacity and wavelength filtering capabilities.
  • Altered Physiology — She weighs approximately 80 pounds, has green blood (hemolymph) of otherwise normal composition, and heals by shedding layers of chitin rather than through normal human healing processes.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Flight Limitation — Wings are insufficient for true flight; she can only slow her descent and hover for limited periods.
  • Slow Healing — Her healing process, which involves shedding chitin layers, is slower than normal human healing.
  • Weak Toxin — Her apitoxin is relatively weak, comparable to a bee sting, posing minimal threat to most individuals.
  • Cognitive Limitations — She demonstrates limited understanding of her own capabilities, particularly regarding her eye modifications and the full extent of her transformed anatomy.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• No formal combat training or professional skills on record. She relies primarily on her physical capabilities and close-quarters clawing in fights.
  • Demonstrated verbal acuity and psychological insight in interpersonal confrontations, despite being described as unintelligent in some assessments.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Angela is vain, emotionally volatile, and sharp-tongued. Her PERKS assessment describes her as alternating between manic rage and depression, with manipulative tendencies and an apparent lack of empathy. She displays unrealistic expectations about the duration and consequences of her incarceration, seemingly not fully understanding that participation in a terrorist incident may result in lifetime imprisonment. Despite being characterized as unintelligent in some accounts, she demonstrates a pointed and articulate cruelty in verbal confrontations, as seen in her dismantling of Aaron McKinley's self-image after Sam's escape.

She is not without moral limits. During Sam's torture at Aaron's hands, Chrysalis expressed visible discomfort and disdain for the brutality, particularly Deathgirl's participation, though she did not intervene to stop it. She valued Patches's leadership because Patches genuinely cared for the Phreaks as people, and she measured Aaron against that standard and found him completely lacking. Her loyalty appears rooted in personal bonds rather than ideology.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Her body weight is approximately 80 pounds due to her insectoid transformation.
  • Her blood is green (hemolymph) but otherwise normal in composition.
  • She once told Aaron McKinley he was "not worth the bullet," comparing him to a pug that nobody wants to put down.
  • Her father kicked her out of the house and shot her, a detail she revealed while mocking Aaron's self-pitying monologue about his own abusive upbringing.
  • Her containment procedures at Daedalus include scratch-resistant polymer coatings on cell surfaces, vibration-dampening materials, advanced air filtration to mask scents, and adjustable lighting spectra to counter her modified vision.
  • Staff with recorded allergies to bees and wasps are prohibited from interacting with her at Daedalus.
  • Her PERKS assessment was conducted by Officer Autumn de la Cruz, with a power assessment by Dr. Emily Nakamura and containment procedures prepared by Dr. Ethan Novak.
