The event was connected to the Daedalus prison break and state senate hearings timeline.

docs.title: Connor
docs.text: Former Philly Phreak turned Auditors support member, a hypercontortionist who betrayed his criminal team to help the heroes and later co-founded the Auditors with Sam and Jordan.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Connor (surname unknown/undisclosed; used the alias "Spinelli" in early appearances) Aliases Spindle Date of Birth Unknown Age 18 Gender Male Ethnicity Unknown Place of Birth Unknown (associated with Philadelphia) Residence Bucks County, PA (with foster/adoptive family) Affiliation Auditors (Support) Former Affiliations Philly Phreaks, Young Defenders (associated) Occupation Student (obtaining GED, applying to community colleges) Status Retired First Appearance Chapter 32 Last Appearance Chapter 222 (mentioned)

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Connor was a member of the Philly Phreaks, a gang of visually-apparent metahumans led by Amira Irshad (Patches) that operated in South Philadelphia. The Phreaks had come under the influence of the Kingdom of Keys, who "gifted" the young power-copier Daisy (Deathgirl) to the group and had been threatening its members into increasingly aggressive criminal behavior. Connor, operating under the codename Spindle, grew uncomfortable with Amira's escalating activities and the Kingdom's manipulation. Prior to the Young Defenders' confrontation with the Phreaks on South Street, he placed an anonymous tip warning of the planned attack, an act that Sam Small later recognized when she noticed his visible discomfort during the standoff.

During the battle on South Street, Spindle betrayed his team at a critical moment, allowing the Young Defenders to capture Patches while Deathgirl escaped. In the aftermath, Connor cooperated fully during interrogation at Delaware Valley Defenders headquarters, revealing that the Kingdom of Keys had been influencing Amira and had provided Deathgirl to the Phreaks. He stated he was willing to accept punishment if it meant escaping Amira's escalating criminal activities. Clara Parker, the DVDs' legal advisor, suggested potential leniency in exchange for his continued cooperation. He was subsequently placed in witness protection while residing at the DVD headquarters.

Connor's loyalties quickly shifted to the heroes' side. He began observing Liberty Belle's training sessions with Sam and eventually asked to join Sam and Jordan's independent operations, revealing himself by emerging from Sam's school locker on Halloween night -- a feat made possible by his contortion abilities. That same night, he participated in the team's infiltration of a Kingdom of Keys warehouse on Trenton Avenue, where they witnessed Mr. Polygraph execute a suspected informant. When the team was discovered by Mudslide during their escape, Connor volunteered to stay behind as a diversion, returning battered but alive at dawn. Shortly after Liberty Belle's death, Councilman Jamal Davis proposed an off-the-books investigation into the NSRA, with Sam, Jordan, and Connor operating as a covert team called "The Auditors."

Connor began dating Jordan Westwood during this period and became deeply integrated into the Auditors' social circle. Over the following year, he participated in multiple operations, contributed intelligence from his former criminal contacts, and gradually transitioned toward civilian life. By Arc 9, he was preparing for adoption, which was officially finalized by February 2025. He relocated to Bucks County to live with his foster/adoptive family. As of the beginning of Arc 16, Connor has completed his GED, is applying to community colleges, and maintains a long-distance relationship with Jordan.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Hypercontortionism — Connor possesses the metahuman ability to contort and compress his body to an extreme degree, allowing him to fit into any space his head can pass through. This ability is sometimes described as "elastic" in nature, though it functions more as an extraordinary flexibility and compressibility rather than true elasticity. He has used this power to hide in school lockers, squeeze through narrow gaps in warehouses, and navigate tight spaces during infiltration missions.
  • Contortive Grappling — Connor can wrap his elongated limbs around opponents to restrain them. During the Dobson Mills warehouse battle, he tripped Squeal by wrapping around his legs and subsequently gagged and restrained him to prevent further sonic attacks.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Connor is a baseline human in terms of durability and strength; his contortion ability does not grant enhanced toughness or regeneration.
  • He has been injured in the field, including sustaining cuts from brick fragments during his diversion against Mudslide.
  • His power is primarily utility-based and provides limited offensive capability against opponents with enhanced strength or durability.
  • At almost seven feet tall, Connor's height makes stealth and blending in difficult outside of his contorted state.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Street-level combat experience from his time with the Philly Phreaks, including familiarity with improvised weapons (carried mace during the Kingdom warehouse escape).
  • Intelligence-gathering skills developed through reconnecting with former criminal associates to collect information on drug distribution networks and Kingdom operations.
  • Practical knowledge of Philadelphia's criminal underworld, including contacts and operational patterns of various organizations.
  • Currently pursuing his GED and formal education, with plans to attend community college.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Connor is earnest and somewhat naive, carrying a lingering street toughness from his years as a criminal that contrasts with his genuine desire to do good. He is described as very unintelligent -- the character reference guide bluntly notes he is "very stupid" -- but this does not diminish his loyalty or his willingness to put himself in harm's way for others. His speech features occasional slang, though he has been actively working to improve his vocabulary and education as part of his transition to civilian life. He is deeply devoted to Jordan Westwood, and their relationship serves as one of his primary emotional anchors.

In team settings, Connor provides moments of levity and grounding. During a tense strategy session about the Kingdom and Rogue Wave, he broke the tension by suggesting the group get Slurpees. During a Young Defenders philosophical debate about the ethics of power-enhancing drugs, he cited his own reform as evidence that people can change, reflecting a self-awareness about his past and a belief in second chances. His willingness to sacrifice himself -- staying behind to distract Mudslide, volunteering as lookout during dangerous operations -- demonstrates a courage that compensates for his intellectual limitations.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Connor's alias "Spinelli" appears to be a surname he used during his time with the Phreaks and in early interactions with the heroes, though the character reference guide lists him without a last name, suggesting "Spinelli" may not be his legal surname.
  • His codename "Spindle" references his contortion abilities and is evocative of the Batman villain Ragdoll, as noted in the character reference guide.
  • At almost seven feet tall, Connor is one of the tallest characters in the story, which creates an inherent comedy in his ability to fold himself into small spaces like school lockers and backpacks.
  • He hid in Sam's school locker for an entire day before revealing himself on Halloween night to ask to join the team -- a dramatic introduction that showcased both his power and his determination.
  • Connor is one of only two original Auditors (alongside Sam) who did not attend college, as Jordan left for MIT. He is the only founding Auditor to fully retire from vigilante work.
  • The character reference guide describes him as "very stupid," and notes that without him around, Lily Chen takes the title of least intelligent team member.
  • During the Fly/Jump investigation, Deathgirl is listed as one of Connor's former criminal associates, suggesting he maintained some awareness of her whereabouts after leaving the Phreaks.

docs.title: Daisy Zhen
docs.text: A child soldier created by Project Hollywood, Daisy Zhen is an extremely dangerous metahuman whose anger-induced power-copying ability made her a weapon for the Philly Phreaks before her incarceration and eventual transfer to psychiatric rehabilitation.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Daisy Zhen Aliases Deathgirl, "Demon King" (self-styled), Inmate 84927166 Date of Birth Unknown (approximately 2011–2012) Age 12–14 Gender Female Ethnicity Chinese-American Place of Birth Los Angeles, CA Residence Whitford Institute, Chicago, IL (current); formerly Daedalus Correctional Facility, northern New York; formerly Philly Phreaks safehouse, Philadelphia, PA Affiliation None (currently in psychiatric care at Whitford Institute) Former Affiliations Philly Phreaks, Project Hollywood Occupation N/A (minor, institutionalized) Status Incarcerated (Whitford Institute, psychiatric rehabilitation) First Appearance Chapter 32 Last Appearance Interlude DZ.3

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Daisy Zhen was kidnapped at approximately age eight from Los Angeles by agents of Project Hollywood, a clandestine program that mass-abducted marginalized children to condition them into metahuman weapons. She was lured into a black car by strangers who claimed her parents had sent them, then transported to a facility with gray buildings, barbed wire fences, and locked doors. A woman in a white coat informed Daisy this was her "new home" and that training would begin soon. Over the following years, she was subjected to mysterious "treatments" where she was put to sleep and woke with new injuries and unexplained bandages. She heard screams from other children at night and learned to stay quiet and compliant after being punished for crying. Her only comfort object was a stuffed penguin named Mr. Waddles, given to her at the facility. Her parents, Wei and Xiuying Zhen, were never able to find her.

During a "final test" involving a bald man with telekinetic abilities, Daisy's own powers manifested violently under intense mental pressure, and she threw the man through a door with copied telekinesis, possibly killing him. Rather than being punished, she was rewarded and put through regular power testing, moving objects with her mind, and "desensitization training" involving violent images and simulated weapon scenarios.

At approximately age twelve, Daisy was transported to Philadelphia in a shipping container and delivered to Amira Irshad (Patches), the leader of the Philly Phreaks, by a handler known as Mrs. Z. Spinelli later confirmed that the Kingdom of Keys had "gifted" Daisy to the Phreaks as a weapon. Patches gave Daisy a basement room with a soft mattress and stuffed penguins. Daisy experienced nightmares that triggered her gravity nullification power, and Patches comforted her by reading manga featuring a girl who joins a Demon Lord. Daisy identified with the character who chose power and independence, and adopted the persona of "Deathgirl." Patches served as a surrogate parental figure, but Daisy remained deeply emotionally damaged from her years of abuse.

Daisy participated in the Phreaks' confrontation with the Young Defenders on South Street, where she demonstrated her power-copying abilities by cycling through multiple teammates' powers. She later took part in the kidnapping and torture of Sam Small alongside Aaron McKinley and the other Phreaks. During the Chernobyl trial, the Phreaks launched a terrorist attack on the Philadelphia courthouse, where Daisy fought Sam in a brutal one-on-one battle on the courthouse steps. Sam ultimately subdued her, and Daisy was remanded to Daedalus Correctional Facility in solitary confinement.

In September 2025, a joint Kingdom of Keys and Red Calf operation breached Daedalus to extract Daisy on Porcelain's orders. She woke prematurely during the extraction, copied the operatives' powers, and escaped on her own. Daisy fell through a liquefied tunnel floor into an older mining level beneath Daedalus, deliberately maintaining anger at Mudslide to keep his liquefaction powers active. She discovered she could liquefy stone with a single touch rather than needing both hands, an advancement beyond her previously known capability, and used a mental mantra about Mr. Waddles to maintain her emotional connection to Mudslide's powers.

After encountering a group of escaped prisoners who recognized her as "Deathgirl, the copier" from the isolation wing, Daisy formed a tactical alliance with Cold-Cut (who had freezing abilities) and Switchback (gravity manipulation). As rising floodwaters created urgency, the group navigated mine tunnels with Cold-Cut creating ice bridges to seal leaks. At Junction 12, Daisy used liquefaction powers to carve a spiral ramp up a ventilation shaft, and Flux (a prisoner with metal manipulation) removed grates blocking their exit. On the surface, Switchback provided money and advice before departing toward the Canadian border, while Cold-Cut unexpectedly agreed to accompany Daisy south. They acquired civilian clothes and adopted false identities as aunt and niece, boarding a bus to Albany. Cold-Cut departed at Albany for Saratoga.

Alone in Albany, Daisy used payphones and the public library to search for her parents, leveraging her limited Cantonese to connect with the local Chinese-American community and track down their address on Western Avenue. She had been awake for approximately four days by the time she arrived at their apartment. Her father Wei immediately activated an "emergency protocol," revealing that her parents had been planning for her potential return for three months with legal representation already in place. Federal marshals arrived almost immediately, but family attorney Patricia Gilly intervened and established Daisy's rights as a minor.

A compromise medical evaluation at Albany Medical Center by Dr. Michaels confirmed exhaustion, mild dehydration, and post-traumatic stress. During an emergency court hearing, DOJ attorney Jennifer Ross argued for federal custody, but Judge Esposito denied the government's request and ordered temporary placement at the Whitford Institute in Chicago, the country's only specialized psychiatric facility for powered youth. The judge mandated full parental access, weekly medical reports, and comprehensive review in 30 days. Dr. Olivia Reed from Whitford coordinated the transfer. Wei promised to relocate the family to Chicago. During the flight, Daisy produced Mr. Waddles from her belongings, showing rare vulnerability. Porcelain (Chezki Espinosa), the man with a braided beard and sunglasses, was observed watching the courthouse proceedings, confirming continued Red Calf interest in Daisy.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: Field Value Classification A9/SO/PEM/P Category Adjust Power Ranking 9/10 Control 1/10 Hostility 10/10 Collateral Damage 10/10 Threat Level 10/10

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Anger-Induced Dynamimesis — Automatically and autonomously copies and enhances the superpowers of the individual Daisy is currently most angry at. The copied power is estimated to be 20–30% stronger than the original and often manifests without the original power's weaknesses.
  • Physical Mutation Manifestation — Copied powers manifest as physical mutations on her body, including additional appendages, bone spikes, chitinous skin, insect wings, and other alterations depending on the source power.
  • Rapid Power Shifting — Can shift between copied powers by redirecting her anger toward a different individual. This shifting can occur multiple times in quick succession, making her highly unpredictable in combat.
  • Emotional Power Direction — Demonstrated the ability to consciously maintain or redirect anger to control which power she copies. During the Daedalus escape, she deliberately maintained anger at Mudslide to keep his liquefaction powers active by repeating a mental mantra, and could consciously "chase" specific individuals by making herself angry at them to recall their powers without needing proximity. She can also switch between copied powers by redirecting her emotional focus to a different target.
  • No Proximity Requirement — Does not require physical proximity to the target whose power she copies. The ability is classified as "Postmile" range.
  • Power Enhancement — Copied powers sometimes manifest with reduced limitations. During the Daedalus escape, Daisy's copied liquefaction worked with a single touch rather than the original user's two-handed requirement, though effectiveness varied by material (less effective on soil than stone).

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Emotional Dependency — Power is entirely dependent on anger. If her anger subsides or is redirected, the copied and enhanced powers may diminish or disappear.
  • Physical Strain — Rapid shifting and physical mutations place significant strain on her body. Long-term effects are unknown but potentially severe.
  • Lack of Control — Power activates and shifts autonomously based on anger, increasing the risk of unintended consequences and collateral damage. Her control rating is assessed at 1/10.
  • Exhaustion — As a young teenager of otherwise normal endurance, Daisy is prone to fits of exhaustion and overexertion that cause her to lose consciousness, deactivating her powers.
  • Singular Copying — Can only copy a single power at a time.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Conditioned in combat and violence through Project Hollywood's desensitization training program, including exposure to violent imagery and simulated weapon scenarios.
  • Demonstrated tactical intelligence and survival skills during her escape from Daedalus, including navigating underground tunnel systems, forming strategic alliances, and using public resources to locate her parents.
  • Limited Cantonese language ability, sufficient to communicate with members of the Chinese-American community.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Daisy masks intense misanthropy and self-loathing beneath a layer of bravado, rage, and violent posturing. She styled herself as a "Demon King" and displayed extreme hostility and willingness to cause harm during her time with the Phreaks, including eagerly participating in the torture of Sam Small. Underneath the aggression lies deep fear, emotional immaturity, and the psychological scars of years of abuse beginning in early childhood. She is prone to tantrums and emotional outbursts, and her lack of emotional regulation directly feeds her uncontrollable powers.

Despite her conditioning, Daisy has shown glimpses of vulnerability and capacity for growth. She kept a stuffed penguin named Mr. Waddles throughout her imprisonment and carried it with her during her escape, producing it during the medical transport flight to Chicago in a moment of rare openness. During her final confrontation with Sam on the courthouse steps, she broke down sobbing and apologizing incoherently as her strength gave out. Her behavior during the Daedalus escape demonstrated remarkable resourcefulness, self-sufficiency, and a desperate desire to reunite with her parents: she proposed a "tactical alliance" with Cold-Cut based on complementary powers, navigated mine tunnels under rising floodwater, used public resources systematically to find her parents in an unfamiliar city, and leveraged her limited Cantonese to connect with a community that could help her. The personal items in her Daedalus cell (Mr. Waddles, educational books, photos) indicated that rehabilitation efforts were having a positive effect before the prison break interrupted her progress. Her methodical approach to finding her parents despite having been awake for four consecutive days demonstrates remarkable determination and self-sufficiency for a fourteen-year-old.

docs.text: Book Role Key Events Book 3: Dybbuk Supporting First appearance. Revealed as the Phreaks' "secret weapon" during the South Street confrontation. Copies and amplifies multiple Young Defenders' powers. Escapes through a storm drain after Spindle's betrayal. Book 4: Exorcism Supporting / Interlude Participates in the kidnapping and torture of Sam alongside Aaron and the Phreaks. Sam provokes her to create chaos and escape. Interlude DZ.1 reveals her backstory: kidnapping by Project Hollywood, experimentation, power manifestation, and delivery to the Phreaks. Book 6: Sideshow Supporting Led the Philly Phreaks' terrorist attack on the courthouse during the Chernobyl trial, force-feeding tainted Jump to protesters and causing mass mutagenic transformations. Fought Sam in a savage one-on-one battle on the courthouse steps, exchanging brutal strikes before being pinned by Sam's superior size and weight. Dissolved into sobbing and incoherent apologies before losing consciousness. Captured and sent to Daedalus Correctional Facility under chemical sedation. Crossroads warned Illya that if Deathgirl copied his nuclear powers, she would kill everyone in Philadelphia. Book 7: Security Mentioned Mentioned in context of the courthouse attack aftermath. Sam references the danger of power-copying villains like Deathgirl potentially replicating Chernobyl's abilities. Referenced in congressional hearing investigating metahuman incidents. Book 9: Sheol Mentioned In Interlude LTN.2, Mrs. Xenograft reveals to Mr. Antithesis that she has cultured cells from Daisy Zhen to create Compound B for Hypeman, connecting Daisy's biology to the Kingdom's drug development pipeline. Book 13: Burn After Reading Main (Interlude) Target of a joint Kingdom of Keys and Red Calf extraction operation at Daedalus on September 10th, orchestrated by Porcelain to coincide with state senate hearings and Boston protests as cover. The extraction team (Mudslide, Vector, Tarbaby, Mrs. Synapse) reaches her cell (D-7, Cell Block D), but Daisy wakes prematurely from sedation because she is better nourished than expected -- her cell contains personal items (Mr. Waddles, books, photos) indicating rehabilitation was having a positive effect. She copies Vector's telekinesis, Mrs. Synapse's nerve manipulation, and Mudslide's liquefaction in rapid succession without physical contact, dissolves the tunnel floor, and escapes into older mining levels beneath the facility. In Interlude DZ.2, Daisy falls through the liquefied floor and deliberately maintains anger at Mudslide to keep his powers active, discovering she can liquefy stone with a single touch rather than needing both hands. She encounters other escapees who recognize her as "Deathgirl, the copier" from the isolation wing, and forms a tactical alliance with Switchback (gravity manipulation) and Cold-Cut (freezing abilities). The group navigates flooded mine tunnels -- Cold-Cut creates ice bridges to seal leaks, Daisy carves a spiral ramp up a ventilation shaft using liquefaction, and Flux (metal manipulation) removes grates blocking their exit. On the surface, Switchback provides money and departs toward the Canadian border; Cold-Cut accompanies Daisy south, posing as aunt and niece on a bus to Albany. Cold-Cut departs at Saratoga. Alone in Albany, Daisy uses payphones, the public library, and the Chinese-American Cultural Association to locate her parents on Western Avenue using her limited Cantonese, having been awake for approximately four days. In Interlude DZ.3, her father Wei activates a pre-arranged "emergency protocol" with attorney Patricia Gilly already retained. Federal Marshals arrive but Gilly establishes Daisy's minor rights. A medical evaluation by Dr. Michaels at Albany Medical Center confirms exhaustion, dehydration, and PTSD; Dr. Michaels references "The First Place" (implied to be Project Hollywood). At an emergency hearing before Judge Esposito, DOJ attorney Jennifer Ross demands federal custody, but the judge orders temporary placement at the Whitford Institute in Chicago with full parental access, weekly reports, and 30-day review. Dr. Olivia Reed from Whitford coordinates the transfer. Wei and Xiuying pledge to relocate to Chicago. During the medical flight, Daisy produces Mr. Waddles from her belongings. Porcelain (braided beard, sunglasses) is observed watching the courthouse proceedings, confirming Red Calf's continued interest. Book 15: Severe Weather Warning Mentioned Referenced by Songbird protesters who invoke Deathgirl's name to argue against metahumans. Her status at Whitford Institute is a dangling narrative thread.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Her comfort object, a stuffed penguin named Mr. Waddles, has been with her since her time in the Project Hollywood facility, where it was her only source of comfort.
  • During the Daedalus extraction, the operatives found her cell contained personal items including Mr. Waddles, books, and photos, indicating rehabilitation efforts rather than pure imprisonment.
  • Mudslide, one of the Red Calf operatives, insisted on taking Daisy's personal belongings during the extraction to keep her calm.
  • The extraction team expected Daisy to be malnourished and neglected, but she woke prematurely from sedation because she was better-fed than anticipated.
  • Her PERKS assessment was conducted by Officer Michael Johnson in August 2024, with a supplemental power assessment by Dr. Emily Nakamura in September 2024.
  • The Kingdom of Keys "gifted" Daisy to the Philly Phreaks, as confirmed by Spinelli during his interrogation and by Councilman Jamal Davis during the mission debriefing.
  • Patches manipulated Daisy into fighting by telling her that Playback worked for "bad people" who made her parents leave.
  • Illya Fedorov (Chernobyl) was kept out of the courthouse battle specifically because Crossroads warned that Deathgirl could copy his powers and become a walking nuclear meltdown.
  • During her escape from Daedalus, other prisoners recognized her as "Deathgirl, the copier" from the isolation wing, indicating she had a reputation among the inmate population.
  • Daisy and Cold-Cut adopted false identities as aunt and niece while traveling to Albany by bus, demonstrating her survival conditioning.
  • The facility where she was held as a child (Project Hollywood) is referred to as "The First Place" by Dr. Michaels during her medical evaluation, though the name is never confirmed by Daisy.
  • Her parents Wei and Xiuying had relocated to Albany specifically to be close to Daedalus and had legal contingency plans in place for months before her escape, including retaining attorney Patricia Gilly.
  • The prison break itself was not yet public knowledge at the time of Daisy's court hearing, with only "seven" high-risk escapees reported in the press (the "Magnificent Seven").
  • The character reference guide notes she appears positioned for a potential "heel-antihero turn."

docs.title: Darnell Hayes
docs.text: Founding member and co-lead interrogator of the Kingdom of Keys' Philadelphia branch, a power-nullifying enforcer who negates metahuman abilities through physical contact.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Darnell Hayes Aliases Mr. Nothing, Mr. N Date of Birth Unknown Age Mid 30s Gender Male Ethnicity Black Place of Birth Unknown Residence Philadelphia, PA (area) Affiliation Kingdom of Keys (Philadelphia branch) Former Affiliations N/A Occupation Kingdom co-lead interrogator, enforcer Status Active First Appearance Chapter 12 Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Darnell Hayes is a founding member of the Kingdom of Keys, one of the most powerful criminal organizations operating in the northeastern United States. He serves as co-lead interrogator of the Philadelphia branch alongside his partner Lucas Donovan (Mr. Polygraph), with whom he forms an inseparable operational duo. His power to nullify other metahumans' abilities on contact makes him an exceptionally effective enforcer, particularly dangerous when paired with Polygraph's lie-detection capabilities during interrogations.

Darnell first appeared in the story when he and Mr. Polygraph oversaw a loyalty test for Mudslide at the abandoned Dobson Textile Factory, ordering Mudslide to murder a captive by burying him alive. This event was accidentally witnessed by Sam Small and Jordan Westwood, triggering a violent confrontation that established the Kingdom of Keys as a major antagonistic force. Over the course of the story, Darnell has been involved in numerous Kingdom operations ranging from interrogations and drug heists to prison transport rescues, consistently serving as one of the organization's most reliable operatives in Philadelphia.

Darnell was captured alongside Mudslide during the Philadelphia Zoo heist (Operation Ivory) and incarcerated at the Philadelphia Industrial Correctional Center. He was subsequently liberated during a Kingdom-orchestrated ambush of a prison transport convoy on the Pennsylvania Turnpike in March 2025. Since his release, he has continued operating as a key Kingdom lieutenant, participating in interrogations, coordinating with Mrs. Xenograft on drug production, and responding to the growing threat of Rogue Wave.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Power Nullification — Darnell can negate other metahumans' powers through physical contact, specifically skin-to-skin touch. The nullification persists as long as he maintains contact. This ability is particularly devastating against metahumans whose powers involve physical mutation or biological alteration, as it removes not only the primary ability but also the required secondary powers that keep their altered physiology functional (e.g., removing the secondary powers that prevent super-dense muscles from crushing their owner).
  • Comprehensive Nullification Scope — His power cancels all abilities simultaneously upon contact, including passive powers. When he touched Sam Small during their encounters, her regeneration and blood-sensing abilities were neutralized. When he touched Jordan Westwood, their spatial distortions collapsed entirely.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Contact Requirement — Power nullification requires direct physical contact, specifically skin-to-skin. Targets can avoid the effect by preventing bare-skin contact.
  • Single-Target Application — He must physically touch the individual whose powers he wishes to negate, limiting him to one target at a time in most practical combat scenarios.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Well-trained in street fighting, dirty tactics, brawling, and grappling. He and Polygraph are experienced enough in close-quarters combat to engage teenage metahumans and hold their own against seasoned heroes.
  • Has begun taking boxing lessons to improve his hand-to-hand capabilities, described as wanting to "keep up with the Joneses."
  • Second-best marksman in the Kingdom of Keys among those who do not possess a power that enhances their shooting.
  • Skilled interrogator who leverages his calm demeanor and power-nullification ability to extract information from metahuman targets.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Darnell is notably cool, calm, and collected, presenting a professional demeanor that contrasts sharply with his partner Mr. Polygraph's barely concealed anger. Very little provokes him to genuine emotion; when he raises his voice, it is a deliberate tactical choice rather than a loss of control. He has developed a philosophical outlook on life and death, informed largely by his experience killing people, which has led him to view life as a temporary and precious thing. He takes genuine satisfaction in his work, believing himself to be good at it, and derives meaning from his role within the Kingdom. He holds a coldly pragmatic view of his victims, reasoning that if they did not want to be on the wrong end of his gun, they should have made better choices.

Darnell maintains a quiet, observant presence in group settings. During the Kingdom's post-prison-transport gathering at a Lancaster steakhouse, he remained notably quiet throughout the team's conversations and banter. He shares a past romantic history with Maya Richardson (Mrs. Zenith) and the two continue to have occasional flings, though their professional interactions carry an undercurrent of tension. His private conversations with Maya reveal a sharp, suspicious mind; after the staged death of Soot, he confirmed the kill but shared lingering doubts about missing details.

Described as "heterosexual life mates" despite having met relatively recently. They operate as an inseparable duo on interrogations and field operations. He serves as her primary contact for emergency situations and shares private doubts with her. Trent Fairfax (Mr. Antithesis) Superior Leader of the Kingdom of Keys. Has fought her multiple times across the story, including at the factory, the Philadelphia Zoo, and during the Soot interrogation. Sam personally overpowered and zip-tied him during the zoo heist. Neither party is aware of this connection, and it is not plot relevant.

docs.title: Arc Appearances
docs.text: Book Role Key Events Book 1: Pup Supporting First appears at the Dobson Textile Factory (Ch. 12) alongside Mr. Polygraph and Mudslide, overseeing Mudslide's loyalty test where a captive is buried alive. Shoots down Alex's surveillance drone. Interrogates Sam at gunpoint after she is discovered. Engages in brutal combat with Sam and Jordan (Ch. 13), strangling Jordan and firing multiple shots. Jordan stabs him through the stomach with a metal spear, severely wounding him. Orders the retreat when police sirens approach despite having the pipe still lodged in his side. Book 2: Keys Mentioned Drone footage of the Dobson Factory murder is presented to the Delaware Valley Defenders (Ch. 15), identifying the Kingdom of Keys as a major threat and Mr. Nothing as one of its operatives. Book 3: Dybbuk Mentioned Spinelli, a captured Philly Phreak member, identifies two suited men who influenced his gang leader Amira as Mr. T-Rex and Mr. Nothing (Chapter 34). Spinelli reveals the Kingdom "gifted" Deathgirl to the Phreaks and had been threatening the group. Book 7: Security Interlude (MR.1) Guides Maya Richardson to safety via phone while she is pursued by an SUV through Philadelphia streets. Briefs Maya and Mudslide at a Kingdom safehouse at 12th and Pine on the upcoming Chernobyl trial and its implications. Participates in strategic discussion about the NSRA, the Rogue Wave mind-control threat (triggered by the phrase "Rogue Wave"), and recruitment strategies. Maya proposes offering Kingdom services to the NSRA as security consultants. Book 8: Big Supporting Catches Devonte (Playback) eavesdropping on Kingdom operations at the docks near Bleigh Avenue during Operation Ivory preparations (Interlude DH.2). Threatens Devonte and nearly kills him before Devonte escapes with Akilah's help. Participates in the real heist at the Philadelphia Zoo, stealing poison dart frogs in the Reptile House alongside Mrs. Heartbeat and Mudslide while Mr. Tyrannosaur creates a distraction (Chapter 134). Grabs Sam and neutralizes her powers, threatening to shoot her knee. Maggie arrives and hits him with a power-propelled baseball. Sam engages him in intense hand-to-hand combat (Chapter 135), ultimately overpowering and zip-tying him. Captured and arrested alongside Mudslide. Mrs. Xenograft later takes responsibility for his and Mudslide's capture in her meeting with Mr. Antithesis (Interlude LTN.2). Mentioned in MR.3 when Maya receives a text from him acknowledging Richard Duvall's death, suggesting this text was sent before his arrest. Book 10: Plume Supporting Sam discusses the upcoming prison transfer of Mr. Nothing and Mudslide from Philadelphia Industrial Correctional Center and predicts a Kingdom rescue attempt (Chapter 149). The Kingdom successfully liberates both operatives during a highway ambush of the prison transport convoy on the Pennsylvania Turnpike (Interlude RG.1). Mr. Nothing is present at the Kingdom-owned steakhouse in Lancaster during the post-operation gathering but remains notably quiet throughout (Interlude BM.2). Sam notes the eerie absence of both Nothing and Mudslide on Kensington streets, creating a sense of foreboding (Chapter 155). Book 11: Alarm Will Sound Supporting Arrives unexpectedly alongside Mr. Retribution, Mrs. Quiet, and Mr. Polygraph at Lardner's Point Park during the staged Soot confrontation (Chapter 174). Neutralizes "Soot's" (actually Sam in disguise) smoke powers by touching her fingers. Mr. Polygraph questions Sam using Darnell's nullification to keep her powerless during the interrogation. The Kingdom operatives pay the Washes $2000 for first crack at questioning Soot before Mrs. Quiet shoots "Soot" and the Washes throw her into the Delaware River. Mentioned in Interlude MR.7 where Maya assigns him and Polygraph to coordinate with Mrs. Xenograft on rebuilding Hypeman production in Camden. Maya and Darnell have a tense private conversation about their past; he confirms Soot's death but shares suspicions about missing pieces. Book 12: Authorized Personnel Only Mentioned Listed among Kingdom operatives during the period of escalating three-way conflict between vigilantes, Argus Corps, and criminal organizations. Continues operating as a key Kingdom lieutenant in Philadelphia. Book 13: Burn After Reading Supporting Listed among Kingdom operatives participating in the Daedalus prison break operation. Part of the "B-Team" providing distraction during the extraction of Deathgirl from Daedalus Correctional Facility. The extraction team receives communication that Mr. Nothing is injured and the B-Team is withdrawing during the operation. Book 14: Shelter in Place Mentioned Sam notes Kingdom operatives pressuring local businesses in her neighborhood. Kingdom activity continues in background. Book 15: Severe Weather Warning Supporting Arrives with Mr. Polygraph at Roxborough Memorial Hospital to investigate a private investigator (Rick) snooping around on behalf of Rogue Wave. Birthday Suit engages Mr. Nothing while Dead Drop's chains subdue Kingdom operatives, allowing Rush Order to capture Mr. Polygraph for power extraction. Polygraph's lie-detection ability is permanently extracted by Snake Oil at a Camden warehouse, crystallizing as a blue-green crystal. Darnell calls Maya at 8:43 PM to report Mr. Polygraph's capture and permanent depowerment by Rogue Wave (Interlude MR.9), triggering Mr. Antithesis's unprecedented personal attendance at the Port Richmond warehouse debrief. Already at the warehouse securing the location when Maya arrives at 11:40 PM. Provides his account of the Roxborough operation to the assembled Kingdom leadership. Antithesis gives Maya 72 hours to develop a comprehensive response to Bloodhound and pledges to acquire Fly to restore Polygraph's powers. First arc where Darnell's full name (Darnell Hayes) is revealed.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Mrs. Xenograft created the superpower suppressant drug Vysera using an advancement of Hypeman research combined with samples of Darnell's flesh, leveraging his innate power-nullification biology.
  • His second cousin is Director Hayes, Rachel Small's boss at the Philadelphia Public Library. Neither Darnell nor Director Hayes is aware of this familial connection, and it is described by the author as a coincidence that will not be plot relevant.
  • He and Lucas Donovan (Mr. Polygraph) are described as "what Kevin Smith would call 'heterosexual life mates'" despite having met only relatively recently.
  • During his first encounter with Sam and Jordan at the Dobson Textile Factory, Jordan stabbed him through the stomach with an improvised metal spear, yet he still managed to order the retreat and escape with the pipe lodged in his side.
  • His Kingdom codename follows the organization's alphabetical naming convention, with "Mr. Nothing" corresponding to the letter N.
  • His current status as of the beginning of Arc 16 is hunting down Rogue Wave members.

docs.title: Dean Carver
docs.text: Rogue Wave's distribution specialist and field operative, a superhuman speedster who manages Jump distribution networks across Philadelphia and has developed an unlikely adversarial rapport with Sam Small.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Dean Carver Aliases Rush Order Date of Birth Unknown Age 28 Gender Male Ethnicity Irish (self-described as "Irishly pale") Place of Birth Unknown Residence Camden, NJ (safehouse) Affiliation Rogue Wave Former Affiliations N/A Occupation Distribution Specialist (Rogue Wave); formerly delivery driver and cable installer Status Active First Appearance Chapter 158 (Rogue Wave broadcast); Chapter 182 (in person) Last Appearance Interlude DC.3 (Intermission 15.5: This Side Up); mentioned in Chapter 236

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Dean Carver is a 28-year-old metahuman who serves as the distribution specialist for Rogue Wave, the criminal organization led by Lawrence Sullivan (Monkey Business) that produces and distributes the metahuman drugs Jump and Fly throughout Philadelphia and the eastern seaboard. Prior to joining Rogue Wave, Dean worked as a delivery driver and cable installer. He discovered his superhuman speed powers while fleeing loan sharks, an experience that fundamentally shaped his worldview around freedom and velocity as the highest virtues.

Within Rogue Wave's organizational structure, Dean operates under the codename "Rush Order" and handles the logistics of Jump distribution across the city. He coordinates contracted dealers, manages territory, and serves as Monkey Business's primary field agent for direct operations. During the Interlude LS.1 strategic planning meeting in June 2025, Rush Order reported a 22% increase in contract distribution with a 92% retention rate following Jordan Westwood's exposure of a contract vulnerability, demonstrating his effectiveness in the role. He is also one of the six core members featured in Rogue Wave's televised manifesto broadcast in April 2025, where he was publicly identified as the organization's delivery specialist.

Dean lacks the deep ideological commitment that drives some of his Rogue Wave colleagues. Unlike Dead Drop's anarchist fervor or Snake Oil's evolutionary philosophy, Dean's motivations are more personal and pragmatic. He enjoys operating above the law, relishes the freedom his speed affords him, and treats his criminal career with a theatrical flair that suggests he views the whole enterprise as a performance worth staging.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Superhuman Speed (Subconscious Biodynamic Control) — Dean possesses superhuman speed generated through subconscious biodynamic control, meaning his body automatically compensates for any movement he wants to make. His reflexes, acceleration, and movement speed vastly exceed normal human limits. During his South Street confrontation with Bloodhound in Arc 12, he demonstrated an overwhelming speed advantage in combat, systematically outmatching Sam despite her training in pattern recognition from Multiplex.
  • Subconscious Aerokinesis — Complementing his speed, Dean possesses subconscious aerokinesis that nullifies air resistance during movement. This passive ability allows him to move at superhuman velocities without the friction, drag, and thermal effects that would otherwise make such speeds lethal. During the Interlude DC.3 rooftop confrontation with Maya Richardson, his aerokinesis actively attempted to counteract her barokinetic pressure field, functioning as a partial defensive barrier. Dean described the sensation as his body trying to "equalize" against the crushing atmosphere, and noted that without his aerokinesis, Dead Drop would have been "turned into paste" by the same pressure. However, the aerokinesis could not fully overcome a sustained, concentrated barokinetic assault in an enclosed space.
  • Person Location (Fly Power) — Dean can locate any individual as long as he knows their full legal name, functioning similarly to a carrier pigeon's homing instinct. He demonstrated this ability during the Rogue Wave negotiation in Arc 14, when he revealed to Sam that Maya Richardson was not actually in Harrisburg during the senate hearings but was instead somewhere in New York State. He described this as being able to sense people's locations once he knows their names.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Dean must plant his feet before accelerating, a biomechanical "tell" that Sam identified during their South Street fight using Multiplex's training techniques. While Sam was still unable to exploit this effectively, the tell represents a predictable vulnerability in his movement patterns.
  • His speed advantage is primarily linear; opponents who can anticipate his planting motion or force close-quarters engagements may find brief windows of opportunity.
  • He carries a revolver, suggesting that his speed alone is not always sufficient for resolving confrontations and that he relies on conventional weapons as a supplement.
  • He was shot in the shoulder by Benjamin Small during the South Street confrontation, indicating that he is not invulnerable and can be injured by conventional firearms despite his speed.
  • His aerokinesis, while providing passive protection against pressure-based attacks, can be overwhelmed by sustained barokinetic force in enclosed spaces, as demonstrated during the DC.3 stairwell confrontation with Maya Richardson, where he sustained cracked ribs, a nosebleed, and a sprained ankle despite his body's attempts to compensate.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Experienced in logistics and distribution management from his prior career as a delivery driver and cable installer, skills that translate directly into his role managing Rogue Wave's drug distribution networks.
  • Proficient with firearms; carries a revolver and engaged in a gunfight standoff with Benjamin Small during the South Street confrontation.
  • Skilled in hand-to-hand combat, capable of using his speed advantage to systematically dismantle opponents in sustained engagements.
  • Adept at reconnaissance and stealth operations, as demonstrated by his approach to the Tacony Music Hall disguised as a delivery person during the Shrike crisis negotiations.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Dean Carver is cocky, irreverent, and theatrical, approaching both criminal enterprise and superhuman combat with a showman's instinct for spectacle. He values freedom and speed above all else, treating his powers not merely as tools but as the purest expression of what he believes life should be. His South Street confrontation with Bloodhound was deliberately staged as a public event, complete with crowd engagement, drone footage, and ideological speechmaking. He introduced himself with theatrical flair, drew public attention on purpose, and framed the fight as entertainment as much as combat. When asked the difference between criminals and supervillains, his answer was simple: style.

Despite his theatrical confidence, Dean demonstrated sound tactical judgment during the DC.3 rooftop encounter with Maya Richardson, calling off the pursuit when it became clear they were outmatched and reframing the defeat as an intelligence-gathering success. He acknowledged without ego that Maya "wasn't even trying to kill us" and that she had simply been leaving, a degree of honest self-assessment that contrasts sharply with his usual showmanship.

Beneath the bravado, Dean possesses a calculating intelligence that his flamboyance tends to obscure. He confirmed after the South Street fight that the entire confrontation was a publicity stunt designed to increase Rogue Wave's visibility and drive both gun sales and Jump distribution. He lacks the ideological purity of teammates like Dead Drop, instead operating from a more self-interested position that he dresses up in Rogue Wave's rhetoric when convenient. His relationship with Sam Small is perhaps the most revealing aspect of his character: he wants to be the one who beats her, and he has shown a pattern of providing her with crucial intelligence and warnings even as they remain on opposite sides. He strangely respects Benjamin Small for shooting him rather than resenting the injury, treating it as an acceptable consequence of his own carelessness rather than an affront. This capacity for admiring people who stand their ground against him, even when it costs him, suggests a code of personal honor operating underneath his performative villainy.

docs.title: Relationships
docs.text: Character Relationship Notes Lawrence Sullivan (Monkey Business) Leader / Employer Dean serves as Monkey Business's primary field agent and distribution coordinator. Reports directly to Sullivan and executes strategic operations on his behalf, including the Mr. Polygraph extraction. Sam Small (Bloodhound) Adversary / Developing rapport A complicated dynamic that has evolved from pure antagonism toward a strange villainous quasi-friendship. Dean wants to be the one who beats Sam and has repeatedly provided her with warnings and intelligence. He confronted her on South Street, was impressed by her resilience, and later negotiated protection for her family. Benjamin Small ("Gun Dad") Mutual respect Ben shot Dean during the South Street confrontation, wounding his shoulder. Dean strangely respects rather than resents this, later releasing a public video declaring Ben under Rogue Wave's protection and framing his actions as exemplifying Rogue Wave's philosophy of individual empowerment. Mai-Anh "Annie" Vo (Birthday Suit) Teammate Fellow core Rogue Wave member. Participated together in the Mr. Polygraph extraction and the Shrike crisis negotiation with Sam. Renee Costello (Dead Drop) Teammate / Field partner Fellow core Rogue Wave member. Rush Order extracted Dead Drop via motorcycle during the Sunoco station confrontation in Arc 12, leaving Marathon (a lower-level Rogue Wave dealer) and his crew behind to prioritize a core member's escape. Worked together on the Mr. Polygraph extraction. In Interlude DC.3, the pair conducted a joint reconnaissance-turned-ambush on Maya Richardson, demonstrating established tactical coordination: Dean described them as "a good team" with complementary abilities (speed and reach), having "run this play a dozen times on Kingdom couriers and drug shipments." Dead Drop drove while Dean navigated using his person-location sense. She supported him physically after the failed capture, helping him descend six flights of stairs with his injured ankle. Maya Richardson (Mrs. Zenith) Target (reassigned to avoidance) Dean and Dead Drop attempted to capture Maya Richardson on a Northeast Philadelphia rooftop during Interlude DC.3 after tracking her via Dean's person-location ability. The encounter revealed Maya's true power as barokinesis rather than weather control. Maya incapacitated Dean with crushing pressure in an enclosed stairwell and escaped. Dean subsequently briefed Monkey Business, who reclassified Maya as "a hazard to be routed around, not an objective to be pursued." Dr. Felix Ortega (Snake Oil) Teammate Rogue Wave's chemist who treated Dean's gunshot wound at the Camden safehouse. Snake Oil hoped Dean would not get shot again, which Dean dismissed as merely being "careless." Elias Franklin (Chimera) Teammate Rogue Wave member who assisted with Dean's medical treatment at the Camden safehouse after the South Street fight. Tomas Reynoso (Jackpot) Teammate Fellow core Rogue Wave member. Participated in team dinners and philosophical discussions at the safehouse.

docs.title: Arc Appearances
docs.text: Book Role Key Events Book 10: Plume Supporting First referenced by name during Jordan's intelligence debrief following the marina infiltration, identifying Rogue Wave's delivery system as using "Rush Order" for contract distribution (Ch. 158). Appeared as one of the six core Rogue Wave members in their televised NBC10 manifesto broadcast, publicly identified as the organization's delivery specialist (Ch. 158). Book 11: Alarm Will Sound Supporting Featured in Interlude LS.1, where he reported a 22% increase in contract distribution with 92% retention during a strategic planning meeting at Rogue Wave headquarters. The report demonstrates Rogue Wave's continued expansion despite Jordan Westwood's exposure of the contract enforcement vulnerability. Book 12: Authorized Personnel Only Supporting Arrived on motorcycle at the Sunoco station to extract Dead Drop during the confrontation with the Auditors, leaving Marathon (a lower-level Rogue Wave dealer) and his crew behind to prioritize a core member's escape (Chapter 182). Tasha later identified Rush Order and Dead Drop from the May broadcast footage, confirming them as core Rogue Wave operatives. Confronted Bloodhound on South Street in a deliberately staged public fight (Chapter 187), demonstrating overwhelming speed advantage and delivering Rogue Wave's ideological message to the crowd and cameras. Benjamin Small intervened, leading to a gunfire exchange in which both men were wounded. Dean was shot in the shoulder and retreated to an underground clinic in Camden. Featured in the Rush Order section of Interlude RS/DC/JF recovering at a Camden safehouse, where Snake Oil and Elias Franklin tend to his gunshot wound and facial lacerations while Monkey Business monitors the online reaction to the incident. Dean describes Sam's tooth-from-knuckles ability to teammates (comparing it to Wolverine's claws) and confirms the fight was a deliberate publicity stunt, expressing satisfaction that it has gone viral and is driving both gun sales and Jump distribution. The team debates Bloodhound's identity and whether to target her again. Dead Drop and Jackpot return with food, leading to a team dinner and philosophical discussion about Rogue Wave's cause. Dean reaffirms his commitment despite his injuries. Released a public video declaring "Gun Dad" under Rogue Wave's protection, challenging Bloodhound to a rematch while praising her resilience. Book 13: Burn After Reading Mentioned Referenced as Rogue Wave's ongoing presence in the escalating three-way conflict between vigilante heroes, government-sanctioned forces, and criminal organizations across Philadelphia. Book 14: Shelter in Place Supporting Mentioned alongside Monkey Business as a potential resource during the Shrike crisis (Chapter 204). Arrived at the Tacony Music Hall disguised as a delivery person bringing pizza during the Rogue Wave negotiation (Chapter 205). Confirmed that Ben Small's protection had been active since his video. Drew weapons briefly when Sam cut Monkey Business's hand but stood down. Privately revealed to Sam that Maya Richardson was not actually in Harrisburg during the senate hearings, describing this intelligence as "a curse, not help." Returned in Chapter 206 to collect the list of people needing protection, confirming his location-sensing ability and stating Maya had been "way more North" in New York State. Sent a warning text to Sam's Rogue Wave burner phone ("Square up. Run. -RO") before a Kingdom contractor attacked the Music Hall (Chapter 217). Book 15: Severe Weather Warning Major (Interlude DC.2) Receives Sam's text about Kingdom evidence disposal at Roxborough Memorial Hospital (Chapter 220), fulfilling her obligation to Rogue Wave, and responds with a single smiley face emoji. Featured as narrator of Interlude DC.2, depicting the Polygraph extraction operation from Rogue Wave's side: uses the geased private investigator Rick as bait at Roxborough for three days. When Mr. Polygraph and Mr. Nothing arrive on Thursday, Dead Drop's chains subdue Kingdom operatives while Rush Order personally captures Polygraph. At the Camden warehouse, Snake Oil extracts Polygraph's lie-detection power through 90 seconds of direct neck contact, the ability crystallizing as a blue-green crystal from Snake Oil's hand. The crystal becomes raw material for Fly. Monkey Business prepares Polygraph for transport and tips police after forty-five minutes. Texts Sam confirming her debt is paid but warns never to involve police in Rogue Wave dealings again. Referenced later when Sam cites Rush Order's earlier intel about Maya not being in Harrisburg as evidence supporting the existence of a Kingdom shapeshifter (Chapter 224). Intermission 15.5: This Side Up POV (Interlude DC.3) Narrated an interlude set during a winter storm in which he and Dead Drop tracked Maya Richardson to a rooftop in Northeast Philadelphia using his person-location ability. The pair observed that the blizzard was concentrated unnaturally over Northeast Philly and deduced someone was generating it. After locating Maya on a six-story industrial building's roof conducting weather manipulation, they attempted to capture her. Dead Drop's chains snagged Maya's ankle and wrist, and Dean grabbed her coat, but Maya broke free using a taser, pepper spray, and physical resistance. In the enclosed stairwell, Maya sealed the fire door and demonstrated devastating barokinetic power — creating crushing pressure gradients, stopping Dead Drop's gyroscopically stabilized chain-link projectiles mid-flight, and slamming Dean against a concrete wall with directed air pressure. Dean's passive aerokinesis partially protected him from the worst of the crushing force but could not fully counteract it. Dead Drop broke the pressure seal by tearing the fire door off its hinges with brute ferrokinesis, and Maya escaped by dropping down the stairwell center using controlled pressure descent. Dean sustained a sprained or fractured left ankle, cracked ribs, and a nosebleed from the pressure exposure. The pair retreated to the Camden safehouse, where Dean delivered a factual debrief to Monkey Business. Sullivan concluded that Maya Richardson was no longer a viable target for direct action and should be "routed around, not pursued." Dean confirmed the intelligence value of the encounter: Maya's true power was pressure manipulation rather than weather control, indoor spaces were kill zones, projectile weapons were neutralized within her effective range, and she carried conventional self-defense tools (taser and mace) as backup. Dead Drop noted Maya could use pressure for three-dimensional mobility via controlled falls.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Dean's interlude code is "DC," with Interlude DC.2 being his narrated chapter covering the Mr. Polygraph extraction operation. The existence of a DC.2 designation implies a DC.1 interlude exists earlier in the story.
  • He described Sam's teeth-from-knuckles ability to his teammates by comparing it to Wolverine's claws, suggesting familiarity with pop culture references.
  • His response to being shot by Benjamin Small was to dismiss it as being "careless" rather than expressing anger or desire for revenge, a reaction that surprised even his own teammates.
  • He brought pizza as a "peace offering" when arriving at the Music Hall for the Rogue Wave negotiation during the Shrike crisis, a characteristically theatrical gesture.
  • Marathon, a lower-level Rogue Wave dealer who ran a crew (Brass Knuckles, Baseball Bat, Refrigerator Guy) out of a Sunoco station on Longshore Avenue, is a separate character from Dean. Rush Order extracted Dead Drop from the Sunoco confrontation while leaving Marathon and his crew behind, establishing the hierarchy between core and peripheral Rogue Wave members.
  • His warning text to Sam before the Garbage Day attack ("Square up. Run. -RO") demonstrated that he monitors Kingdom movements and chose to alert Sam despite their adversarial relationship.
  • He carries a revolver rather than a more modern firearm, consistent with his theatrical personality and preference for dramatic flair.
  • In Interlude DC.3, Dean described his person-location sense as "like a compass magnet in my brain" and a "tugging my body into a certain orientation in space," and referred to the sensation colloquially as "yankety yankety."
  • He wears glasses, as noted when he adjusted them before addressing Maya in the stairwell during DC.3.
  • Dean compared Maya's oppressive pressure aura to an anime about "the orange haired dude with the big sword," a reference to Bleach's concept of spiritual pressure (reiatsu).
  • During the DC.3 stairwell confrontation, Dean executed a sliding maneuver he mentally described as "Megaman-esque" to jam his ankle through the closing fire door.
  • His comfort with pop culture references extends beyond Western media; in addition to the Wolverine comparison from the South Street fight, he referenced X-Men vs. Street Fighter when assessing Maya's combat style and compared her to Storm from the X-Men.

docs.title: Derek Taylor
docs.text: A werewolf vigilante and former petty criminal who became Sam Small's ally through a trauma support group, eventually inheriting the Bloodhound identity after Sam's retirement.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Derek Taylor Aliases Fenrir (temporary alias), Bloodhound II (current) Date of Birth Unknown (circa late 1990s/early 2000s) Age Mid-twenties Gender Male Ethnicity White (Irish-American) Place of Birth Boston, MA Residence South Philadelphia, PA Affiliation The Auditors (loosely affiliated), NSRA Vysera Trial Former Affiliations None Occupation Independent Vigilante, Public Investigator (vigilante detective) Status Active First Appearance Chapter 66 Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Derek Taylor was born in Boston to Finn Taylor, a low-level Irish mob associate who worked under boss Callahan. In 2002, during the early emergence of superheroes, Finn and his associates watched news coverage of a superhero named Windstorm thwarting a robbery in Chicago at their regular haunt, The Clover & Harp dive bar. Finn attended a secret meeting with a younger mobster named Sean and others considering breaking away from Callahan, but Russian mobsters interrupted the meeting. A masked vigilante intervened, easily defeating the Russians and warning Finn's group to change their ways. Shaken by the encounter and motivated by a desire to give his young son a better life, Finn confided in his friend Mikey Flanagan, who suggested leaving Boston entirely. Finn spent several weeks planning the departure, using "family drama" as his cover story for Callahan. On the night they left, Finn spotted another costumed figure swinging between buildings as they crossed the bridge out of Boston, confirming his belief he was making the right choice. He moved himself and Derek to Philadelphia, using construction work as a cover for their fresh start.

Derek grew up in Philadelphia and at some point developed werewolf abilities, which cause him to involuntarily transform into a wolf-like form at sundown every night. Unable to control the transformation, Derek adopted a grim routine of dosing himself with veterinary-grade tranquilizers and locking himself into a reinforced cage in his apartment each evening. This nightly imprisonment effectively cut him off from normal social life for approximately seven years and contributed to his antisocial demeanor. He also accumulated a petty criminal record during this period.

Derek met Sam Small in a trauma support group for superhumans led by Dr. Jensen in April 2024, where he was notably confrontational and dismissive, consistently leaving sessions early before sunset. After recognizing Sam as the vigilante Bloodhound, Derek approached her for help when his friend Elias Franklin took the power-enhancing drug Fly and transformed into the chimeric villain "Chimera." This collaboration marked Derek's entry into the vigilante world and his gradual integration into Sam's network of allies. In late October 2025, following Sam's retirement from the Bloodhound identity, Derek enrolled in an NSRA experimental trial for Vysera (daxerimab) after three months of screening. The drug provides 14 doses per week, each suppressing his transformation for 3-4 hours. He was fitted with a monitoring bracelet that tracks his location and biometrics, managed by Agent Sarah Jennings. Derek administered his first dose at 5:05 PM and watched the sunset without transforming for the first time in seven years. That evening, he met his father Finn for dinner at Vincenzo's Restaurant and walked the Philadelphia streets after dark, seeing the stars for the first time in years. During his first week on the trial, Derek used his enhanced daytime senses to locate missing college student Gina Martinez, infiltrating an underground club in Fishtown where she was being given experimental drugs and extracting her safely. At his first weekly NSRA check-in, Agent Jennings questioned irregular biometric readings and warned him against vigilante activities, which Derek denied. On Halloween morning, he met Amelia (Gossamer) at a high school to receive a modified Bloodhound costume redesigned for his larger frame, with both summer and winter variations, and officially assumed the Bloodhound II identity.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Involuntary Werewolf Transformation — Transforms into a wolf-like form at sundown each night. The transformation is entirely involuntary and has occurred nightly for approximately seven years. In wolf form, Derek possesses enhanced strength and speed.
  • Enhanced Sense of Smell (Daytime) — Even in human form, Derek possesses a heightened sense of smell that functions during daylight hours. This makes him a particularly effective tracker, capable of following scent trails through urban environments, identifying individuals by smell, and detecting specific odors such as ozone.
  • Injury Reset on Transformation — Injuries sustained in one form vanish when Derek changes between human and wolf forms. This effective regeneration occurs at each transformation, meaning wounds accumulated during the day heal when he transforms at sunset, and vice versa.
  • Enhanced Senses (Wolf Form) — In wolf form, all senses are significantly heightened beyond their already enhanced daytime levels.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• No Transformation Control — Derek cannot choose when to transform. The change occurs involuntarily at sundown every night, requiring him to secure himself beforehand.
  • Nightly Incapacitation — Without Vysera, Derek is effectively incapacitated every night, forced to tranquilize himself and lock himself in a cage to prevent harm.
  • Vysera Time Limit — The experimental drug Vysera suppresses his transformation for only 3-4 hours per dose, creating a strict operational window after dark. He receives 14 doses per week.
  • Sunset Deadline — All daytime operations must conclude before sunset, or Derek risks transforming in an uncontrolled environment. This creates constant time pressure during missions.
  • NSRA Monitoring — While on the Vysera trial, Derek wears a monitoring bracelet that tracks his location and biometrics. Agent Jennings has warned him against vigilante activities based on suspicious readings.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Skilled street fighter with experience using brass knuckles and a switchblade in close combat.
  • Experienced tracker who combines his enhanced sense of smell with investigative methodology, conducting private investigations including missing persons cases.
  • Possesses street-level intelligence networks and criminal contacts from his background.
  • Competent at undercover work and bluffing, as demonstrated during the Sparkplug infiltration and his private investigation work in Fishtown.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Derek is gruff, antisocial, and bluntly practical, with a deep streak of cynicism born from years of living under the constraints of his condition. He speaks with little regard for social niceties and maintains emotional distance from almost everyone. His confrontational demeanor was evident from his first appearance in the support group, where he scoffed at others' sharing and left sessions early without explanation. He carries himself with the wariness of someone accustomed to operating alone and trusting no one.

Beneath the abrasive exterior, Derek demonstrates a capacity for loyalty and self-sacrifice. He held a switchblade to his own throat to save Sam during the Chimera confrontation, and he stabbed his friend Elias to provide Sam with a blood trail for tracking. He is reliable when it counts, even if he resists being seen that way. His assumption of the Bloodhound identity reveals a desire for purpose and connection that he would likely never articulate. His approach to the role is more methodical and less hands-on than Sam's, with greater command presence but less familiarity with emergency protocols. When Cape Watch Philly blogger Alicia C. tracked him down conducting a missing person investigation with a notebook in a South Philly vacant lot, Derek's confirmation was characteristically dismissive of public relations: "People who need to know, know." He shows no interest in ceremony, announcements, or public perception, focusing entirely on the work itself.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Derek has orange hair and typically wears a leather jacket.
  • His temporary superhero alias "Fenrir" was adopted on the spot during the Independence Blue Cross confrontation, referencing the giant wolf of Norse mythology.
  • His father Finn Taylor's interlude (DT.1) is set in 2002 at a Boston dive bar called The Clover & Harp.
  • He was unable to see the stars at night for approximately seven years due to his nightly transformations, until the Vysera trial allowed him his first after-dark freedom.
  • His apartment in South Philadelphia features a reinforced cage specifically built for containing his wolf form during nightly transformations.
  • The public became aware of the Bloodhound identity change partly because Derek has a notably broader build and taller frame than Sam, and his movement patterns and behavior differed significantly.
  • His confirmation to the Cape Watch Philly blogger was characteristically blunt: "Yeah, she retired. I'm Bloodhound now."
  • The Auditors gave him the Bloodhound equipment and costume as a show of good faith after Sam retired.
  • He operates publicly as a "public investigator" (vigilante detective) and people are aware he is a different person than the original Bloodhound.
  • Derek's first Vysera dose was administered at exactly 5:05 PM, and his monitoring bracelet tracked biometric irregularities during his first week that raised NSRA suspicion about unauthorized vigilante activities.
  • The Cape Watch Philly blog post speculating about the identity change went live at 10:47 AM on November 4, 2025, and Derek's confirmation interview was posted at 1:23 AM on November 5.
  • Eyewitnesses noted multiple differences between the two Bloodhounds: broader shoulders, taller build, completely redesigned costume with different helmet, a more "androgynous" voice distorter, more methodical approach, and less familiarity with emergency medical protocols.
  • EMT Sophia Martinez, who had worked with both Bloodhounds, was among those who noticed the differences at the Spring Garden telekinetic incident scene.
  • Finn Taylor used "family drama" as his excuse to Callahan and Sean when taking time off before fleeing Boston with Derek.

docs.title: Devonte Harris
docs.text: Former Young Defender turned private investigator, a sound-filching metahuman now operating under the alias Ventriloquist alongside Akilah Washington at Chambers & Woo Investigations.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Devonte Harris Aliases Playback (former), Ventriloquist (current) Date of Birth c. 2006 Age 15–20s Gender Male Ethnicity African-American Place of Birth Philadelphia, PA Residence Philadelphia, PA Affiliation Chambers & Woo Investigations Former Affiliations Young Defenders, Delaware Valley Defenders (associated) Occupation Private Investigator, College Student Status Active First Appearance Chapter 5 Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Devonte Harris was a fifteen-year-old running with a local gang in Philadelphia when Liberty Belle intervened to redirect his talents toward heroism. As a precursor to formal assignment with the Young Defenders, Belle insisted he acquire a JLUMA (juvenile license), and he was enrolled in the PERKS assessment system in 2021. Despite being evasive and combative with his interviewing officer, Devonte demonstrated a genuine interest in helping his local community and was accepted onto the team under the codename Playback.

Devonte served with the Young Defenders through several years of escalating crises, including the battles against the Philly Phreaks, Liberty Belle's terminal illness and death at the hands of Chernobyl, and the subsequent political upheaval surrounding superhuman oversight. He developed from a rebellious teenager into a more reliable operative, showing particular aptitude for stealth operations and intelligence gathering. He had a brief romantic relationship with teammate Amelia (Gossamer) that ended because of differences regarding his Christian faith and views on premarital sex.

In 2023, following the courthouse crisis and the team restructuring that saw Crossroads graduate to the senior Delaware Valley Defenders and Rampart assume leadership, Devonte resigned from the Young Defenders alongside Akilah Washington to pursue personal goals. He adopted the new codename Ventriloquist and transitioned into private investigation work at Chambers & Woo Investigations. He now assists with the ongoing investigation into the Kingdom of Keys, providing technical expertise in evidence analysis and surveillance. He was shot and deafened in one ear during an investigation of Operation Ivory at the docks, and now wears a hearing aid designed by Fury Forge that allows him to use his powers without removing sounds from the environment.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: Field Value Classification F4/E/P/B Category Filch Power Ranking 4/10 Control 6/10 Hostility 4/10 Collateral Damage 2/10 Threat Level 3/10

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Sound Marking — Can mentally "mark" objects or individuals, allowing him to steal or play back sounds from those targets. Can theoretically mark a limitless number of objects, but practically limited to around 6 or 7 due to cognitive constraints. Marks are invisible and undetectable by any known method, but vanish as soon as he stops thinking of the marked object.
  • Sound Stealing — Prevents sounds from occurring in real-time by stealing them from marked targets. A stolen footstep is completely silent. Requires conceptualizing the target as a cohesive unit; he can mute an entire person, specific parts like their shoes, an entire firearm, individual bullets, or specific mechanisms within a gun.
  • Sound Playback — Can reproduce stolen sounds through any marked surface, creating new vibrational energy. Multiple sounds can be played simultaneously. Once a sound is played back, it is consumed and cannot be reproduced again.
  • Sound Library — Maintains an internal library of stored sounds. Sounds degrade in quality after approximately 24 hours. If he steals incidental noises without being aware they occurred, he typically cannot utilize them.
  • Weaponized Sound — Loud sounds such as explosions or gunshots can be played back to produce deafening effects or physical damage through sufficient kinetic force.
  • Hearing Aid Integration — Wears a hearing aid designed by Fury Forge that allows him to steal sounds from the hearing aid's playback rather than from the environment, enabling him to use his powers without silencing the original source.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Concentration Dependency — Effectiveness is directly tied to his concentration. Distractions can cause unintentional release of marked sounds or failure to maintain marks.
  • Cognitive Load — Maintaining multiple marks and managing his sound library is mentally taxing, especially during extended operations.
  • Environmental Interference — Noise pollution and chaotic environments can interfere with concentration and control.
  • Memory Requirement — Can only hold and utilize sounds he is consciously aware of and can keep in memory.
  • Hearing Loss — Deaf in one ear from a gunshot wound sustained while investigating Operation Ivory. Compensated by Fury Forge's custom hearing aid.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Technical specialist with expertise in evidence analysis and surveillance techniques acquired through work at Chambers & Woo Investigations.
  • Trained in grappling and close-quarters combat during his time with the Young Defenders; was observed training Spindle in grappling techniques including the omoplata.
  • Proficient in counter-surveillance protocols and investigative methodology.
  • Knowledge of encryption and digital security, including understanding of AES-256 encryption limitations.
  • Currently completing a college degree.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Devonte is laid-back and technically brilliant, functioning as the class clown in most group settings. He is incapable of taking anything seriously for long, frequently cracking jokes and engaging in lewd humor that stays just short of crossing the line. His banter with Akilah Washington has evolved from genuine friction into a comfortable, well-worn dynamic. He has an anti-authoritarian streak and a history of rebelliousness, but pairs it with a consistent interest in justice and fairness. He is a Christian whose faith is sincere enough to have ended a romantic relationship over it.

Beneath the humor, Devonte is perceptive and supportive. He was the one who intervened during the confrontation between Puppeteer and Sam by playing back evidence of Liberty Belle's illness, defusing the situation. He has consistently offered quiet encouragement to Sam during difficult moments. His PERKS interviewing officer noted steady maturation across three consecutive annual assessments, observing that his personality shifted from being a hindrance to being part of his charm as he grew into his role.
