docs.title: Arc Appearances
docs.text: Book Role Key Events Book 1: Pup Supporting Introduced as a Young Defenders member. Welcomes Sam after her first patrol. Intervenes during the Puppeteer-Sam confrontation by playing back evidence of Liberty Belle's illness. Accompanies Sam to Wawa afterward. Book 2: Keys Supporting Participates in the South Street battle against the Philly Phreaks. Reveals pre-powers history with Patches. Delivers a crucial sound blast against Deathgirl. Watches Amira's interrogation from behind the glass. Book 3: Dybbuk Supporting Present for Liberty Belle's cancer revelation. Arrives at the refinery scene after Belle's death at the hands of Chernobyl. Book 5: Mayfly Supporting Present during team missions. Battles Ricochet alongside Crossroads. Offers quiet consolation to Sam after Crossroads reprimands her. Book 6: Sideshow Supporting Participated in team debates about the drug Fly and artificial powers. Argued alongside Sam against following NSRA suppression orders at the courthouse protest, refusing to use force against civilians. Used the LRAD system to urge protesters to evacuate during the Phreaks' attack. Used his sound-manipulation powers to fight Pumice alongside Spindle and Gale during the courthouse battle. Resigned from the Young Defenders at the end of the arc, citing a return to college, though Sam detected underlying bitterness; whispered "Don't trust these bitches" to Sam before leaving. Book 6: Sideshow (Interlude DH.1) Main POV interlude set during the Phreaks' courthouse attack. Devonte tries to stop bleeding from his nose using his torn costume while assessing the warzone-like street scene. He and Spindle engage Pumice, with Devonte using sound manipulation to distract and disorient Pumice, but Pumice proves extremely resilient, throwing Spindle and withstanding Playback's blows. Gale arrives disguised in biker gear and a helmet, headbutting Pumice to temporarily incapacitate him. The trio coordinates their attacks: Gale uses wind to enhance Spindle's strikes and Playback's movements, launches Spindle with wind gusts, and ultimately creates a vortex of air to suffocate Pumice. They secure Pumice with zip ties. Despite the victory, they acknowledge the devastation around them and that their work is far from over. Book 7: Security Supporting Returns in Chapter 116 alongside Akilah Washington. They visit the DVD gym and pull Sam aside for a private meeting at the Tacony Music Hall with Jordan, Tasha, and Maggie present. Now working as a private investigator at Chambers & Woo Investigations while attending college. Delivers critical intelligence on Project Titan, a classified military program that attempted to create enhanced soldiers through artificial power induction, identifying Patriot as an original test subject and war criminal. Provides physical evidence (dried blood containing Fly traces) proving Egalitarian uses the superpower-granting drug Fly. This intelligence becomes the leverage Sam uses to confront and negotiate a truce with Patriot. Book 8: Big Main (Interlude) In Interlude DH.2, Devonte investigates Kingdom activities at the docks near 5245 Bleigh Avenue on a cold, snowy November day. Using his sound-stealing powers to evade guards, he overhears plans for "Operation Ivory" involving elephant and rhino trafficking to Johannesburg, a mysterious "second phase," and Maya Richardson's role as political cover. Mrs. Heartbeat arrives to check on progress. Mr. Nothing catches Devonte eavesdropping and threatens to kill him. Akilah (Marionette) arrives to rescue him, and they escape with Devonte using sound powers for cover. Shot during the escape, Akilah helps him reach the Music Hall where he loses consciousness (Ch. 130). From his hospital bed, shares intelligence about Operation Ivory with the team (Ch. 131). Fury Forge promises hearing implants after his powers have damaged his hearing. Book 10: Plume Mentioned Referenced as continuing private investigation work at Chambers & Woo Investigations alongside Akilah. Book 12: Authorized Personnel Only Supporting Sam enlists Devonte and Akilah at Chambers & Woo Investigations to help decrypt Kingdom files. They confirm Stheno Pharmaceuticals and Tremont & Fairfax connections. Provides counter-surveillance advice and discusses AES-256 encryption. Book 14: Shelter in Place Supporting Participates in the gambit against the Kingdom from the Tacony-Palmyra Bridge alongside Akilah and Jordan. Plays police sirens and Kate's recorded voice from Soot's mask to deceive Mr. Polygraph's lie-detection powers. Visits Sam during recovery.

docs.text:

  • His PERKS assessment was originally a JLUMA (juvenile license) in 2021, later upgraded.

  • His interviewing officer, Elena Martinez, described him as a "smartass 15-year-old" in his first assessment but expressed willingness to take a gamble on him.
  • The civilian clerk for his PERKS assessment was Jason Lee.
  • He lost a bet to Rampart about whether Sam and Jamila were dating.
  • His hearing aid from Fury Forge represents a creative workaround for his disability, allowing him to steal sounds from the aid's playback rather than from the environment directly.
  • He has the N-word pass and uses it.

docs.title: Diane Williams
docs.text: Leader of the Delaware Valley Defenders, super-strength vigilante, and mentor to a generation of Philadelphia heroes, whose death at the hands of Chernobyl remains a defining event in the city's superhero community.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Diane Williams Aliases Breakout (former), Liberty Belle (primary) Date of Birth March 17, 1985 Age 38 (at time of death) Gender Female Ethnicity African-American Place of Birth Baltimore, Maryland Residence Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Affiliation Delaware Valley Defenders Former Affiliations N/A Occupation Registered Superhuman Entity, vigilante, detective Status Deceased First Appearance Chapter 3 Last Appearance Chapter 45 / DW.2 (alive); Intermission 15.5 JP.2 (flashback as Breakout)

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Diane Williams was born in Baltimore on March 17, 1985. She demonstrated leadership qualities from an early age, notably standing up to a school bully at age eight. Her mother, Martha Williams, died in 1999 from complications related to diabetes, after which Diane became the primary caregiver for her younger brother, Alex Williams. She graduated from Patterson High School in 2003 with a community service award and enrolled at Towson University to study Criminal Justice. A period of depression following a failed relationship led her to temporarily withdraw from college in 2004, but she returned the following year and eventually graduated in 2008, making the Dean's List in her final year.

On November 3, 2005, Diane survived a catastrophic subway crash in New York City. Trapped beneath rubble for hours, her superhuman abilities manifested, allowing her to shield herself and other passengers from the crushing weight. She subsequently sought therapy to cope with the trauma and spent the next several years training and honing her powers. After graduating from Towson, she moved to Philadelphia in 2008 and began operating as a vigilante under the alias "Breakout," a name referencing a brick-breaking video game she had enjoyed in her youth. She received her official vigilante license in 2013.

In 2010, Diane encountered Professor Franklin (Jeffery Brown) at an underground superhuman event, and he became her mentor. Under his guidance, she refined her approach to heroism, shifting from raw physicality to strategic thinking. In 2015, at Franklin's suggestion, she changed her alias to "Liberty Belle" to better reflect her protective nature. She registered as a superhuman entity with the NSRA in 2016 and officially joined the Delaware Valley Defenders the same year. Professor Franklin's death at the hands of Chernobyl in 2017 deeply affected her, causing a brief hiatus from vigilante work. She subsequently took on the mantle of leadership within the Delaware Valley Defenders, training multiple generations of young heroes.

In May 2021, Diane was diagnosed with terminal stomach cancer, allegedly caused by radiation exposure from an earlier encounter with the supervillain Chernobyl. She began chemotherapy but continued her duties as leader of the Delaware Valley Defenders and the Young Defenders. By the time of her death in late 2023, the cancer had spread to her lungs, liver, and bones, leaving her with an estimated eight to twenty-four months to live. She was killed by Chernobyl at the abandoned PES refinery in Southwest Philadelphia on the first night of Hanukkah, dying in the arms of her young protege, Sam Small.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: Field Value Classification G6/S/P/T (Super Strength), B5/S/P/T (Super-Proprioception) Category Gigant, Brain Power Ranking 6/10 Control 9/10 Hostility 0/10 Collateral Damage 4/10 Threat Level 3/10

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Super Strength (Gigant) — Tremendous physical strength allowing her to lift and throw cars, trucks, and firetrucks, break concrete pillars, and dent heavy mechanical armor. She could kick vehicles across a road and punch through reinforced doors with ease.
  • Super-Proprioception (Brain) — Advanced proprioceptive sense that allowed her to detect the precise position, orientation, and movement of her body without relying on visual cues. This ability functioned through her vestibular senses, granting heightened spatial awareness in combat and navigation, particularly useful during low-visibility situations such as nighttime operations and fire rescues.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Her powers were purely physical and touch-range, offering no defense against ranged attacks, radiation, or environmental hazards beyond her own durability.
  • The terminal stomach cancer progressively weakened her over time, reducing her stamina and physical resilience in her final years.
  • Her fighting style, while agile, could not fully compensate for opponents with environmental manipulation abilities or heavily armored foes.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Trained in martial arts including judo and aikido, which she incorporated into her combat style and taught to her proteges.
  • Criminal Justice degree from Towson University (Class of 2008).
  • Skilled detective whose deductive abilities and investigative tenacity were described as nearly a superpower in their own right. She maintained extensive files and detective equipment that she bequeathed to Sam Small.
  • Proficient in surveillance techniques, stakeout methodology, legal and gray-area investigation methods, and information gathering.
  • Decade-long experience in superheroics with exceptional power control, reflected in her 9/10 PERKS control rating.
  • Trained in first aid and emergency medical response; carried a utility belt with first aid supplies during field operations.
  • In her early career as Breakout, she drove an armored SUV while monitoring police radio and wore tactical gear including layered Kevlar vests, shin guards, forearm braces, and a modified helmet.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Diane was charismatic, inspiring, and strategic, with a fierce dedication to justice. She spoke with natural authority and compassion, carrying herself as a leader who saw potential in others before they saw it in themselves. She had a sense of humor, as seen in her willingness to play six-on-one basketball with teenagers and her use of poker to teach misdirection, but could be blunt about difficult truths, telling Sam plainly that she would keep going until she died.

During her early mentorship under Franklin, she nearly quit being a hero when the work became overwhelming, but Franklin convinced her to stay, a turning point she later cited as pivotal during his eulogy. Franklin's guiding philosophy shaped her deeply; he taught her that her name "Breakout" reflected only destruction and encouraged her to embody responsibility, sharing the Benjamin Franklin quote: "By failing to prepare, you're preparing to fail."

Later assessments have painted her legacy in a more complex light. While her dedication to uncovering corruption beneath institutions like Daedalus was genuine, many fellow heroes criticized her for recklessness bordering on suicidality, an inability to know when to give up, and a tactical mindset that failed to account for long-term strategy. Some of these criticisms hold merit, though she did have a long-term plan that others simply did not agree with. Her decision to confront Chernobyl alone at the refinery, despite her terminal illness, exemplifies both her courage and her self-destructive tendencies.

docs.title: Relationships
docs.text: Character Relationship Notes Sam Small (Bloodhound) Protege Recruited Sam to the Young Defenders, trained her in combat and detective work, and left her all detective equipment and files in her will. Sam was present at her death. Professor Franklin (Jeffery Brown) Mentor (deceased) Her most formative relationship. Franklin guided her from a raw vigilante into a disciplined hero and suggested the Liberty Belle name. His death at Chernobyl's hands in 2017 haunted her for the rest of her life. Chernobyl (Illya Myronovych Fedorov) Adversary The supervillain who killed Professor Franklin, gave Diane her cancer through radiation exposure, and ultimately killed her at the PES refinery. Elijah Brooks (Multiplex) Colleague Second-in-command of the Delaware Valley Defenders during the Liberty Belle era. Had philosophical disagreements with Diane about mentoring young heroes, favoring systems over charismatic leadership. Akilah Washington (Puppeteer/Marionette) Protege Recruited Akilah to the Young Defenders. Left her $100,000 in her will. Joshua Pleasants (Miasma) Friend / Confidant Close friend who was bequeathed items in her will. Came to Philadelphia after her death and continued her investigations. Mark Ramirez (Silver Strike) Ex-partner Short-lived romantic relationship with a Delaware Valley Defenders Maryland branch member in early 2018, ending by mutual agreement in April. Alex Williams Brother Younger brother whom Diane raised after their mother's death. Shrike (Niles Nolan) Adversary (defeated) Villain she confronted during her early Breakout days in the Strawberry Mansion area. Shrike was stealing copper wiring from homes and had trapped a family of three in a lattice of metal spikes. Diane fought him through a spike-filled rowhome, taking a wound to her calf before Franklin arrived and incapacitated Shrike with an electrical shock. Franklin knew Shrike's real name was Niles and zip-tied him for containment transport, possibly to Daedalus. Martha Williams Mother (deceased) Died in 1999 from complications related to diabetes, instilling in Diane a strong sense of responsibility.

docs.title: Arc Appearances
docs.text: Book Role Key Events Book 1: Pup Supporting Appears at a basketball game where Sam detects her internal bleeding. Visits the Small household to recruit Sam for the Young Defenders, revealing her terminal cancer diagnosis. Book 2: Keys Mentioned Absent from active team operations, referenced as investigating the Kingdom of Keys on her own. Book 3: Dybbuk Main Returns to headquarters gaunt and bald from chemotherapy, revealing her cancer has spread. Trains Sam in combat, detective work, and deception. Briefs the team on Chernobyl's history. Confronts Chernobyl alone at the PES refinery and is killed. DW.1 interlude depicts her 2015 battle against Shrike as Breakout. DW.2 interlude depicts her eulogy at Professor Franklin's funeral at Laurel Hill Cemetery on a snowy day in 2017, where she wore a black dress and spoke after Jim Cramer, recalling how Franklin turned mistakes into teaching moments and once convinced her not to quit hero work; she broke down crying as the coffin lowered, overwhelmed by memories of holding Franklin as he died in the rain. Book 4: Exorcism Mentioned Diane's death reverberates through the hero community. Her will is read at Goldman, Reid & Miller (Ch. 46), distributing her detective equipment and files to Sam, $100,000 to Akilah, and other bequests to allies. Her letter to Sam warns of "dark things in the shadows" and names Sam her investigative successor. Sam attends her funeral at Laurel Hill East Cemetery (Ch. 47). Chernobyl is charged with her second-degree murder. Intermission 15.5: This Side Up Interlude (JP.2) Appears as "Breakout" in Joshua Pleasants' origin flashback. After Pleasants' first vigilante intervention in Baltimore (a convenience store robbery where a gunshot ruptured his hazmat suit), Breakout finished subduing the gunman and invited Pleasants for coffee at a nearby diner. She was described as wearing a cheap domino mask and street clothes with an athletic build and steel-wool-textured hair, and was the first person outside of medical professionals and family to voluntarily spend time in his presence after his condition became unmanageable. This scene predates her move to Philadelphia (2008) and her adoption of the Liberty Belle identity (2015).

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Her original alias "Breakout" was a reference to a brick-breaking video game she enjoyed during her youth.
  • Professor Franklin suggested the name change to "Liberty Belle" in 2015 to reflect her protective nature rather than her brute strength.
  • Her PERKS interviewing officer was Matthew R. Grayson, who assessed her from 2013 through 2023.
  • She had a brief romantic relationship with Mark "Silver Strike" Ramirez of the Delaware Valley Defenders Maryland branch in early 2018.
  • She received a commendation from the NSRA in September 2021 for bravery in the face of personal adversity following her cancer diagnosis.
  • Her postcognitive background assessment was conducted by a team of five NSRA specialists and updated as recently as February 2023.
  • During her confrontation with Chernobyl, he accused her of being haunted by a "dybbuk" -- a possessing spirit -- specifically the spirit of Professor Franklin.
  • In 2015, Philadelphia police were reluctant to engage superhuman threats directly following an incident with a cape called "Tesla" two years prior, relying instead on registered capes like Diane.
  • At Professor Franklin's funeral, she sat in the front row wearing a black dress that she described as feeling unnatural compared to her usual tactical gear.
  • She held a degree in Criminal Justice from Towson University, where she made the Dean's List in her final year.
  • At age eight, she received one day of in-school suspension for giving a school bully a nosebleed while defending a peer.

docs.title: Egalitarian
docs.text: Co-leader of Pattinson's Pals with vertigo-inducing powers that selectively affect non-powered individuals, secretly using the drug Fly while publicly opposing metahuman threats.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Natalie (surname unknown) Aliases Egalitarian Date of Birth Unknown Age Unknown (adult, likely late twenties to thirties) Gender Female Ethnicity Unknown Place of Birth Unknown Residence Philadelphia, PA (presumed) Affiliation Pattinson's Pals Former Affiliations N/A Occupation Vigilante / Community Organizer Status Active First Appearance Chapter 104 Last Appearance Chapter 141

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Natalie, operating under the codename Egalitarian, is the co-leader of Pattinson's Pals alongside Patriot (Richard Johnson). She was present at the funeral of Richard Johnson Sr. in 2017 along with fellow teammate Sean (later known as Bulldozer), establishing that she has been part of Patriot's inner circle for years before the events of the main story.

Egalitarian possesses a vertigo-inducing power that selectively incapacitates non-powered individuals while leaving metahumans unaffected. This unusual mechanic -- targeting a biological mechanism absent in metahumans -- makes her power function as the inverse of most combat abilities in the setting, rendering her effective against civilians and baseline humans but useless against powered opponents.

Physical evidence obtained by Devonte Harris and Akilah Washington revealed that Egalitarian secretly uses the drug Fly, a substance that grants temporary superpowers. This discovery is deeply hypocritical given that Pattinson's Pals publicly position themselves as opponents of metahuman threats. Sam Small used this evidence as leverage during her negotiation with Patriot, threatening to expose Egalitarian's Fly use to DA Alvarez. Whether Egalitarian's vertigo power is her natural ability or was granted by Fly use remains an open question.

After Patriot departed the Pals to join the Argus Corps, Egalitarian continued operating in Philadelphia. During the Book 9 arson crisis, she co-organized civilian defense patrols with fellow Pals member Parabellum, positioning the group as community protectors while expressing concerning surveillance-state views.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Vertigo Induction -- Deploys an area-of-effect power that causes disorientation and vertigo, incapacitating those within range. The effect is potent enough to drop an entire gymnasium of people.
  • Selective Targeting -- Her power exclusively affects non-powered individuals. Metahumans (including Sam Small and Jordan Westwood) remained standing and fully functional while everyone else in the homecoming gymnasium was incapacitated. This suggests the ability targets a biological mechanism that is absent or altered in metahumans.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Her power has no effect on metahumans, making her ineffective in direct confrontations with powered opponents.
  • The mechanism of her selective targeting is not fully understood -- whether she consciously selects targets or the power inherently discriminates is unknown.
  • If her vertigo power is Fly-derived rather than natural, losing access to Fly would render her powerless.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Long-standing operational experience as a member of Pattinson's Pals, including street-level vigilante work and community organizing.
  • Capable of coordinating large-scale civilian patrols and public-facing community defense operations.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Egalitarian's personality is not extensively documented through direct characterization. Her actions suggest a figure comfortable with authoritarian enforcement methods -- she deployed her vertigo power against an entire gymnasium full of teenagers and civilians during the homecoming attack without apparent hesitation. Her co-organization of civilian defense patrols during the arson crisis, while ostensibly community-minded, carried undertones of surveillance-state ideology that concerned observers.

The central contradiction of her character is the gap between the Pals' anti-metahuman public platform and her secret Fly use. Whether this hypocrisy reflects cynical manipulation, addiction, or a more complicated relationship with power is not explored in the text.

docs.title: Relationships
docs.text: Character Relationship Notes Richard Johnson (Patriot) Co-Leader / Partner Long-standing partnership dating back at least to 2017 (Richard's father's funeral). Co-led Pattinson's Pals together. Patriot appeared not to know about Egalitarian's Fly use when confronted with evidence by Sam. Sean (Bulldozer) Teammate Fellow Pattinson's Pals member. Present alongside Natalie at Richard Johnson Sr.'s funeral in 2017. Parabellum Teammate Fellow Pattinson's Pals member. Co-organized civilian defense patrols during the Book 9 arson crisis. Sam Small (Bloodhound) Adversary Sam obtained evidence of Egalitarian's Fly use and wielded it as leverage against Patriot. Sam was unaffected by Egalitarian's vertigo at the homecoming dance. Devonte Harris (Ventriloquist) Adversary (indirect) Devonte provided the physical evidence (dried blood containing Fly traces) proving Egalitarian's drug use.

docs.title: Arc Appearances
docs.text: Book Role Key Events Book 7: Security Supporting Present at Patty's Bar when Sam and Jordan infiltrate it on September 13, confronting them in the parking lot alongside Patriot (Ch. 104). Derek discovers embarrassing and incriminating materials in Egalitarian's garbage during surveillance operations (Ch. 111). Storms the Tacony Charter homecoming dance with Patriot and a police tactical squad, deploying her vertigo power on the gymnasium crowd and incapacitating everyone without superpowers while Sam and Jordan remain standing (Ch. 112). Devonte and Akilah provide physical evidence (dried blood containing Fly traces) proving Egalitarian's drug use (Ch. 116). Sam uses the Fly evidence as leverage against Patriot and exposes it to DA Alvarez (Chs. 117-118). Appears at the Dilworth Park rally flanking Patriot (Ch. 117). Also appears in Interlude RJ.1 (Patriot's backstory) as "Natalie," present at Richard Johnson Sr.'s funeral in 2017 alongside Sean. Book 9: Sheol Minor Co-organizes civilian defense patrols with Parabellum in response to Aaron McKinley's arson campaign. Melissa Marshall invites Sam to the community defense walks organized by Egalitarian and Parabellum, during which concerning surveillance-state views are expressed (Ch. 141).

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Egalitarian's real name, Natalie, is revealed through the Interlude RJ.1 flashback to Patriot's father's funeral, where she and Sean (Bulldozer) are identified as Richard's teammates.
  • Her vertigo power's selective effect on non-powered individuals creates an interesting thematic irony: a member of an anti-metahuman vigilante group wields a power that is specifically harmless to metahumans.
  • The question of whether her vertigo power is natural or Fly-derived is flagged as an open thread in the plot thread tracker (Thread 18, Books 6-7): "If her primary combat power comes from Fly, exposure would render her powerless."
  • During the homecoming "Spartacus moment," teachers and students fought through Egalitarian's disorienting effect to form a human barrier protecting Sam and Jordan, demonstrating that her power can be partially resisted through sheer willpower.
  • The text notes some ambiguity about whether the crowd at homecoming noticed Sam and Jordan's immunity to Egalitarian's power, which would have revealed their superhuman status.
  • Her name "Egalitarian" is ironic given the Pals' discriminatory ideology and her secret drug use to maintain an advantage over the people she claims to protect.

docs.title: Elias Franklin
docs.text: Former PhD biochemistry student turned criminal metahuman, serving as scientific consultant for Rogue Wave after a brief tenure with the Philly Phreaks.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Elias Franklin Aliases Chimera Date of Birth Unknown Age 26 Gender Male Ethnicity Unknown Place of Birth Unknown Residence Camden, NJ (Rogue Wave safehouse) Affiliation Rogue Wave (Scientific Consultant) Former Affiliations Philly Phreaks; University of Pennsylvania (student) Occupation Scientific Consultant, Drug Formulation Researcher Status Active First Appearance Chapter 75 Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Elias Franklin was a PhD-level biochemistry student at the University of Pennsylvania whose academic career collapsed under the weight of compounding medical bills and student loans. A wheelchair user who required ongoing medical treatment, Elias was repeatedly denied insurance claims for basic needs, an experience that radicalized him against the healthcare system and the broader institutional structures governing metahuman abilities in America. Bankrupt and unable to continue his studies, he left UPenn and fell out of mainstream society.

Elias was approached after a physical therapy session by a bald white man with electrical powers — later identified as Sparkplug, a distributor for the criminal organization Rogue Wave — who promised to "fix" his disability. The man demonstrated superpowers to convince Elias and provided him with Fly, the semi-permanent power-granting injectable drug. Elias gained the ability to transform parts of his body into different animal components, a chimeric power set that earned him his villain name. He uses Fly for mobility enhancement and Jump for regeneration, allowing him to operate far beyond the physical limitations imposed by his disability.

Following his empowerment, Elias joined the Philly Phreaks, a group of disaffected young metahumans. His first major criminal act was an attack on the Independence Blue Cross building in Center City Philadelphia in late April 2024, motivated by revenge against the insurance company that had denied his claims. His former friend Derek Taylor, a werewolf vigilante, enlisted Sam Small to help stop him. After a violent confrontation on the seventh floor of the IBC building, Elias escaped by transforming into a deer and leaping through a seventh-story window. He subsequently participated in the Phreaks' courthouse attack during the Chernobyl trial, distributing tainted Jump to protesters and causing mass chaos. Three of the four Phreaks were apprehended, but Elias remained at large, prompting a multi-state manhunt.

Following the Phreaks' dissolution, Elias resurfaced as a recruit for Rogue Wave. He was formally interviewed by Monkey Business and Snake Oil at a Toyota dealership back office, where his PhD-level biochemistry background, experience with Fly, and former Phreaks membership distinguished him from other candidates. He was recruited by Snake Oil as his scientific assistant, providing expertise on Jump and Fly formulation improvements. By the summer of 2025, Elias was conducting field research during Rogue Wave's citywide Jump distribution events, testing different formulations and gathering scientific data from a makeshift research station in a South Philadelphia storage facility.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Chimeric Transformation — Can transform individual body parts into those of different animals simultaneously, creating a hybrid form. Documented animal components include bear arms and legs with claws, armadillo scutes on chest and back, an alligator tail, a fox muzzle replacing his face, yellow bulging eyes, snow leopard limbs, vulture wings, and deer form. Each transformation grants the physical attributes of the corresponding animal.
  • Full-Body Transformation — Capable of transforming his entire body into a single animal form, such as a complete deer. Can shift between forms rapidly, including mid-fall to survive otherwise lethal drops.
  • Fly-Enhanced Mobility — Uses Fly to overcome his wheelchair-bound condition, with animal transformations providing enhanced locomotion including flight (vulture wings), powerful leaping (deer and snow leopard forms), and raw strength (bear arms).
  • Jump-Based Regeneration — Regularly uses Jump to access temporary regenerative abilities, compensating for his baseline physical vulnerability.
  • Overwhelming Physical Strength — In transformed states, possesses strength sufficient to overpower multiple combatants simultaneously. During the IBC building confrontation, he overpowered both Sam Small and Derek Taylor in direct combat.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Elias is a wheelchair user in his baseline human form, requiring Fly to achieve mobility through animal transformations.
  • His powers are drug-dependent rather than innate; he requires ongoing access to both Fly (for his transformation abilities) and Jump (for regeneration), making him reliant on Rogue Wave's supply chain.
  • Fly users exhibit distinctive physiological markers including orange-tinged blood and a "fizzy" quality detectable by Sam Small's blood-sensing abilities, making him trackable.
  • The specific duration and sustainability of his transformations under combat conditions are not documented, though he was able to maintain chimeric form throughout extended confrontations.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• PhD-level biochemistry education from the University of Pennsylvania (incomplete but at an advanced stage), providing deep expertise in pharmacology and drug formulation.
  • Scientific methodology skills applied to field-testing Jump formulations, including data collection, documentation, and analysis of different drug variants.
  • Practical laboratory and research station management, as demonstrated by his makeshift facility in the South Philadelphia storage building.
  • Sufficient physical resourcefulness to complete Rogue Wave's recruitment scavenger hunt from a wheelchair, impressing Monkey Business who questioned how he managed the physical challenges.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Elias is intellectually brilliant but deeply embittered by his experiences with the American healthcare system and its treatment of disabled individuals. He combines academic precision with revolutionary zeal, articulating his criminal activities through a coherent philosophical framework. During his confrontation with Sam at the IBC building, he rejected the suggestion that Fly had altered his thinking, insisting he was "lucid" and "aware" — framing his violence as a rational response to systemic injustice rather than drug-induced mania. He believes that the Genesis Births should have been the greatest paradigm shift in human history, but instead produced a system he characterizes as oppressive enforcement of the status quo.

His ideology centers on the democratization of superpowers. He views Rogue Wave's distribution of Jump and Fly as a form of radical equality, rejecting the premise that abilities should be controlled by government agencies or determined by the genetic lottery of natural metahuman activation. This conviction drives his scientific work: he does not merely distribute drugs but actively works to refine them, seeking to create safer and more effective formulations. When confronted by Sam during the July 2025 Jump distribution event, he justified his actions by claiming Rogue Wave had promised him a lifetime supply of Fly for his condition in exchange for his expertise — pragmatism and ideology operating in tandem. Despite his willingness to threaten violence, he demonstrated reluctance to actually kill when Derek threatened suicide during their IBC confrontation, suggesting that his bitterness has not entirely displaced his capacity for connection.

docs.title: Relationships
docs.text: Character Relationship Notes Derek Taylor (Fenrir/Bloodhound II) Former friend Met before Elias's empowerment. Derek attempted to intervene during the IBC attack and later cut Elias with a knife to provide Sam with a blood sample for tracking. Derek is currently hunting Elias. The character reference guide notes a possible romantic dimension to their former relationship. Felix Ortega (Snake Oil) Employer / Mentor Recruited Elias as his scientific assistant. They work together on Jump and Fly formulation improvements. Snake Oil tended to Rush Order's injuries alongside Elias at the Camden safehouse. Lawrence Sullivan (Monkey Business) Organization leader Interviewed and approved Elias for Rogue Wave membership. Elias operates under his authority within the organization's structure. Sam Small (Bloodhound) Antagonist / Recurring opponent Confronted Elias at the IBC building, tracked him through South Philadelphia, and later contacted him via Derek's phone to negotiate with Rogue Wave leadership. Sparkplug Recruiter The bald man with electrical powers who first approached Elias after physical therapy and provided him with Fly, initiating his transformation into a metahuman. Deathgirl (Daisy Zhen) Former teammate Fellow Philly Phreak. Elias served as transport for Pumice during the LOVE Park incident. Pumice (Joseph Jones) Former teammate Fellow Philly Phreak. Pumice escaped the LOVE Park battle on Elias's back in his monstrous form. Rush Order (Dean Carver) Colleague Fellow Rogue Wave member. Elias helped tend to Rush Order's injuries after his fight with Sam and subsequent shooting by Ben Small.

docs.title: Arc Appearances
docs.text: Book Role Key Events Book 5: Mayfly Supporting First mentioned in Chapter 74 when Derek reveals his friend has taken Fly and plans criminal activity. Physically appears in Chapter 75 at the Independence Blue Cross building in Center City, where he has been destroying offices in revenge against the insurance company that denied his claims. Confronted by Sam and Derek on the seventh floor; demonstrates chimeric transformation with bear arms, armadillo scutes, alligator tail, fox muzzle, and bear legs. Overpowers both Sam and Derek in combat. Reveals that a bald man with electrical powers provided him with Fly after physical therapy. Escapes by transforming into a deer and leaping through a seventh-story window. His escape and the information he provides about Fly's source launch the broader investigation into Jump and Fly distribution, leading Sam's team to identify Sparkplug as the distributor. Book 6: Sideshow Supporting Reappears in Chapter 90 in his monstrous form at LOVE Park, serving as transport for Pumice during an encounter with a mutating Jump overdose victim. Sam recognizes him during the chaos. In Chapter 91, Sam briefs the Delaware Valley Defenders on Elias and his connection to the Phreaks, theorizing they are distributing tainted Jump. Participates in the Phreaks' courthouse attack during the Chernobyl trial (Chapter 97), where the group distributes tainted Jump to protesters outside the courthouse, causing violent mutations and mass panic. Three Phreaks are apprehended, but Elias escapes. The subsequent mayoral press release (Interstice EF.1) declares a state of emergency and announces a multi-state manhunt for Elias Franklin. Book 7: Security Mentioned Derek mentions Elias's continued disappearance during the farewell party at the Tacony Music Hall, establishing that Elias has successfully evaded capture since the courthouse attack. Book 8: Big N/A No documented appearances. Book 9: Sheol N/A No documented appearances. Book 10: Plume Mentioned Referenced in the context of the expanding three-way conflict between the Auditors, the Kingdom, and Rogue Wave. Elias's earlier activities are part of the backdrop as Rogue Wave emerges as a major threat. Book 11: Alarm Will Sound N/A No documented appearances. Book 12: Authorized Personnel Only Supporting Appears in the Rogue Wave recruitment interlude (Chapter 183 interlude), where Monkey Business and Snake Oil interview candidates for their scientific team at a Toyota dealership back office. Elias is the final candidate, arriving in a wheelchair and surprising Monkey Business. His PhD-level biochemistry background, Fly usage for mobility, and Philly Phreaks connection are discussed. The interview is interrupted at a cliffhanger. In Chapter 186, Derek reports that Elias visited his apartment appearing "better" and well-cared for, prompting Derek to cut him with a knife so Sam can track his blood. Sam tracks Elias through South Philadelphia during the Rogue Wave emergency alert chaos (Chapter 187), discovering his makeshift research station in a five-story storage facility. She confronts him; Elias reveals he is helping Rogue Wave test different Jump formulations, justifying his work through anarchist philosophy and his personal medical history. He transforms into a chimera combining snow leopard, vulture, and other animal features and escapes across rooftops. In the interlude following Chapter 189 (RS/DC/JF), Elias is seen at the Camden safehouse tending to Rush Order's injuries alongside Snake Oil after the fight with Sam and the "Gun Dad" shooting. Book 13: Burn After Reading Mentioned Referenced in the context of Sam's ongoing conflict with Rogue Wave and the Kingdom. His scientific work for Rogue Wave continues in the background. Book 14: Shelter in Place Supporting Referenced in Chapter 204, where Sam proposes contacting Rogue Wave through Derek's connection to Elias to secure protection from Shrike. Derek reluctantly provides his phone for Sam to contact Elias. In Chapter 205, Sam leaves a voicemail for Elias requesting contact with Rogue Wave leadership, which leads to the negotiation with Monkey Business, Birthday Suit, and Rush Order at the Tacony Music Hall parking lot. Appears in Interlude DC.2, assisting with medical procedures during Rogue Wave's operation to extract Mr. Polygraph's powers at Roxborough Memorial Hospital. Book 15: Severe Weather Warning Mentioned Referenced as a wheelchair-using Rogue Wave member. Derek continues operating as Bloodhound II, and the Vysera drug trial that suppresses his werewolf transformation is noted — a drug Elias is separately investigating, suspecting it derives from Snake Oil's research. Book 16: Category Five Hurricane Mentioned Currently investigating Vysera, the power suppressant drug that has appeared on the market. He suspects it is derived from Snake Oil's research, which is confirmed to be correct. His investigation is ongoing as of the beginning of Arc 16.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Elias is one of the few characters in the story whose villain name directly describes his power set — "Chimera" referring to the mythological creature composed of parts from multiple animals.
  • The mayoral press release following the courthouse attack (Interstice EF.1) is one of the few in-universe government documents to use a character's full legal name, identifying him as "Elias Franklin" rather than his alias.
  • His recruitment interview with Rogue Wave ends on a deliberate cliffhanger when he reveals his Philly Phreaks connection, a narrative device that delays the reader's understanding of how and why he transitioned between criminal organizations.
  • Elias's blood has a distinctive orange tint and "fizzy" quality common to Fly users, a detail that allows Sam to track him but also marks him as a drug user to anyone with similar sensory abilities.
  • His ability to complete Rogue Wave's physically demanding recruitment scavenger hunt from a wheelchair impressed Monkey Business, who questioned how he managed the challenges — a detail that underscores Elias's resourcefulness and the effectiveness of his Fly-enhanced transformations.
  • The character reference guide notes Derek Taylor's relationship with Elias as that of a "friend (and possible romantic interest)," suggesting a deeper personal dimension to Derek's ongoing pursuit.
  • Elias's current investigation into Vysera positions him as one of the few characters actively working to uncover the connection between the Kingdom's drug operations and Rogue Wave's research — an investigation whose outcome could significantly shift the balance of power between the two organizations.

docs.title: Elijah Brooks
docs.text: Senior member and effective leader of the Delaware Valley Defenders, a self-duplicating former professional boxer who serves as Sam Small's combat trainer and mentor.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Elijah Brooks Aliases Multiplex Date of Birth Unknown Age 30s Gender Male Ethnicity Unknown Place of Birth Unknown Residence Philadelphia, PA Affiliation Delaware Valley Defenders Former Affiliations Professional boxing (career ended by power manifestation) Occupation Superhero, Combat Trainer Status Active First Appearance Chapter 5 (mentioned); Chapter 15 (on-page) Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Elijah Brooks was a professional boxer and boxing coach before his metahuman powers manifested, an event that effectively ended his fighting career. The sudden ability to create independent duplicates of himself rendered competitive boxing impossible, forcing him to find a new purpose. He channeled his discipline and combat expertise into superhero work, joining the Delaware Valley Defenders where he served as second-in-command under Liberty Belle.

Following Liberty Belle's death at the hands of Chernobyl and the subsequent loss of Professor Franklin, Elijah became the effective operational leader of the Delaware Valley Defenders. His early years of heroism were marked by recklessness, including a traumatic mission in which three of his clones were killed, one of them tortured to death. This experience profoundly shaped his philosophy, driving him to prioritize systems, structure, and discipline over the charismatic, freeform approach favored by Belle.

In the summer of 2025, Elijah took on a new role as Sam Small's personal combat trainer after an unexpectedly candid conversation at DVD headquarters in which he shared his backstory and offered to spar with her. Over the following months, he trained Sam in boxing fundamentals, tactical thinking, creative power integration, and the importance of functioning while exhausted. His mentorship proved instrumental in Sam's development as a fighter and leader.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Self-Duplication — Can create up to twelve independent clones of himself. Each clone operates autonomously with its own decision-making capability and lasts up to twenty-four hours before expiring.
  • Memory Absorption — Upon a clone's expiration or voluntary recall, Elijah absorbs all knowledge and memories the clone accumulated during its existence. This effectively allows him to be in multiple places at once and gather intelligence from numerous sources simultaneously.
  • Consciousness Transfer ("Seat" Transfer) — If Elijah's primary body dies, his consciousness instantly transfers to his oldest active clone with full continuity of experience. He refers to his active consciousness as his "seat." This ability renders him extremely difficult to kill permanently as long as at least one clone exists.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Clone Cap — Limited to a maximum of twelve simultaneous clones.
  • Clone Duration — Each clone expires after twenty-four hours if not recalled.
  • Clone Vulnerability — Clones can be injured, tortured, and killed. The trauma and memories from these experiences transfer back to Elijah, causing psychological harm.
  • No Power Stacking — His clones do not appear to possess any enhanced physical abilities beyond those of a well-trained human; they share his baseline physical capabilities.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Former professional boxer and boxing coach with expert-level hand-to-hand combat skills. Vastly outmatches Sam Small in sparring, demonstrating superior technique, reach control, and ring craft.
  • Highly skilled tactical thinker who emphasizes disciplined, methodical approaches to crisis situations, including surveillance planning and coordinated team operations.
  • Described as one of the smartest non-supergenius humans alive.
  • Experienced in training and mentoring young metahumans, with a coaching style that emphasizes fundamentals, endurance, creative power application, and functioning under exhaustion.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Elijah is strict, demanding, and outwardly emotionless, particularly in professional settings. He speaks in clipped, efficient sentences and rarely wastes words, valuing discipline and structure above all else. He carries the weight of leadership with visible stress, and his by-the-book approach to heroism frequently puts him at philosophical odds with more impulsive or charismatic figures. He has clashed with colleagues over matters of protocol, recruitment, and how to handle young heroes' personal lives.

Beneath the rigid exterior, Elijah reveals a more human side when coaching. Boxing brings out his sense of humor, and he becomes noticeably less tense when teaching. He has demonstrated genuine concern for Sam's wellbeing, giving her his jacket after Liberty Belle's death and later offering her combat training with no strings attached. He is capable of surprising vulnerability, as shown when he shared the story of his clones' deaths with Sam. He harbors deep respect for Liberty Belle despite their philosophical disagreements, and he acknowledged that Sam reminds him of Belle, a comparison he appeared to find both amusing and meaningful.

docs.title: Relationships
docs.text: Character Relationship Notes Samantha Small (Bloodhound) Mentee / Trainee Trains Sam in boxing and tactical thinking throughout Summer 2025. Initially stern and distant, their relationship evolves into mutual respect. Gave Sam his jacket after Belle's death. Told Sam she reminds him of Belle. Liberty Belle (Diane Williams) Former leader (deceased) Served as her second-in-command. Disagreed with her freeform, charisma-driven leadership approach, preferring systems and structure. Despite their differences, respected her deeply. Bianca Agnelli (Fury Forge) Colleague Fellow DVD senior member. They clash over differing attitudes, with Bianca being more passionate and impulsive compared to Elijah's by-the-book tendencies. Kwame Adjei (Bulwark) Colleague Fellow DVD senior member. Kwame occupies a middle ground between Fury Forge's cowboy tendencies and Multiplex's inflexibility. Councilman Jamal Davis Colleague / Civilian liaison Works alongside Jamal on DVD operations. Jamal mediates between Elijah and other team members during disputes. Clara Parker Colleague DVD legal advisor. Shares Elijah's preference for working within established systems and expressed similar reservations about outside recruitment. Nurse Sylvia Colleague DVD medical staff. Sylvia has overridden Elijah's authority when medical concerns demand it, and she serves as a moderating voice between his strict training regimen and Sam's wellbeing. Captain Plasma (Rodney Greene) Colleague Fellow DVD member who departed for a New York assignment. Elijah arranged a sparring match between Plasma and Sam as a training exercise before Plasma's departure. Crossroads (Maxwell Martinez) Colleague (promoted) Former Young Defender promoted to the senior team. Works alongside Elijah on operations and training.

After the battle, acknowledges alongside Crossroads that Sam was right about the Kingdom's true heist target. Offers Sam combat training once she heals. Begins intensive daily training sessions with Sam (Ch. 169-170), identifying her three fundamental problems: poor dodging, overreliance on regeneration, and insufficient power integration. Pushes Sam to think creatively about her powers with the challenge "why only shark teeth?", leading her to develop the jaw-clenching absorption technique and the Instant Armor ability. His training mantra "powers fail, skills don't" becomes a foundational principle. Introduces the concept that all powers have costs beyond simple energy expenditure. Recommends bloodwork to identify what resources Sam's powers deplete. Present at DVD headquarters in Chapter 177 when Sam delivers the Stheno data flash drive and Hypeman sample; joins Fury Forge, Bulwark, and Councilman Davis in reprimanding Sam for reckless behavior, leading to a heated argument about tactics and Belle's legacy. Book 12: Authorized Personnel Only Supporting Continues training Sam in boxing and combat. Arranges a sparring match between Sam and Captain Plasma before Plasma's departure for New York, confirming Sam passed the test of adapting to impossible odds. Sam begins teaching Maggie and Tasha the techniques she learned from Multiplex. Referenced throughout the arc as Sam applies his training principles in combat situations, including against Rush Order. Resumes limited training with Sam after her injuries, reaching sixty percent capacity. Book 13: Burn After Reading Mentioned Referenced as part of the DVD senior team during the escalating Shrike crisis and the period surrounding the Daedalus prison break. Book 14: Shelter in Place Mentioned Referenced as already knowing about Councilman Davis's youth mentorship program proposal alongside city officials. Sam's father's shooting stance reminds Sam of Multiplex's boxing form. Book 15: Severe Weather Warning Supporting Part of the DVD team assisting in the search operation for Shrike, the escaped Daedalus inmate targeting Bloodhound.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• The canon document for Book 2 mistakenly labels Multiplex as a "Young Defender" in one instance, though he is consistently an adult member of the Delaware Valley Defenders throughout the story.
  • His consciousness transfer ability, which he calls his "seat," makes him one of the most difficult-to-kill heroes in the story, as he effectively has multiple lives running at all times.
  • His philosophical disagreement with Liberty Belle about mentoring methods is a recurring thematic thread. Belle favored inspiration and charisma; Elijah believes in systems and structure. Sam's development under both influences represents a synthesis of the two approaches.
  • His training mantra emphasizes functioning while exhausted, encapsulated in the phrase "powers fail, skills don't."
  • He is described as really liking boxing, and more of his personality emerges when coaching, where he develops a genuine sense of humor.
  • His offer to train Sam came with "no strings" attached, a notable gesture given his typically guarded and professional demeanor.

docs.title: Evan Thomas Williams
docs.text: Blue-collar metahuman enforcer for the Kingdom of Keys' Philadelphia branch, known as Mr. Mudslide, with the ability to liquefy solid surfaces through physical contact.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Evan Thomas Williams Aliases Mudslide, Mr. Mudslide, Mr. M, Bills, Evvie Date of Birth May 14, 1989 Age 34–36 Gender Male Ethnicity Unknown Place of Birth Camden, New Jersey Residence Philadelphia, PA (formerly Camden, NJ) Affiliation Kingdom of Keys (Philadelphia Branch) Former Affiliations None Occupation Kingdom operative; formerly construction worker, sanitation worker, factory worker, demolition specialist Status Active First Appearance Chapter 7 Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Evan Thomas Williams was born in Camden, New Jersey, the son of Elise Williams (nee Johnson), a school teacher, and Peter Williams, a former steelworker. He attended Camden High School but dropped out during his senior year in 2007 without obtaining a GED. Over the following decade, he cycled through a series of blue-collar jobs: construction worker at Dynamic Constructions (2007-2010), sanitation worker with the Camden City Sanitation Department (2010-2013), factory worker at Camden Metal Works (2013-2015), and demolition specialist at Urban Renewal Demolition Services (2015-2018). An undisclosed HR incident in 2018 forced him off the books, after which he worked under the table for Urban Renewal, took odd jobs around his neighborhood, and worked as a bouncer at local bars.

Evan's metahuman abilities manifested at an unknown point, and his first known use of them was during an attempted robbery of a Walgreens in August 2023. He was apprehended by Sam Small (Bloodhound) and Gale (Jamila Fayad) during their first patrol together, making him Sam's first arrest. He was subsequently incarcerated pending trial. While in custody, he was connected with Mr. Bomb, a Kingdom of Keys operative who operates as a lawyer, and was recruited into the organization. The Kingdom identified his liquefaction powers as ideal for heisting, infiltration, and enforcement work. Since his recruitment, Evan has undergone significant development from a petty criminal into a genuinely threatening supervillain, rising to fill the Mr. M position within the Kingdom's alphabetical hierarchy.

The Professional Asset Dossier compiled on Evan by Kingdom operatives Mr. E and Mr. C assessed him as a prime candidate for recruitment, noting that his socioeconomic background, sense of unfulfillment, and need for belonging made him highly receptive to the organization's overtures. The dossier recommended financial incentives coupled with a purposeful role as effective motivators. This assessment proved accurate: the Kingdom became the first group in Evan's life that genuinely believed in him and found him useful.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Surface Liquefaction — Evan can transmute any solid, contiguous, non-living surface he is touching into thick, wet sludge approximately the consistency of mud. This power is activated through physical contact, typically via his feet, though it can emanate from any point of contact on his body. Activation requires specific hand gestures, mental concentration, physical exertion, and contact with a surface contiguous with the target material. The ability functions through clothing such as shoes and gloves.
  • Terrain Manipulation — Uses liquefaction to burrow through walls, carve tunnels underground, trap opponents by sinking them into floors, and create escape routes through solid structures. Can form J-shaped tunnels to prevent flooding during underground infiltration.
  • Projectile Generation — Can liquefy solid objects such as bricks, then throw them; the material re-solidifies upon losing contact with his hands, creating extremely dangerous high-velocity projectiles.
  • Burial — Capable of completely submerging objects and people underground by liquefying the ground beneath them. Has demonstrated the ability to bury a person thirty feet underground.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Direct Contact Requirement — Must be in physical contact with the material he wishes to liquefy, limiting the range of his powers to his immediate environment. The contact must be with a surface contiguous with the desired target surface.
  • Exclusion of Living Matter — Powers do not extend to living organisms.
  • Exclusion of Pre-Liquefied Materials — Powers do not affect materials already in a liquid or semi-liquid state, such as mud, water, blood, or silt.
  • Ineffectiveness on Loose Surfaces — Powers are ineffective on particularly loose surfaces like sand or dusty dirt, suggesting a threshold of material cohesion is necessary.
  • Ejection Effect — Current observations indicate an involuntary ejection effect on individuals who are not completely submerged in the liquefied material, which may prevent burying someone alive unless full submersion is achieved quickly.
  • Conductive Material Vulnerability — During the Daedalus operation, an anti-phase/intangibility lattice security system severely electrocuted Evan through conductive titanium ore while he was tunneling, indicating that his liquefaction process does not insulate him from electrical conductivity in the material.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Extensive demolition expertise from years of professional work, including understanding of structural weak points and efficient deconstruction techniques.
  • Skilled urban explorer with experience navigating abandoned buildings and complex urban environments.
  • Proficient in mechanical engineering, particularly rapid assembly and disassembly of vehicles and industrial components. Maintains a motorcycle in his spare time.
  • Significantly above-average upper body strength for his weight class despite moderate obesity, developed through years of physically demanding labor.
  • Exceptional night vision, possibly a side effect of his activation, accompanied by mild light sensitivity to bright lights and direct sunlight.
  • Competent in physical altercations, with experience as a bar bouncer.
  • Participates in local demolition derbies, indicating physical agility and robustness.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Evan is quiet, contemplative, and introverted, preferring solitary activities like urban exploration and mechanical work. He is not socially anxious or lonely by nature but rather a genuine introvert with thrill-seeking tendencies. He relishes his power and can be a bully, enjoying the authority and capability his abilities grant him. He tends to talk when nervous but is silent and focused when in his element. He carries a pronounced inferiority complex rooted in his socioeconomic background and history of unstable employment, which manifests as an intense hatred of wealthy people. He has a history of mood swings and an addiction-prone personality, with frequent purchases of lottery tickets and cigarettes and visits to local casinos.

Evan harbors deep-seated resentment toward authority figures, likely stemming from negative experiences with law enforcement and the justice system. He is less boisterous and less prone to fits of anger than his frequent partner Mr. Tyrannosaur, having made efforts to get a grip on his temper over time. His signature uniform always includes a brown paper bag with holes cut out over his head, which serves both as an identity concealment and as a deliberate symbol of his blue-collar labor upbringing. He takes this symbolism seriously, even as his Kingdom colleagues mock it.

docs.title: Arc Appearances
docs.text: Book Role Key Events Book 1: Pup Supporting Robs a Walgreens and is apprehended by Sam and Gale during their first patrol (Ch. 7). Sam later testifies against him in court (Ch. 9). Subsequently recruited by the Kingdom of Keys; witnessed by Sam and Jordan murdering a captive at the Dobson Textile Factory as a loyalty test (Ch. 12). Fights Sam and Jordan in a brutal confrontation alongside Mr. Nothing and Mr. Polygraph; retreats when police sirens approach (Ch. 13). Book 2: Keys Mentioned Drone footage of the Dobson Factory murder is presented to the Delaware Valley Defenders (Ch. 15), identifying Mudslide as a Kingdom operative. Book 3: Dybbuk Supporting Referenced as a Kingdom enforcer. Confronts Sam's team during their escape from a Kingdom warehouse on Trenton Avenue on Halloween night (Ch. 41), forcing Spindle to stay behind as a diversion. Book 4: Exorcism Supporting Ambushes the Auditors alongside Mr. ESP in the abandoned Arch Street Subway tunnels beneath Philadelphia during their pursuit of Chernobyl (Ch. 59). Uses brick projectiles and liquefied concrete to trap the team. Abandons the fight to tend to the injured Mr. ESP when Chernobyl arrives and violently rejects the Kingdom's recruitment offer (Ch. 60). Book 7: Security Interlude (MR.1) Present at a Kingdom safehouse at 12th and Pine alongside Maya Richardson and Mr. Nothing. Participates in the debriefing about the Rogue Wave mind-control threat and the upcoming Chernobyl trial. Part of the strategic discussion about Kingdom positioning during the trial chaos and Maya's proposal to offer their services to the NSRA. Book 8: Big Supporting Confronts Sam at the Crescent nightclub during her undercover operation, shooting her in the arm as she escapes. Participates in Operation Ivory at the Philadelphia Zoo, trapping Sam in liquefied floor during the Reptile House confrontation. Arrested alongside Mr. Nothing at the conclusion of the battle. Book 9: Sheol Mentioned Sam notes his absence from the streets while he is incarcerated. Book 10: Plume Supporting Transferred from Philadelphia Industrial Correctional Center. The Kingdom launches a highway ambush on the Pennsylvania Turnpike to liberate him and Mr. Nothing, successfully freeing both operatives. In Interlude BM.2, the team retreats in a disguised plumbing van ("Ace Flow Solutions") to a Kingdom-owned steakhouse in Lancaster. During the van ride and subsequent meal, the team mocks Evan's paper bag mask, prompting him to explain its symbolic meaning -- it represents his blue-collar labor upbringing and working-class identity. The discussion reveals team dynamics and Kingdom infrastructure, including the steakhouse's role as a money laundering front. Evan remains notably quieter than his colleagues throughout the interactions (per Mr. Nothing, who is even more silent). Book 12: Authorized Personnel Only Mentioned Referenced during Kingdom operations planning. Book 13: Burn After Reading Main (Interlude) Narrates Interlude EW.1, the Daedalus Correctional Facility extraction of Deathgirl. Wears unusual combat gear instead of Kingdom's standard suits, signaling this operation differs from normal protocol. Leads a four-person extraction team (Mudslide, Vector, Tarbaby, Mrs. Synapse) while a separate B-Team creates diversions at the main facility. Creates a J-shaped tunnel beneath Daedalus to prevent flooding, but is severely electrocuted by an anti-phase/intangibility lattice security system through conductive titanium ore. After Mrs. Synapse treats his burns, the team breaches utility corridors behind Cell Block D and reaches Deathgirl's cell (D-7). Mrs. Synapse sedates the sleeping Deathgirl with an aerosol compound, and Evan insists on bringing her personal belongings (penguin plushie, books, photos) to keep her calm -- a display of practical empathy. Vector transports the sedated girl via telekinesis, but Deathgirl wakes prematurely because she is more well-fed than the team expected (they had anticipated malnourishment and neglect, but her cell showed signs of rehabilitation). She copies Vector's telekinesis, then Synapse's nerve manipulation, then Evan's liquefaction in rapid succession -- all without physical contact, revealing her power-copying is more advanced than intelligence suggested. The tunnel floor dissolves completely when she copies Evan's power, and she escapes into lower tunnels. Tarbaby reveals a tracking device was planted on Deathgirl as a pre-planned contingency that was deliberately not shared with Kingdom operatives. The team extracts via helicopter, with Red Calf treating Deathgirl's physical capture as secondary to removing her from government custody. Book 14: Shelter in Place Mentioned Referenced in Kingdom discussions and planning.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Evan was Sam Small's very first arrest as a superhero, making their rivalry personally significant for both characters.
  • His Kingdom designation is Mr. M, fitting into the organization's alphabetical naming convention.
  • The Professional Asset Dossier compiled on him was authored by Mr. E and Mr. C and includes an explosive tracker that detonates if the document is moved into unauthorized locations.
  • His dossier was prepared through the law office of Mrs. Ashley Thompson at Thompson & Sons, P.C., a Kingdom-affiliated firm.
  • During the Daedalus operation, Tarbaby provided him with an upgraded carbon-fiber version of his signature paper bag mask.
  • He has a minimal online footprint, limited to occasional posts on urban exploration forums under various pseudonyms.
  • His brief 2019 jail term was for involvement in a bar fight over an unpaid debt.
  • The character reference guide identifies him as one of Sam's narrative foils, though he has no idea what a narrative foil is.
  • During the Daedalus extraction, he insisted on bringing Deathgirl's personal belongings, including a penguin plushie, books, and photos, showing a degree of practical empathy unusual for a Kingdom enforcer.
  • The Daedalus operation revealed a significant tension between Kingdom and Red Calf operatives: Tarbaby's pre-planted tracking device on Deathgirl was a contingency deliberately withheld from the Kingdom team, suggesting Red Calf did not fully trust their partners.
  • Evan's narration of the Daedalus extraction reveals his competence under pressure -- despite being severely electrocuted by the security lattice, he continued tunneling and led the team to the target cell.
  • The operation was deliberately timed to coincide with Boston protests and state senate hearings, maximizing political distraction.
  • Deathgirl's cell at Daedalus contained personal items (books, photos, stuffed animals) suggesting she was receiving some degree of rehabilitation rather than pure imprisonment, which contradicted the extraction team's expectations of finding a malnourished, neglected prisoner.
