docs.title: Felix Fleischer
docs.text: German bioterrorist supervillain who engineers targeted pathogens against pharmaceutical industry figures, known for deliberate restraint and ideologically motivated attacks spanning two decades.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Felix Fleischer Aliases Dr. Necrosis Date of Birth Unknown Age Unknown (described as having gray-flecked stubble and the face of a "tired academic" as of August 2021) Gender Male Ethnicity German Place of Birth Germany Residence Detroit, Michigan (as of August 2021); also reported operating out of Chicago Affiliation None (operates independently) Former Affiliations N/A Occupation Bioterrorist; biomedical researcher; pathogen designer Status Active (went missing from Chicago circa late 2025/early 2026) First Appearance Chapter 3 (mentioned by name) Last Appearance Interlude FF.1 (POV interlude); Chapter 229 (mentioned)

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Felix Fleischer, known publicly as Dr. Necrosis, was a German-born supervillain who operated primarily in the United States for over two decades. He was classified as an Ideological Power Entity and was widely regarded as one of the most notorious supervillains in the world, described by TIME Magazine as "The World's Most Notorious Supervillain." His crusade targeted the pharmaceutical industry, specifically executives and corporate leadership responsible for practices he deemed responsible for mass suffering and death.

Fleischer's German accent was noted to have been worn smooth by years spent in the American Midwest. He maintained a basement laboratory in a building in Detroit that appeared abandoned from the outside, equipped with positive-pressure seals and scientific equipment. He also operated out of Chicago at various points, where news reports described his activities as "systematic dismantling of for-profit medical infrastructure." He employed encrypted communication channels, intermediaries, and extensive vetting procedures to maintain operational security.

In addition to his terror campaigns, Fleischer periodically created novel pathogens and sold them to pharmaceutical companies for research purposes, with the stipulation that all resulting research be open-sourced and any patents released to the public domain. He used the revenue from these transactions to fund his operations, a dynamic he described as the industry funding its own opposition.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Novel Pathogen Engineering — Fleischer possessed the superhuman ability to engineer novel pathogens with extraordinary precision. His power allowed him to create viruses and biological agents that traditional bioengineering could not replicate. He designed pathogens with specific incubation periods, symptom presentations, transmission limitations, and environmental vulnerabilities. His creations ranged from targeted lethal agents to non-lethal viruses engineered for maximum psychological impact with minimum physical harm.
  • Biological Precision Control — Fleischer demonstrated the ability to engineer pathogens targeting extremely specific biological systems. In the Meridian outbreak of 2019, he created a virus that caused superficial capillary fragility in only the periorbital region and thenar eminence (palms), producing "stigmata" symptoms. The virus was photosensitive, nonviable outside climate-controlled conditions, and self-terminated within six hours. This level of biological specificity — controlling exactly which capillaries in which anatomical locations would be affected — exceeded conventional bioengineering capabilities.
  • Organ-Dissolving Toxin Creation — Sam Small's early research described Dr. Necrosis as "infamous for his ghastly organ-dissolving toxins," indicating he also created highly destructive biological agents when his targets warranted lethal force.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Fleischer's pathogen engineering appeared to require extensive preparation time. He stated that he spent months, sometimes years, designing individual pathogens.
  • His pathogens required controlled conditions for deployment. The Meridian virus, for example, was fragile and photosensitive, necessitating specific environmental conditions for effective transmission.
  • He carried a consumer-grade taser for personal defense, suggesting his powers did not provide him with direct combat capabilities.
  • His operational security depended on physical infrastructure (laboratories, equipment) that could theoretically be located and raided.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Expert-level knowledge of virology, epidemiology, and immunology. Fleischer maintained active engagement with current scientific literature in these fields.
  • Demonstrated sophisticated understanding of cultural psychology, religious iconography, and media dynamics, which he applied to maximize the psychological impact of his attacks.
  • Skilled in operational security, employing encrypted communications, intermediaries, and elaborate vetting procedures.
  • Possessed sufficient scientific expertise that pharmaceutical companies paid for access to his research, recognizing his creations as beyond conventional bioengineering capabilities.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Fleischer presented as a methodical, intellectually rigorous individual who maintained a sharp distinction between his civilian identity and his Dr. Necrosis persona. In conversation, he was soft-spoken, precise, and deliberate, with a tendency toward small fussy gestures such as adjusting chair angles and aligning objects with table edges. He displayed genuine passion when discussing horror films, particularly the work of John Carpenter, and became notably more animated during these digressions than during discussions of his criminal activities. He described himself as someone who burned his eggs, played piano badly, and had opinions about horror films — a conscious effort to present his humanity alongside his monstrous acts.

His philosophy centered on the concept of "pressure" rather than "catastrophe." He framed his pathogen attacks as rhetorical arguments with premises, evidence, and conclusions, and drew a sharp distinction between himself and other criminal superhumans who used ideology as a costume for self-indulgent violence. He expressed contempt for those who "escalate past the point of usefulness" and whose work was "sloppy." He acknowledged the moral weight of his actions without apology, describing the Dr. Necrosis persona as a form of professional distance analogous to a surgeon's detachment. He stated his intention to eventually surrender to authorities when his work was finished, expressing acceptance of accountability while maintaining that his targets had faced none. Lawrence Sullivan (Monkey Business) assessed Fleischer as ideologically incompatible with profit-driven enterprises, noting that approaching him for collaboration would be futile because he wanted "complete elimination of profit motives in medical treatment."

docs.title: Relationships
docs.text: Character Relationship Notes Elena Martinez Interview subject TIME Magazine journalist who conducted the August 2021 interview. Fleischer expressed respect for her scientific understanding and described her questions as "better than most." Lawrence Sullivan (Monkey Business) Unaffiliated; ideologically opposed Sullivan discussed Fleischer as a potential collaborator at Snake Oil's suggestion but concluded that Fleischer's opposition to profit-based medicine made collaboration impossible, comparing the idea to "asking the Unabomber to consult on postal service efficiency." Dr. Felix Ortega (Snake Oil) Unaffiliated; admired by Ortega Snake Oil expressed scientific admiration for Fleischer's viral engineering capabilities and advocated for collaboration with him, envisioning retroviral vectors carrying Jump enhancement properties. Sullivan overruled the idea. Pink Mist Referenced as example Fleischer referenced figures like Pink Mist as examples of the type of "activist villains" he considered sloppy and self-indulgent, though he stated he did not know them personally. Shrike Referenced as example Similarly referenced alongside Pink Mist as an example of villains who copied the aesthetics of ideological violence without the substance.

docs.title: Arc Appearances
docs.text: Book Role Key Events Book 1 Mentioned Sam Small researched Dr. Necrosis during her investigation into Liberty Belle's injuries, noting his reputation for organ-dissolving toxins and a possible presence in the Philadelphia area years prior (Chapter 3). He remained on her suspect list due to his long operational history. Book 12: Authorized Personnel Only (Interlude LS.2) Mentioned Snake Oil suggested recruiting or collaborating with Dr. Necrosis during a Rogue Wave candidate review session, envisioning retroviral vectors carrying Jump enhancement properties. Monkey Business rejected the idea due to ideological incompatibility, comparing it to "asking the Unabomber to consult on postal service efficiency." Sullivan noted that Fleischer was operating out of Chicago at the time and assessed that Fleischer would view Rogue Wave's drug distribution enterprise as exactly the kind of profit-driven medical innovation he was trying to destroy. Intermission 15.5: This Side Up (Interlude FF.1) POV (Interlude) Subject of a TIME Magazine interview conducted by journalist Elena Martinez in an abandoned building's basement laboratory in Detroit on August 10, 2021. Fleischer, wearing a skull helmet with red LEDs that resembled exposed teeth when deactivated, discussed his philosophy of targeted bioterrorism as "pressure" rather than "catastrophe" -- framing pathogen attacks as rhetorical arguments with premises, evidence, and conclusions. Described the Meridian Therapeutics shareholder meeting "stigmata" outbreak of 2019, in which he engineered a virus causing superficial bleeding from palms and eye sockets -- photosensitive, nonviable outside climate-controlled conditions, and self-terminating within six hours. Explained his business model: selling novel pathogens to pharmaceutical companies with the stipulation that all resulting research be open-sourced and patents released to the public domain, using their payments to fund his campaigns against them. Drew a sharp distinction between himself and "sloppy" imitators like Shrike, describing them as people who "leak" their psychology into their work and escalate past the point of usefulness. Discussed his views on the "Second Wave of Supervillainy," his kill count of approximately a dozen people over two decades (all targeted), his personal life (piano, cooking, horror films -- particularly John Carpenter's Prince of Darkness), and his stated intention to eventually surrender to a superhuman containment facility when his work was complete. Book 16 Mentioned Maxwell informed Sam and Ben Small that federal superhuman resources were unavailable because onshore federal superhumans were dealing with Dr. Necrosis having gone missing from Chicago two weeks prior, describing the situation as one that "nobody likes" (Chapter 229).

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Fleischer's interlude code is "FF," with the TIME Magazine interview designated as Interlude FF.1.
  • His favorite film was John Carpenter's Prince of Darkness (1987), which he considered underrated. He deliberately chose it over The Thing as "the interesting choice."
  • He wore a helmet with a sculpted grin and red LEDs that, when deactivated, resembled exposed teeth. He removed the lower half during the interview to speak more easily.
  • His personal hobbies included practicing piano (badly), cooking simple meals, watching films, and keeping up with scientific literature.
  • He referenced the "Seven Hells" superhuman containment facilities by name, specifically mentioning Daedalus and "Tartarus" (no facility by that exact name exists among the Seven Hells; the closest is Tantalus Detention Center in Florida).
  • In Sam's early research (Chapter 3), Dr. Necrosis was listed alongside Cold Snap, Pyrausta, Chernobyl, and Blast Shadow as major villains in the region.
  • He described his approach to pathogen design as having "artistry" and compared it unfavorably to imitators who were "fucking without protection" — using their ideology without disciplined boundaries.
  • Elena Martinez noted he was "not the worst person" she had ever spoken to, describing him as "a man who has looked at the world, identified something genuinely wrong with it, and decided that the appropriate response is carefully calibrated terror."
  • His kill count was described as approximately a dozen confirmed deaths over two decades, all targeted.
  • He moved with the posture of a man who had been tall his entire life, slightly hunched and careful with ceilings.
  • When Rogue Wave discussed him in Interlude LS.2, Monkey Business assessed that Fleischer would view their drug distribution enterprise as exactly the kind of "entrepreneurial innovation" he was trying to destroy.

docs.title: Dr. Felix Ortega
docs.text: Rogue Wave's resident chemist and the creator of Jump and Fly, a disillusioned biochemist whose power to extract superpowers as crystals fuels Philadelphia's metahuman drug trade.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Dr. Felix Ortega Aliases Snake Oil Date of Birth Unknown Age 37 Gender Male Ethnicity Unknown Place of Birth Unknown Residence Philadelphia, PA (various safehouses) Affiliation Rogue Wave Former Affiliations Unknown (previously employed as a licensed pharmacist) Occupation Chemist, Drug Manufacturer, Scientist Status Active First Appearance Chapter 158 (NBC10 broadcast) Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Dr. Felix Ortega is a 37-year-old biochemist and pharmacist who was dismissed from professional service after repeatedly prescribing patients medications that had not been authorized by their doctors. Ortega operated on the assumption that he knew better than the treating physicians, and while he was usually correct in his assessments, he was not always right. This pattern of behavior ultimately cost him his license and his career in legitimate medicine.

Following his dismissal, Ortega's disillusionment with the medical establishment and regulatory frameworks drove him toward increasingly radical views about human biology and the nature of superpowers. At some point, he joined Lawrence Sullivan's criminal organization Rogue Wave, where his metahuman ability to extract superpowers in crystalline form and his genius-level understanding of biochemistry made him indispensable. He became the architect of Rogue Wave's core products: Jump, a green capsule powder granting temporary powers for approximately three hours, and Fly, an injectable colored liquid conferring semi-permanent abilities. Both substances are derived from crystals that Ortega extracts from powered individuals using his metahuman ability, which he then grinds and chemically adulterates into distributable drug forms.

Ortega views his work with Jump and Fly as merely the beginning of a much larger project. He regards powered individuals as the next stage of human evolution and considers his research an acceleration of natural selection. This philosophical framework, combined with his total disregard for ethical constraints, positions him as one of the most intellectually dangerous members of Rogue Wave's leadership, even if he rarely engages in direct combat.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Superpower Extraction — Ortega can extract superpowers from other metahumans in the form of crystals that grow painfully from the backs of his hands. The process requires physical contact with the target (typically placing his hand on their neck) and takes approximately 90 seconds to complete. The resulting crystal physically manifests the extracted power, leaving the target permanently depowered. The procedure is extremely painful for both Ortega and the subject.
  • Crystal Ingestion Transfer — The raw crystals produced by extraction can be ingested whole to grant the consumer the extracted power. This method is unpleasant, as the crystals are solid mineral formations that must be swallowed.
  • Crystal Processing (Jump/Fly Production) — The crystals can be ground up and chemically adulterated through Ortega's pharmaceutical expertise to produce Jump (temporary power capsules) and Fly (semi-permanent power injectables). A single extraction from Jackpot's probability assessment power yielded a larger-than-average crystal capable of producing 60 standard doses.
  • Anomalous Crystal Properties — Aurora Reyes (Pyrausta) revealed during her interview that the crystals Ortega produces have additional, previously unknown properties beyond ingestion and drug production. When burned, the crystals produce unusual effects on fire, the full implications of which remain unexplored.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• The extraction process is extremely painful for Ortega, with crystals growing out of the backs of his hands each time he uses his ability.
  • Extraction requires sustained physical contact with the target, making the process vulnerable to interruption.
  • Ortega's power is purely extractive; he does not gain the abilities he removes from others.
  • He has no known combat abilities and relies entirely on Rogue Wave's other operatives for protection during operations.
  • His powers fall under the Filch category (extracting properties from a system), not the Brain category — his scientific genius is entirely natural, not power-derived.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Holds a doctoral-level education in biochemistry and pharmacology.
  • Possesses genius-level expertise in pharmaceutical compounding, drug formulation, and biochemical research, all achieved through natural intellect rather than Brain-type metahuman enhancement.
  • Capable of providing field medical treatment, as demonstrated when tending to Rush Order's gunshot wound and facial lacerations at a Camden safehouse.
  • Knowledgeable about viral vector research and advanced drug delivery mechanisms, having discussed potential collaboration with Dr. Necrosis on creating viral vectors for Jump enhancement.
  • Skilled at evaluating scientific talent, as shown during the LS.2 interlude where he assessed seventeen candidates for the role of his laboratory assistant.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Ortega embodies the mad scientist archetype in its purest form. He is obsessive, amoral, and singularly focused on advancing his research, dismissing ethical concerns as intellectual weakness. He speaks in a distinctive blend of clinical terminology and grandiose pronouncements about human evolution, reflecting a worldview in which scientific progress justifies any methodology. He is autistic, and his blunt, unsentimental communication style reflects both his neurodivergence and his fundamental disinterest in social convention.

Ortega hates everyone equally and is grumpy virtually all of the time. He does not play favorites among his Rogue Wave colleagues, though he demonstrates a capacity for dry concern, as when he expressed hope that Rush Order would not get shot again. His management style is demanding enough that at least one qualified candidate (Jennifer Torres) was rejected during the assistant recruitment process specifically because she would struggle to work under him. Despite his misanthropy, Ortega recognizes competence when he encounters it — he was genuinely impressed by Aurora Reyes's self-taught chemical knowledge and her discovery of previously unknown properties of his crystals, even though she lacked formal education.

Elias provides expertise on Jump and Fly formulation improvements and assists with medical procedures at safehouses. In Interlude LS.2, Snake Oil and Monkey Business conduct a full day of interviews at a Toyota dealership to recruit a scientific assistant. He also suggests potential collaboration with Dr. Necrosis on viral vector Jump delivery, which Sullivan rejects. The final candidate, Elias Franklin (Chimera), is ultimately recruited. Snake Oil performs the power extraction at a secondary location in Camden, placing his hand on Mr. Polygraph's neck after administering local anesthetic. Over 90 seconds, Mr. Polygraph's lie detection power materializes as a blue-green crystal growing from Snake Oil's hand. The extraction leaves Mr. Polygraph permanently depowered. The crystal is designated for processing into Fly. This operation was enabled by Sam's tip to Rogue Wave about the Kingdom's evidence disposal location. Book 15: Severe Weather Warning Mentioned The consequences of Snake Oil's extraction of Mr. Polygraph's power continue to reverberate. Monkey Business has acquired Mr. Polygraph's lie-telling ability through ingestion of the crystal. The Kingdom's interest in power extraction technology is noted as an unexplored thread. Vysera (daxerimab), a power suppressant drug that enters NSRA experimental trials, is suspected by Elias Franklin to be derived from Snake Oil's research — and it is. Book 16: Category Five Hurricane Supporting Snake Oil is among the Rogue Wave leadership working to hold the organization together while Mr. Antithesis rampages offscreen. Elias continues investigating Vysera's connection to Snake Oil's extraction research.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Snake Oil's alias is a reference to the historical term "snake oil salesman," denoting a fraudulent peddler of miracle cures — an ironic name given that his products genuinely grant superpowers, albeit through criminal means.
  • He was introduced to readers visually during the NBC10 broadcast in Chapter 158, where he appeared alongside the five other core Rogue Wave members as the team declared war on the Kingdom of Keys.
  • The extraction process produces crystals of varying sizes depending on the power being extracted. Jackpot's probability assessment power produced a "larger-than-average" crystal.
  • His research has had unintended downstream consequences: the NSRA's experimental drug Vysera (daxerimab), a power suppressant used in Derek Taylor's werewolf trials, is derived from Snake Oil's extraction research without his knowledge or consent.
  • Despite being called "Dr. Snake Oil" during the NBC10 broadcast, it is unclear whether Ortega holds a formal doctorate or whether the title is self-applied based on his expertise.
  • He is one of the few Rogue Wave members whose real name has been established in the character reference materials, though it has not been revealed in-story.
  • Jennifer Torres was rejected as an assistant candidate specifically because evaluators determined she could not handle Snake Oil's management style, suggesting he is a notoriously difficult person to work under.
  • Snake Oil's power falls under the Filch classification in the PERKS system (extracting properties and removing them from a system), making him one of the rarer power types in the setting, where Filch abilities account for approximately 12% of all powers.

docs.title: Gerald "Jerry" Caldwell
docs.text: Defense attorney specializing in metahuman cases who first represents Illya Fedorov (Chernobyl) through his trial and later becomes Sam Small's legal counsel during her fugitive arc, serving as a narrative bridge between the two cases.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Gerald "Jerry" Caldwell Aliases Jerry Date of Birth Unknown Age Upper-middle-aged Gender Male Ethnicity Black Place of Birth Unknown Residence Philadelphia, PA (presumed) Affiliation Independent (defense attorney) Former Affiliations N/A Occupation Defense Attorney (specializing in metahuman/superhuman cases) Status Active First Appearance Interlude IF.2 (Intermission 4.5: Amnion) Last Appearance Chapter 234 (possibly; see Trivia)

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Gerald "Jerry" Caldwell is a defense attorney who specializes in metahuman legal cases. He first appears representing Illya Fedorov (Chernobyl) after Fedorov's voluntary surrender following the Chernobyl Incident in Philadelphia. Caldwell agreed to take the case and immediately established trust with his client by forgoing protective gear during their first meeting in Illya's containment cell -- a deliberate gesture that moved Illya to tears when contrasted with his paralegal Riya Kapoor, who wore full hazmat equipment.

Caldwell built a necessity defense for Fedorov, arguing that Illya's actions during the Chernobyl Incident were taken "to avoid greater harm." He represented Fedorov through his arraignment (Interlude IF.3), his trial in Book 6 where he cross-examined Sam Small and introduced Liberty Belle's handwritten note as evidence, and through the sentencing and courthouse attack in Book 7. His courtroom style is described as smooth and sharp -- he presents as an affable, warm presence but conceals a razor-sharp legal intellect beneath the surface.

In Book 15, Rachel and Benjamin Small hired Caldwell to represent their daughter Sam during her fugitive arc, after Sam was framed by four "Alice" impersonation incidents and fled arrest. Caldwell secured Sam's release with an ankle monitor, navigated her hearing to a plea of disorderly conduct with time served, and had the monitor removed on February 3, 2026. Sam noted the significance of having Chernobyl's former lawyer: "He'll know me. Good" -- suggesting the prior interaction during the trial created a foundation of trust.

docs.title: Powers & Abilities
docs.text: Gerald Caldwell has no metahuman abilities. His expertise is entirely legal and interpersonal.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Specialist in metahuman and superhuman legal defense, handling cases involving powered individuals, government agencies (NSRA), and the complex intersection of superhuman activity and criminal law.
  • Sharp cross-examiner capable of dismantling prosecution witnesses while maintaining affable composure. Bianca Agnelli (Fury Forge) described him as "a legal buzzsaw."
  • Skilled at building rapport and trust with unusual clients, demonstrated by his gesture of forgoing protective gear with Chernobyl and his warm, immediate connection with Sam.
  • Knowledgeable about federal de-gunning initiatives, post-Genesis gun restrictions, premises liability, and metahuman contractor regulations.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Caldwell presents as warm, genuine, and disarmingly approachable. Sam describes him as having "Santa Claus energy -- fat and jolly in a way that immediately makes you trust him," and his initial impression reads as "overgrown fratboy" rather than "soulless legal shark." His handshake is firm and warm, his voice carries "resolute compassion," and he compliments his clients' families with unforced sincerity.

This warmth is genuine but coexists with formidable professional capability. In the courtroom, he transforms: his gaze sharpens, his questioning becomes relentless, and Sam describes him as having the "coiled energy of a predator ready to strike." His cross-examination technique involves planting seeds in the jury's mind through questions he knows will be sustained on objection -- he does not need the answer, just the implication. Clara (DVD leadership) expressed concern about his "tendency to prioritize metahuman affairs over guilt or innocence," while Bianca internally dismissed his clients as "a mewling cadre of supervillain-sympathizers."

He stays for dinner at the Small house, discusses monitoring rules with patience, and tells Sam's parents: "You really raised a stupendous young girl here." He insists Sam call him "Jerry" rather than "Mr. Caldwell."

Sam learns of his involvement through her parents' voicemail relayed by Lily: "We've hired Jerry Caldwell, he's handled superhuman cases before." Sam notes: "That was Chernobyl's lawyer. So he'll know me. Good" (Ch. 225). Caldwell communicates through Lily's family relay that "the case is weak" and "tracker data is holding up as alibi evidence" (Ch. 226). docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Caldwell has no entry in the character reference guide despite being one of the more developed recurring secondary characters in the story.
  • His physical description is vivid: big, Black, upper-middle-aged, wearing suits that are "professional but slightly rumpled." Sam says he has "Santa Claus energy -- fat and jolly."
  • His paralegal Riya Kapoor is described as petite with auburn hair cropped short. She wore full hazmat gear to Illya's containment cell while Caldwell deliberately went without protection.
  • The plot thread tracker explicitly calls his representation of both Chernobyl and Sam the "Legal Bridge" thread (R35/Thread 45), noting that "Caldwell representing both Chernobyl and Sam creates interesting continuity. He has insight into government corruption from Chernobyl's case."
  • He explained federal de-gunning initiatives to the Small family -- post-Genesis gun restrictions designed to prevent powers-versus-firearms escalation -- adding worldbuilding context through natural conversation.
  • A character named "Gerald (Insurance)" gives Sam a premises liability briefing at the Tacony Community Center grand opening in Book 16 (Ch. 234). Whether this is Gerald Caldwell in a new capacity handling the center's legal and insurance needs, or a separate character, is unclear from the text.
  • Sam's courtroom description of Caldwell evolves across their interactions: during the deposition he seems like an "overgrown fratboy," but at trial she recognizes "the brilliance that lurks behind those easy smiles and casual quips" and describes him as having "razor-sharp intellect lurking just beneath the surface."
  • He is unrelated to Emily Caldwell (Mr. Antithesis's mother) or Liam Caldwell (Mr. Antithesis's birth name), despite the shared surname.

docs.title: Illya Myronovych Fedorov
docs.text: Ukrainian nuclear engineer turned reluctant supervillain whose uncontrollable radiation powers led to tragedy, ultimately surrendering to authorities after a moral appeal from Sam Small.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Illya Myronovych Fedorov Aliases Chernobyl (government-assigned codename, which he hates) Date of Birth Unknown Age Unknown (adult) Gender Male Ethnicity Ukrainian Place of Birth Ukraine Residence Aurora Springs Residential Facility (current); formerly Philadelphia abandoned subway tunnels Affiliation None Former Affiliations NSRA (coerced arrangement); independent Occupation Former nuclear engineer Status Incarcerated First Appearance Chapter 1 (mentioned); Chapter 37 (named/detailed); Chapter 44 (first physical appearance) Last Appearance Interlude IF.5 (Aurora Springs arrival)

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Illya Myronovych Fedorov is a Ukrainian national and former nuclear engineer whose body emits lethal ionizing radiation. The circumstances of how he acquired this condition are not fully detailed, but his technical expertise as an engineer informs his understanding of his own powers and the containment measures required to manage them. Unable to safely exist among other people without shielding, Illya constructed improvised mechanical armor to contain his radiation output, though the suit leaked and could never fully suppress his emissions.

Before the events of the main story, Illya killed Professor Franklin, Liberty Belle's mentor and predecessor among the Delaware Valley Defenders, approximately eight years prior to the story's start (around 2015). He also severely injured Liberty Belle herself roughly two years before the main narrative begins. Despite these acts, the National Superhuman Response Agency entered into a covert arrangement with Illya, using his radiation to power electrical substations in exchange for his freedom. This arrangement meant the government was effectively enabling his continued existence outside containment while publicly treating him as a fugitive.

Illya's primary motivation throughout the story was survival and his desire to reunite with his wife and daughter, Yulia, who remained in Ukraine. He wore his mechanical suit not as a weapon but as a means of containing the danger his body posed to everyone around him. When Liberty Belle lured him to the abandoned PES refinery for a final confrontation on the first night of Hanukkah 2023, their battle ended with Illya fatally wounding her. Months later, Sam Small tracked Illya to the abandoned subway tunnels beneath Philadelphia and confronted him alone. Rather than killing him, Sam dismantled his suit and appealed to his humanity, embracing him and asking him to pretend she was Yulia. This encounter profoundly affected Illya. On February 23, 2024, he surrendered to authorities on the steps of the Philadelphia Federal Building, citing "a conversation with a young girl" as his reason.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file. Illya is classified informally by the superhero community and NSRA as an extremely dangerous radiation emitter, but no formal PERKS document for him has been presented in the story.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Ionizing Radiation Emission — Illya's body continuously emits ionizing radiation at lethal levels. Without his containment suit, direct exposure causes severe radiation poisoning, internal microwave burns, and potentially fatal injury within minutes. Sam Small sustained over 10 Grays of radiation exposure during their confrontation, a dose that would be lethal to ordinary humans.
  • Mechanized Containment Suit — Illya constructed and operated a seven-to-eight-foot-tall hazard-colored mechanical suit designed to contain his radiation. The suit featured pile-driver weapons capable of firing metal spikes, steam vents that released scalding vapor, reinforced armor plating, and hydraulic-powered limbs. The suit hissed and groaned with each movement and had an observable "input lag" between Illya's physical actions and the suit's mechanical response.
  • Technical Knowledge — As a nuclear engineer, Illya possesses deep expertise in radiation containment, including knowledge of proper shielding materials such as lead, boron, silicon-based sealants, aluminum foil layers, and concrete. After his surrender, he provided detailed technical advice to the hazmat-suited workers preparing his containment cell, including specifying the proper sealant type and layering order. He also designed and provided schematics for his own specialized containment cell, which the court acknowledged during his arraignment.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Uncontrollable Radiation — Illya cannot turn off or modulate his radiation output. His body is a constant danger to everyone in his proximity, making normal human contact impossible without heavy shielding.
  • Suit Dependency — Without his mechanical suit, Illya is exposed and his radiation harms everyone nearby, including himself emotionally, as he cannot interact with other people. The suit was improvised and prone to leaking radiation, and once sufficiently damaged it could not contain his emissions.
  • Isolation — His condition renders him incapable of physical human contact. He cannot touch, embrace, or be near his own family without endangering their lives.
  • Mechanical Lag — The suit's hydraulic systems exhibited a delay between his intentions and the suit's movements, an exploitable weakness that Sam used during their fight.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Trained nuclear engineer with expertise in radiation physics, containment design, and materials science.
  • Literate and philosophical, drawing on literary references including Harlan Ellison and religious texts in conversation.
  • Knowledgeable in Hebrew prayer, suggesting cultural or religious familiarity beyond his Ukrainian background.
  • Capable mechanical engineer who designed and maintained his own containment suit.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Illya is an introspective, articulate, and deeply sorrowful individual. He speaks with a Ukrainian accent and engages in philosophical debate even during combat, invoking historical and literary references to frame his actions. During his confrontation with Liberty Belle, he quoted from Harlan Ellison and referenced the concept of the Dybbuk, a possessing spirit from Jewish folklore, accusing Belle of being haunted by Professor Franklin's ghost. He challenged Sam's understanding of justice by citing examples of self-defense and survival, comparing himself to the Maccabees and Moses.

Beneath his capacity for violence lies a man defined by grief and desperation. Illya's overriding concern was always his family -- his wife and daughter Yulia -- whom he could never safely be near. During his containment following surrender, he contemplated the racial dynamics of his treatment, noting that officers showed him "guarded empathy" rather than hostility -- a reflection he acknowledged might differ had he not been white. He wept when his attorney confirmed Sam had survived their encounter, and he silently recited a Hebrew prayer for his daughter and for Sam during the Philly Phreaks' attack on the courthouse. He kept a collection of jelly beans in his containment cell, including popcorn flavor, as a small comfort. He maintained meticulous mental counts of his cell's dimensions and materials, watching the space gradually shrink as 18 inches of concrete blocks were added to each wall. He observed the marble courtroom during his arraignment with analytical detachment while spectators wore lead smocks for protection, and maintained his composure even as the court reacted with murmurs to his not-guilty plea. His surrender was not motivated by defeat but by Sam's compassion reaching something inside him that years of conflict had not. He is not a villain in any conventional sense; he is a man trapped in a terrible situation who caused terrible harm while trying to survive and return to the people he loved.

docs.title: Relationships
docs.text: Character Relationship Notes Sam Small (Bloodhound) Adversary / Catalyst for surrender Sam confronted Illya twice: once witnessing his battle with Liberty Belle, and once fighting him alone in the subway tunnels. Rather than killing him, Sam appealed to his humanity. Sam refers to him as "Illya" rather than "Chernobyl." Her compassion directly led to his surrender. Diane Williams (Liberty Belle) Adversary (deceased) Illya severely injured Belle two years before the main story and fatally wounded her at the PES refinery. Their relationship was complex; he tried to dissuade her from fighting and acknowledged their shared history. Professor Franklin Victim (deceased) Illya killed Franklin approximately eight years before the main story (around 2015), an act that defined his reputation as a dangerous villain. Yulia Fedorov Daughter Illya's primary emotional anchor. His desire to see Yulia drove many of his actions. Sam's request to "pretend I'm Yulia" during their final confrontation broke through his defenses. Olena Fedorov Wife Lives in Kyiv, Ukraine. Illya requested visitation with her upon surrendering. Visits him at Aurora Springs through lead glass alongside Yulia. His separation from his family is central to his tragedy. Gerald "Jerry" Caldwell Defense attorney Caldwell agreed to represent Illya and showed genuine trust by forgoing protective gear during their first meeting, while his paralegal Riya Kapoor wore full protective equipment. He discussed attorney-client privilege-protected strategy focused on showing "context" and Illya's "humanity," arguing actions were taken "to avoid greater harm." Illya initially questioned whether Caldwell's representation was a government trick but was moved to tears by the offer of genuine help. Caldwell also confirmed Sam was "alive and recovering well" and suggested avoiding calling her as a witness. Agent Evelyn Shaw NSRA handler Shaw appeared via camera link to question Illya following his surrender, demanding explanation for his unexpected change of heart. She expressed skepticism when Illya vaguely referenced "a conversation with a young girl." Her later testimony at trial revealed the NSRA's covert arrangement with him. Anne-Marie Gibson Prosecutor Led the prosecution against Illya, building a case on his past crimes including the deaths of Professor Franklin and Liberty Belle. Riya Kapoor Legal staff Caldwell's paralegal who accompanied him to the containment cell wearing full protective gear. Assisted in assuring Illya of the defense team's genuine commitment to his case. Judge Harold Bennett Presiding judge Presided over Illya's arraignment at Philadelphia Federal Courthouse. Set precise pre-trial timeline with motions deadline April 1, discovery May 15, status hearing June 5, pre-trial conference July 20, and trial commencement August 15, 2024. Reaffirmed Illya's rights to fair trial, representation, and silence. Maxwell Martinez (Crossroads) Brief ally During the Philly Phreaks' courthouse attack, Crossroads warned Illya not to intervene because Deathgirl could copy his powers. Crossroads showed Illya a gesture of trust by flipping a coin. NSRA Former coerced partner The NSRA maintained a secret arrangement exploiting Illya's radiation to power substations, effectively enabling his freedom while using him as an asset. This arrangement was exposed during his trial.

docs.title: Arc Appearances
docs.text: Book Role Key Events Book 1: Pup Mentioned Listed among villains Sam researches while investigating Liberty Belle's injuries. Identified as a mysterious radiation villain. Book 3: Dybbuk Main Liberty Belle reveals Illya's identity and history to the Young Defenders at an emergency briefing, disclosing that he killed Professor Franklin and nearly killed her. The Kingdom of Keys is discovered to be following behind Illya's movements to steal materials. On the first night of Hanukkah, Illya arrives in Philadelphia, triggering city-wide evacuation. At the abandoned PES refinery, he confronts Liberty Belle, revealing his government arrangement and accusing her of being possessed by Franklin's ghost. Despite attempting to dissuade Belle from fighting, their battle ends with Illya fatally wounding her with a pile-driver spike. He tells Sam to tend to Belle and warns her not to follow him. Book 4: Exorcism Main Sam inherits Liberty Belle's detective files, including a notebook on Illya revealing his background as a Ukrainian nuclear engineer with government protection. The Auditors discover the NSRA's covert arrangement with Illya. Agent Torres reveals Illya has been hiding in Philadelphia's abandoned subway tunnels near the old Arch Street Subway station. Sam confronts Illya alone underground, engaging him in both physical combat and philosophical debate about justice, survival, and responsibility. Sam dismantles his suit, forces him out of it, and embraces him rather than killing him, asking him to pretend she is Yulia. Illya briefly returns the embrace before retreating into his damaged suit. Sam suffers near-fatal radiation exposure. On February 23, 2024, Illya surrenders at the Philadelphia Federal Building, requesting incarceration at Aurora Springs and visitation with his family. Intermission 4.5: Amnion Supporting (Interludes) Interlude IF.1 covers a Philadelphia Inquirer article about Illya's surprise surrender on February 23, 2024, noting he requested incarceration at Aurora Springs and visitation with his family; the NSRA publicly claims credit for the outcome. Interlude IF.2 (late February/early March 2024) provides his perspective in containment: he observes hazmat-suited workers preparing his cell and offers technical advice about materials (silicon-based sealant, lead layers, boron, aluminum foil), while the cell gradually shrinks as 18 inches of concrete blocks are added to each wall. Agent Shaw questions him via camera link; he vaguely references "a conversation with a young girl" and reveals his primary motivation as concern for his wife and daughter. He contemplates the racial dynamics of his treatment and maintains meticulous counts of his cell dimensions. Caldwell arrives with paralegal Riya Kapoor, foregoes protective gear to show trust, and discusses strategy under attorney-client privilege. Illya acknowledges responsibility for "incidents" including Professor Franklin and Liberty Belle. He weeps when Caldwell confirms Sam is "alive and recovering well." Sam watches news coverage of Illya's case from her hospital bed (Ch. 64), feeling an unnamed emotion about her unacknowledged role in his surrender. Book 5: Mayfly Supporting (Interlude) In Interlude IF.3 (spring 2024), Illya appears in federal court for arraignment. Spectators wear lead smocks for radiation protection. Judge Bennett lists formal charges: two counts second-degree murder for Professor Franklin and Liberty Belle, four counts theft, three counts property damage exceeding $500,000, illegal generation/release of hazardous materials, and seven counts unlicensed use of superhuman abilities. Illya voluntarily waives bail citing public safety, pleads not guilty based on necessity rather than denial, and provides containment cell schematics. The court erupts in murmurs at his plea, requiring gavel intervention. Judge Bennett sets the precise legal timeline through trial commencement August 15, 2024. A bailiff escorts Illya with unexpected empathy. Book 6: Sideshow Main Sam prepares testimony for Illya's trial with prosecutor Mrs. Anne-Marie Gibson, uncovering further evidence of the NSRA's past collaboration with him. Sam testifies on Day 4 of the trial, presenting video evidence of Liberty Belle's death. Defense attorney Caldwell cross-examines Sam and introduces a handwritten note allegedly from Belle inviting Illya to the refinery. Over nine days, the trial reveals Illya's self-defense claims, expert testimony on his radiation dangers, and the shocking NSRA arrangement exposed through Agent Shaw's testimony. During the Philly Phreaks' attack on the courthouse, an interstice from Illya's POV shows him wanting to help but being warned by Crossroads that Deathgirl could copy his powers. Illya prays for Sam's safety and his daughter's protection. He is found guilty of manslaughter and other charges. Book 7: Security Supporting Illya's sentencing is covered in Chapter 107. He receives 50 years in prison to be served at Aurora Springs Residential Facility (not Daedalus). The sentence proves controversial: manslaughter rather than murder suggests self-defense, Aurora Springs is perceived as lenient, and the NSRA's involvement complicates public perception. Patriot incites protests in response. Sam watches the sentencing with her family and Maggie. In Interlude IF.5, Illya arrives at Aurora Springs and settles into his new life. He reflects on his guilt and his family: his wife Olena and daughter Yulia, both living in Kyiv. He establishes a routine of exercise, engineering work (designing portable radiation shielding), and radiation purges. Dr. Chen serves as his chief medical officer and Ms. Patel as his case worker. He has a video call with his family and later a physical visit through lead glass. He finds renewed purpose in his engineering work and family reconnection. He recalls his grandmother's Yiddish saying: "Man plans, God laughs." Book 10: Plume Mentioned Illya's former attorney Gerald Caldwell is later hired by Sam's parents for her own legal defense, connecting the two cases. Book 15: Severe Weather Warning Mentioned Gerald Caldwell, identified as Illya's former lawyer, secures Sam's release with an ankle monitor during her fugitive arc.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Sam Small consistently refers to him as "Illya" rather than "Chernobyl." The codename "Chernobyl" was assigned to him by the government, and he hates it.
  • The character reference guide explicitly describes him as "not a bad guy, just a guy who was in a bad situation" and "extremely sympathetic."
  • Illya's blood appears "white" rather than red when sensed through Sam's blood-sensing abilities, likely due to the radiation altering his physiology.
  • He quoted from Harlan Ellison's "I Have No Mouth, and I Must Scream" during his confrontation with Liberty Belle, drawing parallels between his existence in the mechanical suit and being a sentient being trapped without agency.
  • He keeps a collection of jelly beans in his containment cell, with popcorn flavor mentioned specifically.
  • Illya recites Hebrew prayers despite being Ukrainian, suggesting interfaith or cross-cultural familiarity.
  • His mechanical suit was described as seven to eight feet tall and colored in hazard markings (yellow and black).
  • The PES refinery where he fought Liberty Belle was also the location where he killed Professor Franklin years earlier.
  • There are reference images for the character: "illya federov.png" (his appearance) and "chernobyl.png" / "chernobylmech.png" / "chernobylmech 2.png" (his mechanical suit).
  • During his trial, he voluntarily waived bail and provided schematics for his own containment cell, demonstrating cooperation and concern for public safety.
  • His containment cell was progressively shrunk by 18 inches on each wall through concrete block additions, a process Illya observed with engineering detachment while offering technical corrections to the workers.
  • The courtroom spectators at his arraignment wore lead smocks for radiation protection, underscoring the unique danger he posed even in legal proceedings.
  • Illya's not-guilty plea was based on necessity rather than denial of his actions; he internally acknowledged what he had done but maintained the legal position that his actions were taken to avoid greater harm.
  • His defense attorney Caldwell's decision to forgo protective gear during their first meeting was a deliberate gesture of trust that moved Illya, contrasting with paralegal Riya Kapoor who wore full protective equipment.
  • Illya noted that officers treated him with "guarded empathy" rather than hostility during his containment, a dynamic he reflected on through the lens of racial politics.
  • The formal charges at his arraignment totaled seventeen counts across six categories, the most unusual being seven counts of "unlicensed use of superhuman abilities."
  • The pre-trial legal timeline set at his arraignment ran from April through August 2024, establishing a parallel timeline to Sam's recovery arc in Intermission 4.5.

docs.title: Councilman Jamal Davis
docs.text: Philadelphia city councilman and civilian liaison for the Delaware Valley Defenders, serving as the political bridge between the city government and its registered superhero team.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Jamal Davis Aliases Councilman Davis, JD Date of Birth Unknown Age 40s Gender Male Ethnicity Black Place of Birth Unknown Residence Philadelphia, PA Affiliation Delaware Valley Defenders (Civilian Liaison), Philadelphia City Council Former Affiliations N/A Occupation City Councilman, DVD Civilian Liaison Status Active First Appearance Chapter 15 Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Jamal Davis is a Philadelphia city councilman who serves as the civilian liaison for the Delaware Valley Defenders, the city's premiere registered superhuman team. In this capacity, he functions as the de jure leader of the organization, managing its political relationships, providing institutional cover, and coordinating with law enforcement and government agencies on the team's behalf. While Liberty Belle served as the de facto field leader during her lifetime, Davis handled the administrative and political dimensions of the DVD's operations.

Davis first came to Sam Small's attention during her early days with the Young Defenders, when he joined the senior DVD members to assess drone footage of a Kingdom of Keys murder at Dobson Mills. His role expanded significantly during Arc 4, when Sam confronted him with evidence of a government conspiracy protecting Chernobyl. Sam initially suspected Davis of complicity in the cover-up, but Davis forcefully denied any knowledge, explaining that he had been following NSRA safety directives without awareness of the underlying arrangement. He proposed an off-the-books investigation to avoid government scrutiny, offering to provide surplus equipment and resources while working official channels. This covert arrangement effectively gave birth to "The Auditors," an unofficial investigative team comprising Sam, Jordan, and Spindle, with Davis providing political cover from behind the scenes.

Over the course of the story, Davis has evolved from a background authority figure into one of Sam's most important institutional allies. He has repeatedly navigated the tension between his public office and his private support for Sam's increasingly aggressive methods, maintaining official distance when necessary while quietly providing intelligence, resources, and political protection. His relationship with Sam deepened through moments of crisis — advising her during the Maya Richardson election, providing a keycard override granting Sam access to DVD headquarters, and texting quiet encouragement after her confrontation with Richardson at town hall.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file. Davis possesses no superhuman abilities.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text: • N/A — Jamal Davis has no superpowers. His value to the Delaware Valley Defenders and to the broader Philadelphia superhero community is entirely political, strategic, and institutional.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• As a baseline human, Davis has no physical capabilities beyond those of an ordinary person. He cannot participate in combat operations or field missions.
  • His effectiveness is constrained by political realities — every action he takes must be weighed against potential consequences for his elected position, the DVD's legal standing, and the broader political landscape.
  • His off-the-books support for Sam places his career and legal standing at considerable risk.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Experienced politician with deep knowledge of Philadelphia's government structure, legislative processes, and municipal bureaucracy.
  • Skilled negotiator and diplomat, capable of managing relationships across the superhero community, law enforcement, federal agencies, and city government simultaneously.
  • Knowledgeable about RICO laws, chain of evidence requirements, and the legal complexities surrounding superhuman prosecution.
  • Adept at redirecting government funding and navigating institutional channels — demonstrated by his ability to redirect historical preservation funding triggered by Garbage Day's attack on the Music Hall into the community center renovation.
  • Maintains professional connections across Pennsylvania state government, including relationships with families like the Kirbys (mid-level state government functionaries from Harrisburg).

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Davis is diplomatic, strategic, and cautious to his core. He speaks carefully, weighing the political implications of every word before it leaves his mouth. He genuinely believes in the value of superhero work and has demonstrated real courage in supporting Sam's investigations off-the-books, but he never loses sight of the political realities that constrain his actions. He intervenes in disputes among DVD members with measured authority, reminding colleagues of the importance of unity and communication rather than taking sides.

Beneath the politician's polish, Davis possesses a moral seriousness that has sharpened over time. The Shrike incident in Arc 14 — watching Sam, a teenager, kill a white supremacist on live television — triggered a crisis of faith in the entire young-superhuman-to-hero pipeline. His growing disillusionment did not lead to paralysis but to action: he spearheaded a mentorship program designed to offer powered youth an alternative to becoming child soldiers. When pushed past his limits, Davis does not explode — he plans. Maya Richardson sending Garbage Day after Sam and injuring Tasha Reynolds, a civilian noncombatant, crossed a line in his book. His response has been to bide his time, build evidence, and wait. As the character reference guide notes, "the guns will come out soon enough."

Delivers a comprehensive critique of the superhero system's reliance on child soldiers, citing the Shrike incident as a turning point. Confirms federal movement against Maya Richardson: FBI questions, NSRA power registration review, grand jury convening. Redirected historical preservation funding triggered by Garbage Day's attack to fund the renovation. Had the Faraday cage room professionally built to classified signal-blocking standards, clearly knowing what the Auditors would use it for. Referenced as a contact in Sam's intel distribution circuit alongside the DVD, Titans, Argus Corps, and Pals.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Davis sealed his secret alliance with Sam in Chapter 49 with a fist bump and the phrase "For great justice," establishing a tone of conspiratorial idealism that has characterized their relationship since.
  • He signs his text messages to Sam with "-JD."
  • Miasma initially warned Sam against trusting Davis, calling him "the governmentest, stoogiest of them all" — an assessment that proved wrong when Davis proposed the off-the-books investigation.
  • Davis knows the Kirby family professionally through Pennsylvania state government connections, which is how Alex Kirby entered the mentorship program rather than being flagged through Dr. Jensen's referral system like the other students.
  • The community center renovation was made possible because Garbage Day's attack on the Music Hall triggered historical preservation funding, which Davis redirected to the project — turning an act of violence against Sam into institutional support for powered youth.
  • His keynote speech at the grand opening was deliberately timed by Miasma to coincide with Elena Morales's televised confession, maximizing media impact in Maya Richardson's district.
  • The legal case United States v. Davis (2005), which established the legal framework for treating superhuman abilities as weapons, shares his surname but is not confirmed to involve him directly.

docs.title: Jamila Fayad
docs.text: Former Young Defender and Sam Small's ex-girlfriend, an aerokinetic hero who left the team and Philadelphia due to the escalating violence of superhero work.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Jamila Fayad Aliases Gale, Zephyr Date of Birth Unknown Age 15–19 Gender Female Ethnicity Pakistani-American (Muslim) Place of Birth Unknown Residence Chicago, IL (formerly Philadelphia, PA) Affiliation Chicago Powered Youth Initiative Former Affiliations Young Defenders, Delaware Valley Defenders (associated) Occupation College Student, CPYI Member Status Active First Appearance Chapter 5 Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Jamila Fayad gained her wind control powers after suffering a concussion during severe plane turbulence while returning from Iran. She had her powers for approximately one year before being registered as a prerequisite to joining the Young Defenders in 2022. A thorough background check, including NSRA postcognitive analysis, confirmed her clean record. Her family background and Muslim faith were noted by her PERKS interviewing officer as a source of strength and moral grounding.

Jamila served as a core member of the Young Defenders during a particularly turbulent period for the team, participating in major engagements including the South Street battle against the Philly Phreaks and the chaotic events surrounding the Chernobyl trial. During her time on the team, she developed a romantic relationship with Sam Small, becoming Sam's first girlfriend. The relationship was marked by genuine affection but also significant strain caused by Sam's escalating involvement in dangerous situations and extended hospitalization.

In mid-2025, during a team meeting where the Young Defenders discussed their futures, Jamila announced her desire to step back from active duty, citing the increasing violence and her fear of losing her life. She broke up with Sam around the same time and subsequently disappeared from the team and Sam's life. She later resurfaced in Chicago, where she had moved for college and to maintain the family homestead while her parents and extended family were in Pakistan for religious and professional reasons. She joined the Chicago Powered Youth Initiative (CPYI), an infrastructure-focused organization that puts superpowered youth to work on infrastructure projects rather than combat or search and rescue operations, operating under the new codename "Zephyr." In Chicago, she assists with lakefront storm barrier support at Navy Pier, demonstrating precision wind control that earns the approval of Whiteout, a professional Chicago superhero. She is coordinated by Nour, the CPYI coordinator. Despite her new life, Jamila obsessively watches footage of Sam's beating by Rush Order, struggles with guilt over abandoning Philadelphia and Sam, and is urged by her brother Ahmed to contact Sam after the incident. She contemplates reaching out but remains uncertain, torn between her decision to make a "clean break" and her unresolved feelings.

Despite her departure, Jamila returned one final time during the courthouse crisis, arriving disguised in biker gear and a helmet to help Playback and Spindle subdue Pumice when civilians were in danger.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: Field Value Classification E4/E/P/B Category Employ Power Ranking 4/10 Control 6/10 Hostility 1/10 Collateral Damage 5/10 Threat Level 4/10

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Wind Control (Aerokinesis) — Manipulates and controls already-moving air. Cannot generate wind from still air; requires an initial air movement of approximately 1.5 m/s to begin. Often initiates this using a small battery-powered fan clipped to her belt. Categorized as aerokinetic but not aerogenetic.
  • Air Volume Manipulation — Can manipulate up to approximately 65 cubic meters of air, sufficient to lift herself and one additional passenger in close proximity. Maximum lift capacity of approximately 330 lbs in ideal conditions. Control is most effective as vertical columns or cylinders of swirling wind.
  • Wind Speed Generation — Capable of generating wind speeds up to 75 MPH (Beaufort scale 12) within two inches of her skin, with a functional maximum of approximately 60 MPH (Beaufort scale 10) at usable range.
  • Directional Control — Exhibits high precision in directing wind currents, especially effective within a 20-meter radius. Precision decreases with distance. Maximum control range of approximately 81 meters, with wind speed decreasing linearly to about 2.5 m/s at the edge.
  • Air Vortex Creation — Can create and sustain air vortices with diameters of up to 2 meters. Limited to two simultaneous vortices, one per hand, as complex phenomena require hand-based concentration. Can also replicate small-scale meteorological phenomena such as squalls and downbursts.
  • Flight — Uses wind control for personal flight and can carry passengers. Certified for JLUMA flight at Basic proficiency level with an altitude limit of 30 feet, restricted to daylight hours and designated flight zones.
  • Enhanced Mobility — Leverages wind control for rapid movement, evasive maneuvers, and aerial repositioning in combat.
  • Immediate Disengagement — Can cease wind control instantaneously upon decision, with wind speeds returning to ambient conditions within 2–3 seconds.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Initiation Requirement — Power is entirely dependent on the presence of moving air. Still air renders her unable to initiate wind control. She relies on a battery-powered fan to create initial airflow.
  • Environmental Interference — Effectiveness diminishes in complex, cluttered, or enclosed spaces. Powers are most effective outdoors.
  • Physical Strain — Extended use causes fatigue equivalent to moderate-intensity physical activity. Functional upper limit of approximately 30 minutes of continuous usage before fatigue overtakes her ability to sustain winds.
  • Concentration Dependency — Wind control is closely tied to concentration. Distractions or divided attention significantly reduce control effectiveness. Complex phenomena like vortices require hand-based focus, limiting her to one vortex per hand.
  • No Pressure/Temperature Control — Control extends only to wind speed and direction. She cannot manipulate air pressure, temperature, or humidity.
  • Range Degradation — Maximum wind speed decreases linearly with distance, reaching only 2.5 m/s at the 81-meter edge of her range.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Basic self-defense training, described as knowing enough to be dangerous to a random person on the street.
  • Practices archery recreationally.
  • JLUMA flight certification (Basic proficiency) obtained in March 2023.
  • Tactical experience from coordinated missions with the Young Defenders, including aerial combat and team-based engagements.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Jamila is motherly, smothering, and deeply pacifistic. She shows genuine warmth and care for those around her, often going out of her way to comfort and support her teammates. She has an unexpected interest in heavy metal music, particularly bands from the 2000s, and enjoys attending her brothers' metal band concerts. Her sweet demeanor and earnest approach were noted as refreshing by her PERKS interviewing officer, and her empathetic nature and strong ethical values are rooted in her family and faith.

Beneath her nurturing exterior, Jamila possesses a venomous side that emerges when people she cares about are threatened, as demonstrated when she used her wind powers to physically lift Puppeteer during the confrontation where Puppeteer assaulted Sam. However, her fundamental inability to tolerate violence ultimately drove her away from the Young Defenders. She still harbors feelings for Sam but chose to end their relationship rather than continue to be part of a world she found increasingly unbearable. Her stated claim of being asexual was made to soften the breakup; she is heterosexual but has stringent taste in men and had genuinely cared for Sam. In Chicago, her guilt manifests as obsessive monitoring of Philadelphia news and Sam's public appearances, particularly after the Rush Order beating, yet she cannot bring herself to make contact, paralyzed between the clean break she chose and the connection she still feels.

docs.text: Book Role Key Events Book 1: Pup Supporting Introduced as a Young Defender during Sam's induction. Paired with Sam for her first patrol, where they apprehend Mudslide at a Walgreens and encounter Safeguard. Develops a friendship with Sam through flying and a Rita's Water Ice outing. Accompanies Sam during power testing with Dr. Leonard Harris; Sam drops her off at home before being ambushed by Aaron (Ch. 50). During a private conversation, Sam apologizes for being a poor girlfriend; Jamila tells Sam she will not break up with her while she is in the hospital but implies a future discussion is needed. Sam impulsively says "I love you"; Jamila responds warmly but noncommittally ("I love you too, Sam. No matter what"). Sam has an anxiety attack and vomits after Jamila leaves. On Sam's fifteenth birthday (Chapter 68), Jamila arrives last, bringing a pendant with wind-inspired patterns. They share a quiet reconnection, their hands entwined, closing the intermission with "All's well." Book 5: Mayfly Supporting Present when Sam returns to active patrolling after her hospitalization. Attends the Small family Passover Seder (Ch. 71), experiencing her first Seder and participating in the Afikomen hunt. Book 6: Sideshow Supporting / Interlude Broke up with Sam during a private conversation in her room, revealing she may be asexual and cannot reconcile herself with the violence of superhero life; told Sam their paths were incompatible. Announced her desire to step back from active duty during a subsequent team meeting. In Interlude DH.1 (Playback's POV), returned disguised in biker leathers and a motorcycle helmet during the Phreaks' courthouse attack, headbutting Pumice to temporarily incapacitate him and coordinating with Playback and Spindle: used wind to enhance their strikes, launched Spindle with wind gusts, and created a vortex of air to suffocate Pumice into submission. Departed before Sam could identify her. Moved away from Philadelphia by the end of the arc. Book 12: Authorized Personnel Only Interlude Featured in the Jamila section of Interlude RS/DC/JF (approximately August 1, 2025). Now living in Chicago, she obsessively watches footage of Sam's beating by Rush Order. She is enrolled at a university while participating in the CPYI under the codename "Zephyr," performing sanctioned community service including lakefront storm barrier support at Navy Pier. She meets Whiteout, a professional Chicago superhero who approves of her "structured" approach. Her friend Sana confides about previously using Jump, revealing the drug has reached Chicago. Her brother Ahmed calls, urging her to contact Sam after the Rush Order incident; they argue about her decision to make a "clean break" when moving to Chicago. The interlude ends with Jamila contemplating calling Sam but remaining uncertain whether she should reconnect, struggling with guilt over abandoning Philadelphia and Sam.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Her power origin involved a concussion sustained during plane turbulence while returning from Iran.
  • She wears a hijab with yellow accents as part of her hero costume.
  • Her PERKS code E4/E/P/B stands for Employ-4 / Environment / Physical / Block-sized radius.
  • She carries a small battery-powered fan on her belt to initiate her wind control, having upgraded from a hand fan.
  • Her JLUMA flight certification restricts her to 30 feet altitude, daylight hours, and designated flight zones.
  • Her power assessment was conducted by Dr. Leonard Harris, the same specialist who assessed multiple other Young Defenders.
  • She has four brothers and a sister.
  • The Chicago Powered Youth Initiative, which she joined after leaving Philadelphia, focuses on infrastructure projects rather than combat operations.
  • She told Sam she was asexual to soften the breakup, when she is actually heterosexual.
  • Her friend Sana's confession about using Jump in Chicago establishes that the drug crisis is not contained to the Philadelphia region.
  • Her brother Ahmed actively opposes her "clean break" policy and serves as a voice urging her to reconnect with Sam.

docs.title: Jasmine Perez
docs.text: Government-sanctioned speedster and de facto public face of Argus Corps, whose growing moral doubts about her team's mission have begun driving her toward independent investigation of her own handler.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Jasmine Perez Aliases Turbo Jett Date of Birth Unknown Age Late 20s (was 13 at Activation Event; operated for 15 years before LUMA revocation) Gender Female Ethnicity Hispanic Place of Birth Camden, New Jersey Residence Philadelphia, PA Affiliation Argus Corps Former Affiliations Independent licensed vigilante (Camden, NJ; ~15 years) Occupation Registered Superhuman Entity (RSO operative) Status Active First Appearance Chapter 157 (in person); Interlude MR.4 (recruitment) Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Jasmine Perez is a metahuman from Camden, New Jersey, whose powers activated at age thirteen during an eighth-grade class trip to Camelback Mountain in the Pocono Mountains. As revealed in Interlude TJ.1, the trip was subsidized by a school grant, but her family still struggled to afford it — her mother ("Mami") picked up extra shifts at the hospital where she worked, and her father ("Papi") sold his old car instead of repairing it. Jasmine was a hyperactive child whom teachers consistently described as "bright but needs to focus," and her mother had taken her to three different doctors trying to determine why she could not sit still. Her father described her as having "his engine but somebody forgot to install the brakes."

During the class trip, Jasmine was snowboarding on an intermediate run when an avalanche struck. Ski patrol later noted the snowpack had been stable that morning, suggesting the slide was not natural in origin. Buried under heavy snow with no room to breathe, Jasmine's Activation Event triggered: her body generated extreme heat, melting the snow around her face and creating enough space to breathe and dig free. Steam poured off her body in visible waves, and the snow beneath her melted into a spreading circle of slush. Rather than seeking help for herself, she immediately searched for other buried victims. She rescued three people — a shallow-buried sixteen-year-old boy, a younger girl buried deep whom she reached by melting through the snow with her superheated hands, and an unconscious male buried so deep that her heat began to flicker during the extraction. She gave her snow clothes to the survivors before collapsing from exhaustion. Search and rescue teams credited her with enabling them to focus on the remaining four buried victims; all seven people caught in the avalanche survived with zero fatalities. Her best friend DeShawn, who had stayed inside the lodge during the run, refused to leave the hospital afterward.

Following the avalanche, Jasmine operated as a vigilante in Camden for approximately fifteen years, eventually obtaining a LUMA (License to Utilize Metahuman Abilities). She was Camden's most prominent protector, pulling people from fires, stopping muggers and carjackers, and handling metahuman threats. At age sixteen, she encountered an arsonist called Coilgun — a former shipyard worker with a multiplied-force power (described as having "extra hands" and "extra everything") who targeted corporate facilities connected to environmental pollution and predatory real estate. Their first encounter was at the Camden shipyard, where Coilgun was destroying records belonging to Delmarva Chemical, a company he accused of dumping in the river for thirty years. Coilgun challenged Jasmine's worldview, arguing that rescuing individuals did nothing to address the systems causing harm. Three weeks later, she fought him again at a real estate developer's office building, hitting Gear Four for the first time in combat. The fight was brutal — Coilgun hit her with multiplied air-compression strikes and a roundhouse kick that connected everywhere at once — but ended in a stalemate after Jasmine's tackle caused more structural damage than Coilgun had planned. She eventually captured Coilgun before her eighteenth birthday.

After fifteen years of operation, Jasmine's LUMA was revoked via letter, citing "a pattern of disproportionate collateral damage inconsistent with continued provisional licensing." Shortly afterward, she received a phone call from Maya Richardson's office. Richardson met with Jasmine in a federal building in Philadelphia, offering her a place on a government-sanctioned metahuman team (Argus Corps) as a Registered Superhuman Entity. Richardson appealed to Jasmine's desire to rebuild her reputation and framed the opportunity as "a second chance." During the meeting, Richardson showed Jasmine a news clip of herself (Maya) being interviewed years earlier about the federal ban on her own weather manipulation powers, wearing a domino mask — establishing a shared experience of institutional power being used against metahumans. This personal connection was the decisive factor in Jasmine's recruitment, though she has implied a history remarkably similar to that of Sam Small, including having been placed on an older version of the parental tracking bracelet that Sam later wore.

Argus Corps was publicly announced at a press conference following a Philadelphia City Council emergency session in late April 2025, with Jett presented as one of four operatives tasked with combating the Jump epidemic and criminal metahuman organizations. Behind the scenes, the team operated under NSRA Special Directive 14-B with detention powers, body camera mandates, and oversight nominally under Richardson. From the outset, Jett served as the team's de facto public relations figure, largely because she was attractive and personable and the team lacked any actual PR infrastructure.
