docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Hyperthermia Immunity — Jett's body can operate normally at any temperature below the ignition point of her tissues. This allows her to sustain the extreme heat output generated by her Gearshifting power without suffering heatstroke, burns, or thermal organ damage. At higher gears, her body radiates significant heat, enough to be felt by those nearby.
  • Passive Aerokinesis — Jett possesses a secondary power that grants her limited control over air currents around her body. At lower gears, this manifests as enhanced movement efficiency and drag reduction. At higher gears, she can generate air shockwaves powerful enough to affect her surroundings and other combatants.
  • Gearshifting (Primary Power) — Jett's core ability is a tiered power-amplification system she refers to as "Gearshifting," which she internally conceptualizes as a mental stickshift that she shifts up or down. At Gear Zero (her default state), she is a moderately athletic gymnast with no notable superhuman traits. Each subsequent gear doubles her energy consumption, calorie burn rate, body heat output, and physical power output in watts. Gear 1 provides 2x output, Gear 2 provides 4x, Gear 3 provides 8x, and Gear 4 provides 16x. At Gear 4, she is capable of feats such as smashing a car in half and has a lifting strength of approximately 1.6 metric tons. Higher gears dramatically increase her speed; at Gear 3, she has been observed ping-ponging off surfaces at extreme velocity during pursuit sequences. Interlude TJ.1 revealed that Gear Four first manifested during combat against Coilgun and could only be sustained for seconds at a time, with severe burnout consequences; Jasmine described it as something that "decided to hit me" rather than a deliberate activation. During her Activation Event at age thirteen, her heat generation was powerful enough to melt through packed avalanche snow on contact, creating steam clouds and bare-earth circles, but the power "guttered out" after sustained use across multiple rescue extractions.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Gearshifting is directly tied to caloric consumption. Each gear doubles the rate at which Jett burns through energy reserves, meaning sustained high-gear operation rapidly depletes her stamina and requires significant food intake to recover from.
  • At higher gears, Jett's body heat output becomes extreme. While she is personally immune to this heat, it can damage her surroundings and potentially injure allies or bystanders in close proximity.
  • Jett has no documented enhanced durability, regeneration, or defensive capabilities beyond her heat immunity. She remains vulnerable to conventional weapons and attacks when not actively evading through speed.
  • Her aerokinesis is passive and supplementary rather than a primary combat tool; she cannot direct focused wind attacks at will outside of the shockwave effects generated at higher gears.
  • She is described as having no real parkour experience at Gear Zero, suggesting her impressive movement at higher gears is a product of raw power and speed rather than trained technique.
  • Gear Four can only be sustained for a few seconds before risking total burnout. During the Coilgun fight in TJ.1, even brief use left her vomiting blood and unable to continue fighting at full capacity.
  • Gear Five has been referenced but never fully achieved. In MR.10, Maya described Jett as approaching near Gear Five during their confrontation — Jett walked through 5-7 atmospheres of directed barokinetic force, step by step, suggesting Gear Five's output may approach or exceed 32x baseline. The full capabilities and costs of Gear Five remain unknown.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Trained gymnast, with her costume incorporating gymnastic equipment as a reflection of this background.
  • Studied karate, funded by grateful civilians she initially refused payment from but eventually accepted. Applied martial arts training during her second fight with Coilgun, using throws, clothesline attempts, and grappling in combination with her Gearshifting.
  • Combat-capable in the field, though her fighting style relies more on speed, momentum, and overwhelming force than on refined martial arts technique. Fifteen years of active vigilante work in Camden provided extensive real-world combat experience.
  • Competent at tactical field operations including building entry, pursuit, zip-tying suspects, and civilian extraction.
  • Skilled at public relations and community interaction, particularly with children, serving as Argus Corps' primary public-facing representative.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Interlude TJ.1 established the foundation of Jett's personality: a hyperactive, impulsive young woman whose brain was "never quiet" until she found something big enough to match what was inside her. The avalanche rescue at age thirteen was not a calculated act of heroism but an instinctive response — she heard someone screaming and went to find them. She felt the word "hero" was like "a coat that doesn't fit." Her mother's advice after the LUMA revocation captured her core: she was never going to slow down, and the question was whether she would find something worth running toward. Coilgun's philosophical challenges during their encounters — questioning whether rescuing individuals mattered if the systems causing harm remained intact — represent an unresolved tension in her worldview that she never satisfactorily answered.

Jett radiates what the narrative describes as "older sister" energy. She is warm, enthusiastic, and genuinely kind in a way that distinguishes her sharply from her more hardened or ideologically rigid teammates. She loves fighting and loves a good chase, approaching superhero work with the genre-savvy excitement of someone who grew up watching superhero procedurals rather than living through the grim political thriller that Philadelphia's metahuman landscape actually resembles. She is not unintelligent, but she is consistently unprepared for how complicated the real world is, operating under the sincere but naive belief that enough good-hearted enforcers could fundamentally restructure broken institutions from within.

Beneath the exuberance, Jett carries genuine insecurities about her tarnished reputation, which Richardson exploited during recruitment. She does not care about property damage, prioritizing people over things without hesitation, and has a documented pattern of disobeying her chain of command when she believes lives are at stake. She very rarely gets angry, and when she does, it tends to manifest as reluctant frustration rather than hostility. Her playful demeanor during the pursuit of Sam through Northeast Philadelphia, and her decision to let Sam escape after witnessing her rescue a civilian and a cat from a burning building, both speak to a moral compass that increasingly conflicts with her orders. Sam's pointed question, "Are you a superhero or not, Jett?" haunts her, and as of the beginning of Arc 16, she is actively reevaluating her life choices and investigating Maya Richardson on the down low alongside Captain Devil.

docs.title: Relationships
docs.text: Character Relationship Notes Maya Richardson (Mrs. Zenith) Handler / Employer / Betrayer Richardson recruited Jett by appealing to her desire to rebuild her reputation. During their initial meeting at a federal building in Philadelphia, Richardson showed Jett a news clip of herself being interviewed about the federal ban on her own powers, wearing a domino mask — establishing a personal connection through shared experience of institutional suppression. Jett increasingly suspected Richardson and was quietly investigating her. In MR.10, Jett discovered Maya's barokinesis through an independent autopsy of Richard Duvall showing decompression injuries, and confronted Maya at her apartment — approaching near Gear Five, walking through Maya's full pressure field (5-7 atmospheres), destroying the apartment. Maya neutralized Jett's rage by revealing her daughter Roxy and framing herself as a Kingdom hostage. Jett left numb and manipulated, the anger alloyed with doubt. Richard Johnson Jr. (Patriot) Teammate / Team Leader Fellow Argus Corps member. Patriot serves as operational leader. Jett initially dismissed Bloodhound's accusations against Richardson during a team briefing, but her views have since shifted. Joshua Pleasants (Miasma) Teammate Fellow Argus Corps member. Unbeknownst to Jett, Miasma is a mole working against the Kingdom from within the team. Andrew Mitchell (Captain Devil) Teammate / Investigation Partner Fellow Argus Corps member. Jett and Captain Devil are conducting a parallel, secret investigation into Maya Richardson, independent of Patriot's own covert investigation. Neither pair knows about the other's efforts. Sam Small (Bloodhound) Adversary / Complicated Respect Jett has pursued and confronted Sam multiple times on official orders. However, she has shown genuine interest in Sam's evidence, let Sam escape after a building rescue, and is visibly troubled by the moral implications of hunting a teenage hero. Sam's question "Are you a superhero or not?" was a turning point. Sam compares Argus Corps to fighting dogs on spiked collars and recognizes Maya as holding the leash, but cannot bring herself to hate Jett. Benjamin and Rachel Small Adversarial (by role) Confronted the Smalls outside their home while attempting to serve Sam's arrest warrant. Rachel attempted to show tracker data proving Sam's alibi; Jett showed genuine interest in this evidence before Sam fled. Mami (Mrs. Perez) Mother Works at a hospital. Picked up extra shifts to fund Jasmine's class trip to the Poconos. After the LUMA revocation, she told Jasmine that she had always prayed for her to find something worth running toward, and that a license could not take away what she was. Papi (Mr. Perez) Father Former shipyard worker. Sold his old car to fund Jasmine's class trip. Described Jasmine as having "his engine but somebody forgot to install the brakes." Told Jasmine after the avalanche that she was "the hero of Camelback Mountain." DeShawn Best friend Friends since third grade. Described as the only person who could keep up with Jasmine. Was inside the lodge during the avalanche and refused to leave the hospital afterward, sleeping on the floor of her room. Coilgun Early adversary A former Camden shipyard worker turned arsonist who targeted corporate facilities linked to environmental pollution and predatory real estate. Possessed a multiplied-force power (extra hands/limbs, compressed-air strikes). Fought Jasmine twice during her teenage years — first at the Camden shipyard (Delmarva Chemical records), then three weeks later at a real estate developer's office. Challenged her worldview by arguing individual rescues did nothing to change systemic harm. Jasmine captured him before her eighteenth birthday. He carried a Zippo lighter and used Molotov cocktails, called himself her "Green Goblin," and told her "I'm what you need."

docs.text: Book Role Key Events Book 10: Plume Supporting Recruited by Maya Richardson alongside Patriot, Miasma, and Captain Devil during Interlude MR.4, where Richardson appealed to her desire to rebuild her tarnished reputation. Zip-tied Sam, though Sam broke free once Jett stopped paying attention. Participated in the Stheno Pharmaceuticals warehouse raid (Ch. 163-164): forced open the warehouse shutter, attacked Kingdom enforcer Bash with super-speed and heat generation, and operated as part of the full Argus Corps team during the chaotic three-way battle that ended with the warehouse's destruction. Discussed by the Auditors as they investigate connections between Argus Corps, Tremont & Fairfax, and the Kingdom. Present during Patriot's team briefing where Bloodhound's accusations against Richardson were shared; Jett dismissed the claims entirely. Participated in the team's registration bill tour across Pennsylvania. Part of Argus Corps during the "Safer Streets Initiative" that offered $500 bounties for reporting powered youth. Book 15: Severe Weather Warning Supporting Confronted Sam alongside Patriot on January 3rd with an arrest warrant for unlicensed vigilantism, breaking and entering, stalking, and reckless endangerment, citing evidence of "three Bloodhounds" operating. Pursued Sam through Northeast Philadelphia in a sustained chase, demonstrating three speed "gears" with escalating speed and heat output. Sam mentioned Richardson's Harrisburg impersonation to Jett during the chase, planting doubt. Showed genuine interest in Rachel Small's tracker data proving Sam's alibis before Sam escaped. Later encountered Sam at a burning Rittenhouse Kingdom target; after Sam rescued a civilian and a cat from the fire and handed Jett the cat, Sam asked "Are you a superhero or not, Jett?" Jett told Sam to go and reported over comms that she had lost visual -- a pivotal moral turning point. During the Remora/Stingray operation to capture Alice, chased decoy pepper spray canisters thrown by Sam, realizing too late the team had been played. Present at the final confrontation at Maya's Mayfair residence where Alice-as-Sam was exposed as a second physical body. Intermission 15.5: This Side Up POV (Interlude TJ.1) Full origin story. Jasmine's Activation Event occurred at age thirteen during an eighth-grade class trip to Camelback Mountain in the Poconos. Buried in an avalanche whose conditions suggested an unnatural origin, she generated extreme body heat that melted the surrounding snow and freed her. She then rescued three other buried victims — melting through packed snow with her superheated hands — before collapsing from exhaustion. All seven buried people survived. Three years later, as an established Camden vigilante, she encountered the arsonist Coilgun at the Camden shipyard, where he was destroying Delmarva Chemical records and lecturing her about systemic injustice. Three weeks later she fought him again at a real estate developer's office, hitting Gear Four for the first time. The fight ended in a stalemate after her tackle caused more damage than his arson plans. She captured Coilgun before turning eighteen. After fifteen years of operation, her LUMA was revoked for excessive collateral damage. Maya Richardson's office contacted her, and Richardson recruited her to Argus Corps during a meeting at a federal building in Philadelphia, sealing the pitch by showing Jasmine a news clip of her own powers being federally banned — a shared experience of institutional suppression. Book 16: Category Five Hurricane Main (Interlude MR.10) Continuing to operate with Argus Corps while secretly investigating Maya Richardson alongside Captain Devil. In Interlude MR.10 (Maya's POV), Jett discovers Maya's true power (barokinesis) through an independent autopsy of Richard Duvall — the report showed decompression injuries inconsistent with natural causes. Jett confronts Maya at her apartment in a rage, approaching near "Gear Five" for the first time in the narrative, and walks through Maya's full barokinesis "hammer" (5-7 atmospheres of directed force) step by step, screaming, dragging herself against the pressure gradient. The fight destroys Maya's apartment. Maya barely outlasts her. In the aftermath, Maya manipulates Jett by revealing her daughter Roxy (Roxanne Elisabeth Hayes, age 6, fathered by Mr. Nothing) and claiming the Kingdom holds Roxy hostage to ensure her cooperation, framing herself as a captive rather than a mastermind. Jett leaves numb, the anger replaced by something more complicated. Maya's internal monologue confirms this is deliberate manipulation — "a better story than the actual one." Whether Jett fully believes it or simply cannot process the alternative remains unclear.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Jett's costume consists of gymnastic equipment in blue with hot rod flames, paired with a leather jacket also decorated with hot rod flames. The aesthetic leans heavily into her speedster persona.
  • She is described as "extremely attractive and knows it," which is explicitly cited as the reason she became Argus Corps' de facto PR person in the absence of an actual public relations team.
  • Her implied history of wearing an older version of Sam's parental tracking bracelet suggests she may have been a monitored minor metahuman herself, creating an unspoken parallel between her past and Sam's present circumstances.
  • During the chase through Northeast Philadelphia, Jett demonstrated a playful demeanor, treating the pursuit as something between a game and a job, which Sam found simultaneously infuriating and humanizing.
  • Her reaction to discovering the Remora/Stingray decoy canisters were just pepper spray was described as both funny and annoyed: "They're fucking with us!"
  • Sam internally compared Argus Corps to "fighting dogs on spiked collars controlled by gamblers," with Maya as the one holding the leash, but specifically noted she could not bring herself to hate Jett despite wanting to.
  • The character reference guide describes her simply as "Likes Sam. Good hearted."
  • Her current status as of the beginning of Arc 16 involves three simultaneous tensions: trying to keep Argus Corps ethical, being haunted by Sam's moral challenge, and secretly investigating Maya Richardson.
  • Interlude TJ.1 establishes that her father's jacket (oversized, smelling of motor oil) served as her snowboarding jacket during the Camelback class trip.
  • She internally conceptualizes her Gearshifting power as a mental stickshift, using car terminology ("downshift," "ka-clunk") consistent with her father's mechanical background.
  • Coilgun described himself as Jasmine's "Green Goblin," casting their dynamic as an archetypal hero-nemesis relationship, and told her she needed a worthy adversary to become what the city needed. He lobbed his only Zippo lighter to her underhand during their stalemate, effectively surrendering his means of arson.
  • Her LUMA revocation letter cited "disproportionate collateral damage inconsistent with continued provisional licensing." She noted that fifteen years of service ended with "a fucking letter."
  • She stopped Tornado Allie in Hoboken at some point during her career, indicating her reputation extended beyond Camden.
  • She funded her karate training with money from grateful civilians, which she initially refused but eventually accepted.
  • The avalanche that triggered her Activation Event was described as occurring under conditions that ski patrol said were "not right for a natural slide," with the snowpack reportedly stable that morning. The cause was never officially determined.
  • During the avalanche rescue, snowflakes visibly avoided her body, swirling around rather than landing on her — an early manifestation of her passive aerokinesis interacting with her heat generation.
  • Maya Richardson's recruitment of Jasmine involved showing a news clip captioned with a reference to "Stormr—" (cut off), suggesting Maya operated under a hero alias beginning with "Storm" before her powers were federally banned.
  • In MR.10, Jett's confrontation with Maya over the Duvall autopsy represents her most intense emotional and physical display in the narrative. She walked through Maya's full barokinetic pressure field — something that should have killed her — driven by rage at discovering her handler had murdered someone and lied about her powers for years.
  • Maya's internal description of Jett during the MR.10 fight suggests Jett's near-Gear Five output was genuinely terrifying to Maya, who has neutralized multiple opponents with her pressure powers. This is the closest Maya has come to losing a direct physical confrontation.
  • After the MR.10 confrontation, Jett's knowledge of Maya's barokinesis and the Duvall murder makes her the most dangerous person to Maya's cover — whether she believes the "hostage mother" narrative or not, she now holds information that could unravel everything.

docs.title: Jasmine Walker
docs.text: Fifteen-year-old chlorokinetic and member of the Tacony Community Center mentorship program, transferred to Philadelphia from the Whitford Institute in Chicago following a traumatic activation event that killed her father.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Jasmine Walker Aliases N/A Date of Birth Unknown (approximately 2010–2011) Age 15 Gender Female Ethnicity African-American Place of Birth Unknown (resided in Chicago area prior to transfer) Residence Philadelphia, PA (foster care placement) Affiliation Mentorship Program (Tacony Community Center) Former Affiliations Whitford Institute (Chicago, IL) Occupation Student Status Active First Appearance Chapter 211 Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Jasmine Walker is a teenage metahuman whose powers activated in approximately May 2025 under circumstances traumatic enough to require institutional intervention. During the activation event, Jasmine's father was killed. He had been born in 1979, placing him just outside the threshold for potential superhuman emergence (individuals born 1981 and later), meaning he could not have developed powers of his own and had no biological defenses against whatever occurred during his daughter's manifestation. Jasmine internalized her father's death as a deeply personal failing, interpreting it through what the character reference guide describes as "a sort of agnostic divine intervention thing" — the cruel randomness of a system that gave her abilities she never asked for while killing the parent who could never have shared them. She does not reveal the circumstances of her father's death to others.

Following the activation incident, Jasmine was admitted to the Whitford Institute in Chicago, the only psychiatric inpatient-outpatient facility for powered youth in the country. The Whitford intervention indicates that her early power manifestations were sufficiently alarming to require institutional containment and treatment, though not dangerous enough to warrant placement at Aurora Springs Residential Facility. At Whitford, Jasmine's subconscious plant manipulation was treated as a threat rather than a symptom, reinforcing her sense of isolation and the perception that she was dangerous. She was subsequently transferred to Philadelphia as part of a partial-stay program, where she was identified by Councilman Jamal Davis as one of four initial cases for his pilot peer mentorship program.

Jasmine's mother holds a demanding, high-paying job that provides financial stability but leaves little time for her daughter. In Philadelphia, Jasmine resides with a foster mother who works in a medical capacity (arriving at pickups in scrubs) and who has been characterized as arriving late and with limited engagement — her foster mother was the last parent to arrive during the Songbird attack on the community center, showing up forty-five minutes after the incident. Jasmine walked to the car without speaking. The combination of an absent biological mother, a deceased father, institutional upbringing, and a foster placement that appears functionally adequate but emotionally distant has left Jasmine profoundly isolated.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Chlorokinesis (Plant Manipulation) — Jasmine possesses the ability to influence and direct plant matter in her vicinity. Plants nearby respond to her emotional state, particularly feelings of threat, repositioning themselves to shield her. This manifests as branches bending toward her, leaves draping protectively over her body, roots and grasses reaching in her direction, and dormant plants spontaneously sprouting. The response operates on a subconscious, automatic level tied to her emotional state.
  • Protective Plant Response — When startled or frightened, nearby plants move to physically intercept perceived threats and create barriers between Jasmine and whatever she perceives as dangerous. During the Pennypack Park training session in January 2026, dead tree branches, bushes, and grass moved to catch Liam O'Connor when he slipped and fell toward her, demonstrating that even dormant or dead plant material responds to her impulses.
  • Escalation Potential (Protection to Harm) — Jasmine's powers can shift from defensive ("protect me") to offensive ("hurt them") if her conscious impulse changes. During the Songbird attack on the community center, plants within the building grew thorns oriented toward the door — a defensive posture that also constituted a hostile response to the perceived threat outside. Dr. Jensen flagged this escalation potential as high-risk.
  • Area-of-Effect Emotional Broadcast — During states of intense fear, Jasmine's influence extends well beyond her immediate surroundings. When frightened during the Songbird attack in March 2026, hedges within one to two blocks of the community center leaned toward the building, weeds pushed through pavement, and a winter-dormant garden began spontaneously sprouting — all orienting toward Jasmine's location. Sam Small noted this range as significant and undocumented.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Jasmine's control over her chlorokinesis is currently involuntary and subconscious. She cannot consciously direct plants and has expressed distress over the inability to stop the response once triggered ("I can't make them stop").
  • Plant material manipulated by her power retains its structural properties — wood is only as strong as wood, and her ability cannot make organic material exceed its natural physical limits. However, thorns remain sharp and branches can still strike with considerable force.
  • The power creates literal physical barriers between Jasmine and other people, reinforcing her psychological isolation in a feedback loop: fear produces plant walls, plant walls push people away, being pushed away produces more fear.
  • The full upper limits of her range and the scope of plant material she can influence are not yet established, though the two-block radius observed during the Songbird attack represents the most extreme documented manifestation.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Participating in mentorship program sessions run by Sam Small and Maggie O'Brien, including group discussions about civilian encounters, de-escalation techniques, and career planning.
  • Receiving individual therapy from Dr. Hernandez at the Tacony Community Center.
  • Previously received psychiatric treatment at the Whitford Institute, though the nature and focus of that treatment beyond containment is not detailed.
  • Sam Small has committed to helping Jasmine learn conscious direction of her powers, though progress toward voluntary control has not yet been documented.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Jasmine presents a black goth aesthetic that suggests an interest in the macabre or "creepy," but her actual interests run toward conventionally beautiful things — butterflies and flower arranging among them. The disconnect between presentation and preference is characteristic of her broader behavioral pattern: Jasmine constructs an exterior designed to keep people at a comfortable distance while privately craving the connection she is too afraid to pursue. She is described as the "bad shy" in contrast to Zara Khan's "good shy" — where Zara is quietly curious and willing to engage on topics she knows well, Jasmine wants to be perceived as the cool, detached quiet kid in the corner. She sits back and observes, saves up cutting remarks, and performs the role of a quiet curmudgeon until she believes she has something sufficiently clever to contribute.

Beneath the affect is a teenager who craves positive attention and affection but is scared to reach out for it. This fear is compounded by the trauma of her father's death during her activation, the institutional experience at Whitford where her powers were treated as dangerous, and a home life that provides material stability but little emotional warmth. Her chlorokinesis reinforces this cycle on a physical level — the plants that move to protect her also wall her off from the people around her, creating a visible manifestation of the emotional barriers she has built. At the time of Arc 16, Jasmine is described as "very slowly defrosting," suggesting incremental progress toward trust and openness within the mentorship peer group.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Jasmine's powers were undisclosed for approximately two months of mentorship sessions before being involuntarily revealed at Pennypack Park, making her the last of the four mentees to have her abilities seen by the group.
  • Her father's birth year of 1979 is specifically noted as placing him just before the 1981 threshold for superhuman potential — a two-year gap that Jasmine has internalized as cosmically significant.
  • The character reference guide describes Jasmine as representing "kids failed by psychiatric and institutional systems despite those systems genuinely trying to help," positioning her as a thematic counterpoint to characters like Daisy Zhen who were failed by systems that were not trying to help.
  • Jasmine's chlorokinesis creates a literalized metaphor: her power physically constructs the emotional barriers she uses to keep people away, with plants forming walls between her and others in direct response to the fear and isolation that drive her withdrawal.
  • She is one of two mentorship members (alongside Zara Khan) whom Sam directly addressed regarding the racial disparity in how the justice system treats powered youth of color.
  • During the career planning discussion with the mentorship group, Liam said he wanted to be an electrician, Zara said research, and Alex said business or drag racing. Jasmine was the only one who said she did not know.
  • The Whitford Institute, where Jasmine was previously housed, is also where Daisy Zhen was remanded following her emergency legal hearing in Arc 13. It is the only facility of its kind in the country.
  • Dr. Jensen flagged three of the four mentorship members (Jasmine, Zara, and Liam); Alex Kirby was the exception, having been referred through Davis's professional connection to his parents.

docs.title: Jason Reynolds
docs.text: Former Young Defenders leader and kinetic impact nullifier who graduated to the Delaware Valley Defenders, serving as Sam Small's primary combat trainer and a steadfast frontline protector.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Jason Reynolds Aliases Rampart Date of Birth Unknown (activated in 2019) Age 17-19 Gender Male Ethnicity White Place of Birth Unknown Residence Philadelphia, PA Affiliation Delaware Valley Defenders Former Affiliations Young Defenders (Leader) Occupation Registered Superhuman Entity Status Active First Appearance Chapter 5 Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Jason Reynolds gained his superhuman abilities in 2019 and was forced to quit football as a result, since competing in sports with powers raised fairness concerns. Despite his initial disappointment, he was enthusiastic about the prospect of becoming a superhero and received JLUMA approval the same year. He joined the Young Defenders in 2020 and quickly established himself as a reliable frontline presence, leveraging his kinetic impact nullification to shield teammates during field operations.

Over the following years, Jason's role on the team solidified. He became the primary combat trainer for younger members, most notably Sam Small, whom he trained in boxing fundamentals, bone conditioning, Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu, and grappling techniques beginning in the fall of 2023. When Crossroads graduated to the senior Delaware Valley Defenders roster in the summer of 2024, Councilman Jamal Davis appointed Jason as the new leader of the Young Defenders, citing his physical and mental strength and his dedication to the team.

Jason led the Young Defenders through a turbulent period that included the Philly Phreaks' courthouse attack, the Chernobyl trial, and the rise of Pattinson's Pals. When Councilwoman Maya Richardson's anti-youth-vigilantism ordinance (the Superhuman Activity Regulation Act) passed the Philadelphia City Council, Jason chose to graduate to the Delaware Valley Defenders rather than operate illegally. He continues to serve as a professional hero on the senior team.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: Field Value Classification F8/S/P/T Category Filch Power Ranking 8/10 Control 8/10 Hostility 1/10 Collateral Damage 3/10 Threat Level 4/10

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Kinetic Impact Nullification — Selectively negates any kinetic force directed at him that he is aware of, including punches, bullets, and collisions with vehicles. The nullified kinetic energy is channeled away and harmlessly dispersed into the nearest large mass, typically the ground. No upper limit to the magnitude of force he can nullify has been found in laboratory testing. When airborne, the energy disperses through the air, occasionally producing a mild gust.
  • Selective Activation — Can choose which impacts to nullify, allowing him to interact normally with objects and people while remaining invulnerable to hostile kinetic forces he is tracking.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Awareness Requirement — His power only activates against impacts he is consciously aware of. Attacks from blind spots, unseen angles, or those he fails to register will land normally. His reaction time is within human norms at approximately 220 milliseconds.
  • Mental Strain — Extended or intensive use causes mental fatigue but not physical fatigue. Mental exhaustion can reduce his effectiveness and reaction time during prolonged engagements.
  • Vulnerability to Non-Kinetic Attacks — Susceptible to extreme temperatures, energy-based assaults (such as electricity and lightning), and airway obstructions. His power does not protect against these threat types.
  • Multi-Directional Overwhelm — Rapid successive impacts from multiple directions can overwhelm his ability to track and nullify all threats simultaneously, particularly if they come from unseen angles or exceed his capacity to remain aware.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Trained in grappling, Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu, and pankration, specifically chosen to complement his kinetic nullification power. If he pins an opponent, they cannot escape unless they have a means of harming him through non-kinetic force.
  • Former football player with an athletic background, contributing to his large, powerful build.
  • Experienced combat instructor who trained Sam Small in striking technique, bone conditioning, takedowns, ground positions, and submission holds.
  • Field leadership experience as Young Defenders team leader, including tactical coordination and crisis management.
  • Wears heavy ceramic and metal armor in the field.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Jason is hard-headed but good-hearted, carrying himself with a calm, composed demeanor that becomes increasingly stoic under pressure. He is straightforward and blunt, preferring direct communication over diplomacy. He thinks he knows best in situations that fall within his area of expertise but readily defers to others when he recognizes he is out of his depth. He has a notable tendency to trust government institutions and legal frameworks, often defaulting to the assumption that authorities will act properly. He is deeply protective of his teammates, frequently positioning himself as the team's frontline shield, and takes his responsibilities as both a hero and a trainer seriously.

He maintains a warm, older-brother dynamic with Sam Small, characterized by good-natured ribbing, hair-ruffling, and nicknames like "Smurfette" and "Lemony Snicket." He has a borderline religious devotion to Philadelphia sports, particularly the Eagles, and habitually chews bubblegum. Despite his serious bearing, he shows flashes of dry humor and can be flustered by teasing. He harbors a quiet bitterness about having to quit football when he gained his powers, though he keeps this to himself. He is noted as religious but does not discuss it while on duty.

docs.title: Jeffery Brown
docs.text: Founder and former leader of the Delaware Valley Defenders, an electricity-wielding superhero and educator who operated as Professor Franklin in Philadelphia until his death in 2017.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Jeffery Brown Aliases Professor Franklin Date of Birth December 31, 1981 Age 35 (at death) Gender Male Ethnicity African-American Place of Birth Strawberry Mansion, North Philadelphia, PA Residence Philadelphia, PA Affiliation Delaware Valley Defenders (founder) Former Affiliations Independent vigilante, Registered Superhuman Entity Occupation Superhero, Former public high school science teacher Status Deceased First Appearance Chapter 3 (mentioned) Last Appearance Interlude DW.2 (depicted)

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Jeffery Brown was born on New Year's Eve 1981 in the Strawberry Mansion neighborhood of North Philadelphia to Darling "Knuckle Sandwich" Brown, a boxer, and Madison Brown-Smith, a schoolteacher. Raised in a low-income household, Jeffery lost his father at age two when Darling died of an aneurysm during a championship boxing match. Despite economic hardship, Jeffery excelled academically, particularly in physics. At age twelve, he defended his younger sister from a neighborhood gang, sustaining injuries that caused lifelong deficits to his grip strength and the use of his left arm. A middle school career day encounter with a physicist cemented his interest in the sciences, and he earned a full-ride scholarship to Temple University, graduating in 2003 with a BSc in Physics.

After graduation, Jeffery took a teaching position at a local public high school, determined to give back to the community that raised him. In August 2004, while chaperoning a school field trip, he was struck by lightning, which activated his latent superpowers. This was not his first brush with superhuman danger -- in 2001, he had been severely burned while attempting to intervene in a superhuman conflict near his campus, leaving him with lifelong scarring and pain across his torso and arms. His lightning strike activated the abilities that the earlier incident had failed to trigger.

Adopting the alias "Professor Franklin" as a tribute to Benjamin Franklin and his famous kite experiment, Jeffery began moonlighting as a vigilante while continuing to teach. He focused on combating gang-related activities and mentoring young potential vigilantes, combining scientific principles with combat techniques. After five years of independent vigilante work, he applied for and was accepted as a Registered Superhuman Entity in 2009, at which point he retired from teaching to focus on superhero work full-time. In 2016, he founded the Delaware Valley Defenders, uniting heroes across the Delaware Valley area. He was killed on December 19, 2017 during his final mission attempting to stop the villain Chernobyl from stealing military-grade munitions from an industrial factory. A memorial service was held on March 18, 2018 at Laurel Hill Cemetery in Strawberry Mansion, attended by superheroes, former students, and Philadelphia citizens from across the region.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: Field Value Classification G4/SE/P/T (Immunity), F7/SO/P/V (Electrokinesis) Category Gigant, Filch Power Ranking High (no numeric score on file) Control 7/10 Hostility 0/10 Collateral Damage 7/10 Threat Level 4/10

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Immunity to Electrocution — An intrinsic biological trait classified under the Gigant category. Professor Franklin was virtually impervious to all forms of electric shocks, up to and including natural lightning strikes. He also appeared to act as a lightning rod during storms and adverse weather conditions, though this effect was difficult to discern except statistically. Classification: G4/SE/P/T.
  • Electrokinetic Storage and Discharge — Could accumulate electrical energy within his body and discharge it at will, tied to his electrocution immunity. He could release stored energy as lightning bolts over considerable distances. While his aiming was largely restricted to his understanding of electric conductance and grounding principles, the power's range was classified as Visual (V) due to its reach. Classification: F7/SO/P/V.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• His aiming ability for electrical discharges was imprecise, relying on his understanding of conductance and grounding rather than fine control. This reduced the versatility of his offensive capabilities.
  • The imprecise nature of his electrokinetic discharges posed substantial risk to bystanders and infrastructure when used at high intensities, contributing to a collateral damage rating of 7/10.
  • He had lifelong deficits to his grip strength and use of his left arm from a childhood injury sustained defending his sister.
  • He carried lifelong scarring and pain across his torso and arms from severe burns sustained in a 2001 superhuman conflict.
  • In his final years, he showed signs of emotional and physical fatigue from the mounting demands of leadership and combat.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• BSc in Physics from Temple University (Class of 2003), providing a strong scientific foundation that informed his combat methodology and mentorship approach.
  • Former public high school science educator, skilled in teaching and mentoring young people.
  • Devised support items and practical methods to utilize his electrical powers in non-destructive ways, compensating for his aiming limitations.
  • Introduced innovative cape-fighting methods that were adopted by local police forces and was tapped for tutoring in anti-superhuman tactics by multiple police departments.
  • Began attending therapy in 2014 and developed an interest in psychology, incorporating therapeutic techniques into his mentorship style and approach to his rogues' gallery.
  • Maintained personal intelligence on local villains, knowing Shrike's real name (Niles) and subduing him with a precision electrical shock to the neck during the 2015 Strawberry Mansion incident, then zip-tying him for containment transport.
  • Wore professional, up-to-date Kevlar under a white lab coat with fingerless gloves and round glasses as his costume.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Professor Franklin was calm, strategic, and deeply supportive as both a hero and a mentor. He approached superhero work with thoughtfulness and precision, emphasizing preparation and scientific knowledge in combat. He was known for turning serious situations into teaching moments, famously asking his proteges "What did you learn?" after mistakes rather than admonishing them. He stressed the importance of public perception and how superhero conduct impacts policy and legislation. He advised Diane that her alias "Breakout" reflected destruction rather than protection and shared the Benjamin Franklin quote: "By failing to prepare, you're preparing to fail." His ethical grounding was unquestioned, reflected in a hostility rating of zero and a demonstrated compassion even toward his most vicious enemies.

Beyond his heroic work, Jeffery was a community-minded individual who organized outreach programs to reintegrate former criminals, including reformed supervillains. He attended therapy to manage the mounting stress of his responsibilities and used the techniques he learned to develop greater empathy and stewardship. His rational, multifaceted approach to crime-fighting -- combining direct intervention, preventive initiatives, and mentorship -- set a standard for what a Registered Superhuman Entity should be, according to his PERKS liaison Officer Thompson.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• His alias "Professor Franklin" is a tribute to Benjamin Franklin and his famous kite experiment, connecting his electrical powers to Philadelphia's most famous scientist.
  • His date of birth on the NSRA postcognitive background assessment is listed as March 5, 1981, while the detailed timeline lists December 31, 1981. The detailed timeline is treated as authoritative.
  • His father's nickname was "Knuckle Sandwich," reflecting his boxing career.
  • He was the youngest of three children.
  • Comic books instilled in him an early sense of right and wrong at age six.
  • He testified in Washington, D.C. during the proceedings regarding "United Superhumans v. Department of Defense" in 2013.
  • His PERKS file was formally closed on February 2, 2018. The NSRA post-cognitive team updated and closed his full file on July 30, 2018, confirming no posthumous activities or indications of resurrection.
  • The character reference guide lists his death year as 2015, but the detailed NSRA timeline and all narrative sources consistently place his death on December 19, 2017.
  • His funeral on a snowy day in 2017 drew an unprecedented crowd to Strawberry Mansion, including East Coast superheroes, former students, and ordinary Philadelphians.
  • He died in the rain, as recalled by Liberty Belle during her eulogy when she broke down crying at the memory of holding him as he passed.
  • His postcognitive background assessment was contributed to by five RSE specialists: Emily "Seeker" Thompson, Marcus "Elder" Johnson, Zara "Reminisce" Evans, Allison "Echo" Smith, and Dr. Ethan "Puzzler" Rogers.
  • A New Year's Eve incident in 2012 caused a brief crisis of faith, haunting him with the idea that he could not save more lives despite minimizing the death toll.

docs.title: Jordan Westwood
docs.text: Sam Small's former adversary turned best friend and co-founder of the Auditors, a non-binary spatial manipulator now attending MIT and interning at the Department of Applied Anomalous Sciences.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Jordan Anise Westwood Aliases Safeguard, Avery (birth name, deadname) Date of Birth Approximately early February 2007 Age 16–18 Gender Non-binary (they/them) Ethnicity Unknown Place of Birth Unknown (Philadelphia area) Residence MIT campus, Cambridge, MA (formerly the abandoned Tacony Music Hall, Philadelphia, PA) Affiliation Auditors (co-founder), Department of Applied Anomalous Sciences (DAAS) Former Affiliations N/A Occupation College student (MIT), DAAS intern Status Active First Appearance Chapter 7 Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Jordan Westwood grew up in the Tacony neighborhood of Philadelphia under the care of a neglectful and abusive mother. Their home life was marked by chronic neglect, including being forgotten on birthdays and left without food. Jordan's powers manifested during a traumatic childhood incident in which they were accidentally locked in a car trunk and nearly died, the extreme duress triggering their spatial manipulation abilities for the first time. Their mother responded to these abilities with disgust, calling Jordan a "freak" and a "monster," and CPS was involved at some point during Jordan's upbringing.

Jordan adopted the alias Safeguard, naming themselves after an antagonist from the manga "BLAME!" They first appeared in the story as a mysterious figure in a black cloak and white motorcycle helmet who warped the interior of a Walgreens during Sam Small's first patrol with the Young Defenders in August 2023. After Sam identified Jordan as a fellow student at Tacony Charter Academy High School, Jordan proposed that the two stage fake superhero fights to gain public notoriety. While scouting a location for their planned performance at the abandoned Dobson Textile Factory, they accidentally witnessed members of the Kingdom of Keys force Mudslide to murder a captive. Both barely escaped with their lives, and the shared trauma forged a genuine partnership.

Following the factory incident, Jordan and Sam established a headquarters in the abandoned Tacony Music Hall in Tacony, Philadelphia, where Jordan also began living to escape their mother's home. They co-founded the Auditors, a small investigative team dedicated to exposing the Kingdom of Keys and confronting government corruption. Jordan served as the team's primary technical specialist, handling intelligence analysis, electronic surveillance, digital infrastructure, and strategic planning. Their abusive mother tracked them to the Music Hall on two separate occasions, the second resulting in a permanent severing of their relationship after Jordan confronted their mother about years of neglect. Jordan received a full scholarship to MIT and departed Philadelphia for the university's summer program, transferring leadership of the Auditors to Sam. At MIT, Jordan began interning at the Department of Applied Anomalous Sciences, a government think tank that studies metahuman abilities, where their supervisor Dr. Famiglietti praised them for having "exceptional intuition for spatial dynamics." Jordan's unique ability to duplicate sealed rooms made them an invaluable research asset, allowing scientists to precisely measure what happens when AOM (Anomalously Originated Material) is created and destroyed in controlled environments. Jordan was published as fourth author on a groundbreaking preprint paper proposing the "quantum mirage" theory of AOM — the hypothesis that superhuman powers create material by overlaying quantum-entangled copies of nearby matter molecule by molecule, frame by frame, rather than generating genuinely new mass. Jordan was considering switching their major from Computer Science to Dynology, or pursuing a dual major, driven by their growing fascination with the science of superhuman abilities.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file. Jordan does not hold a LUMA (License to Utilize Metahuman Abilities) and has historically denied having powers when confronted by authorities. NSRA agents connected reports of a vigilante called "Safeguard" to Jordan but were unable to obtain proof.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Spatial Manipulation (Enclosed Spaces) — Can manipulate the spatial dimensions within enclosed spaces, either expanding them by duplicating the space or compressing them by "cutting" the space. Compressed space re-appears when Jordan deactivates their powers. Objects duplicated by the expansion effect tend to dissolve into ash over time.
  • Multi-Region Control — Can maintain spatial manipulation across up to three distinct regions simultaneously.
  • Living Being Exclusion — Jordan's powers inherently ignore living beings, meaning spatial compression and expansion do not directly harm people. However, environmental effects of the manipulation (such as collapsing structures or shifting concrete) can still cause indirect harm.
  • Spatial Compression Combat Applications — Can compress space to sever structural elements (demonstrated by compressing space to sever a staircase and drop an opponent), block escape routes, and create tactical advantages in enclosed environments. Compressed space can disintegrate inanimate objects caught within it (demonstrated when a thrown can dissolved into ash).
  • Spatial Expansion Utility — Can expand the interior of small spaces to create hidden areas, such as turning a cardboard box into a concealed observation post large enough for multiple people to hide inside.
  • AOM Research Applications — Jordan's spatial expansion creates measurable AOM in laboratory conditions, making them uniquely valuable to DAAS. When Jordan expands a sealed chamber, objects within it are duplicated exactly, though these duplicates vanish if jostled too hard. Scientists can measure everything about the extra space and the duplicated objects, providing controlled data on AOM behavior that is otherwise extremely difficult to obtain, since most AOM (fire, force fields, etc.) is not easily placed under a microscope.
  • Distance Manipulation — Can manipulate perceived and actual distance within their field of effect, making running toward or away from them ineffective within an enclosed area.
  • Lock Manipulation — Demonstrated the ability to open padlocks and locks using spatial manipulation (described as using a "wave rake"), suggesting fine-scale control over small enclosed mechanisms.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Enclosed Spaces Only — Powers function only within enclosed or semi-enclosed spaces. Open-air environments appear to limit or negate Jordan's abilities.
  • Three-Region Limit — Cannot manipulate more than three spatial regions at once.
  • Living Being Exclusion — Cannot directly affect living organisms with spatial manipulation, limiting offensive applications to environmental and structural manipulation.
  • No LUMA — Operates without legal authorization to use metahuman abilities, placing them at constant legal risk.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Exceptional computer science and technical aptitude, sufficient to earn a full scholarship to MIT. Published as fourth author on a physics paper while still a freshman, working under Dr. Famiglietti at DAAS. Considering switching to Dynology or dual-majoring.
  • Proficient in electronic surveillance, counter-surveillance, and digital security. Built homemade bug-detection devices, set up Faraday cages, established encrypted communications, and defended against DDoS attacks on the Auditors' whistleblower website.
  • Skilled investigator with expertise in open-source intelligence, public records analysis, financial forensics, and social engineering. Identified shell company networks linking the Kingdom of Keys to legitimate businesses and government entities.
  • Competent in basic lockpicking, which they taught to Sam and Spindle.
  • Drone operation experience through their friend Alex.
  • Proficient in data encryption and decryption, including working with pirated biochemistry software to partially decrypt Kingdom USB drives.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Jordan is witty, sarcastic, and deeply intellectual, frequently referencing obscure anime and peppering their speech with pop culture allusions and technical jargon. They approach problems analytically and maintain emotional distance through humor, rarely allowing vulnerability to surface. They would never describe themselves as a "superhero," preferring to frame their work in practical, anti-establishment terms. Jordan is fiercely loyal to those within their inner circle but guards that loyalty behind layers of deflection and banter.

Despite their intellectual confidence, Jordan struggles with impostor syndrome at MIT, admitting to Sam that they keep waiting for "the other shoe to drop" and for someone to figure out they do not belong there and escort them off campus. When asked directly if they were happy, Jordan responded tentatively that they thought they were, a notable admission for someone who deflects most emotional vulnerability through humor. They described the work as interesting, the people as "mostly not assholes," and their own lab space — a closet, but their closet — as a point of quiet pride.

Beneath the sardonic exterior, Jordan carries significant emotional weight from years of parental abuse and neglect. They struggled with guilt after Sam was hospitalized following the Chernobyl fight, avoiding visiting for months before admitting they felt unable to face Sam's injuries. Jordan has described Sam as a sibling and credited Sam's influence as transformative in their life. Their relationship with authority is deeply skeptical, informed both by their mother's failures and by witnessing government complicity with criminal organizations. Despite this, Jordan has demonstrated a pragmatic willingness to collaborate with institutions when the situation demands it, as shown by their acceptance of the DAAS internship and their cooperation with Agent Torres.

docs.title: Arc Appearances
docs.text: Book Role Key Events Book 1: Pup Supporting Introduced as the mysterious villain Safeguard who warps space inside a Walgreens during Sam's first patrol. Sam identifies Jordan as a classmate and they plan staged fights. While scouting the Dobson Textile Factory, they witness a Kingdom murder and barely escape. Jordan's friend Alex captures drone footage of the crime. Book 2: Keys Supporting Partners with Sam as a vigilante, establishing the Tacony Music Hall as their headquarters. They confront the Coyotes gang, with Jordan stealing drugs and money. Jordan and Sam infiltrate the Crescent nightclub on an undercover mission for Crossroads. Jordan visits Sam's home to meet her parents. The Kingdom attacks the Small home in retaliation. Book 3: Dybbuk Supporting Hides at the Tacony Music Hall to protect their mother from Kingdom retaliation. Reconnects with Sam and participates in the Halloween warehouse infiltration alongside Sam, Jamila, and Spinelli, gathering intelligence on Kingdom operations. Presents extensive documentation of Kingdom shell companies to allied heroes. Declines an offer to join the heroes officially. Book 4: Exorcism Supporting Part of the Auditors during the formation of the team. Confronted by their abusive mother at the Music Hall, who reveals Jordan's birth name "Avery" and mocks their gender identity. Sam punches Mrs. Westwood in Jordan's defense. The team adopts the name "The Auditors" at Miasma's suggestion. Jordan establishes digital infrastructure, discovers surveillance bugs, and implements counter-surveillance measures at the Music Hall. Book 5: Mayfly Supporting Conducts surveillance of a suspected NSRA facility and analyzes intelligence from Agent Torres. Accompanies Sam and Spindle into the abandoned subway tunnels beneath Philadelphia, where they are ambushed by Mr. ESP and Mr. Mudslide. Jordan is injured by brick shards during the confrontation. The team faces Mrs. Westwood's second visit, resulting in the permanent severing of Jordan's relationship with their mother after Jordan reveals their powers were activated by nearly dying in a car trunk. Intermission 4.5: Amnion Supporting Visits Sam in the hospital in mid-April after months of guilt-driven absence, admitting they were overwhelmed by fear of losing Sam and unable to face her injuries. Reveals they tracked down the Music Hall's owner and secured a rental agreement using their college fund, providing approximately four months of rent. Describes Sam as a sibling and the two reconcile, reaffirming their bond as chosen family. Jordan partially hopes Sam's return to action will fund continued operations. Sam confides details of her support group, and Jordan offers to tail the mysterious member Derek but ultimately does not. Book 6: Sideshow Supporting Brings a mysterious USB drive during a visit with Alex. Book 7: Security Supporting Operates the Tacony Music Hall as a secret base with converted dressing rooms serving as living quarters and workspace. Records Officer Ridley's assault on a student in Chapter 102, providing video evidence. Discovers Patty's Bar as a police hangout connected to school security guards. Infiltrates Patty's Bar with Sam on September 13 and encounters Patriot and Egalitarian in the parking lot. Co-creates the anonymous whistleblower website with Sam, Derek, and Spindle, distributing QR codes through school bathrooms. Defends the site against DDOS attacks. Subtly uses space-warping powers to help Mike Giannopoulos during a fight with security guard Kowalski. Present at the Tacony Music Hall when Sam and Maggie arrive fleeing Zero's power-negation field. Programs the timed evidence upload to coincide with the homecoming dance. At the dance, evades Patriot's arrest attempt using space-manipulation, escaping through Egalitarian's vertigo field (which does not affect powered individuals). Becomes a fugitive with an active warrant for cybercrimes, domestic terrorism, unlicensed use of superpowers, and petty theft. The whistleblower website is taken down via legal injunction, though Jordan retains backups. Referenced by Sam during the congressional testimony as a symbol of unjust persecution. Book 8: Big Supporting Leads investigation into Kingdom drug operations involving Jump and Fly. Provides intelligence on Squeal's identity and coordinates stakeout operations. Uses spatial manipulation to create concealed observation posts and control battlefields. Coordinates with Sam on surveillance of Kingdom properties and infiltration of the Crescent nightclub. Book 9: Sheol Supporting Receives a full MIT scholarship, representing a path toward a conventional future. Finds Sam in the library after her panic attack at the fire (Ch. 137) and confronts her at 5 AM about who she is without the mask. Investigates the series of fires alongside Sam, mapping a pattern around Tacony Charter Academy (Ch. 139). Uses space manipulation to evacuate civilians from a burning coffee shop (Ch. 138). Hits Aaron with a baseball bat during the Music Hall break-in (Ch. 144). Accompanies the group to Kalahari water park in the Poconos after Aaron's arrest (RS.2). Book 10: Plume Supporting Introduces a police scanner and has an emotional conversation with Sam about the looming MIT departure (Ch. 150). Investigates Rogue Wave activity with Sam, finding pepper-sprayed drug dealers and evidence of coordinated vigilante activity (Ch. 150). Deliberately provokes Officer Ridley, exposing him as a Rogue Wave sleeper agent through the contract system (Ch. 159). Leads the Auditors' infiltration of the Stheno Pharmaceuticals warehouse, stealing USB drives with critical intelligence before the warehouse is destroyed by Soot's chemical chain reaction (Chs. 161–164). Provides spatial compression for the team's escape. Book 11: Alarm Will Sound Supporting Leads post-warehouse debrief; reveals the stolen USB drives are encrypted with military-grade RSA keys containing dense biochemical data beyond the team's capability (Ch. 165). Joins remotely via video call to assist with decryption and intelligence analysis. Discusses encryption limitations with Devonte at Chambers & Woo and transfers approximately 200 GB of Kingdom-related data to the PI server (Chs. 167–168). Mentions interning at the Department of Applied Anomalous Sciences near MIT, implied to have received the scholarship because of their powers. At the farewell party at the Music Hall (Ch. 177), reveals they and Connor never actually broke up. Formally transfers all Auditors leadership and Music Hall administration to Sam. Departs Philadelphia for MIT's summer program by Greyhound bus. Book 12: Authorized Personnel Only Supporting Provides remote intelligence from MIT. Reports significant developments near the MIT campus during the Bloom crisis, including police kettling protesters before an explosion. Relays observations about MIT security conducting sweeps of technology labs. Communicates with Sam via HIRC when regular networks become overloaded. Book 13: Burn After Reading Supporting Assists remotely by sorting 300+ evidence photos into 47 usable images documenting organized crime infrastructure. Drafts media packages for the Philadelphia Inquirer. Helps coordinate the team's public exposure of Kingdom financial evidence through CapeWatch Philly. Manages the Auditors' online presence. Book 14: Shelter in Place Supporting Participates in the gambit against the Kingdom from the Tacony-Palmyra Bridge, using spatial manipulation to keep Akilah and Devonte hidden while Akilah fakes Brainwash's commands with her invisible strings. Video calls the team to discuss Music Hall repairs, Connor's GED progress, and college applications. Jordan's earlier exposure of Rogue Wave's contract vulnerability forces Lawrence Sullivan to revise the system, described as "evolutionary pressure." Book 15: Severe Weather Warning Mentioned Referenced remotely. Assists with evidence organization and timeline analysis. Jordan confirms all lost research from the Music Hall attack can be reconstructed from public records. Intermission 15.5: This Side Up Interlude (JW.2) Text conversation between Jordan and Sam. Jordan excitedly announces their co-authorship (fourth author) on a preprint paper proposing the "quantum mirage" theory of AOM — that superhuman powers create material by overlaying quantum-entangled copies of nearby matter frame by frame, and AOM dissolves not through decay but by the overlay ceasing to be maintained. Jordan explains the science to Sam using movie frame and photograph analogies, describing how AOM "telefrags" (overwrites) existing matter in place rather than displacing or transmuting it, and how this resolves the longstanding air chamber paradox in AOM research. Jordan references a teenage girl with laser eyes who worked with DAAS as a prior research subject, and mentions the "vermiform appendage" that likely mediates AOM creation in all superhumans. Jordan reveals they are considering switching their major from Computer Science to Dynology or dual-majoring, admits to impostor syndrome at MIT while tentatively acknowledging happiness, and describes their own lab space. Jordan mentions Dr. Famiglietti's praise and Dr. Harris guest-lecturing at MIT and remembering Sam fondly. Jordan notes Sam is "getting better at opsec" after Sam deflects questions about a city councilwoman's alibi manufacturing operation being exposed. The two plan to hang out during summer break, possibly with Connor. Jordan mentions Connor's foster family being "really protective, in a good way." Sam mentions her ankle monitor recently came off. The conversation ends with mutual affection and purple heart emojis.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Jordan named themselves "Safeguard" after an antagonist from the manga "BLAME!" by Tsutomu Nihei, as discovered by Sam's friend Marcus during research.
  • Their birth name is Avery, which their mother used repeatedly during confrontations to invalidate their identity. Their middle name is Anise.
  • Jordan's initial appearance featured a black cloak and a white motorcycle helmet, giving them a villainous aesthetic before their true nature was revealed.
  • They were eating cold Chef Boyardee from a can when Sam first observed them at the school lunch table, hinting at their neglectful home situation.
  • Jordan used their college fund to pay rent on the Tacony Music Hall, converting it from a squatter hideout into a legitimate base of operations.
  • They have approximately $13,000 in savings from unspecified "night jobs" as of early 2024.
  • Jordan has a fondness for anime and frequently discusses it with their friend Alex and other school friends.
  • The students and teachers of Tacony Charter Academy rallied in a "Spartacus moment" during the homecoming dance, all claiming to be Jordan Westwood when Patriot attempted to arrest them.
  • Jordan paid for taxi rides with hundred-dollar bills during the team's trip to investigate the NSRA office in Hatboro.
  • They taught Sam and Spindle basic lockpicking and established regular counter-surveillance sweeps at the Music Hall using homemade detection equipment.
  • Jordan's 17th birthday fell in early February 2024, shortly after the second confrontation with their mother.
  • The DAAS internship is implied to have been offered specifically because of Jordan's spatial manipulation abilities, with the scholarship serving as an incentive.
  • Jordan described their lab space at MIT as "basically a closet but it's MY closet."
  • When explaining AOM science to Sam, Jordan used the analogy of movie frames, photograph overlays, and the Cottingley Fairies hoax of 1917 — which Sam had never heard of. Jordan was exasperated to learn Sam considered molecular formulas to be "math."
  • Jordan used the video game term "telefragged" to describe how AOM overwrites existing matter in place, a characteristically geeky metaphor.
  • Jordan referenced Aaron McKinley's fire powers as an example of unsolved AOM questions, wondering how he creates a flash-igniting substance without a "Fire Pouch."
  • Jordan mentioned that the catchphrase between them and Sam — "Don't make it weird" — was used by both during the JW.2 conversation, a symmetry neither acknowledged.
  • Jordan admitted to having done only 40% of required reading for a lab meeting, planning to read the rest during the walk over.

docs.title: Joseph Jones
docs.text: Member of the Philly Phreaks with a complete stone physiology, currently incarcerated at the Daedalus Correctional Facility for his role in the courthouse terrorist attack.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Joseph Jones Aliases Pumice Date of Birth Unknown Age Late teens to early 20s Gender Male Ethnicity Unknown Place of Birth Philadelphia, PA (presumed) Residence Daedalus Correctional Facility Affiliation Philly Phreaks Former Affiliations N/A Occupation N/A Status Incarcerated First Appearance Chapter 32 Last Appearance Chapter 99

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Joseph Jones, known as Pumice, is a metahuman who underwent a complete transformation into a humanoid entity composed entirely of mobile, motile stone. The circumstances surrounding his activation event are not documented in available records. His stone physiology is permanent and constantly active, leaving him as a hulking figure covered in dark grey rock with a surface roughness equivalent to 24-grit sandpaper. He weighs approximately 630 pounds.

Pumice was a member of the Philly Phreaks, a gang of visually apparent metahumans operating in Philadelphia. He participated in the Phreaks' confrontation with the Young Defenders on South Street, where he fought Rampart and other heroes before fleeing alongside Chrysalis when fellow member Spindle betrayed the group. Following the arrest of the Phreaks' leader Patches, Pumice was recruited by Aaron McKinley into an alliance against Sam Small. He participated in the kidnapping and torture of Sam during winter of 2023, though he expressed visible discomfort with Aaron's sadistic methods. Sam damaged his stone face during her escape, and the Phreaks subsequently severed ties with Aaron, with Pumice punching him when Aaron attempted to threaten Chrysalis.

Pumice later reappeared at LOVE Park during the crisis involving the mutagenic drug Jump, attacking Sam and Rampart before escaping on the back of Elias (Chimera). His involvement in the Phreaks' terrorist attack at the Philadelphia courthouse during the Fedorov trial ultimately led to his arrest. He was subdued through the combined efforts of Playback, Spindle, and Gale, and was subsequently incarcerated at the Daedalus Correctional Facility.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: Field Value Classification G6/S/P/T (primary), E5/S/P/T (secondary), A1/S/P/T (tertiary) Category Gigant (primary), Employ (secondary), Adjust (tertiary) Power Ranking 6/10 (Gigant), 5/10 (Employ), 1/10 (Adjust) Control 9/10 Hostility 7/10 Collateral Damage 6/10 Threat Level 6/10

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Stone Physiology — Pumice's entire body, both internal and external, has been converted into a highly abrasive and porous stone material. His stone composition has a Mohs hardness rating of 6.5, comparable to quartz, granting exceptional durability and resistance to physical damage. Most melee weapons and many conventional firearms are incapable of doing meaningful damage.
  • Abrasive Surface — His body has a measured surface roughness of approximately 24-grit on the CAMI scale, making his skin extremely coarse. Physical contact with his body can rapidly abrade and damage organic and inorganic materials alike, grating off several layers of skin on contact and causing numerous small cuts capable of rapid blood loss.
  • Enhanced Strength — Possesses proportional enhanced strength that allows him to move and operate at speeds comparable to a normal human despite weighing approximately 630 pounds. Capable of hurling people, lifting and dragging vehicles, and overpowering most opponents in hand-to-hand combat.
  • Stone Regeneration — Limited ability to heal damage to his stone body by absorbing inorganic materials such as concrete or grout. These materials are slowly converted into new stone tissue when applied to chips, cracks, or other damage.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Porous Vulnerability — His porous stone composition makes him susceptible to corrosive agents and chemical attacks. Strong acids or bases could potentially penetrate his stone matrix and cause widespread internal damage.
  • Slow Regeneration — His regenerative process is extremely slow, even slower than normal human healing. Minor chips or cracks require hours or days to heal, while severe damage may take weeks or months.
  • Repair Material Dependency — Regeneration relies on the availability of suitable inorganic materials. Without access to concrete, grout, or similar substances, his healing process halts.
  • Weight and Mobility — At approximately 630 pounds, he can have difficulty navigating narrow spaces, fragile structures, or unstable terrain.
  • Biological Requirements — Despite his stone composition, Pumice still requires food, water, and sleep. He avoids acidic food and drink. It is currently unknown whether he still possesses internal organs, a skeleton, or a brain.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• No formal combat training is documented. Relies on raw physical power and durability in fights.
  • Shows awareness of how to use his abrasive surface offensively in close-quarters combat, including smothering bear hugs designed to scrape opponents.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Pumice views his criminal actions as a necessary response to societal marginalization and injustice, expressing little remorse for his involvement in terrorist activities while simultaneously showing a noted desire to see a "body count." He is blunt and direct in conversation, preferring to get straight to the point and dismissing what he considers unnecessary drama. Despite his willingness to engage in violence, he demonstrated visible discomfort during Aaron McKinley's torture of Sam Small, suggesting limits to his tolerance for cruelty even if he did not intervene.

Outside of criminal activity, Pumice has a strong interest in Philadelphia sports, particularly the Phillies and Sixers. He was frequently seen wearing Allen Iverson and Sixers jerseys, and was willing to engage in casual sports conversation even with adversaries. His containment procedures at Daedalus note that updates on Philadelphia professional sports teams and approved sports paraphernalia serve as effective behavioral incentives.

docs.text:

  • His containment procedures at Daedalus were prepared by Dr. Ethan Novak and approved by Warden Elizabeth Hold, with NSRA liaison Agent Marcus Lee.
  • His containment unit uses ultra-high-performance concrete or steel-fiber-reinforced concrete, with vibration sensors to detect attempts to wear down the walls.
  • High-pressure quick-hardening foam dispensers are installed in his cell as an immobilization measure.
  • A carefully controlled supply of inorganic repair materials is provided in his containment unit to facilitate his regeneration.
  • Spindle refers to him casually as "Joe" in conversation with other heroes.
  • His surface areas vary in roughness, with his palms, the soles of his feet, and facial stone being smoother than the rest of his body.
  • His Daedalus inmate number is 84928166.
