docs.title: Joshua Clark
docs.text: Second-in-command and intellectual powerhouse of the Tacony Titans, a sleep-manipulating metahuman who serves as the team's tactical planner, financial backer, and night watchman.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Joshua Clark Aliases Sandman Date of Birth Unknown Age 18 Gender Male Ethnicity Black Place of Birth Unknown (likely Philadelphia, PA) Residence Tacony, Philadelphia, PA Affiliation Tacony Titans (Second-in-Command) Former Affiliations N/A Occupation Student, Vigilante Status Active First Appearance Chapter 13 (mentioned); Chapter 80 (on-page) Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Joshua Clark is an eighteen-year-old metahuman operating in Northeast Philadelphia under the alias Sandman. He serves as the second-in-command of the Tacony Titans, a young vigilante team led by Sundial that patrols the Tacony and surrounding neighborhoods. The Tacony Titans were first referenced by Sam Small's school friends in September 2023, when Lilly Rodriguez mentioned her father had encountered the local team. At that time, the Titans' roster included Bubble, Compass, Weave, Sandman, and Sundial. By the time the Auditors formally encountered the Titans in late April 2024, the team had shifted membership, with Moonshot replacing Weave.

Joshua comes from an upper-middle-class household with parents described as "Blunt Black Academic" types who emphasized intellectual rigor and educational achievement. This upbringing instilled in him a voracious reading habit and a sharp analytical mind, both of which he channels into the team's tactical operations. His natural resistance to unconsciousness grants him extended waking hours, which he uses to read extensively and serve as the Titans' overnight sentry, keeping their base secure during the hours when the rest of the team sleeps. He also functions as the team's primary financial backer, using his family's resources to fund their operations.

Physically, Joshua is described as scrawny with short dreadlocks. Despite his slight build, he has proven himself a capable field operative through creative applications of his sleep-manipulation powers, most notably his ability to control the movements of sleeping bodies -- including directing the werewolf Derek Taylor during combat operations by riding on his back and puppeteering his unconscious form.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Somnipathy (Sleep-Body Manipulation) -- Can manipulate the bodily movements of sleeping people, effectively puppeteering their physical actions while they remain unconscious. This power extends to any sleeping individual within his range, allowing him to direct their movements with precision sufficient for coordinated combat.
  • Self-Somnambulism -- Can manipulate his own body while asleep, enabling him to remain physically active and functional even during periods of unconsciousness.
  • Unconsciousness Resistance -- Possesses a natural resistance to being rendered unconscious, whether through fatigue, sedation, or external forces. This allows him to maintain extended periods of wakefulness far beyond normal human limits.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Joshua's combat applications are dependent on the availability of sleeping subjects to manipulate; without them, his offensive capability is significantly reduced.
  • His scrawny physical build offers no enhanced durability or strength, making him vulnerable in direct physical confrontations.
  • The precise range and upper limit of subjects he can simultaneously control are not documented.
  • Specific conditions required for his power to function (e.g., whether targets must be in natural sleep versus drug-induced unconsciousness) are not established in the narrative.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Extensively self-educated through marathon reading sessions enabled by his resistance to unconsciousness, giving him a broad base of knowledge applicable to tactical planning and strategic analysis.
  • Serves as the Tacony Titans' primary tactician and strategic planner, working closely with Sundial to coordinate team operations.
  • Experienced in surveillance and sentry duty, having conducted solo overnight watches of the Titans' base as well as external locations such as Sam Small's neighborhood during the Aaron McKinley arson crisis.
  • Capable of disguise and covert observation, as demonstrated when he posed as a homeless person to monitor Sam's street undetected.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Joshua is sarcastic and sharp-tongued, serving as the Tacony Titans' resident cynic. He speaks with a dry, cutting wit and does not shy away from blunt assessments of situations or people. Despite this abrasive exterior, he is deeply protective of his teammates and genuinely committed to the Titans' mission of defending their neighborhood. He occupies a role within the team that has been compared to Batman -- the intellectual without the flashiest powers who compensates with preparation, funding, and tactical acumen.

He struggles with moral dilemmas related to his powers, particularly the ethical implications of controlling other people's bodies without their conscious consent. This tension between utility and ethics is a recurring undercurrent in his characterization. When the Argus Corps' Safer Streets Initiative began targeting underage heroes with bounties, Joshua was among those who suggested standing down entirely, reflecting a pragmatic streak that sometimes conflicts with the more action-oriented members of both the Titans and the Auditors. He is book-smart and tactical, and his extended waking hours give him an unusual perspective -- he is often the one watching while everyone else sleeps, a solitary role that reinforces both his value to the team and his emotional distance from it.

docs.title: Joshua Pleasants
docs.text: Boston-based superhero with high-grade regeneration and perpetual decomposition, former confidant of Liberty Belle, and covert mole inside Argus Corps working to expose Maya Richardson as Mrs. Zenith of the Kingdom of Keys.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Joshua Pleasants Aliases Miasma Date of Birth Unknown Age Early 30s (was 22 at time of Activation Event) Gender Male Ethnicity Unknown Place of Birth Boston, Massachusetts Residence Philadelphia, PA (multiple safehouses); maintains safehouses in Boston and New York Affiliation Argus Corps (covert mole) Former Affiliations Independent hero (Boston); informal ally of Liberty Belle and the Auditors Occupation Registered Superhuman Entity (Argus Corps member) Status Active First Appearance Chapter 46 (mentioned as will beneficiary); Chapter 48 (first on-page appearance) Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Joshua Pleasants is a metahuman from Boston whose powers activated at the moment of his death, triggering a high-grade regeneration ability that restored him to a state of perpetual biological function while leaving his body in a constant cycle of decay and renewal. The result is an individual who is, by all practical definitions, a walking corpse that cannot die again. His heart beats approximately eight to twelve times per minute but does not circulate blood effectively; his blood has coagulated into a pudding-like sludge that oozes rather than flows. It remains unclear even to him how his brain continues to operate, as he has survived headshot wounds. The regeneration process produces an overwhelming stench of decomposition, which Pleasants contains by wearing a neon-yellow hazmat suit, sometimes augmented with a zombie mask and a black cloak overtop.

As revealed in Interlude JP.2, Pleasants was diagnosed with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) at age 22 by Dr. Kessler, a neurologist in Boston. CJD is a fatal prion disease with an average survival time of four to six months from diagnosis. After informing his parents and sister (who flew in from Portland), Pleasants traveled to Mammoth Lakes, California, a volcanic region in the Eastern Sierra where carbon dioxide vents naturally through the soil at lethal concentrations. He located a small cave with elevated CO2 levels and, on day twelve of his trip, entered it with the intention of dying by asphyxiation. He survived over thirty minutes in the lethal atmosphere, his body spontaneously adapting to not require oxygen — a classic near-death Activation Event. Upon emerging, he discovered rapid regeneration: cuts sealed in approximately fifteen seconds, leaving no scars. He returned to Boston, where Dr. Kessler's subsequent testing revealed that the CJD was initially still progressing — protein markers were higher than ever, indicating neural destruction "incompatible with" his continued coherent consciousness — but his brain was simultaneously rebuilding itself, with healthy tissue appearing in areas previously devastated by spongiform changes while the disease "chased" the regenerating tissue to new regions. By day eighteen of his hospitalization, the protein markers dropped dramatically and the CJD was effectively outpaced by his regeneration, with new neural tissue filling in the damaged areas. However, Dr. Kessler emphasized that the replaced tissue was entirely new — not healed original neurons, but rebuilt replacements. On day twenty-three, hospital chemical sensors detected ammonia, hydrogen sulfide, and organic compounds emanating from his body, revealing the full scope of his condition: arrested decomposition. His digestive system functioned minimally, his circulatory system was practically inert, and his regeneration sustained him at the "minimum viable state" for consciousness and mobility while toxic byproducts accumulated and vented through his skin and breath. Specialists from the Department of Applied Anomalous Sciences (DAAS) and an organization called Aurora Springs assessed him, provided containment equipment (the hazmat suit), and discharged him with documentation of his registered metahuman status.

Two months after his discharge, Pleasants began operating as a vigilante in Baltimore, where he intervened in an armed robbery at a convenience store. The gunman shot him center-mass, rupturing his hazmat suit and releasing his decomposition gases into the enclosed space, incapacitating the attacker. During this incident, he met a vigilante named Breakout — a woman in a cheap domino mask and street clothes with an athletic build and steel-wool hair — who finished subduing the gunman and invited Pleasants for coffee at a nearby diner. Breakout was the first person outside of medical professionals and family to voluntarily spend time in his presence after his condition became unmanageable.

Pleasants was a friend and confidant of Diane Williams (Liberty Belle) during their college years. When Liberty Belle was killed by Chernobyl in December 2023, Pleasants traveled from Boston to Philadelphia for her funeral, where he delivered a eulogy, and attended the reading of her will, where he was named as a beneficiary. He remained in Philadelphia after Belle's death to continue her unfinished investigations, effectively inheriting her mission. He took a particular interest in looking after Sam Small, whom Belle had designated as her investigative successor.

Shortly after his arrival in Philadelphia, Pleasants became an early ally to Sam. When NSRA agents attempted to confiscate Liberty Belle's materials from Sam, Crossroads of the Young Defenders foresaw the trouble and contacted Pleasants to intervene. He arrived at Lily Chen's house, repelling the agents with his stench and legal knowledge, and then brought Sam to his temporary base at an abandoned pier near the Betsy Ross Bridge. There, he helped Sam process the implications of Chernobyl's government protection and proposed assembling a team to investigate. Though he clashed with the teenage Auditors over his ends-justify-the-means approach to the NSRA investigation, it was Pleasants who suggested the team name "The Auditors" and who ultimately conducted the solo raid on the NSRA's Hatboro-Horsham facility on their behalf.

In January 2024, the Kingdom of Keys framed Pleasants for the murder of four security guards at the NSRA office he had been investigating. Security footage appeared to show him inside the facility at the time of the killings. A citywide manhunt followed, with police, federal agencies, and vigilantes from other cities searching for him. The Auditors investigated and concluded the Kingdom was responsible for the frame-up, using their surveillance of the team's operations to orchestrate the false flag. Pleasants was eventually acquitted, but the incident left a permanent black mark on his record. Sam later advocated for clearing his name from her hospital bed after being injured by Chernobyl.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• High-Grade Regeneration — Possesses an extreme regenerative ability that renders him practically unkillable without depowering. His regeneration activated at the moment of death in a CO2-filled cave near Mammoth Lakes, California, where his body spontaneously adapted to survive lethal asphyxiation. The regeneration operates at such a fundamental level that it rebuilt his brain from CJD-induced spongiform destruction, replacing devastated neural tissue with new, healthy neurons faster than the prion disease could destroy them. Surface wounds (cuts, scrapes) heal in approximately fifteen seconds, leaving no scars. His body exists in a perpetual state of decay and recycling: tissue rots and is continuously replaced, sustaining biological function at the minimum viable threshold. He has survived headshot wounds and shows no signs of degradation over time.
  • Pain Immunity / Overexertion Tolerance — Does not experience pain in any meaningful way, allowing him to exert himself well beyond normal human limits without consequence. Pleasants himself identified this trait during his hospitalization, noting that his muscles no longer undergo lactic acid buildup normally, enabling him to recruit them at full capacity whenever needed. This makes him appear stronger than he actually is, as he can push his body to extremes that would incapacitate or injure a normal person.
  • Respiratory Independence — Does not require oxygen to survive. His lungs function mechanically (allowing speech, breathing, and coughing) but do not perform gas exchange in the normal human sense. This ability first manifested when he survived over thirty minutes in a CO2-saturated cave that should have killed him within ten minutes.
  • Toxic Gas Production — His decomposing body continuously generates noxious gases, which he contains within his hazmat suit. He can release these gases tactically in combat situations to flood enclosed spaces and incapacitate opponents, as demonstrated during the Stheno Pharmaceuticals warehouse confrontation.
  • Firebomb Improvisation — Can recycle and compress his own decomposition gases to create improvised incendiary devices.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Cannot build muscle mass; his regeneration reverts any gains from exercise, keeping his body in a fixed state of decay-renewal equilibrium. This means he cannot train to become physically stronger.
  • His overwhelming stench of decomposition makes stealth and social interaction extremely difficult. He requires a hazmat suit at all times to contain the odor.
  • His rotting condition prevents him from perceiving subtle flavors, requiring strong-tasting foods like kimchi and heavily spiced dishes.
  • While practically unkillable, depowering would presumably be fatal given his body's reliance on regeneration to sustain function.
  • His heart beats approximately eight to twelve times per minute, insufficient for effective circulation. His blood has coagulated into a pudding-like consistency and oozes rather than flows. His circulatory system is technically functional but practically inert.
  • His digestive system has minimal nutrient absorption. His regeneration compensates by pulling what it needs directly from the digestive tract, bypassing normal metabolic pathways entirely. He does not need to eat or excrete.
  • His liver and kidneys filter toxins, but the byproducts accumulate in his tissues and vent through his skin and breath: ammonia from protein breakdown, hydrogen sulfide from bacterial activity, methane in the digestive tract, and various volatile organic compounds from incomplete cellular processes. This is the source of his incapacitating stench.
  • DAAS specialists described his state as "arrested decomposition" — not rotting in the traditional sense, but failing to maintain homeostasis, with regeneration continuously resetting him to the minimum viable functional state.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Extensively self-educated across a wide range of disciplines, including criminal justice, international relations, metahuman law, Daedalus documentation, and geopolitics. Maintains an organized personal library at his safehouses covering subjects from the Federation of Saharan States to prison design philosophy.
  • Skilled interrogator, as demonstrated in his extraction of a confession from Elena Morales (Mrs. Doppelganger/Alice) at the Fishtown safehouse.
  • Trained in operational security: maintains multiple safehouses across cities (four in Philadelphia, six in Boston, two in New York), rotates locations, uses burner phones, and manages compartmentalized information.
  • Proficient in legal strategy, able to cite and apply legal frameworks in real time, as shown when he challenged the NSRA agents' authority during their attempt to seize Belle's materials.
  • Experienced in long-term covert operations, successfully maintaining his cover as a mole inside Argus Corps from its formation through the present.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Pleasants is a self-described curmudgeon whose abrasive exterior predates his powers; as the character reference guide notes, his abilities simply made the outside match the inside. He approaches the world through a rationalist lens, favoring Bayesian probability and utilitarian calculus in his decision-making. He is strongly anti-government as a matter of principle, viewing institutional power with deep skepticism regardless of which institution wields it. Despite this philosophical framework, he is not cold or detached. He maintains a long-term engagement (seven years), a wide circle of friends, and genuine emotional investment in the people he chooses to protect.

Interlude JP.2 revealed the depth of Pleasants' pragmatism in the face of his own mortality. When diagnosed with CJD at age 22, he responded with clinical detachment — asking his neurologist about the error bars on the diagnosis, processing the news through data rather than emotion, and spending the following two weeks on what he described as "administrative" preparation for death. He told his family he might not return from California, choosing a death on his own terms over the long decline into a vegetative state. When his Activation Event robbed him of that choice, his reaction was a bitter mixture of laughter and anguish — the absurdity of gaining immortality only to keep dying in a different way. He described his situation as having gotten "exactly what I wanted: survival," delivered with the dry resignation of someone who understands that the universe does not negotiate.

His intellectual rigor is his defining trait. Unable to exercise or engage in much conventional social interaction due to his condition, Pleasants devotes enormous amounts of time to reading and studying. He knows a little bit of everything and can contextualize local events within global patterns of metahuman politics and institutional power. He is pragmatic to a fault, willing to propose plans with "collateral damage" that horrify his younger allies, but he is also capable of deferring to their ethical objections. He compared Sam to Liberty Belle, noting the same "particular kind of insanity" that drives people to care about systemic injustice. He described that drive as "the flu" that makes people become superheroes. His relationship with Sam echoes and contrasts his relationship with Belle: where Belle was his peer, Sam is someone he mentors and protects, though he respects her autonomy and strategic instincts.

Provided Sam with multiple safehouses, supplies, operational funds, strategic guidance, and his extensive library during her fugitive period. Helped Sam deduce the existence of a Kingdom shapeshifter ("Alice") responsible for framing both of them. During the operation to capture Alice, evacuated "Maya" (actually Alice in disguise) to an unmarked car alongside Captain Devil. Intermission 15.5: This Side Up POV (Interlude JP.2) Full origin story. Diagnosed with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease at age 22 by Dr. Kessler in Boston. Informed his parents and sister, then traveled to Mammoth Lakes, California, intending to die by CO2 asphyxiation in a volcanic cave. On day twelve, entered the cave and lost consciousness, but survived over thirty minutes in a lethal atmosphere — his Activation Event. Discovered rapid regeneration upon emerging (wounds healing in fifteen seconds). Returned to Boston, where testing revealed the CJD was initially still progressing but his brain was simultaneously regenerating, creating new tissue faster than the prions could destroy it. Hospitalized for seizures starting eleven days after his return; experienced memory loss, confusion, and temporary inability to recognize his mother. By day eighteen, protein markers dropped and the CJD was outpaced by regeneration. On day twenty-three, hospital chemical sensors detected toxic gases emanating from his body, leading to a full assessment by DAAS and Aurora Springs specialists who diagnosed "arrested decomposition." Discharged with a hazmat suit and registered metahuman documentation. Two months later, began vigilante operations in Baltimore, where he stopped an armed robbery (absorbing a gunshot center-mass without meaningful injury), met the vigilante Breakout, and adopted the codename Miasma. Book 16: Category Five Hurricane Supporting Continues operating as a mole inside Argus Corps, nominally pursuing Sam while secretly working with her to take down Maya Richardson, whom he knows to be Mrs. Zenith of the Kingdom of Keys.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Pleasants' rationalist philosophical orientation is described as Bayesian/probability-focused utilitarianism. The character reference guide notes that Eliezer Yudkowsky was never born in the story's timeline, so the real-world rationalist movement as such does not exist, though Pleasants arrived at similar conclusions independently.
  • His personal expenses are minimal: rent paid annually, approximately one hundred dollars per month on food, with his superhero pay covering everything else. He leaves cash for Sam in ziplock bags labeled "Operational funds. Don't get robbed."
  • The news broadcast covering his NSRA frame-up mentioned a controversial 2018 raid in Lowell, Massachusetts as a prior incident in his career.
  • He eats kimchi and other strongly flavored foods because his rotting condition prevents him from tasting anything subtle.
  • His fiancee works at a funeral home, a detail Sam found darkly fitting given his condition. They have been engaged for seven years.
  • The character reference guide describes his situation as "not a tragedy," noting he would be living the same way without powers; he is simply unkillable now.
  • He has an interlude chapter from his point of view (Interlude JP.1), in which he interrogates Alice/Elena Morales and delivers the line: "Getting to her was never the outcome. We're after Mrs. Zenith."
  • Sam once awkwardly misinterpreted a "corpse paint" comment from Pleasants as a sex joke, when he was actually referencing a makeup subculture.
  • Interlude JP.2 reveals Pleasants intended to become a chemistry teacher before his CJD diagnosis.
  • His Activation Event location — a CO2-venting volcanic cave near Mammoth Lakes, California — was deliberately chosen for its lethality. He selected it after researching the geology and confirming that CO2 concentrations in certain depressions were high enough to kill animals and hikers.
  • His resting heart rate is approximately eight to twelve beats per minute, compared to the normal human range of sixty to one hundred.
  • DAAS specialists noted that his sperm count remained viable, meaning IVF remained a theoretical possibility despite his otherwise non-functional biological systems.
  • When his hazmat suit was ruptured by a gunshot during the Baltimore robbery, the released gases were described as a complex bouquet: fermenting organic acids, coagulated blood oxidizing on contact with air, ammonia, hydrogen sulfide, and anaerobic bacterial byproducts.
  • Pleasants described Breakout's immediate acceptance of his condition with notable surprise; she did not step back or gag upon seeing the ruptured suit, instead filing the information away and continuing to operate. Her first critique of him was that he was "monologuing."
  • The interlude's opening and closing passages are framed by song lyrics.

docs.title: Kate Smith
docs.text: Sam Small's childhood best friend turned solo vigilante, a gas-absorbing metahuman who operated as Miss Mayfly and later Soot before faking her death and relocating to Center City under a new identity.

docs.title: Infobox

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Kaitlyn "Kate" Smith grew up in the Mayfair neighborhood of Philadelphia, the daughter of Liam Smith, a single father who struggled with a gambling addiction and financial difficulties. Kate was a talented basketball player and one of Sam Small's closest childhood friends, part of a tight-knit group that included Marcus Johnson, Lilly Rodriguez, Tasha Reynolds, and Jenna Nguyen. She attended Abraham Lincoln High School, where she excelled on the basketball team and was known for her competitive athleticism and blunt personality.

Kate's metahuman abilities manifested during the events of Arc 9 ("Sheol"), when Aaron McKinley set fire to her family's house in Mayfair in February 2025. Kate was trapped upstairs and nearly died before Sam rescued her. The near-death experience triggered her gas absorption powers. The circumstances of the fire were ambiguous, as Kate was found with cuts along her arms that may have been self-inflicted, and she later described having visions of fire and smoke during her clinical death that led her to believe she was condemned to hell.

Following her recovery, Kate secretly became the vigilante Miss Mayfly, assembling Team Mayfly from her civilian friends to patrol Northeast Philadelphia, which she identified as being ignored by major superheroes as a place where "quiet" crime "festers unchallenged." The team consisted of Mite (tech expert controlling drones), Ant (tactical leader and programmer), Moth (medical support and chemistry), and Wasp (reconnaissance and emergency services communication). Kate changed into her gear in an alley behind "Tom's," her father's favorite pub, equipping herself with a taser glove, pepper spray dispenser, goggles, and mini-drones. The team's headquarters was Kate's own bedroom. During their first documented operation, they targeted a credit union robbery by criminals wearing knock-off superhero masks (Peregrine, Captain Steel, Railgun, Lady Justice), deploying military-grade stink bombs via drones within a coordinated 60-second operational window while Wasp called police. Kate suffered a crowbar strike to the ribs during the engagement, later assessed as "just a sprain with impressive bruising" by Moth. In a subsequent operation (MM.2), Team Mayfly conducted multi-day rotating surveillance of Sam and Jordan, identified the Dobson Mills warehouse in East Falls as a center of investigation, and expanded their drone fleet to 16 units (4 parent drones with 3 "child" drones each) equipped with LIDAR sensors and coordinated flight patterns. Moth developed paint bombs as distraction devices and studied warehouse blueprints with Wasp, identifying a skylight as a key entry point. The team deployed around the warehouse at sunset with Wasp and Moth on the roof, Mite and Ant in a "Mobile Control Unit," and Kate on the ground. Their intervention during the Dobson Mills operation was not random but a calculated attempt to assist Sam's team, though Kate's protective instinct and misjudgment of Sam's abilities created complications. When her identity was revealed during the warehouse battle in Arc 5, Kate's resentment over class differences and feelings of abandonment by Sam erupted into a physical confrontation in which she took the power-enhancing drug Jump to fight Sam on equal terms. Their friendship fractured but slowly began to rebuild during the recovery period of Arc 9 when Kate moved in with the Small family after the house fire. Kate later adopted the identity Soot, operating as a solo vigilante using chemical smoke powers against Jump drug dealers. As Soot, she demonstrated a calculated and methodical approach: infiltrating dealer gatherings, negotiating trades of drugs for Jump, and using carbon monoxide gas to incapacitate targets when situations escalated. She acquired Jump pills, money, and other drugs during operations, and maintained a warehouse base where she processed chemicals to replenish her powers and treated her own injuries. Her stated motivation was to help her father. When Bloodhound (Sam) tracked Soot to her warehouse and confronted her about her methods and morality, the debate over justice versus survival ended with Soot voluntarily surrendering her acquired Jump pills to Sam. After the Kingdom of Keys began hunting Soot, Sam orchestrated an elaborate plan to fake Soot's death. In a staged confrontation on Linden Avenue, Sam disguised as Soot fled from a fabricated villain team called "The Washes" -- Brainwash (Amelia/Gossamer), Powerwash (Lily/Blink), and Mouthwash (the real Kate in disguise) -- to Lardner's Point Park. Kingdom operatives Mr. Retribution, Mrs. Quiet, Mr. Polygraph, and Mr. Nothing arrived and offered the Washes $2,000 to interrogate "Soot" first. Kate (as Mouthwash) struck Sam with a metal rail to maintain the deception. Sam provided carefully crafted answers mixing truth and deception under interrogation, naming "Jackpot" as her handler and providing a false safehouse location. When Mr. Polygraph demanded to see Soot's face -- threatening to expose the deception -- a police siren (likely triggered by the team) created chaos, and Mrs. Quiet shot Sam multiple times with a silenced weapon. The Washes threw the severely injured Sam into the Delaware River, and Sam injected herself with a Hypeman autoinjector to survive. Kate relocated to Center City under the name Kay Smith, where she now works legitimate remediation jobs while her father recovers from his gambling addiction.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Gas/Aerosol Absorption — Can absorb any type of gas, smoke, or aerosol into her body through her skin. This includes toxic substances such as mold spores, mycotoxins, volatile organic compounds, carbon monoxide, chlorine gas, pepper spray, and chemical byproducts. She can store absorbed gases internally without apparent harm to herself.
  • Gas Deployment — Can release previously absorbed gases through her skin at will, deploying them in controlled bursts or sustained clouds. Uses this offensively for area denial, smoke screens, and targeted chemical attacks. Can release different absorbed substances selectively.
  • Chemical Smoke Manipulation — Primarily uses her power to absorb and redeploy smoke and chemical compounds, creating obscuring clouds, deploying pepper spray-laced smoke, or releasing noxious gases to incapacitate targets. As Soot, she used carbon monoxide gas offensively to incapacitate drug dealers during operations.
  • Toxic Processing — Can process harmful airborne substances at extraordinary rates. During remediation work, she processed black mold concentrations at eleven times the expected level, clearing jobs in six hours that would normally take three days.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Physical Toll — Processing large volumes of toxic substances takes a physical toll on her body, even though the gases themselves do not technically harm her.
  • No Inherent Combat Powers — Her abilities are utility-based rather than directly offensive. She relies on martial arts training and chemical knowledge to make her powers dangerous in combat.
  • Recognition Risk — As a supposedly dead vigilante, any use of her powers in public risks exposing her new identity.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Exceptional basketball player, formerly starring at Abraham Lincoln High School, with the athleticism, speed, and competitive drive that carried over into her vigilante work.
  • Extensively trained in multiple martial arts styles, demonstrating precise, economical movements in combat. Capable of fighting experienced metahumans using technique and tactics rather than brute force.
  • Amateur chemist who systematically catalogs the absorption and deployment properties of various household chemicals, maintaining a detailed spreadsheet (columns: Compound, Vapor Properties, Absorption Feel, Deployment Effect) of substances available at any CVS. Tested compounds include isopropyl alcohol (flammable vapor, rapid dispersion, brief ignition), ammonia (effective area denial, obvious chemical presence), heavy vapors (sink fast, good for ground-level cover), and theatrical fog juice (glycerin/water mixture producing thick, non-alarming, sustained obscurement). Maintains plausible deniability since all chemicals appear as normal household items.
  • Tactical planning and team coordination experience from leading Team Mayfly, including surveillance operations, drone deployment, and multi-team coordination.
  • Proficient with non-lethal weapons including tasers, pepper spray (wrist-mounted canisters), and gas masks.
  • Licensed juvenile metahuman contractor for hazardous material remediation work.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Kate is intensely Catholic, carrying deep religious guilt that colors her worldview and self-perception. She believes herself damned to hell based on visions she experienced during her near-death event, and she attends weekly confession at St. Augustine's church without disclosing what she considers her real sins. She harbors romantic and sexual feelings for Sam that she has confessed but does not act on, and the intersection of her Catholic faith with these feelings compounds her guilt and self-esteem issues. She is snarky, precise, methodical, and morally absolutist, holding rigid views about right and wrong even as she struggles with her own perceived moral failures.

Beneath the sharp exterior, Kate grapples with class resentment, feelings of abandonment, and an addictive need for action and danger that mirrors Sam's own compulsions. She acknowledges having "the same poison Sam does" -- addiction to action and combat. As Soot, she held complex views on morality and justice, maintaining a strict moral code despite illegal activities and demonstrating personal history and philosophical tension with Bloodhound about methods versus morality, justice versus survival. She has described her legitimate post-Soot life as merely "tolerable" and continues to seek out dangerous situations through underground metahuman fight clubs, covert power experimentation, and fantasies of returning to vigilante work. She dreams about mixing chemicals, pulling her gas mask over her face, and hunting Kingdom dealers. Her weekly confessions at St. Augustine's church omit what she considers her real sins: "I let someone else take bullets for me. I abandoned my mission. I ran away." Her father's encouragement -- "You saved us. You don't have to keep saving us. Save a little of yourself too" -- falls on deaf ears; Kate's philosophy is that someone who has been to hell does not get to save herself but can only try to make it mean something. She feels more at home in the fight club than anywhere since leaving Tacony.

The fire serves as the probable activation event for her metahuman powers. Book 10: Plume Supporting Living with the Small family during recovery. Book 10: Plume (Interludes) Interlude Interlude So.1 follows Soot conducting two operations in early April 2025: first infiltrating a dealer gathering to negotiate a drugs-for-Jump trade, escalating to armed confrontation and using carbon monoxide gas to incapacitate the dealers. The Kingdom of Keys hunts Soot, offering millions for her identity. Sam negotiates with Mr. Antithesis, providing carefully crafted misinformation about Kate. Referenced as Sam's estranged best friend. Book 13: Burn After Reading Supporting Sam visits Kate at her Rittenhouse Square apartment during her fugitive operations. Kate now has brown hair, works mold remediation as an independent contractor, and has cleared her father's debts. Kate forces Sam to shower and sleep in her bed while she guards from the couch. Liam Smith gives Sam $300 and pierogies. Kate texts Sam about danger during later events. Book 14: Shelter in Place Mentioned / Interlude Texts Sam warnings about danger during the Shrike crisis. Interlude So.3 (mid-November 2025) reveals Kate's post-Soot life in Center City. Licensed as "KAITLYN SMITH -- LICENSED JUVENILE METAHUMAN CONTRACTOR," working 30 hours/week max, 6 hours/day due to minor labor restrictions. Processes mold at 11x expected concentration, earning triple completion bonuses and 4x hourly rate. Relocated from Tacony six months prior; father clean from gambling, working construction management. Attends Bodine International High School with no friends; missing school counselor appointments. Maintains secret chemistry lab in apartment building basement, systematically testing household chemicals (isopropyl alcohol, ammonia, heavy vapor, theatrical fog juice) in a spreadsheet. Attends underground metahuman fight club in an abandoned boxing gym basement near Passyunk Avenue in South Philly (Tuesday/Thursday/Saturday nights, $50 cover), using fake ID claiming age 21, vouched for by coworker Marco. Observes matches and learns fighter tactics but has not yet competed. Performs weekly confession at St. Augustine's without disclosing real sins. Dreams of returning to vigilante work. Ignores Sam's texts despite not deleting contact.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Kate and Sam first met in kindergarten, establishing the foundation of their deep friendship.
  • Kate shaved her head in solidarity when Sam lost her hair from radiation exposure during the Chernobyl crisis.
  • During her time as Miss Mayfly, Kate operated without superpowers, relying entirely on martial arts training, tactical planning, and non-lethal weapons.
  • Team Mayfly's headquarters was Kate's own bedroom, and the team operated a fleet of sixteen surveillance drones managed by members Mite and Ant.
  • Kate's remediation work allows her to clear hazardous material jobs in six hours that would normally take a conventional crew three days.
  • She uses a fake ID claiming she is 21 to attend the underground metahuman fight club in South Philadelphia.
  • Her father Liam is friends with the Small family; he gave Sam $300 and packed pierogies for her when she visited during her time as a fugitive.
  • Kate's wrist-mounted pepper spray canister was incorporated into Sam's tactical plan to capture Sparkplug during Arc 5.
  • Kate's Miss Mayfly team motto was "Together, we soar."
  • The criminals Kate's team stopped during MM.1 were wearing knock-off superhero masks of Peregrine, Captain Steel, Railgun, and Lady Justice.
  • During the faked death operation (So.2), Kate as "Mouthwash" had to strike Sam with a metal rail to maintain their cover, causing genuine injury to her best friend.
  • The false safehouse location Sam provided to the Kingdom during the faked death interrogation was "Tulip and Keystone," and Mrs. Quiet confirmed it matched intelligence they already received from "the brat" (Sam's earlier planted information).
  • Kate considers her Catholic theology in relation to her powers, wondering whether they are "miracles" or "charisms" from her resurrection experience, though other characters have actual charisms and Kate's powers are of a different nature.
  • The underground fight club she attends has specific rules: no weapons (unless part of a power), no killing, and the referee calls knockouts and submissions. Qualifier matches for newcomers run at 10 PM before the main card.
  • The character reference guide notes that her power activation event during the house fire is qualified with "probably," leaving some ambiguity about the exact circumstances.

docs.text: Ghanaian-born metahuman and member of the Delaware Valley Defenders, capable of generating weightless granite armor on any surface he touches.

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Kwame Adjei is an immigrant from Ghana who operates as Bulwark, a member of the adult roster of the Delaware Valley Defenders in Philadelphia. Little is known about his life prior to joining the team or the circumstances of his power activation. He is described as physically imposing yet possessing a gentle demeanor, and he speaks with a heavy accent, notably avoiding compound words entirely in his speech.

Bulwark serves as one of the core field operatives of the Delaware Valley Defenders alongside Multiplex, Fury Forge, and others, under the organizational leadership of Councilman Jamal Davis and the legal guidance of Clara Parker. He occupies a temperamental middle ground within the team's internal dynamics, positioned between Fury Forge's impulsive, aggressive tendencies and Multiplex's rigid adherence to protocol. His first significant on-page action occurred during the Kingdom of Keys' attack on Sam Small's family home in Arc 2, where he arrived in time to battle Mr. T-Rex in dinosaur form and drive the villain away.

Throughout the story, Bulwark has maintained a consistent presence as a reliable senior hero who participates in team briefings, crisis response, and field operations. He attended Liberty Belle's will reading following her death, was present during the Chernobyl trial crisis, and continued to serve as a mentor-like figure to the younger generation of heroes. He was seriously injured during the Shrike crisis in Arc 14 and was later encountered by Sam while conducting an independent investigation into tainted Jump distribution near Temple University.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Granite Generation — Bulwark can deposit a half-inch-thick layer of granite onto any object or surface by touching it, including his own body. This effectively creates a stone shell or coating over the target.
  • Self-Armoring — When Bulwark coats himself in granite, he gains significant protective armoring. The granite does not impede his movement or flexibility, allowing him to fight unencumbered despite being encased in stone.
  • Weapon Enhancement — By coating blunt objects in granite, Bulwark increases their mass substantially. Because the granite is weightless to him, he can swing these heavier weapons at the same speed as their uncoated counterparts, dramatically increasing their striking force. During his battle with Mr. T-Rex, he used improvised weapons including a car bumper mace and a granite-coated manhole cover.
  • Layer Stacking — Bulwark can apply multiple layers of granite to the same object or surface, compounding the thickness and weight of the coating. However, each additional layer halves the remaining duration of the granite.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Granite coating lasts a maximum of one hour per layer. Stacking additional layers cuts the remaining duration in half with each application, creating diminishing returns for heavy fortification.
  • The granite carries normal weight for anyone other than Bulwark. Allies cannot easily move objects he has coated, and armored civilians or teammates would be burdened by the additional mass.
  • Bulwark's granite armor proved ineffective against electrical attacks; during the Temple University riot, electricity from a seizing Jumphead passed through his stone coating as though it were not there.
  • Bulwark was seriously injured during Shrike's escape at the Van Kirk construction site, indicating that his granite armor has limits against sufficiently powerful or unconventional attacks.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Experienced field combatant with years of service on the Delaware Valley Defenders.
  • Skilled in improvised weapon use, demonstrated by his ability to weaponize everyday objects such as car bumpers and manhole covers in the heat of battle.
  • Conducts independent investigative work, as evidenced by his solo investigation into Rogue Wave's Jump distribution networks near Temple University.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Kwame is calm, measured, and deeply principled. He serves as the emotional and philosophical center of the adult Delaware Valley Defenders, balancing Fury Forge's hotheaded impulsiveness with Multiplex's exacting discipline. He speaks with a heavy Ghanaian accent and avoids compound words entirely in his speech, giving his dialogue a distinctive, deliberate cadence. He frequently addresses younger heroes as "young one," a term of endearment that reflects his paternal warmth toward the next generation.

Beneath his composed exterior, Kwame harbors a genuine frustration with the limitations of due process and institutional inaction. He has openly questioned why known criminals cannot simply be arrested, expressing the exasperation of someone who entered the system expecting it to function and has been repeatedly disappointed by its failures. Despite this frustration, his instincts remain fundamentally protective and compassionate. He sobbed openly when Liberty Belle revealed her terminal cancer diagnosis, encouraged Sam to trust Belle's judgment and her own abilities after the will reading, and has consistently advocated for recruiting fresh perspectives into the team. He has also argued in team meetings that the Defenders should focus on the challenges ahead rather than getting mired in speculation or internal politics.

docs.title: Lawrence Sullivan
docs.text: Leader of Rogue Wave, an ex-corporate lawyer turned anarcho-capitalist drug kingpin who uses supernatural binding contracts to control a decentralized network of Jump and Fly distributors across Philadelphia.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Lawrence Sullivan Aliases Monkey Business Date of Birth Unknown Age 38 Gender Male Ethnicity Unknown Place of Birth Unknown (worked in Philadelphia pre-Rogue Wave) Residence Philadelphia, PA (area) Affiliation Rogue Wave (Leader) Former Affiliations Whitmore & Associates (contract law firm, Meridian Financial building) Occupation Leader of Rogue Wave; drug distribution organizer Status Active First Appearance Chapter 156 Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Lawrence Sullivan is the founder and leader of Rogue Wave, a decentralized criminal organization distributing the power-granting drugs Jump and Fly throughout Philadelphia. Before turning to crime, Sullivan worked as an associate at Whitmore & Associates, a contract law firm on the fourteenth floor of the Meridian Financial building at 1847 Chestnut Street in Philadelphia. He specialized in contract law, distinguished primarily by his ability to find loopholes that more senior partners missed and his complete lack of interest in firm politics.

As revealed in Interlude LS.3, Sullivan's Activation Event occurred during an armed hostage situation at his workplace. Four armed men — two with revolvers, two with collapsible batons — took approximately thirty hostages in the fourteenth-floor conference room. The operation appeared to be organized and professional rather than ideological. The leader made a verbal declaration to the hostages: "We won't hurt any of you, as long as everyone in this room cooperates." Sullivan experienced a nosebleed and then felt the statement crystallize into a supernaturally binding contract. He instinctively parsed the language as he would any legal document, identifying critical asymmetries: "everyone in this room" imposed a spatial limitation on the cooperation clause (applying only to those currently present in the room), while "we won't hurt any of you" contained no spatial restriction (their non-violence obligation was absolute). Sullivan tested his theory by requesting a restroom break with an escort. Upon stepping through the conference room doorway, he felt the cooperation clause dissolve. He called 911 from his personal cell phone (the gunmen had only collected work phones), then confronted his escort, Martinez. When Martinez attempted to swing his baton at Sullivan, the contract physically prevented the motion — his arm locked up, unable to execute the strike. Sullivan incapacitated Martinez with a necktie, photographed the gunmen from the hallway, and waited for the tactical team, which arrived eleven minutes later. All hostages were freed without casualties, and the gunmen were arrested in a state of confused compliance, unable to explain why their weapons had stopped working.

In the three weeks following the incident, Sullivan methodically experimented with his power, testing small agreements with baristas, colleagues, and casual acquaintances. He established the fundamental rules: both parties must understand the terms for a contract to bind; the contract binds both parties equally; and language matters — exact words and precise phrasing determine scope, not intent or common understanding. He recognized that his power executed contracts "as written" rather than as intended, meaning the advantage belonged to whoever controlled the language. Six months later, Sullivan resigned from Whitmore & Associates with a polite resignation letter and two-week notice period. He purchased a monkey mask from a closing costume shop on impulse, and upon putting it on, felt the same shift he had experienced in the conference room — a moment of demarcation, transforming from Lawrence Sullivan, Esq. into something new.

Sullivan built Rogue Wave around an anarcho-capitalist ideology that views the state monopoly on metahuman power as an unmitigated tragedy. Under his leadership, the organization developed Jump (a drug granting temporary superpowers) and Fly (a more dangerous compound granting permanent abilities), created by his chief scientist Dr. Felix Ortega (Snake Oil). Rogue Wave positions itself as a revolutionary enterprise rather than a traditional criminal syndicate, framing its drug distribution as the democratization of power. Sullivan wears a monkey mask during operations and public appearances, maintaining the theatrical persona of "Monkey Business."

Rogue Wave first came to the attention of Philadelphia's hero community when the organization was named during Sparkplug's interrogation in early 2024. Sullivan's organization subsequently expanded aggressively, signing approximately one thousand contracted individuals in Philadelphia by spring 2025, and ultimately declaring open war on the Kingdom of Keys through a hijacked television broadcast on NBC10.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Supernatural Contract Creation — Sullivan can create binding contracts that supernaturally compel all parties to comply with specific terms. These contracts can enforce a wide range of behaviors, including attacking those who question Rogue Wave, following direct orders from designated Rogue Wave representatives, and maintaining operational secrecy. The contracts function as a form of absolute enforcement: a party attempting to violate the terms experiences physical inability to execute the forbidden action (e.g., a gunman's arm locking up mid-swing when attempting to strike Sullivan in violation of a non-violence clause). As demonstrated during LS.3, the power can activate on purely verbal agreements — the hostage-taker's spoken declaration was sufficient to create a binding contract without any written document. Sullivan's Activation Event was itself triggered by a verbal agreement during a hostage crisis, suggesting the power emerged from the intersection of mortal threat and his professional expertise in contract language.
  • Contract Requirements — The contracts must be understood by the signer or speaking party to take effect. There are no hidden fees or concealed clauses; if a party does not comprehend what they are agreeing to, the contract does not bind. This represents a significant limitation on the power's coercive potential. However, Sullivan discovered that the power exploits the gap between what people think they are agreeing to and what the precise words actually specify — not through deception (the understanding requirement prevents that), but through precision of language. Contracts execute "as written" — exact words, precise phrasing, and specific parameters determine scope, not intent or common understanding.
  • Acquired Power: Lie-Telling — Sullivan has recently acquired Mr. Polygraph's lie-telling power after having Snake Oil extract it from the Kingdom operative and presumably ingesting or otherwise absorbing the resulting crystal. The full extent and application of this secondary power have not yet been depicted.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Comprehension Requirement — Contracts only bind those who understand the terms, preventing Sullivan from tricking illiterate or non-comprehending targets into compliance. Agreements made under obvious duress still bind, but agreements made with people who genuinely do not comprehend the terms do not take hold.
  • Mutual Binding — The contract binds both parties equally. Whatever obligations Sullivan creates for others, he also creates for himself. During the LS.3 hostage situation, while the gunmen could not hurt him due to their non-violence clause, Sullivan could not take offensive action against them while the cooperation clause still applied to him inside the room. This symmetry means Sullivan cannot create purely one-sided agreements.
  • Exploitable Clause Language — Jordan Westwood demonstrated that contract clauses can be exploited by deliberately triggering enforcement conditions. After Jordan exposed a vulnerability by provoking a contracted school security guard into a violent attack, Sullivan was forced to redraft his contract language to close such loopholes.
  • No Direct Combat Power — Sullivan's primary ability is administrative and contractual rather than combative; he relies on his enforcers, particularly Birthday Suit, for personal protection in dangerous situations.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Former associate at Whitmore & Associates specializing in contract law, with extensive knowledge of legal language, negotiation tactics, and exploitable ambiguities in contractual terms. His pre-powers career was specifically focused on finding loopholes in agreements, a skill that directly translates into his supernatural contract power.
  • Highly skilled strategic planner capable of orchestrating complex multi-stage operations involving numerous operatives, diversionary tactics, and contingency planning.
  • Demonstrates sophisticated understanding of organizational management, running Rogue Wave as a decentralized network with specialized roles and clear chains of command.
  • Philosophically literate, drawing on anarcho-capitalist and libertarian economic theory to frame and justify Rogue Wave's operations.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Interlude LS.3 revealed Sullivan's pre-Rogue Wave demeanor: calm, analytical, and unflinchingly rational under extreme pressure. During the hostage crisis that triggered his Activation Event, he remained the only person in the room who did not panic, instead parsing the gunman's verbal agreement with the same professional detachment he would apply to a client's licensing agreement. He described himself as someone who had "lost more at the slots" than the fear he felt in that moment. His worldview crystallized during and after the event: the legal system was "built on a beautiful lie" that contracts mean something, when in reality contracts meant nothing without enforcement and the powerful broke agreements whenever convenient. His power allowed him to fix that — not by working within the system or destroying it, but by building something where "contracts actually mean something."

Sullivan is theatrical and philosophical, combining the efficiency of a seasoned businessman with the showmanship of a carnival barker. He speaks in metaphors about meritocracy, evolution, and natural progression, framing Rogue Wave's drug distribution as an ideological mission rather than criminal enterprise. He views the current state of affairs, where metahuman abilities are subject to government surveillance and bureaucratic control, as a disaster, and positions Rogue Wave as the corrective force. He treats setbacks as evolutionary pressure that forces system improvement rather than as defeats. LS.1 reveals a more contemplative side: Sullivan spends significant time considering the philosophical implications of contract language and consciousness, and is genuinely fascinated by the metaphysical question of whether conscious observation can disrupt statistical probability (prompted by Jackpot's probability assessment power). His interview process in LS.2 shows methodical patience -- he evaluates candidates across a full day with clear rubrics rather than relying on gut instinct, though he remains capable of making sharp judgments quickly when a candidate reveals a disqualifying trait.

Sullivan respects competence and conviction regardless of which side it comes from. He is noted to respect Sam Small for her persistence and commitment to her principles. He demonstrates pragmatic judgment in his dealings, such as rejecting a potential collaboration with Dr. Necrosis on ideological grounds despite the tactical advantages it might offer. He is seeing Birthday Suit romantically on the side, a fact known to all of Rogue Wave's core team and treated with indifference. His operational style blends calculated strategic thinking with a flair for dramatic public gestures, as demonstrated by Rogue Wave's hijacked television broadcasts and elaborate recruitment scavenger hunts.

The organization is identified as the source behind Jump and Fly drug distribution. Sullivan is not yet named or seen. Heroes debate whether Rogue Wave's goal is profit or ideological. Book 7: Security Mentioned Maya Richardson encounters mind-controlled individuals triggered by the phrase "Rogue Wave" (Interlude MR.1). The Kingdom of Keys discusses the Rogue Wave situation and the spread of Jump and Fly drugs at a leadership meeting at Nobu Fifty Seven in Manhattan. Book 8: Big Mentioned Sam and Rampart confront gang members at a construction site and discover a connection to Rogue Wave when a dealer named Jackie has a violent reaction to the organization being mentioned (Chapter 128). Sam reports the incident to Captain Plasma and Fury Forge, who express concern about possible mind control. The group later discusses Rogue Wave at the Tacony Music Hall (Chapter 130). Book 10: Plume Main Sullivan makes his first personal appearance at a Rogue Wave Jump distribution event at a private marina in Pennsport, wearing a monkey mask and accompanied by Birthday Suit (Chapter 156). He announces free Jump, outlines his binding contract system, and activates hidden operatives to expose undercover cops and vigilantes. In the ensuing chaos (Chapter 157), Birthday Suit absorbs ranged attacks to protect him while the Auditors fight their way out. Rogue Wave then hijacks NBC10 and the emergency alert system to broadcast their manifesto with all six core members visible, declaring war on the Kingdom of Keys and revealing their network of approximately one thousand contracted individuals (Chapter 158). Book 11: Alarm Will Sound Interlude (LS.1) POV interlude set in June 2025 at Rogue Wave headquarters, including the conference room dubbed the "Nerve Center" and their laboratory. Sullivan analyzes footage of Jordan Westwood triggering a school security guard's contract clause and works to redraft the enforcement clause to avoid violent compulsions, considering philosophical implications of contract language and consciousness. Receives operational reports: Rush Order announces 22% contract distribution increase with 92% retention post-Westwood; Dead Drop provides intelligence on the Kingdom's reduced operations and "erratic" enforcer deployment following their warehouse destruction. Sullivan directs controlled expansion into specific Philadelphia neighborhoods weakened by the Kingdom's losses. Oversees the extraction of a probability assessment power from Jackpot -- Sullivan personally tests the power by flipping coins and asking about probability outcomes. The painful extraction process produces a larger-than-average crystal capable of creating sixty standard Jump doses. Sullivan contemplates the metaphysical implications of consciousness disrupting statistical probability and plans enhanced security for the testing phase of this new variant. Views the Jordan incident as evolutionary pressure forcing system improvement, and the struggle with the Kingdom as natural evolution with Rogue Wave representing adaptation and progress. Book 12: Authorized Personnel Only Supporting Rogue Wave hijacks live television again to announce recruitment for a scientist's assistant, sending candidates on an elaborate scavenger hunt across Philadelphia (Chapter 183). Sullivan and Snake Oil conduct candidate interviews at a Toyota dealership back office (Interlude LS.2), evaluating seventeen finalists who survived the scavenger hunt and signed preliminary contracts. Candidates are assessed for technical competence, ideological alignment, and psychological compatibility. Notable rejects include: Melvin Broderick (pharmaceutical researcher, too institutionalized), Jennifer Walsh/Blackout (electromagnetic abilities, mercenary motivations), David Kim (Army Chemical Corps background raising law enforcement concerns), and Dr. Rebecca Foster (asked uncomfortable questions about organizational structure). The most promising candidate is Aurora Reyes/Pyrausta, a self-taught chemist with fire manipulation abilities who has independently reverse-engineered Jump's chemistry and created her own delivery methods. She reveals that Snake Oil's power crystals produce unusual effects on fire when burned, and controls a flame entity named Espada described as a "tulpa." Snake Oil also proposes collaborating with Dr. Necrosis, a German bioterrorist hiding in Chicago, for viral vectors of Jump enhancement, but Sullivan rejects this on ideological grounds since Necrosis opposes profit-based medical approaches. The final candidate is Elias Franklin/Chimera, who arrives in a wheelchair, holds an incomplete PhD in biochemistry from Penn, uses Fly for mobility enhancement and Jump for regeneration, and reveals connections to the Philly Phreaks. His interview is interrupted at a cliffhanger. Sullivan also monitors the aftermath of Rush Order's staged public confrontation with Bloodhound on South Street (Interlude RS.3/DC.1). Rogue Wave launches a citywide emergency alert scavenger hunt for free Jump samples, causing widespread chaos (Chapter 186). Book 13: Burn After Reading Mentioned Rogue Wave's activities continue in the background as Sullivan maintains operations during the Daedalus prison break arc and the escalating conflict with the Kingdom. Book 14: Shelter in Place Supporting Sullivan negotiates a protection arrangement with Sam Small at the Tacony Music Hall after Shrike's home invasion threatens her family (Chapter 205). Arrives with Birthday Suit in an unmarked sedan while Rush Order delivers pizza as a peace offering. Confirms Ben Small's existing protection and agrees to expanded surveillance of locations Sam's associates frequent in exchange for an undefined future favor. Sam cuts Sullivan's hand and mixes their blood to seal the agreement. Rogue Wave subsequently provides surveillance photos of Shrike's followers. After Sam's hospitalization, sends a package confirming protection extends to Shrike's followers and requesting future assistance with Mr. Polygraph. Book 15: Severe Weather Warning Supporting Sam fulfills her debt to Rogue Wave by tipping Rush Order about Kingdom evidence disposal at Roxborough Memorial Hospital (Chapter 220). Sullivan recognizes the strategic opportunity and orchestrates a complex operation using a geased private investigator as bait to draw out Mr. Polygraph (Interlude DC.2). Selects Rush Order, Birthday Suit, and Dead Drop as the extraction team. The operation results in the capture of Mr. Polygraph, whose lie-detection power is extracted by Snake Oil at a Camden warehouse -- crystallizing as a blue-green crystal that becomes the raw material for Fly. Sullivan acquires the lie-telling ability for himself through the extracted crystal. Sullivan instructs the team to tip police about Polygraph's location after forty-five minutes. Texts Sam confirming her debt is paid but warns not to involve police in future dealings. Sam and the Auditors speculate Sullivan planned for DVD involvement all along. The operation produces 19 arrests total, including 15 Rogue Wave and 4 Kingdom operatives. Intermission 15.5: This Side Up POV (Interlude LS.3) Full origin story. Sullivan was an associate at Whitmore & Associates on the fourteenth floor of the Meridian Financial building when four armed men took approximately thirty hostages in the conference room. The leader declared "We won't hurt any of you, as long as everyone in this room cooperates," and Sullivan's power activated — he experienced a nosebleed and felt the verbal statement become a supernaturally binding contract. He parsed the agreement's asymmetries: the cooperation clause was spatially limited to "this room" while the non-violence clause was absolute. He obtained a restroom break with an escort named Martinez, called 911, and then confronted Martinez in the hallway. Martinez's baton swing was physically prevented by the contract's enforcement. Sullivan incapacitated him with a necktie, gathered intelligence on the gunmen, and awaited the tactical team. All hostages were freed without casualties. In the following three weeks, Sullivan systematically tested his power through small everyday agreements, establishing the core rules: mutual comprehension required, mutual binding on both parties, and precise language determining scope. He resigned from his law firm six months later and purchased a monkey mask from a closing costume shop, feeling a transformative shift upon putting it on. Began recruiting people wronged by broken contracts and failed institutional promises to form Rogue Wave. Book 16: Category Five Hurricane Active (off-page) Sullivan is currently focused on keeping Rogue Wave together while Mr. Antithesis conducts a rampage through the organization to acquire Fly for re-powering Mr. Polygraph. Sullivan has also acquired Mr. Polygraph's lie-telling power via Snake Oil's extraction.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Sullivan wears a monkey mask during operations and public appearances, maintaining his Monkey Business persona even during relatively informal settings like candidate interviews.
  • His first in-person appearance involved banging metal pans together to get the crowd's attention at the Pennsport marina distribution event.
  • Sullivan's contract terms are explicitly laid out and require comprehension, a detail that distinguishes his power from simple mind control and reflects his background in contract law.
  • Rogue Wave's operational style under Sullivan reflects his legal background: distribution is run like a legitimate business with vendor support, contracts have explicit terms, and recruitment involves structured interview processes.
  • The blood-mixing gesture Sam used to seal their protection agreement was her spontaneous addition, not part of Sullivan's typical contract process. Rush Order and Birthday Suit briefly drew weapons in response before standing down.
  • Sullivan's organization operates out of deliberately mundane locations, such as a Toyota dealership back office for candidate interviews, chosen for their lack of surveillance interest.
  • Rogue Wave under Sullivan hates the Kingdom of Keys more than any other faction, viewing them as sclerotic bureaucrats with no real ideological values.
  • Rogue Wave's headquarters includes a conference room called the "Nerve Center," revealed in LS.1.
  • Sullivan's interview process in LS.2 reveals the depth of Rogue Wave's recruitment pipeline: seventeen candidates survived a scavenger hunt before reaching the interview stage, and each was evaluated against explicit criteria of technical competence, ideological alignment, and psychological compatibility.
  • In LS.1, Sullivan explicitly considered and rejected a potential collaboration with Dr. Necrosis, a German bioterrorist hiding in Chicago who could have created viral vectors for Jump -- the rejection was purely ideological, as Necrosis opposes profit-based medical approaches, which conflicts with Rogue Wave's anarcho-capitalist foundation.
  • Sullivan personally tested Jackpot's probability assessment power by flipping coins, demonstrating his hands-on approach to evaluating new capabilities before committing them to production.
  • Interlude LS.3 reveals the Meridian Financial building at 1847 Chestnut Street as the location of his Activation Event. The building is described as "fourteen floors of beige carpeting, fluorescent lighting, and the quiet desperation of people who've made peace with spending their finite lives reviewing spreadsheets."
  • During the hostage situation, Sullivan was reviewing a licensing agreement for a pharmaceutical client ("predatory terms disguised as industry standard") at the moment the gunmen arrived — a detail that mirrors his eventual career exploiting contractual language.
  • Sullivan kept his personal cell phone hidden when the gunmen collected devices, handing over only his work phone. He used the personal phone to call 911 twice from the restroom.
  • The hostage-taker's leader used the phrase "no monkey business" while addressing the hostages, an unintentional foreshadowing of Sullivan's eventual alias.
  • Sullivan's first act after discovering his power's enforcement mechanism was to strangle Martinez with a necktie — a weapon that is itself a symbol of corporate professionalism.
  • He described the monkey mask purchase as an impulse buy from a costume shop going out of business, but noted that putting it on produced the same psychological shift he felt when first stepping outside the conference room during the hostage situation — "the moment of demarcation."
  • Sullivan's recruitment methodology for Rogue Wave specifically targeted "people who've been wronged by broken contracts, failed promises, systems that couldn't or wouldn't hold the powerful accountable" — people with skills, grievances, and nothing left to lose.
  • His stated philosophy crystallized after the hostage event: the legal system is "built on a beautiful lie" that contracts mean something, when in truth "contracts mean nothing without enforcement" and "the powerful break agreements whenever it's convenient."
