docs.title: Tomás "Tommy" Reynoso
docs.text: Former casino pit boss turned Rogue Wave tactical support operative whose randomized, periodically cycling powers make him the organization's most essential resource for Jump drug production.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Tomás Reynoso Aliases Tommy, Jackpot Date of Birth Unknown Age 27 Gender Male Ethnicity Unknown (implied Hispanic/Latino based on name) Place of Birth Unknown Residence Philadelphia, PA (Rogue Wave safehouses, including Camden, NJ) Affiliation Rogue Wave Former Affiliations Casino industry (pit boss) Occupation Rogue Wave tactical support, primary power source for Jump production Status Active First Appearance Chapter 158 (mentioned by name); Interlude LS.1 (first on-page appearance) Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Tomás "Tommy" Reynoso is a former casino pit boss and recovering gambling addict who gained metahuman abilities after being left to die in the desert by his former employers. The precise circumstances of his activation event remain largely undocumented, though the experience evidently transformed both his physiology and his outlook on life. Rather than harboring resentment over his near-death experience, Reynoso adopted a philosophy that treats existence itself as the ultimate game of chance.

Reynoso joined Rogue Wave at some point prior to the organization's public emergence in Philadelphia and became one of the six core members of its leadership team. His unique power profile — a constantly cycling rotation of random abilities — made him indispensable to the group's operations. Dr. Felix Ortega (Snake Oil) regularly extracts Reynoso's manifesting powers through a painful crystallization process, producing the raw material that is then refined into Jump, the temporary power-granting street drug central to Rogue Wave's mission of democratizing superhuman abilities. Unlike many of the organization's contracted operatives, Reynoso is a fully willing participant who understands his role as a living resource and embraces it without reservation.

Reynoso was first identified by name when Jordan Westwood reported intelligence gathered during an infiltration of a Rogue Wave distribution event at a marina, noting that a person called "Jackpot" was essential to Jump production. He subsequently appeared as one of the six featured members of Rogue Wave's televised manifesto broadcast when the organization hijacked NBC10 and the emergency alert system to declare war on the Kingdom of Keys. Sam Small later invoked Jackpot's name as a fabricated handler during an elaborate deception operation in which she impersonated the vigilante Soot, a claim that Kingdom operative Mrs. Quiet confirmed as referencing a real Rogue Wave operative.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Randomized Power Manifestation — Reynoso's primary ability is the spontaneous generation of random superpowers that cycle periodically. Each manifestation is entirely unpredictable; documented examples include super strength, telekinesis, enhanced senses, and probability assessment. He can never predict which power will appear next, but the powers are described as almost always being at least somewhat useful.
  • Probability Assessment (temporary manifestation) — During a documented extraction session in June 2025, Reynoso manifested the ability to assess probability outcomes. Lawrence Sullivan tested this power by flipping coins and querying Reynoso about the results. This particular manifestation produced a larger-than-average crystal capable of generating approximately sixty standard Jump doses.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Each power manifestation lasts exactly three hours, fourteen minutes, and fifteen seconds (3:14:15) before cycling to a new ability.
  • Reynoso cannot predict, choose, or influence which power will manifest next.
  • The extraction process performed by Snake Oil is described as painful for both parties — the power crystallizes out of Snake Oil's hands during direct physical contact.
  • Once a power is extracted, it is no longer available to Reynoso for the remainder of that cycle.
  • While his powers are almost always useful, there is no guarantee of combat applicability in any given cycle.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Former casino pit boss with extensive knowledge of gambling operations, probability, and risk assessment.
  • Demonstrates rapid adaptability, having learned to quickly assess and utilize whatever random power manifests during a given cycle.
  • Possesses calculating intelligence beneath his casual demeanor, allowing him to operate effectively in high-stakes tactical situations.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Reynoso treats life like a casino game — unpredictable but riggable. He is a thrill-seeker with a casual, joking demeanor that masks a sharply calculating intelligence underneath. He is consistently described as the least serious member of Rogue Wave's core team, providing levity in an organization otherwise populated by ideologues, professionals, and obsessives. During downtime, he has been observed playing Mario Kart at the Camden safehouse and returning from food runs with Dead Drop during team meetings.

Despite his easygoing surface, Reynoso is not a passive participant in Rogue Wave's operations. He understands clearly that he functions as the organization's most critical resource — the renewable engine of their entire Jump production pipeline — and accepts this role willingly. He is not framed as a victim exploited for his abilities but as someone who genuinely believes in what Rogue Wave is doing and loves the work. His gambling background informs his worldview: he sees risk, chance, and adaptation as the fundamental mechanics of existence, and he has found in Rogue Wave a cause that aligns with that philosophy.

docs.title: Arc Appearances
docs.text: Book Role Key Events Book 10: Plume Supporting First identified by name when Jordan Westwood reports intelligence gathered during the Pennsport marina infiltration, noting that a person called "Jackpot" is essential to Jump production (Ch. 158). Appears as one of the six core Rogue Wave members featured in the NBC10 broadcast hijacking, during which the organization declares war on the Kingdom of Keys and reveals its network of contracted operatives. Described as possessing "luck-based powers" during the televised manifesto (Ch. 158). Manifests a probability assessment capability during a strategic planning meeting. Sullivan personally tests the power by flipping coins and asking Reynoso about probability outcomes, confirming its viability. Snake Oil and Jackpot then perform the extraction process in the laboratory: the power crystallizes out of Snake Oil's hands during direct physical contact in a painful procedure for both parties. This particular manifestation produces a larger-than-average crystal capable of generating approximately sixty standard Jump doses, a significantly higher yield than typical extractions. Sullivan calculates the market impact and application potential of this new probability variant and plans enhanced security for the testing phase. The extraction takes place during a broader meeting where the team reports Philadelphia operations exceeding projections, with Rush Order reporting a 22% contract distribution increase. Sullivan contemplates the metaphysical implications of Jackpot's power -- specifically whether conscious observation can disrupt pure statistical probability. Also invoked by name during Sam's Phase Two deception: while impersonating Soot, Sam claims Jackpot is her Rogue Wave handler, which Mrs. Quiet confirms as a real operative, lending critical credibility to the ruse. Book 12: Authorized Personnel Only Supporting Present at the Camden safehouse during the Interlude RS/DC/JF sequence, set approximately August 1, 2025. Status described as active alongside Monkey Business, Birthday Suit, and Snake Oil.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• The duration of Reynoso's power cycles — exactly 3 hours, 14 minutes, and 15 seconds — corresponds to the digits of pi (3.14159...), suggesting a mathematical or cosmic precision underlying his otherwise random ability.
  • His codename "Jackpot" is a direct reference to his gambling background and the slot-machine-like randomness of his power manifestations.
  • During the Rogue Wave NBC10 broadcast, Jackpot's powers were described to the public as "luck-based," a simplification of his actual randomized power cycling.
  • Reynoso was observed playing Mario Kart during the planning phase of the Mr. Polygraph extraction operation, reinforcing his characterization as the most laid-back member of the core team.
  • Sam Small's decision to name Jackpot as her supposed Rogue Wave handler during the Phase Two Soot deception was a calculated choice — it relied on the Kingdom already having intelligence on Jackpot as a real operative, which Mrs. Quiet confirmed on the spot.
  • The character reference guide explicitly states Reynoso is "not a victim," distinguishing him from characters who might be sympathetically framed as exploited for their powers. He knows he is a resource and chooses the role freely.
  • The probability assessment crystal extracted in LS.1 was notably larger than average, producing approximately sixty standard doses compared to typical extractions. Sullivan viewed this as a significant addition to Rogue Wave's Jump variant portfolio.
  • Sullivan's fascination with the metaphysical implications of Reynoso's probability assessment power -- whether consciousness itself can disrupt statistical probability -- represents one of the few times Sullivan's philosophical interests extend beyond contract theory and market ideology into genuinely abstract territory.
  • The extraction process is described as painful for both Reynoso and Snake Oil, with the crystal growing from the backs of Snake Oil's hands during physical contact. The mutual pain underscores the collaborative sacrifice at the center of Rogue Wave's production model.

docs.title: Trent Fairfax
docs.text: The clinical, calculating leader of the Kingdom of Keys, a multi-city criminal organization, who presents publicly as an unremarkable financial investor connected to one of New York City's largest law megafirms.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Trent Fairfax Aliases Mr. Antithesis (Kingdom codename), Upper Management, Mr. A Date of Birth Unknown (early 1990s estimated) Age Early 30s Gender Male Ethnicity Caucasian Place of Birth Philadelphia, PA Residence Manhattan, New York City Affiliation Kingdom of Keys (Leader) Former Affiliations N/A Occupation Kingdom of Keys leader; licensed attorney (Columbia Law, criminal law specialty); public-facing role as a financial investor associated with Tremont & Fairfax law firm; philanthropist through Alcott & Associates Status Active First Appearance Interlude MR.2 (voice only); Chapter 173 (in person) Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Trent Fairfax was born in Philadelphia to a single mother, Emily Caldwell, who worked two jobs to cover the costs of his doctors, medication, and specialized schooling. He was diagnosed with severe obsessive-compulsive disorder in childhood, manifesting in compulsive counting (67 steps from lobby to apartment door), need for cleanliness and order, catastrophizing thought spirals, and a persistent tightness in his chest he described as constant. His childhood therapist, Dr. Hendricks, helped him develop coping strategies including redirecting catastrophizing and building adaptive routines. The family lived in a fourth-floor apartment in a building that had been declining since the 1970s; the elevator worked most days. Fairfax was assessed as intellectually gifted, though he recognized the word typically meant "difficult in ways we don't want to specify." He was placed on SSRIs and other medications that he credited with preventing the "uncontrollable, alien thoughts" from overwhelming him, forming a pharmaceutical scaffold that held throughout his life. His mother learned to adapt to his needs -- hugging briefly, with warning, not too tight -- and he made deliberate efforts to minimize the costs his condition imposed on her.

As a child, Fairfax developed an intense engagement with comic books, purchasing The Amazing Spider-Man #252 at age nine with most of his weekly allowance and eventually accumulating 847 comics organized by title and issue number in plastic sleeves with cardboard backings across seven long boxes. He analyzed villains critically, cataloguing their structural failures -- monologuing, executing minions, ego overriding strategy, elaborate deathtraps -- treating these patterns as an instructive taxonomy. He was particularly drawn to Miracleman, citing Kid Miracleman as the most compelling villain. In high school, he cultivated strategic invisibility, eating lunch in the library (where Mrs. Patterson looked the other way about food), arriving early to claim the same seat in every class, and maintaining routines that kept his differences invisible.

Fairfax was accepted to Columbia Law School, where he excelled under the Socratic method, finding it relaxing rather than intimidating because it mirrored the constant stress-testing of reasoning he had practiced since childhood. He described Professor Whitman's interrogation technique as "debugging -- someone stress-testing your reasoning to find the errors before they cause real damage," and considered the professor an amateur by comparison to his own self-scrutiny. He maintained a study group (Sarah, Michael, David, Lisa) and transitioned to a new psychiatrist, Dr. Ndiaye, who practiced in Brooklyn and conducted sessions by phone. He lived in a small, clean studio apartment organized precisely to his specifications, ate alone by preference, and maintained what he characterized as "collegial relationships -- functional, adequate." During law school, a classmate introduced him to The Sopranos, which he watched analytically, cataloguing Tony Soprano's strategic errors and recognizing the same failure modes he had identified in comic book villains: ego over strategy, immediate satisfaction over sustainable advantage, personality-driven instability at the cost of long-term institutional durability.

His metahuman abilities manifested during a traumatic incident in which he was accidentally pushed off a balcony by an intoxicated metahuman, triggering latent powers that allowed him to sense his attacker's weaknesses and generate counter-abilities, saving his life.

After graduating, Fairfax explored his powers in secret while developing a vision for a metahuman criminal organization. Inspired by the Big Raid, he founded the Kingdom of Keys and began recruiting metahuman operatives, each assigned a codename beginning with "Mr." or "Mrs." followed by a word corresponding to a letter of the alphabet. By 2023, he had consolidated power and firmly established the organization's structure and operations across multiple cities in the northeastern United States and Miami.

Fairfax's public identity is carefully maintained as the unremarkable second cousin to the partners of Tremont & Fairfax, one of New York City's largest law megafirms. He presents himself as a freewheeling financial investor with no public appearances of note, hiding in plain sight as someone too inconsequential to attract attention. His actual role as the Kingdom's leader is known only to his inner circle, with most subordinates knowing him only as "Upper Management" or "Mr. A." He also operates through a secondary front, Alcott & Associates, which he uses for philanthropy and legal casework including prison visits under attorney-client privilege.

Fairfax privately funded the William J. Hofmann Memorial Recovery Ward at Jefferson Hospital in Philadelphia, which treated the survivors of the Phreaks' courthouse attack. He visited the ward regularly (at least fourteen times over two years), presenting himself as Mr. Fairfax from Alcott & Associates, accompanied by Ophelia Grady posing as his assistant. The funding was motivated by personal guilt: Maya Richardson, operating under Fairfax's authority, had brought Deathgirl into the Kingdom's orbit. After Patches was arrested, Deathgirl redirected the Phreaks toward the courthouse attack, distributing bad Jump mixed at random with stolen pharmacy chemicals -- no quality control, no consistency. The attack killed seventeen and left hundreds transformed. Fairfax rejected the degrees-of-separation defense, holding that responsibility does not evaporate because it passes through intermediaries. His funding brought in metahuman healers, experimental enzyme treatments, and research infrastructure that advanced the field of power-induced transformation medicine. He characterized this not as altruism but as recognizing that "a safe world is a profitable world."

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Reactive Counter-Power Generation — Trent uncontrollably generates counter-powers to anyone with metahuman abilities near him. These counter-powers either nullify their advantages, target their weaknesses, or, most frequently, do both simultaneously. The ability is automatic and not consciously directed. When multiple powered individuals are present, the counter-power effect is split and diluted proportionally, reducing its effectiveness against each individual target.
  • Weakness Detection — As a component of his counter-power generation, Trent can sense the vulnerabilities of metahumans in his proximity, gaining an immediate understanding of their weaknesses. This detection appears to encompass physical, mental, and emotional vulnerabilities, not just power-specific weaknesses.
  • Power Disruption Aura — His ability has a passive disruptive effect on things created or maintained by superpowers. Precautions are taken to keep powered individuals and their creations outside his range, as demonstrated when Maya Richardson was kept away from his office during meetings and when Mrs. Xenograft's chimerized creature Scylla was left outside before entering his presence.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Uncontrollable Activation — The counter-power generation is involuntary, meaning Trent cannot suppress it around allies or selectively target only enemies. This necessitates careful management of his proximity to powered individuals, including his own operatives.
  • Dilution Against Multiple Targets — When surrounded by multiple metahumans, the counter-power effect splits between them, reducing its potency against any single individual.
  • Reactive Nature — The powers appear to be reactive rather than proactive, generating counters only in response to nearby metahuman abilities rather than functioning as standalone offensive capabilities.
  • Story-Breaking Designation — The character reference guide explicitly notes his power is "story-breaking" in its potential, requiring narrative management of his direct involvement in conflicts.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Licensed attorney who passed the bar and maintains his credentials, occasionally taking cases to keep the fiction plausible. Attended Columbia Law School, where he excelled under the Socratic method and specialized in criminal law after his 1L year. His legal knowledge allows him direct access to incarcerated individuals under attorney-client privilege.
  • Lifelong analytical thinker who developed strategic reasoning through decades of studying comic book villains' structural failures, then formalized it through legal education. He described the Socratic method as "debugging" and considered his own internal self-scrutiny more rigorous than anything a law professor could produce.
  • Skilled strategic planner who treats criminal operations as business ventures, emphasizing financial return over ideology. His study of The Sopranos and organized crime fiction during law school reinforced his focus on sustainable institutional design over personality-driven leadership.
  • Avid chess player who studies famous matches and strategies, reflecting his emphasis on planning and outwitting opponents.
  • Accomplished cook who finds solace in the precision of measurements and techniques.
  • Well-read, with a particular interest in ancient mythology, from which he occasionally draws inspiration for operations.
  • Carries personal self-defense equipment (mace and a taser) as a matter of practical habit, reflecting his risk-aware mindset even before gaining powers.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Trent Fairfax is obsessively clean and precise, with frequent use of hand sanitizer and a habit of destroying stress balls in his office. He speaks with businesslike detachment, viewing crime as a purely financial enterprise without ideological motivation. His OCD manifests in strict routines, a need for symmetry and order, and intense agitation when his environment is disrupted -- patterns that have been present since childhood, when he compulsively counted steps and organized comics with archival precision. He maintains a sterile office in a Manhattan skyscraper and conducts meetings with cold, clinical efficiency. He was raised by a single mother who struggled with his condition, and he treats her well. The persistent "tightness in his chest" he described as a child has been a lifelong companion, managed but never fully resolved through medication and behavioral systems.

Fairfax possesses a deep, intellectualized self-awareness about his condition that borders on clinical detachment from his own psychology. He processes emotions analytically rather than experientially, describing feelings as information to be categorized rather than states to be inhabited. His childhood psychiatrist Dr. Hendricks noted this tendency; his law school psychiatrist Dr. Ndiaye cautioned him against optimizing experiences rather than allowing himself to live them. He acknowledged her point but could not meaningfully distinguish between the two. Despite this emotional flatness, he is capable of dry, situational humor -- when cornered by powered criminals in a New York alley during law school, he told them they would make "excellent clients one day" -- suggesting a wry detachment that operates even under extreme duress.

Despite his controlled exterior, Fairfax is capable of rare but intense emotional reactions. After a meeting with Porcelain of Red Calf in which he was coerced into the Daedalus prison break operation, he destroyed his own office in anger before composing himself for subsequent meetings. He radiates an unnatural intensity that Sam Small described as making him appear less like a man or a monster and more like "a child." He does not take personal interest in low-level threats, delegating problems like Sam to his subordinates, and views interactions with informants and adversaries as simple business transactions. He has expressed that Sam is only spared because her powers do not cause significant collateral damage that would attract unwanted attention.

docs.text: Character Relationship Notes Maya Richardson (Mrs. Zenith) Subordinate / Philadelphia branch leader Manages the Philadelphia operation under his authority. She has developed an intense, borderline-obsessive attachment to him. His consigliere. Accompanies him to the Jefferson Hospital ward visits as his assistant "Ms. Grady." A passerby mistook them for a couple; Trent noted her blue-haired aesthetic has value and asked her not to change it. She knows when not to ask questions, a trait he explicitly appreciates. Porcelain External threat / Coercer Leader of the Red Calf organization, described as the strongest superhuman on Earth. Coerced the Kingdom into the Daedalus prison break under threat of exposing Richardson's Kingdom ties. Their meeting left Fairfax visibly shaken. Sam Small (Bloodhound) Adversary (minor, from his perspective) Met her once in his Manhattan office during a business transaction. Views her as a negligible concern delegated to Maya. Currently indifferent to her activities. Mr. Retribution Subordinate / Enforcer Boston-based enforcer deployed for high-priority Kingdom tasks. Accompanied Sam to and from her meeting with Fairfax. Mrs. Quiet Subordinate / Investigator Kingdom operative with distinctive grey/white streak hair. Serves as driver and handler for sensitive operations involving Fairfax's interests. Blake Matthews (Mr. Tyrannosaur) Subordinate / Enforcer Receives operational briefings from Fairfax, including the Daedalus prison break assignment. Dr. Trinh-Norwood (Mrs. Xenograft) Subordinate / Scientist Reports to Fairfax on drug development and operational outcomes. He rewarded her Hypeman innovation with a raise but warned that future failures would not be tolerated. Lucas Donovan (Mr. Polygraph) Subordinate / Founding member After Polygraph's depowering by Rogue Wave, Fairfax stripped his codename designation but maintained his salary and authority, pledging to acquire Fly to restore his abilities. Emily Caldwell Mother Single mother who worked two jobs to afford his doctors, medication, and specialized schooling. Learned to adapt to his sensory needs -- hugging briefly, with warning, not too tight. Did not ask detailed questions about his interests because the answers took longer than she wanted and involved details she did not find interesting, an adaptation he appreciated. Cried happy tears when he was accepted to Columbia. Packed his belongings for the bus ride to New York. Dr. Hendricks Childhood Therapist Trent's therapist from childhood through adolescence, practicing in an office downtown (23 minutes by bus). Had a beard he stroked while thinking. Taught Trent to recognize catastrophizing and redirect. Referred Trent to Dr. Ndiaye when he moved to New York. Dr. Ndiaye Law School Psychiatrist Brooklyn-based psychiatrist who conducted sessions by phone during Trent's time at Columbia. More direct than Hendricks. Cautioned Trent against optimizing experiences rather than allowing himself to live them. Trent acknowledged her point intellectually but could not meaningfully distinguish between the two processes. Sarah Fairfax Wife Originally a member of Trent's 1L study group at Columbia who insisted he attend the end-of-year celebration at McGinty's bar. Trent initially characterized their relationship as "collegial -- functional, adequate." They later married; Trent wears a wedding ring and loves her deeply, describing missing her. He thinks fondly about their first time at the shooting range together. She texts him asking if he will be home for dinner; he responds with "Love you too." She is registered firearms-trained. Marcus Whitmore Ward Patient / Guilt Object A survivor of the Phreaks' courthouse attack who was reduced to undifferentiated tissue by bad Jump and spent six months as "a puddle" before metahuman healers reconstructed him cell by cell. Fairfax visits him regularly at the Jefferson Hospital ward. Whitmore has thanked Fairfax despite Fairfax's reluctance to accept gratitude. During one visit, Whitmore mentioned Deathgirl's disappearance from Daedalus and asked Trent whether he ever thinks about "the people behind the people behind the people" -- a question Trent could not safely answer. Aaron McKinley (Mr. Prometheus) Subordinate / Recruit Incarcerated pyrogenetic criminal whom Fairfax personally recruited at Curran-Fromhold prison under the guise of attorney-client privilege. McKinley's right arm was fully braced from injuries inflicted by Samantha Small. Fairfax offered him Kingdom membership, a Fly dose synergistic with his fire powers, a six-month jailbreak timeline, a mission to kill Sam Small, his own fiefdom in Camden, and millions of dollars. Named him "Mr. Prometheus" and emphasized the need for a distinguished name that could not be confused with "McKinley" over a wire.

docs.title: Arc Appearances
docs.text: Book Role Key Events Book 8: Big Mentioned / Voice only (Interlude MR.2) Joins a Kingdom leadership meeting at Nobu Fifty Seven in Manhattan via virtual connection. The meeting covers Maya's new councilwoman position, the Rogue Wave situation, Jump and Fly drug proliferation, and a plan to psychologically pressure young superheroes into burning out. Does not appear in person. Book 9: Sheol Supporting (Interlude LTN.2) Meets with Mrs. Xenograft in his sterile Manhattan skyscraper office following the failed zoo heist (Operation Ivory). Receives her presentation of Hypeman (Compound J-237) and accepts her explanation for the failure. Rewards her with a raise and share of Hypeman's profits but warns that future failures will not be tolerated. His power's passive disruptive effect on superpowered creations is implied, as Scylla is deliberately left outside. Book 11: Alarm Will Sound Supporting (Chapters 173–174) First in-person appearance. Sam Small is brought to his Manhattan office by Mr. Retribution and Mrs. Quiet for a negotiated meeting. Fairfax interrogates Sam about Kate Smith/Soot's identity, treating the exchange as a business transaction. Provides Sam with two Hypeman autoinjectors in exchange for information. Rebuffs Sam's attempt to gain intelligence about Tremont & Fairfax. Notes Sam is only spared because her powers lack significant collateral damage. Sam privately describes him to Retribution as "a child." Book 13: Burn After Reading Supporting (Interludes MR.8, BM.3) In Interlude MR.8, meets with Porcelain of Red Calf, who coerces the Kingdom into extracting Daisy Zhen (Deathgirl) from Daedalus Correctional Facility. Richardson finds his office destroyed and Fairfax in rare emotional distress afterward. He outlines the operation parameters and scheduling for September 10th. In Interlude BM.3, briefs Kingdom operatives via video call at Bella Notte restaurant in Staten Island on the Daedalus prison break details, revealing Porcelain as the contractor and presenting Daedalus schematics. First time showing his face on video to subordinates, noted as highly unusual. Book 14: Shelter in Place Supporting (Interlude MR.9) Personally attends a late-night debrief at a Port Richmond warehouse after Mr. Polygraph is captured and depowered by Rogue Wave, an unprecedented act given his usual remoteness. Arrives in a nondescript sedan at 11:50 PM. Announces Polygraph will lose his codename but retain salary and authority. Pledges to acquire Fly to restore Polygraph's powers. Gives Maya 72 hours to develop a comprehensive response plan against Bloodhound. In a private conversation afterward, advises Maya not to take the situation personally. Book 15: Severe Weather Warning Mentioned Referenced in connection to Maya's 72-hour deadline response plan and the resulting frame-up operation against Sam using Mrs. Doppelganger. Noted as remaining in the shadows with his interest in power extraction technology unexplored. Book 16: Category Five Hurricane Mentioned Currently on a quiet personal rampage through Rogue Wave's operations to acquire Fly for re-powering Mr. Polygraph. His direct involvement is occurring offscreen while Rogue Wave's leadership scrambles to hold their organization together. Intermission 15.5: This Side Up (TF.1) Main (Interlude) Extended first-person flashback interlude covering Fairfax's life from age nine through law school. Opens with nine-year-old Trent purchasing The Amazing Spider-Man #252 at a comic shop while his mother waits outside. Depicts his childhood OCD management with therapist Dr. Hendricks, his strategic invisibility in high school, his acceptance to Columbia Law School, his mastery of the Socratic method under Professor Whitman, his transition to psychiatrist Dr. Ndiaye, and his analytical study of villain archetypes from comics through The Sopranos. Establishes the intellectual foundations of his criminal methodology: a lifetime spent cataloguing structural failures in fictional and fictional-adjacent criminal organizations, which he would later apply to designing the Kingdom of Keys as a sustainable institution rather than a personality-driven enterprise. Intermission 15.5: This Side Up (TF.2) Main (Interlude) Continues from TF.1, covering three distinct sequences in Fairfax's post-law-school life. Opens at McGinty's bar after the end of 1L, where Trent attends a study group celebration but drinks only ginger ale and departs early. Walking home, he overhears four powered criminals (Cryo, Firebrand, Rebrand, Storebrand) planning a robbery in an alley. Rebrand shapeshifts to confront him; Cryo restrains him with hydrokinetic bindings, forces water into his sinuses, and orders Firebrand to brand him with heat-touch as an intimidation measure. Firebrand strikes his chest and abdomen repeatedly. Trent escapes by exploiting the steam generated when Firebrand's heat vaporized Cryo's water, macing Cryo and tasering Firebrand before fleeing. In the second sequence, Trent visits the William J. Hofmann Memorial Recovery Ward at Jefferson Hospital with Ophelia Grady, where he funds treatment for Phreaks courthouse attack survivors. He meets Marcus Whitmore, who had been reduced to undifferentiated tissue by bad Jump and has been partially reconstructed through two years of metahuman healing. Whitmore thanks him and asks about "the people behind the people behind the people." Trent internally acknowledges that the chain of causation leads back to his own decisions through Maya and Deathgirl. In the third sequence, Trent visits Aaron McKinley at Curran-Fromhold prison under attorney-client privilege, recruiting him for the Kingdom. He offers McKinley a dose of Fly synergistic with his pyrogenetic powers, a jailbreak timeline of six months, a mission to kill Samantha Small, and Kingdom membership with his own fiefdom in Camden. He names McKinley "Mr. Prometheus."

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• The Kingdom of Keys psych profiles list his name as "Liam Caldwell," born November 13, 1989, while the character reference guide (current as of Arc 16) identifies him as "Trent Fairfax." This may represent an alias, a retcon, or an in-universe discrepancy.
  • The psych profiles note his 26th birthday inspired a pact to build an organization with 26 metahuman members, one for each letter of the alphabet, which became the Kingdom of Keys' naming convention.
  • The Kingdom's first major heist occurred in Philadelphia in December 2020 according to the psych profile timeline.
  • Precautions are taken to keep powered individuals and their superpowered creations out of his range during meetings, as his counter-power generation is involuntary and disruptive.
  • His public cover as a minor financial investor connected to Tremont & Fairfax is deliberately boring, exploiting the fact that nobody pays attention to a random second cousin of the lawyers running a law megafirm.
  • Sam Small is one of very few characters to have met Fairfax in person and walked away. She assessed him as "a child" rather than a man or a monster.
  • His Manhattan office is described as obsessively sterile, with hand sanitizer prominently available and destroyed stress balls littering the space.
  • Interlude TF.1 reveals that his first comic book purchase was The Amazing Spider-Man #252 (the black costume/symbiote issue), bought at age nine for $1.25. He held it in the store for eleven minutes before buying it, checking for spine and corner damage.
  • By the time he left for Columbia, he owned 847 comics organized by title and issue number, each in a plastic sleeve with a cardboard backing, filling seven long boxes that consumed most of his allotted trunk space.
  • His favorite villain was Kid Miracleman from Miracleman, which he considered the gold standard. He found most other villains disappointing due to structural incompetence.
  • He described feelings as arriving "painted in a magic color," with bright yellow representing noticing, hazard, and fear -- a synesthetic or metaphorical framework for emotional processing.
  • He counted 67 steps from lobby to apartment door including landing turns, not because he needed to but because counting felt correct and loosened the tightness in his chest.
  • The bus ride from Philadelphia to New York took four hours and twenty-seven minutes. He counted the mile markers.
  • His hatred of sweat was a recurring motif, rooted not in the sensation but in its association with germs and illness.
  • He responded to Professor Whitman's Socratic interrogation with enough composure to earn "adequate," which was described as high praise from Whitman. The student beside him exhaled as if she had been holding her breath on his behalf.
  • Interlude TF.2 opens with Pink Floyd's "Money" lyrics and closes with a spoken word excerpt from the same song's outro, framing the interlude's themes of financial power and moral accounting.
  • Fairfax does not drink alcohol. At the McGinty's bar celebration, he held a ginger ale that looked enough like a mixed drink that no one commented.
  • When confronted by four powered criminals (Cryo, Firebrand, Rebrand, Storebrand) in a New York alley after the 1L celebration, he was restrained with hydrokinetic bindings, had water forced into his sinuses, and was branded repeatedly on the chest and abdomen by Firebrand's heat-touch. He escaped by exploiting the steam generated when Firebrand's heat vaporized Cryo's water, macing Cryo and tasering Firebrand. This was his first direct encounter with metahuman violence.
  • His internal monologue at the hospital includes: "Supervillainy is the most fun a boy can have without joining a hedge fund," and "I hold no illusions about what I am. But I think 99 out of 100 Mr. Antithesises live in a much worse world than I do."
  • The reference to "Mr. Espinosa" during the McKinley recruitment ("I can learn, too, Mr. Espinosa. My wheels versus your own.") implies a previous Kingdom operative or contact whose methods informed Fairfax's recruitment strategy.
  • Fairfax explicitly compares himself favorably to mobsters and gangsters, stating they "deserve none of it" and that superheroes "bundle them up by the dozen like cigarettes" while he "hustles on a scale they could never even comprehend."
  • He carries registered firearms and took his wife Sarah to a shooting range, remembering it fondly.
  • His legal work through Alcott & Associates and Tremont & Fairfax provides him with legitimate access to prisons, as demonstrated by his attorney visit to McKinley at Curran-Fromhold. He notes that Tremont & Fairfax's criminal law division is inferior to Alcott & Associates', which is why the McKinley case was transferred.

docs.title: Zara Khan
docs.text: Thirteen-year-old Pakistani-American silicakinetic and member of the Tacony Community Center mentorship program, mentored by Sam Small and Maggie O'Brien.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Zara Khan Aliases N/A Date of Birth Unknown Age 13 Gender Female Ethnicity Pakistani-American Place of Birth Unknown Residence University City rowhouse, Philadelphia, PA Affiliation Tacony Community Center Mentorship Program Former Affiliations Dr. Jensen's Superhuman Support Group Occupation Student (competitive magnet school) Status Active First Appearance Chapter 66 Last Appearance Ongoing

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Zara Khan first appeared as a member of Dr. Jensen's support group for traumatized superhumans, which Sam Small attended during her extended hospital recovery following the Chernobyl confrontation in early 2024. Zara was described as the youngest member of the group, approximately eleven or twelve years old at the time, and was noted for drawing macabre artwork during sessions. Sam initially assessed Zara's powers as ESP-related, unaware of the kinetic component of her abilities.

Zara comes from an upper-middle-class Pakistani-American family in the University City neighborhood of Philadelphia. Her father, Dr. Tariq Khan, is an engineering professor at Drexel University, and her mother, Amina Khan, works as a hospital pharmacist. The family identifies as secular Muslim while maintaining cultural connections. Zara's maternal grandmother recently moved into the household and is more traditionally religious, creating some tension within the home. Zara attends a competitive magnet school and is academically excellent.

In late October 2025, City Councilman Jamal Davis proposed a peer mentoring program for powered youth, identifying Zara as one of four initial cases alongside Liam O'Connor, Alex Kirby, and Jasmine Walker. Zara had been flagged by Dr. Jensen as a candidate due to the dangerous potential of her abilities. She was reunited with Sam during the first mentorship session at the Parkway Central Library in early November 2025, where she revealed the true nature of her powers — silicakinesis, not simply ESP — and disclosed that her father had been contacted by the government about "metahuman containment systems," implying federal awareness of her abilities specifically.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
• Silicakinesis (Glass Manipulation) — Zara possesses the ability to telekinetically manipulate glass and silica-based materials. She can move, lift, and control glass objects at a distance. She can control multiple small objects simultaneously in complex patterns, as demonstrated with glass marbles during mentorship training sessions.
  • Glass Sensing / Silica Echolocation — Zara can sense "through" nearby glass she is able to manipulate, creating a form of echolocation or remote perception. This sensory component operates within an approximate thirty-foot radius and allows her to detect and identify glass objects even with her eyes closed. This ability was initially mistaken for ESP by both Zara and others in Dr. Jensen's support group.
  • Selective Filtering — Through training with Sam, Zara has developed the ability to filter her glass awareness, isolating individual objects from the ambient sensory input rather than being overwhelmed by all glass within her range. She describes the process as "tuning a radio, finding just one frequency."

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Larger glass objects such as windows and mirrors tend to shatter when Zara attempts to control them; her fine control is currently limited to smaller objects.
  • A previous school incident involved accidentally shattering a classroom window while looking through it, indicating that passive perception and active manipulation can blur together involuntarily.
  • Her sensory abilities can produce overwhelming input, particularly in environments with many glass surfaces, requiring ongoing training to filter awareness.
  • Her power triggers include anxiety, being startled, and intense concentration — emotional states common to a thirteen-year-old, making involuntary activation a persistent risk.
  • The kinetic component of her power is considered genuinely dangerous, as glass shards weaponized through telekinesis would be lethal. Therapy and training guidance deliberately avoids developing this capacity.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text:
• Receives power control training from Sam Small and Maggie O'Brien through the Tacony Community Center mentorship program.
  • Has learned selective glass sensing exercises, practicing identification of individual glass objects with eyes closed and lifting single objects without affecting others nearby.
  • Maintains a personalized emergency protocol: physical grounding techniques (feet on floor, hands against solid objects) to regain control when powers activate involuntarily.
  • Academically excellent student at a competitive magnet school, with a methodical and analytical approach to understanding her superhuman condition.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text:
Zara is quiet, smart, and bookish, embodying what Sam and the narrative describe as the "good shy" — a person who is genuinely curious and inquisitive when discussing topics within her knowledge, willing to engage on her interests rather than retreating from conversation entirely. She takes an academic and methodical approach to her powers, treating them as a problem to be studied and understood rather than something to fear or weaponize. Her willingness to ask questions and express gratitude distinguishes her from more withdrawn peers in the mentorship program.

Zara has a taste for macabre art and horror movies, a small rebellion against her parents' preference for educational media that is entirely unrelated to her activation or powers. This aesthetic sensibility was evident from her earliest appearances in Dr. Jensen's support group, where she drew disturbing artwork. Despite the "villain power" nature of her abilities — glass shards as weapons being an archetypal antagonist tool — Zara herself is a fundamentally benign person, and the tension between what her power could do and who she actually is forms a key part of her characterization.

docs.text: Book Role Key Events Intermission 4.5: Amnion Supporting First appeared in Chapter 66 as a member of Dr. Jensen's support group for traumatized superhumans during Sam's hospital recovery. docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Zara's power was initially misidentified as ESP by Sam and apparently by Zara herself, due to the sensory component of her silicakinesis being the most noticeable manifestation before she understood the kinetic aspect.
  • The character reference guide explicitly notes that her macabre taste in art and horror movies is "completely unrelated to her activation," preempting the assumption that her dark aesthetic is connected to her powers or trauma.
  • Her power is described as a classic "villain power" wielded by a benign person, creating a deliberate narrative tension between the destructive potential of glass manipulation and Zara's gentle personality.
  • Her father's Volvo is mentioned twice in the canon documents as his vehicle for picking Zara up from training sessions.
  • Zara's emergency grounding technique — feet on floor, hands against solid objects — is notably physical and tactile, contrasting with Liam O'Connor's breathing-based technique for his dragon transformation.
  • Sam explicitly addressed racial disparity in the justice system to Zara and Jasmine during the Songbird debrief, noting that "the system is significantly less nice" to them than to white-presenting mentees.
  • Her current status as of the beginning of Arc 16 is described as "Learning control. Making progress with selective sensing exercises."

docs.title: Zero
docs.text: Power-negating member of Pattinson's Pals who can suppress metahuman abilities at range, posing a unique threat to Sam Small and her allies during the Tacony Charter crisis.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Unknown Aliases Zero Date of Birth Unknown Age Unknown Gender Male Ethnicity Unknown Place of Birth Unknown Residence Philadelphia, PA (presumed) Affiliation Pattinson's Pals Former Affiliations N/A Occupation Unknown Status Active First Appearance Chapter 109 Last Appearance Chapter 117

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Zero is a metahuman with the ability to negate other metahumans' powers at range, operating as a member of Pattinson's Pals under the leadership of Patriot (Richard Johnson) and Egalitarian (Natalie). Almost nothing is known about Zero's personal identity, history, or the origin of his abilities.

Zero first appeared during a confrontation with Sam Small and Maggie O'Brien (Flashpoint) in Tacony during a training session in September 2024. He and a group of Pattinson's Pals followers stalked and chased Sam and Maggie through the streets after negating their powers from a distance, forcing the pair to flee on foot until they escaped his effective range. Zero later appeared flanking Patriot at the homecoming confrontation at Tacony Charter Academy and at a subsequent rally at Dilworth Park.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: No official PERKS assessment on file.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text: • Area-of-Effect Power Negation -- Suppresses metahuman abilities within a radius around himself without requiring physical contact. Both Sam's enhanced senses and Maggie's force fields ceased functioning while within his range. This is notably distinct from Mr. Nothing's power negation, which requires direct physical touch.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• His effective range has finite limits; Sam and Maggie's powers returned once they put sufficient distance between themselves and Zero during the Tacony chase.
  • Specific upper limits of his range, whether his negation is selective or indiscriminate, and whether it affects all power types equally are not documented.
  • During the chase, Sam noted that her old Deathgirl wound resurfaced without her regeneration active in Zero's field, suggesting his negation affects passive and autonomous powers as well as active ones.

docs.title: Training & Skills
docs.text: • No documented training or non-power skills.

docs.title: Personality
docs.text: Zero's personality is largely unknown. He operates as a loyal follower within Pattinson's Pals, appearing at rallies and confrontations alongside Patriot. His willingness to chase two teenagers through the streets of Tacony with a group of followers suggests an aggressive enforcement mentality consistent with the Pals' vigilante ideology.

docs.title: Relationships
docs.text: Character Relationship Notes Richard Johnson (Patriot) Leader Flanks Patriot at rallies and public events. Operates under Patriot's direction as part of Pattinson's Pals. Natalie (Egalitarian) Teammate Fellow Pattinson's Pals member. Both possess powers that counter metahumans in different ways -- Zero negates powers directly while Egalitarian's vertigo affects only non-powered individuals. Sam Small (Bloodhound) Adversary Chased Sam through the streets of Tacony after negating her powers. Appeared at subsequent confrontations. Maggie O'Brien (Flashpoint) Adversary Negated Maggie's force fields during the Tacony training session confrontation.

docs.title: Arc Appearances
docs.text: Book Role Key Events Book 7: Security Supporting Confronts Sam and Maggie during a training session in an abandoned Tacony lot (Ch. 109), negating their powers at range and forcing them to flee through the streets of Tacony with his followers in pursuit. Sam and Maggie escape once they exit his range and reach the Tacony Music Hall (Ch. 110). Later appears flanking Patriot at the homecoming confrontation at Tacony Charter Academy (Ch. 112) and at the Dilworth Park rally (Ch. 117).

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Zero's power negation at range is explicitly contrasted with Mr. Nothing's contact-based power negation, making Zero a qualitatively different and arguably more dangerous threat in the story's power landscape.
  • His appearance is described as distinctive: a fedora, trench coat, and domino mask with baby-blue eyes visible above it.
  • Sam's old Deathgirl wound resurfacing in Zero's field demonstrates that his negation strips even passive regenerative effects, not just actively deployed powers.
  • His full capabilities, identity, origin, and connection to any broader organization beyond Pattinson's Pals remain entirely unexplored as of Book 16.
  • The plot thread tracker classifies Zero's power negation as an OPEN thread (Thread 19, Books 6-7), noting that power negation is "extremely rare and dangerous in this setting" and that his area-of-effect version is "far more threatening" than Mr. Nothing's touch-based variant.

docs.title: Project Titan
docs.text: A classified U.S. military program spanning 2006 to 2013 that first attempted to artificially induce superhuman abilities in soldiers and, after that effort failed, pivoted to integrating naturally occurring metahumans into military command structures.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Project Titan Date March 15, 2006 – October 12, 2013 Location United States (multiple classified military facilities) Participants Joint Chiefs of Staff; Project Titan Oversight Committee; General James D. Thurman; 500 military volunteers (Phase One); various superhuman service members (Phase Two) Casualties 3 fatalities during Phase One experimentation; 67 subjects with severe health complications; 89 PTSD diagnoses among volunteers Outcome Phase One deemed infeasible and terminated; Phase Two achieved partial success with 65% integration rate but faced diminishing returns and was recommended for restructuring Significance Demonstrated that artificial superhuman induction is not viable with current technology and established foundational doctrine for metahuman military integration First Referenced Worldbuilding article: "Project Titan"

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Project Titan was a top-secret U.S. Department of Defense initiative authorized by the Joint Chiefs of Staff in March 2006. The program was conceived in response to the growing global prevalence of superhuman individuals and the national security implications of that trend. Over the course of seven years, it underwent two distinct phases: an experimental program aimed at creating superhumans through artificial means, and a subsequent integration effort focused on recruiting and fielding naturally powered personnel within existing military structures.

The project was classified at the TOP SECRET//NOFORN level throughout its existence. Its Phase One findings -- that artificial induction yields results statistically indistinguishable from natural activation rates, at enormous human and financial cost -- became a defining conclusion in U.S. metahuman defense policy. Phase Two, while more successful, encountered persistent challenges in command integration, retention, and the psychological toll of superhuman military service.

Both phases were overseen by the Project Titan Oversight Committee. General James D. Thurman authored the Phase Two final assessment, which recommended a continued but more targeted approach to superhuman military utilization.

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
By the mid-2000s, the increasing global emergence of superhuman individuals raised urgent questions about military preparedness. Conventional armed forces lacked doctrine, equipment, or organizational frameworks for operating alongside -- or against -- metahuman combatants. The Joint Chiefs of Staff authorized Project Titan on March 15, 2006, with an initial two-year mandate and three core objectives: developing reliable methods for artificial induction of superhuman abilities, understanding the underlying mechanisms of superhuman activation, and creating a controllable source of superhuman military assets.

The project operated against a broader policy backdrop shaped by incidents such as the Tesla Incident, which had already demonstrated the catastrophic consequences of conventional forces engaging superhumans without adequate preparation. The perceived strategic necessity of fielding superhuman assets of America's own -- rather than relying solely on civilian hero infrastructure -- drove the program's aggressive timeline and substantial funding.

docs.title: Phase One: Artificial Induction (2006–2008)
docs.text: Time Event March 15, 2006 Joint Chiefs of Staff authorize Project Titan with a two-year mandate 2006–2008 500 military volunteers recruited from various branches; rigorous screening and informed consent obtained 2006–2008 Radiation exposure experiments conducted (gamma, cosmic, and other types); no successful activations; 12% of subjects develop severe health complications 2006–2008 Chemical and biological agent trials using compounds synthesized from known superhuman blood work; 2 subjects display temporary enhanced strength, but effects prove unreplicable and result in organ failure 2006–2008 Psychological stress tests involving simulated near-death experiences; 3 subjects activate latent abilities, consistent with the general population activation rate of 0.15% 2006–2008 Genetic manipulation via CRISPR and gene therapy targeting theorized superhuman genes; no successful activations; 1 subject develops uncontrolled cellular growth and is terminated August 12, 2008 Phase One assessment report submitted; committee recommends immediate cessation of all artificial induction experiments and transition to Phase Two

docs.title: Phase Two: Integration and Utilization (2008–2013)
docs.text: Time Event 2008 Project restructuring begins; initial recruitment of naturally occurring superhuman personnel commences 2008–2009 Establishment of 5 dedicated superhuman training bases, 3 R&D centers, and 2 specialized medical facilities 2008–2009 Development of standardized training protocols, adaptive equipment, and new command structures for superhuman units 2009–2013 Approximately 65% of identified superhuman personnel successfully integrated into specialized units or existing forces 2009–2013 Superhuman units demonstrate effectiveness in hostage rescue, disaster response, and special operations; performance in conventional warfare scenarios proves less impactful than anticipated 2009–2013 Approximately 35% of superhuman service members struggle with military structure adaptation; some receive honorable discharges 2009–2013 Higher-than-expected rates of PTSD and stress-related disorders observed among superhuman personnel 2009–2013 Retention challenges emerge as superhuman service members leave for the private sector or cite disagreement with military structure October 12, 2013 General James D. Thurman submits Phase Two final assessment to the Secretary of Defense, recommending continued but more targeted integration

docs.title: Aftermath
docs.text:
The Phase One results carried immediate and far-reaching consequences. All artificial induction experiments were halted, and comprehensive health monitoring was initiated for the 500 volunteers. The human cost was severe: 3 subjects died, 67 suffered severe medical complications, 212 experienced mild to moderate complications, 89 were diagnosed with PTSD, and 134 developed other psychological disorders. Estimated lifetime healthcare costs for affected participants reached $890 million on top of the $1.2 billion already spent on research -- yielding an effective cost of $400 million per activation, with only 3 successes that were statistically insignificant.

Phase Two's aftermath was more nuanced. The integration program successfully proved that superhuman personnel could enhance military capabilities in targeted operational domains. However, the final assessment identified persistent structural problems: command hierarchy friction, resource-intensive individualized training requirements, inadequate psychological support, unresolved questions of international law regarding superhuman warfare, and budgetary strain from diminishing returns. The committee recommended a continued but narrower focus on specialized operations, revised training protocols emphasizing psychological resilience, more flexible command structures, and diplomatic engagement toward international superhuman warfare conventions.

All project data remained classified at the TOP SECRET//NOFORN level.

docs.title: Legacy
docs.text:
Project Titan's most enduring contribution to U.S. metahuman defense policy was its definitive demonstration that artificial superhuman induction is not feasible with existing technology. This conclusion effectively closed a line of military research and redirected strategic thinking toward working with the existing metahuman population rather than attempting to manufacture one.

The infrastructure built during Phase Two -- training bases, R&D centers, medical facilities, and the organizational doctrines developed for superhuman units -- established foundational precedents for how the U.S. military engages with metahuman capabilities. The lessons learned regarding command integration, the psychological burden of superhuman service, and the limitations of superhuman forces in conventional warfare informed subsequent military planning and contributed to the broader national framework for metahuman governance alongside systems such as PERKS and the NSRA.

The project also highlighted the tension between military ambition and ethical constraint. The high casualty and complication rates of Phase One, and the mental health toll of Phase Two, underscored the human costs inherent in treating superhuman abilities as military assets -- a tension that continues to shape policy debates around metahuman service.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• The Phase One activation rate of 0.6% (3 out of 500) was not statistically significant compared to the general population activation rate of 0.15% (p > 0.05), meaning the experiments produced no measurable effect beyond natural occurrence.
  • The total five-year budget for Phase Two was $17 billion, with $5 billion allocated in the first year alone.
  • Phase Two required approximately 5,000 support staff across training, research, administrative, and medical roles.
  • The Phase One report recommended classifying all project data under the same legal framework (U.S. Code, Title 18, Section 798) used for the PERKS assessment documentation.
  • General James D. Thurman is the only named individual associated with the Project Titan Oversight Committee; the Phase One report's signatories are fully redacted.

docs.text:

  • THE FACTSHEET.txt (lines 2236–2283) -- Condensed reference for Phase One and Phase Two statistics, infrastructure details, key challenges, and budget figures.

docs.title: The Big Raid
docs.text: The largest coordinated international operation against superhuman organized crime, carried out in 2018 under the banner of the newly formed GESSOC task force, which dismantled the global criminal hierarchy and permanently reshaped the underworld.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name The Big Raid Date March 2018 Location Global (simultaneous operations across multiple countries) Participants GESSOC (Global Enforcement and Suppression of Superhuman Organized Crime); international superhero teams; national law enforcement agencies Casualties Unknown (specific figures not reported) Outcome Dismantlement of major superhuman and traditional criminal empires worldwide; mass arrests and defections of high-ranking crime figures; seizure of illicit assets on a global scale Significance The single most consequential law enforcement action against organized crime in modern history, credited with destroying the old criminal order but also blamed for the rise of a more dangerous, decentralized successor First Referenced Worldbuilding article: "The Day the World Shifted: Five Years After The Founding of GESSOC"

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The Big Raid was a global, coordinated assault on superhuman criminal networks launched in 2018 by GESSOC, an international task force assembled specifically for the operation. Drawing on the combined resources of governments, superhero teams, and law enforcement agencies across the world, the operation targeted the supervillain organizations and criminal syndicates that had entrenched themselves in the global underworld over the preceding decades. It remains the most sweeping anti-crime operation ever conducted.

The Raid succeeded in its primary objective: the rapid and systematic destruction of the world's most powerful criminal organizations. High-ranking crime lords, both superhuman and non-superhuman, were arrested in rapid succession. Many others turned informant to save themselves, accelerating the collapse of their own organizations. The operation exposed the deep entanglement between superhuman criminal groups and traditional organized crime families, ultimately leading GESSOC to expand its scope well beyond its original superhuman-focused mandate.

While widely regarded as a historic achievement, the Big Raid also had severe unintended consequences. The power vacuum left by the fallen empires gave rise to a new generation of criminal syndicates -- faceless, decentralized, and far more violent than their predecessors. The economic disruption was widespread, and the legal and political aftershocks continue to reverberate years later. As of 2023, five years after the event, its legacy remains deeply contested.

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
By the late 2010s, superhuman criminal organizations had grown into a formidable global problem. Supervillain groups had accumulated enormous power and influence, operating with near-impunity in many jurisdictions. These groups were not isolated actors; they had become deeply enmeshed with traditional organized crime networks -- mafias, triads, cartels, and similar syndicates -- forming a vast, interconnected criminal infrastructure. Superhuman abilities were used to expand the reach of these enterprises and to insulate their leadership from law enforcement.

The scale and sophistication of these intertwined networks exceeded the capacity of any single nation's law enforcement to address. In response, GESSOC was founded in March 2018 as a purpose-built international task force. It was not a preexisting agency but was created specifically for this mission: to coordinate and execute a simultaneous worldwide strike against superhuman organized crime. GESSOC brought together superhero teams and intelligence resources from across the globe under a unified operational command.

docs.title: Timeline
docs.text: Time Event March 2018 GESSOC formally established as an international task force with the mandate to dismantle superhuman criminal networks March 2018 (initial phase) Coordinated strikes launched against high-profile supervillain organizations and known criminal metahumans worldwide Weeks following initial strikes GESSOC operatives uncover deep links between superhuman criminal groups and traditional organized crime syndicates; operational scope expanded accordingly Subsequent weeks Surgical raids dismantle major criminal organizations in rapid succession; high-ranking crime lords arrested or turned informant, triggering cascading collapses of criminal hierarchies Immediate post-Raid period Power vacuum triggers intense turf wars and instability as smaller gangs and emerging superhuman criminals scramble for control Months following Drug prices spike sharply; local businesses tied to laundering networks collapse; seized assets redistributed, primarily through government channels 2018--2019 New, decentralized criminal syndicates begin to consolidate in the vacuum left by the old empires By 2023 The post-Raid criminal landscape has stabilized into a new paradigm of anonymous, fluid, and more violent criminal networks

docs.title: Aftermath
docs.text: The immediate consequences of the Big Raid were dramatic and far-reaching, touching every dimension of global society.

docs.title: Criminal Landscape
docs.text:
The destruction of the old criminal hierarchy created a massive power vacuum. Smaller gangs and opportunistic metahuman criminals rushed to claim territory, sparking a chaotic period of turf wars and street violence. The organizations that eventually consolidated bore little resemblance to their predecessors. The new syndicates were faceless, decentralized, and anonymous -- lacking the named leadership, codes of honor, and public notoriety of the old crime families. They operated with cold pragmatism, favoring stealth and technological sophistication over spectacle. Loyalty within these groups was transactional and fleeting, with criminals shifting between organizations constantly, making infiltration and prosecution far more difficult.

The new criminal element was also markedly more violent. Operating under the assumption that capture meant certain defeat, these criminals showed a far greater willingness to engage in lethal confrontations with law enforcement and superheroes alike. Street-level violence increased, and civilians were more frequently caught in the crossfire.

docs.title: Economic Impact
docs.text:
The Raid caused immediate and severe economic disruption. The abrupt collapse of black market industries -- particularly the drug trade -- sent shockwaves through local and national economies. Drug prices spiked, creating both a public health crisis and a surge in drug-related crime. Numerous small businesses that had unknowingly served as fronts for money laundering operations lost their funding and shuttered, devastating neighborhood economies and eliminating jobs. Seized illicit assets were redistributed, but the process was uneven and disproportionately benefited government agencies rather than affected communities.

On a macroeconomic level, corporations were forced to overhaul financial safeguards in response to the exposure of laundering networks, driving up compliance costs. Consumer spending patterns fluctuated in affected areas. Over time, these pressures spurred innovations in corporate governance and transparency, but the short-term pain was widely felt.

docs.title: Legal and Political Responses
docs.text:
Legal systems worldwide were forced to adapt rapidly. In the United States, federal funding for the NSRA and other superhuman law enforcement units was increased substantially. Some states passed legislation granting these units expanded pursuit and arrest powers. Many state and municipal governments also increased funding for juvenile superhuman training and recruitment programs, aiming to bring young metahumans into the lawful fold before they could turn to crime.

In Europe, several nations expanded surveillance capabilities and introduced stricter anti-terror legislation. Japan and South Korea pursued a more regulated integration of superhuman abilities into their legal systems, emphasizing oversight and ethical guidelines. Russia and North Korea took a more authoritarian approach, granting near-unlimited power to their superhuman enforcement agencies, drawing international criticism for potential human rights violations.

Public reaction was sharply divided. Civil liberties advocates and rights organizations protested the expansion of government powers, particularly the increased use of superhuman abilities in law enforcement. Conversely, a significant portion of the public, driven by fear of the new and more unpredictable criminal landscape, supported stronger measures. This divide was especially pronounced in urban areas, where superhuman crime was most visible.

docs.title: Legacy
docs.text:
The Big Raid is widely regarded as one of the most pivotal events in recent world history. Its legacy is defined by a fundamental duality: it was an extraordinary success in its stated objective of dismantling entrenched criminal empires, yet it simultaneously gave birth to a criminal landscape that many consider more dangerous and harder to combat than what came before.

The operation permanently altered public perception of superheroes and supervillains. In the immediate wake of the Raid, superheroes enjoyed a surge of public support and admiration. Over time, however, growing awareness of collateral damage, questions about accountability, and concerns about the expanding role of superhumans in law enforcement eroded some of that goodwill. The Raid also complicated the public image of supervillains: some had played roles in the takedown of criminal networks, blurring the line between hero and villain in ways that persist in public discourse.

The romanticized image of the powerful crime lord -- charismatic, operating by a code, larger than life -- was replaced in the public imagination by an anonymous, faceless menace. This shift produced a pervasive unease, a sense that the threats of the post-Raid world are less comprehensible and therefore more frightening than those of the old order.

On an institutional level, the Raid demonstrated the potential of large-scale international cooperation between governments and superhero organizations, establishing a model for future collaborative operations. GESSOC's formation and operational success proved that coordinated global action against superhuman threats was achievable, even if its secondary consequences were not fully anticipated. The lessons of the Big Raid continue to inform policy debates about superhuman law enforcement, civil liberties, economic resilience, and the proper balance between security and freedom.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• The Big Raid is the subject of a seven-part retrospective series by journalist Alex Chen, published in HeroWatch Today between April and June 2023 to mark the five-year anniversary of the operation.
  • GESSOC was founded specifically for the Big Raid and did not exist as an organization prior to 2018.
  • The operation initially targeted only superhuman criminal groups but expanded its scope after discovering that these groups were deeply intertwined with traditional organized crime networks such as mafias, cartels, and triads.
  • Among the unintended economic consequences of the Raid, drug prices spiked nationwide, an effect noted to be less severe in states like Colorado and California where legal marijuana was already available.
  • The Raid led to a notable increase in government investment in juvenile metahuman recruitment programs, reflecting a strategic shift toward prevention rather than purely reactive enforcement.
