docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The emergence of superhumans has fundamentally reshaped the media landscape. Traditional outlets such as The Washington Post continue to serve as primary vehicles for investigative journalism, but the subjects they cover now regularly include technopathic financial crimes, anti-superhuman political movements, and the intersection of metahuman abilities with public policy. Reporters must navigate classified information, superhuman threat classifications, and the political sensitivities surrounding metahuman integration when covering these stories.

Alongside legacy journalism, new forms of investigative work have emerged. Collectives of amateur cyber investigators operate in the digital space, conducting independent inquiries into metahuman-linked incidents and publishing findings that sometimes challenge or supplement official narratives. The relationship between these independent actors and traditional media is symbiotic: mainstream outlets amplify and contextualize the raw intelligence that digital collectives uncover, while the collectives benefit from the credibility and reach that established publications provide.

Media coverage of metahuman affairs carries significant societal weight. News reporting shapes public perception of superhumans, influences legislative debates around metahuman rights and regulation, and can either inflame or temper tensions between powered and non-powered populations. The political dimensions of this coverage are considerable, as advocacy groups on all sides actively seek to leverage media attention for their causes.

docs.title: Investigative Journalism and Metahuman Crime
docs.text: Traditional investigative journalism has adapted its methods to address the unique challenges posed by metahuman-related stories. Reporters covering technopathic crime, for instance, must develop literacy in cybersecurity, digital forensics, and the operational characteristics of specific power categories. Helena Fitzgerald's investigation into The London Broker for The Washington Post exemplifies this approach, tracing a two-decade-old financial manipulation case involving a technopath who interfaced directly with the London Stock Exchange's digital systems in late 2000. Such reporting requires collaboration with technical experts and, increasingly, with independent digital investigators.

docs.title: Independent Digital Investigative Collectives
docs.text: Groups such as NetShadows represent a new class of media actor in the metahuman era. NetShadows is a collective of amateur cyber sleuths specializing in ethical hacking and the recovery of buried digital information. Led publicly by Jamie Torres, an MIT graduate and former software developer, the group discovered encrypted communications linking The London Broker to a broader network of technopaths operating across multiple incidents over two decades. These collectives operate outside traditional newsrooms but function as de facto investigative units, feeding discoveries into the broader media ecosystem.

docs.title: Breaking News and Crisis Reporting
docs.text: Metahuman incidents -- whether superhuman-related violence, protests, or large-scale power activations -- demand rapid-response journalism. Coverage of the Manhattan HFC rally demonstrates this dynamic: reporters on the ground provided real-time accounts of the escalation from peaceful protest to violent confrontation, while simultaneously incorporating official statements from law enforcement, elected officials, and legal commentators. The speed at which such events unfold, combined with the potential for superhuman-scale destruction, places extraordinary demands on news organizations.

docs.title: Leaked Communications and Social Media
docs.text: Leaked internal documents and social media disclosures play a prominent role in metahuman-era journalism. In the case of The London Broker, encrypted emails uncovered by NetShadows implicated Sir Edward Langham, a senior Tory MP, in collaboration with a technopathic network. In the Manhattan rally incident, internal HFC communications leaked on social media suggested that the organization's leadership anticipated and may have encouraged the escalation to violence. These leaks frequently drive news cycles, shape public opinion, and prompt official investigations.

docs.title: Expert Commentary and Legal Analysis
docs.text: Media coverage of metahuman affairs relies heavily on expert commentary. Legal scholars such as Professor Elena Vargas of NYU Law School provide analysis on the implications of metahuman-related incidents for civil liberties, criminal law, and legislative policy. This expert layer adds depth to reporting and helps the public understand the legal and regulatory dimensions of events that might otherwise be reduced to spectacle.

docs.title: History
docs.text:
The media's engagement with metahuman affairs has evolved in parallel with the growing presence of superhumans in public life. Early coverage tended toward sensationalism, treating metahuman incidents as isolated curiosities. The London Stock Exchange disruption of late 2000 -- in which a technopath manipulated trading systems, causing stocks to fluctuate wildly and enabling fraudulent trades -- marked a turning point. The incident demonstrated that metahuman abilities could threaten critical infrastructure and global financial systems, elevating superhuman affairs from niche interest to front-page news.

Over the following two decades, "The London Broker" became a media legend: a symbol of the unpredictable impact superhumans could have on society. The case was widely reported as the work of a lone actor until NetShadows' discovery of encrypted documents suggested a coordinated network of technopaths behind multiple high-profile incidents. This revelation, published through collaboration with mainstream outlets like The Washington Post, forced a reassessment of how the media had framed the original story and highlighted the limitations of early metahuman crime reporting.

Domestic coverage has also intensified around the social and political dimensions of metahuman existence. The rise of advocacy organizations such as the Humanity First Coalition, which opposes what it characterizes as preferential treatment of superhumans, has generated a steady stream of politically charged stories. The Manhattan rally -- organized by HFC's New York chapter under leader Alex Mercator and culminating in targeted attacks on a facility rumored to house newly-activated individuals -- exemplifies how metahuman-related protest movements have become major news events with far-reaching implications.

docs.title: Shaping Public Perception
docs.text: Media coverage is one of the primary mechanisms through which the general public forms opinions about superhumans. Investigative pieces that expose metahuman crime networks can reinforce fears about unchecked superhuman power, while crisis reporting on anti-superhuman violence can generate sympathy for metahuman communities. The framing choices made by editors and reporters carry outsized influence in a landscape where most citizens have limited direct experience with powered individuals.

docs.title: Political and Legislative Impact
docs.text: Journalism and leaked communications frequently catalyze political action. The NetShadows revelations concerning Sir Edward Langham's alleged ties to a technopathic network sparked calls for parliamentary investigation in the United Kingdom. In the United States, the Manhattan rally prompted legal experts to predict new legislation addressing domestic extremism targeting metahumans. Deputy Mayor Linda Choi and Governor Andrew Hartman both issued public statements in response to media coverage, illustrating how reporting drives the political conversation around superhuman policy.

docs.title: Anti-Superhuman Movements and Media Strategy
docs.text: Organizations such as the Humanity First Coalition explicitly leverage media attention as a strategic tool. Leaked internal HFC communications suggest that leadership anticipated violent escalation at the Manhattan rally and may have viewed the resulting coverage as beneficial to their cause. This instrumentalization of the news cycle raises difficult questions about editorial responsibility, the amplification of extremist messaging, and the line between covering a story and becoming part of it.

docs.title: Cybersecurity and Information Warfare
docs.text: The existence of technopaths introduces unique vulnerabilities into the media ecosystem. A technopath capable of interfacing with digital systems can potentially manipulate data, plant false evidence, or disrupt communications infrastructure. The London Broker case demonstrated that technopathic abilities could be used not only for financial fraud but also for broader information warfare, forcing news organizations and cybersecurity firms to develop new protocols for verifying the integrity of digital evidence.

docs.title: PERKS Assessment
docs.text: The standardized power classification and threat assessment system used by the National Superhuman Response Agency to categorize metahuman abilities, behavior, and legal status in the United States.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Paranormal Entity Rating/Kill Score Also Known As PERKS; PERKS Power Classification System Category Law / Military Discovered/Established Unknown Key Figures N/A Governing Body National Superhuman Response Agency (NSRA) First Appearance Worldbuilding article: "Superpowers and the PERKS Assessment"

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The Paranormal Entity Rating/Kill Score (PERKS) is the primary framework through which metahuman abilities are classified, quantified, and assessed in the United States. Administered by the National Superhuman Response Agency (NSRA), the system serves both strategic and legal functions: it provides tactical intelligence for containment, recovery, and neutralization operations, while also underpinning the regulatory infrastructure that governs metahuman activity across the country.

PERKS assessments assign each metahuman a structured classification code describing the nature of their power, along with numerical ratings across five scales that measure the magnitude, controllability, and danger of their abilities. The system is complemented by a parallel legal classification framework that sorts metahumans into status categories ranging from unlicensed vigilantes to government-employed Registered Superhuman Entities, and criminal designations ranging from low-level offenders to Classified Threat Entities. Together, these systems form the backbone of American metahuman policy.

The PERKS documentation is classified, and unauthorized dissemination may result in penalty under the U.S. Code, Title 18, Section 798.

docs.title: Classification Code Structure
docs.text: Each metahuman power receives a structured classification code composed of four components: a primary category letter, a numerical power ranking, a targeting type, a context type, and a range type. For example, a classification of G4/S/P/T indicates a Gigant-category power at ranking 4, targeting the self, physical in context, with touch range. Each individual power a metahuman possesses receives its own separate classification and power ranking.

docs.title: Primary Categories (A-H)
docs.text:
Metahuman capabilities are classified into eight categories that describe the fundamental operational nature of the ability:

  • Adjust (A) -- The capability to modify existing variables within a system without creating new or eliminating existing ones.
  • Brain (B) -- Superior or alternative cognitive, sensory, or information processing abilities, encompassing enhanced memory, intelligence, and sensory perception.
  • Create (C) -- The ability to bring into existence objects, entities, or phenomena, typically on a macroscopic scale.
  • Delete (D) -- The capability to erase or negate objects, entities, thoughts, or phenomena from existence, functioning at both macroscopic and microscopic levels.
  • Employ (E) -- The power to augment or enhance characteristics or properties of various entities by adding new attributes to systems.
  • Filch (F) -- The ability to extract specific properties or characteristics from objects or entities, distinct from total erasure or mere modification.
  • Gigant (G) -- Extraordinary physical or biological characteristics, which may be innate or activated at will. These traits are usually active by default.
  • Hopper (H) -- Advanced locomotion abilities, such as teleportation, flight, or super-speed.

docs.title: Targeting Types
docs.text:
Targeting describes what or whom a power affects:

  • Self (S) -- The power affects the user.
  • Other (O) -- The power affects other human individuals.
  • Nonsentient (N) -- The power affects nonsentient entities such as animals, plants, and in some cases machines.
  • Inanimate (I) -- The power affects inanimate objects, either specific ones or in general.
  • Environment (E) -- The power affects the environment or nontargeted entities in the environment.

docs.title: Context Types
docs.text:
Context describes the domain in which a power operates:

  • Physical (P) -- The power is physical and usually tangible in nature.
  • Emotional (E) -- The power targets emotions or emotional processing.
  • Mental (M) -- The power targets cognition, sensory information, or thought processes.
  • Undefined (X) -- The power targets something that cannot be defined using the Physical/Emotional/Mental categories, such as other powers.

docs.title: Range Types
docs.text:
Range describes the effective radius of a power:

  • Touch (T) -- Limited to what the user can physically touch, or themselves.
  • Room (R) -- Approximately a 1-9 meter radius.
  • Block (B) -- Approximately a 10-99 meter radius.
  • Visual (V) -- Approximately a 100-999 meter radius.
  • Mile (M) -- Approximately a 1-9 kilometer radius.
  • Postmile (P) -- Beyond a 9 kilometer radius.

docs.title: Rating Scales
docs.text:
All five rating scales operate on a 0-10 integer scale:

  • Power Ranking (0-10) -- Measures the magnitude of a metahuman ability. A score of 0 corresponds to capabilities practically indistinguishable from a normal human, while a score of 10 indicates capabilities that are impossible to replicate, immense in scale, and/or indefensible. Each individual power a metahuman possesses receives its own power ranking.
  • Control Rating (0-10) -- Measures the metahuman's ability to regulate, direct, or suppress their power. A score of 0 implies involuntary or uncontrolled manifestation, while a score of 10 indicates full mastery and precision.
  • Hostility Rating (0-10) -- Assesses a metahuman's antagonism towards state actors. A score of 0 is equivalent to an average law-abiding citizen, while a score of 10 denotes a high-threat entity demonstrating terrorist or anarchistic behavior.
  • Collateral Damage Potential (0-10) -- Measures potential for harm. A score of 0 denotes an entity incapable of causing loss of life or significant property damage, while a score of 10 indicates the capacity for mass casualties (thousands of fatalities) and/or billions of dollars in property damage.
  • Overall Threat Level (0-10) -- A comprehensive assessment of a metahuman's threat to public safety. This aggregate rating considers the power classification and ranking, control, hostility, and collateral damage potential together.

docs.title: History
docs.text:
The exact date of the PERKS system's establishment is unknown. It was developed by or for the National Superhuman Response Agency as the United States' standardized approach to classifying and tracking the metahuman population. The accompanying legal classification framework, which defines the status categories for both lawful and criminal metahumans, was established alongside or in connection with the PERKS system to provide the regulatory infrastructure for metahuman governance.

The broader policy environment in which PERKS operates reflects lessons learned from catastrophic metahuman incidents, including the Tesla Incident, which underscored the potential for devastating escalation when conventional law enforcement engages with superhumans. This history contributed to the prevailing policy of allowing superhumans to manage and regulate each other rather than relying primarily on conventional forces.

docs.title: Implications
docs.text:
The PERKS system shapes virtually every aspect of metahuman life in the United States. For heroes, it determines their legal standing, the scope of their authorized activity, and the degree of oversight they face. For law enforcement and military operations, it provides the tactical intelligence needed to plan engagements with hostile metahumans, informing decisions about containment strategy, resource allocation, and the authorization of lethal force.

The legal classification tiers create a structured pathway for metahumans who wish to operate within the law. The LUMA licensing system, with its modest fee structure ($40 initial, $20 biennial renewal), is designed to bring the majority of metahumans into a regulated framework. Licensed and Registered metahumans receive tangible benefits including legal immunity for authorized actions and access to specialized healthcare suited to their physiology and secret identity requirements.

On the criminal side, the tiered classification system allows the NSRA and law enforcement to allocate resources proportionally. Known Superhuman Criminals receive standard law enforcement attention, while Ideological Power Entities trigger deployment of specialized NSRA units and interagency counter-terrorism coordination. Classified Threat Entities -- the rarest and most dangerous category -- are subject to continuous high-level surveillance including satellite and SIGINT monitoring, with pre-approved authorization for lethal force under specific conditions.

The system also reflects and reinforces the broader societal compact around metahuman activity. Approximately 500,000 individuals in America possess powers or the potential to gain them, and over two-thirds of metahumans opt to avoid the superhero-supervillain dynamic entirely, instead using their abilities in the workplace or for personal use. The PERKS and LUMA frameworks accommodate this majority by providing a legal pathway for non-combatant metahuman activity.

docs.title: Power Laws
docs.text: The body of federal legislation, legal precedent, and regulatory frameworks governing the use, registration, and criminal application of metahuman abilities in the United States.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Power Laws (collective term for metahuman-related legislation) Also Known As Superhuman legislation; powers legislation; metahuman regulatory law Category Law Discovered/Established 2005 onward (earliest major statute: Mind Privacy Act of 2005; earliest major case: United States v. docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
"Power Laws" is the informal umbrella term for the expanding body of American legislation, case law, and regulatory policy that governs metahuman abilities. Since the emergence of superhumans in the 1980s, the United States has developed a complex and evolving legal infrastructure to address the challenges posed by individuals who can manipulate weather, read minds, interface with digital systems, shapeshift, or wield other extraordinary capabilities. This legislative body touches virtually every domain of law -- criminal, civil, employment, environmental, aviation, digital privacy, and insurance -- and has generated its own specialized bar of attorneys, regulatory commissions, and enforcement mechanisms.

The legislation broadly falls into several categories: registration and licensing requirements (centered on the LUMA system), power-specific regulatory acts targeting abilities deemed uniquely dangerous or intrusive (telepathy, geometeorological engineering, digital interface, flight, shapeshifting), criminal law adaptations (RICO applications, the Davis framework for powers-as-weapons), and civil rights protections (anti-discrimination statutes, privacy rights). The framework is administered primarily by the NSRA, though individual acts may establish their own specialized regulatory bodies.

The power laws remain a subject of significant public debate. Critics range from civil libertarians who view the regulatory apparatus as government overreach to commentators like William "Bill" Thompson who oppose specific mandates on ideological grounds. Meanwhile, an estimated 30,000 powered individuals live entirely outside the LUMA system in an underground network of safe houses, handlers, and shadow clinics, regarding the legal framework as fundamentally hostile to their existence.

docs.title: Registration and Licensing
docs.text:
The foundation of the regulatory framework is the License to Utilize Metahuman Abilities (LUMA), established by the LUMA Act of 2013. LUMA is optional for personal use but mandatory for occupational power use, with an initial fee of $40 and biennial renewal at $20. Unlicensed power use carries a $250 base fine, while entities employing unlicensed metahumans face fines starting at $25,000. The juvenile version (JLUMA) requires annual renewal and carries its own set of restrictions.

An earlier attempt at mandatory registration -- the Superhuman Registration Act of 2008 -- was struck down by the Supreme Court in a 6-3 decision as violating the Fourth Amendment (privacy and search rights) and the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments (due process). The LUMA system was designed as a more constitutionally permissible alternative, framing registration as a voluntary licensing scheme with practical incentives rather than a compulsory mandate.

docs.title: Power-Specific Legislation
docs.text:
Several acts target specific categories of metahuman ability that pose unique regulatory challenges:

  • Mind Privacy Act of 2005 -- Prohibits unauthorized telepathic access to another individual's thoughts, memories, or private mental information. Telepathy is defined as meeting three criteria: information acquisition without physical or digital means, communication of thoughts without conventional language, and independence from traditional sensory input. Violations constitute a misdemeanor punishable by fines of $1,000 to $10,000 and up to six months imprisonment, escalating to a felony with up to three years imprisonment for repeated or aggravated offenses. Exceptions exist for court-authorized law enforcement activity and imminent danger situations.

  • Morales Act of 2005 -- Named after Lana "Facsimile" Morales, a shapeshifting actress whose early career in Hollywood exposed a legal vacuum around metahuman impersonation. The act prohibits unauthorized use of shapeshifting abilities to replicate the appearance of public or private figures without explicit written consent. Penalties range from $5,000 to $50,000 for first offenses and up to $100,000 and three years imprisonment for repeat violations. Exceptions are carved out for authorized law enforcement operations and parody or satire under existing free speech protections. The NSRA oversees enforcement and maintains a database of registered consent agreements.

  • Superhuman Geometeorological Engineering Regulation Act of 2012 -- Regulates the use of metahuman abilities to manipulate weather patterns, atmospheric conditions, or geological structures. Establishes the Superhuman Geometeorological Engineering Commission (SGEC) under the NSRA as a dedicated regulatory body. Licensing requires a master's degree or higher in a relevant scientific field, completion of an SGEC-approved training program, demonstrated power mastery, and passing both a background check and psychological evaluation. Activities rated 5 or higher on the Superhuman Geometeorological Intervention Scale (SGIS, which runs from 1 to 10) are prohibited without explicit SGEC approval. Military or hostile use is strictly forbidden. Penalties include fines up to $1,000,000 per offense, license revocation with a five-year reapplication ban, and up to 20 years imprisonment for willful misconduct.

  • LUMA Flight Modification Act of 2014 -- Requires flight-capable metahumans to obtain a Flight Certification as an addendum to their LUMA. Applicants must demonstrate safe takeoff, navigation, and landing, as well as understanding of air traffic control communications and flight regulations. Juveniles are restricted to a maximum altitude of 30 feet above the nearest surface and a flight curfew between 8 PM and 8 AM. The NSRA collaborates with the Federal Aviation Administration to integrate flight-capable metahumans into the National Airspace System. Uncertified flight in restricted zones is a misdemeanor carrying fines of $2,000 to $30,000, escalating to criminal charges with up to three years imprisonment for severe violations.

  • Digital Interface Regulatory Framework Act of 2014 (DIRFA) -- Establishes federal guidelines for metahuman abilities that interact with electronic systems, digital data, or telecommunications infrastructure. The act creates a certification program for Digital Interface Specialists administered by the NSRA, including background checks, technical proficiency examinations, and continuing education requirements. Unauthorized use of digital interface abilities to access protected systems is punishable under the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act with enhanced sentencing -- minimum sentences increase by 50% when such abilities are employed. Authorized access requires a valid court order, written consent from the system owner, federal law enforcement supervision, contracted security testing agreements, or emergency situations involving imminent threat to life.

  • Telepathic Employment Non-Discrimination Act of 2015 -- Prohibits employers from making adverse employment decisions based on an individual's actual or perceived telepathic abilities, including hiring, firing, promotion, and compensation. Employers cannot require telepathic screening or use telepathic ability as a criterion for assessing job performance. Exceptions apply where telepathic abilities constitute a bona fide occupational qualification. Enforcement falls under the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, with fines up to $50,000 for first offenses and $100,000 for subsequent violations, plus potential compensatory damages.

docs.title: Criminal Law Adaptations
docs.text:
The emergence of powered crime has required significant adaptation of existing criminal law frameworks:

  • United States v. Davis (2005) -- The landmark case that established the legal framework for classifying superhuman abilities as weapons when used in furtherance of a crime. The ruling created the legal term "Felony-Enabled Superhuman Operatives" (FESO) and held that operating under a nom-de-crime while committing felonies with powers constitutes a specific criminal category. Crucially, the decision did not authorize detention of non-criminal superhumans, limiting the weapons classification strictly to criminal contexts. The Davis framework is not automatic; prosecution must demonstrate that a power was actively used in furtherance of a crime, creating significant opportunities for defense attorneys to challenge enhanced charges.

  • RICO Adaptations -- The Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act has evolved substantially to address powered criminal enterprises. Traditional evidence-gathering methods -- financial records, communication intercepts -- are frequently unreliable when technopathic abilities can compromise digital records and enhanced-strength individuals can transport cash outside banking systems. Prosecutors have developed new frameworks centered on physical evidence patterns: power signatures at crime scenes, insurance claim analysis, specialized equipment purchases, and distinctive property damage patterns. LUMA records have become a particularly valuable investigative tool, as registration histories, payment patterns for members' fees, and renewal data help establish organizational structures and patterns of coordinated activity. The conviction of the "Steel Circuit" criminal enterprise exemplified these new prosecutorial methods, relying on insurance claim patterns showing distinctive enhanced-strength forced entry signatures across five states.

  • Powered Criminal Defense -- A specialized defense bar has emerged to address the unique challenges of representing powered defendants. Key issues include jury selection (identifying anti-power bias during voir dire), the separation of LUMA compliance violations from underlying criminal charges, evidence integrity when powers affect crime scenes (particularly temporal manipulation), and expert testimony on power control development and the Bracing Effect to contextualize incidents. The intersection of traditional organized crime law with power-specific regulations has created novel legal questions, particularly in RICO cases involving multiple powered defendants whose abilities may interact.

docs.title: Additional Case Law
docs.text:
• State of New York v. Sentry Insurance (2007) -- A 5-4 Supreme Court decision prohibiting insurance companies from charging higher premiums based solely on superhuman status, citing the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
  • Riley v. California (2015) -- Established that warrantless search and seizure of a superhuman's personal data is unconstitutional under the Fourth Amendment.
  • United States v. Gibson (2017) -- Addressed crimes committed using an "irresistible request" ability. The court ruled that mind-controlled accomplices should receive leniency, while Gibson received multiple life sentences and was imprisoned in Daedalus Correctional Facility.

docs.title: History
docs.text:
The legal framework governing metahuman abilities developed incrementally in response to the growing superhuman population and a series of high-profile incidents that exposed gaps in existing law.

The earliest metahumans appeared in 1982 as Genesis Births, and the first U.S. activation event was recorded in 1986. Through the 1990s, legal responses were largely reactive and ad hoc, with the government establishing the National Superhuman Registration Database in the mid-1990s and implementing the Pivot Protocols in 1997. The Superhuman Study and Response Division (SSRD) was formed in 2000, later absorbed into the NSRA when it was established in 2002.

The mid-2000s marked the beginning of comprehensive power-specific legislation. The Mind Privacy Act and Morales Act, both enacted in 2005, were among the first statutes to regulate specific categories of metahuman ability. The same year, United States v. Davis provided the foundational criminal law framework. The failed Superhuman Registration Act of 2008 -- struck down as unconstitutional -- demonstrated the limits of the government's regulatory reach and led to the more carefully crafted LUMA Act of 2013.

The Stewart presidency (2012-2020) was a period of significant legislative activity. The Geometeorological Engineering Regulation Act (2012), the LUMA Act (2013), the Flight Modification Act (2014), DIRFA (2014), the Telepathic Employment Non-Discrimination Act (2015), and the Digital Privacy Act (2015) were all enacted during this period. Stewart, a Republican who campaigned on superhuman security in the wake of the Tesla Incident, pursued a regulatory approach that balanced business-friendly libertarian principles with public safety mandates.

The Rodriguez presidency (2020-present) has continued to expand the framework with a more progressive orientation, notably passing the Superhuman Healthcare Act of 2021 to prevent healthcare discrimination against metahumans.

Throughout this period, the practical realities of enforcement have remained contested. An estimated 30,000 powered individuals live outside the LUMA system entirely, sustained by an underground network of handlers, safe houses, shadow clinics, encrypted communications channels, and power control trainers. This underground community includes individuals whose immigration status makes registration dangerous, those whose power classifications would result in institutionalization, and those who simply reject the premise that their abilities should be subject to government oversight.

docs.title: Implications
docs.text:
The power laws have reshaped American society in ways both visible and subtle. For the approximately 500,000 metahumans in the United States, the regulatory framework defines the boundaries of legal power use, from the workplace to public spaces to digital systems. Over two-thirds of metahumans avoid the hero-villain dynamic entirely, using their abilities in conventional employment -- but even this requires LUMA compliance.

The laws have generated entirely new professional fields. Specialized attorneys like Jennifer Martinez have built practices around powered criminal defense, teaching courses in powers legislation at law schools and developing novel legal strategies for challenges that have no precedent in conventional law. Insurance investigation has been transformed, with companies like UltraShield maintaining detailed databases of power-related claims that serve both commercial and law enforcement purposes.

The entertainment industry has been directly shaped by the Morales Act, which arose from the exploitation of shapeshifter Lana Morales in early 2000s Hollywood. Studios initially sought to use her ability to replicate celebrity likenesses at a fraction of the cost of hiring actual stars. The legislation established clear boundaries around impersonation but also, paradoxically, narrowed the range of roles available to shapeshifting performers by making their power -- rather than their talent -- the central concern of every contract negotiation.

The Geometeorological Engineering Regulation Act carries some of the most stringent requirements in the framework, reflecting the catastrophic potential of weather and geological manipulation. The requirement for a graduate degree in a relevant scientific field effectively limits licensed geometeorological engineering to a small number of qualified individuals.

For law enforcement, the power laws have created both tools and challenges. LUMA records provide invaluable investigative data, but the complexity of powered evidence -- from crime scenes affected by temporal manipulation to digital records compromised by technopathic interference -- has required fundamental rethinking of evidentiary standards and chain-of-custody procedures.

The underground community of unregistered metahumans represents the framework's most visible failure point. Advocates within this community argue that the system treats powered individuals as threats first and people second, while supporters of the regulatory regime contend that public safety demands accountability for abilities that can cause mass harm.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• The Morales Act was named after Lana "Facsimile" Morales, a shapeshifting actress who was pressured to replicate A-list celebrity likenesses for a fraction of the cost of hiring the actual stars. Her first casting call asked her to shapeshift into Demi Moore.
  • The Geometeorological Engineering Regulation Act requires a master's degree or higher in atmospheric sciences, geology, or a related field -- one of the few laws in any jurisdiction that mandates a specific educational credential for the use of a metahuman ability.
  • Commentator William "Bill" Thompson of capebusters.com, a persistent critic of government regulation, paradoxically supported the Geometeorological Engineering Regulation Act because he believed it would expose what he termed a government conspiracy to fake climate change using rogue weather-controlling operatives.
  • The Telepathic Employment Non-Discrimination Act was preceded by a wave of high-profile lawsuits in the early 2010s involving alleged telepathic workplace invasion and manipulation, generating significant media coverage and public fear.
  • The powered underground network operates through ancient IRC channels and private forums with constantly rotating servers, maintaining an estimated 30,000 individuals off the LUMA grid.
  • The Steel Circuit RICO conviction -- a landmark in powered criminal prosecution -- was built primarily on insurance claim patterns rather than traditional financial evidence or witness testimony.
  • Jennifer Martinez, one of the foremost powered defense attorneys in the country, entered the field by accident when she was assigned a case involving a defendant who activated enhanced strength during a convenience store robbery in 2012.
  • The Superhuman Registration Act of 2008, which would have required mandatory registration, tracking devices, and annual evaluations for all metahumans, was struck down by the Supreme Court in a 6-3 decision as unconstitutional before it could be implemented.

docs.title: Private Superheroing
docs.text: The commercialization and privatization of metahuman security services, encompassing both domestic private superhero firms and international private military contractors that employ superhuman operatives.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Private Superheroing (Privatized Metahuman Security) Also Known As Private superhero industry; privatized metahuman services; superhuman private military contracting Category Economics / Law / Military Discovered/Established Unknown; active by at least the late 2010s Key Figures Alexander Staedler (CEO, Red Calf Inc.); Lt. Gen. Dominic Hartley (COO, Red Calf Inc.) Governing Body NSRA (domestic oversight via LUMA framework); no unified international regulatory body First Appearance Worldbuilding article: "Private Superheroing"

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Private superheroing refers to the broad phenomenon of metahuman abilities being employed outside of government service for commercial purposes, particularly in the security and military sectors. Rather than operating as government-employed Registered Superhuman Entities or as independent Licensed Vigilantes, private superheroes work under the auspices of corporations that contract their services to paying clients. This industry exists on a spectrum ranging from lawful domestic security firms that operate within the LUMA licensing framework to international private military contractors that employ superhumans for paramilitary operations in legal gray zones.

On the domestic side, firms such as ZenithGuard Security Solutions represent the legitimate face of private superheroing. These companies recruit Licensed Vigilantes and offer them structured career paths, competitive compensation, legal liability coverage, and specialized healthcare comparable to what government-employed RSEs receive. Their clients range from Fortune 500 corporations to small businesses, and their services include security, investigations, and disaster response. ZenithGuard and firms like it operate in close collaboration with law enforcement agencies and may even obtain limited arrest and detention powers through formal partnerships.

At the international level, private military contractors such as Red Calf Incorporated represent a far more controversial dimension of the industry. These organizations employ superhuman operatives alongside conventional military personnel to execute high-end military and paramilitary contracts for nation-states, multinational corporations, and private individuals. The integration of metahuman capabilities into private military operations has dramatically increased the lethality and strategic value of these contractors, raising serious questions about accountability, sovereignty, and the ethics of commercialized superhuman warfare.

docs.title: Domestic Private Superhero Firms
docs.text:
Domestic private superhero companies operate within the existing LUMA regulatory framework. Employees are required to hold a current License to Utilize Metahuman Abilities or an equivalent credential from their home country. Firms typically prefer candidates with at least one year of vigilante or security experience, though this is not always mandatory. All applicants undergo thorough background checks and vetting processes before employment.

Once hired, private superheroes work within a professional corporate structure with defined career tracks. These may include security operations, investigations, disaster response, and other specialized roles. The employing firm provides liability coverage for actions taken in the line of duty, access to state-of-the-art training facilities, and ongoing professional development through workshops, certifications, and skill assessments. Compensation packages commonly include competitive salaries, retirement plans, stock options, and performance bonuses.

A key feature of domestic private superhero firms is their formal collaboration with law enforcement. Through established partnerships, these companies and their employees may be granted limited arrest and detention powers, effectively bridging the gap between civilian security and public policing. However, the scope and limitations of these powers remain a point of legal and public debate, particularly when incidents of excessive force occur.

docs.title: International Private Military Contracting
docs.text:
At the international level, private superheroing takes the form of private military contractors (PMCs) that integrate superhuman operatives into their forces. Red Calf Incorporated is among the most prominent of these organizations, with an estimated 30 to 40 percent of its active operatives being superhumans -- a disproportionately high ratio compared to other PMCs.

These superhuman operatives, referred to internally as "specialist personnel," are deployed for missions that exploit their unique capabilities, including strategic assassinations, infrastructure sabotage, and high-intensity combat. PMCs like Red Calf use custom-designed equipment tailored to individual superhuman abilities, including adaptive body armor, advanced sensor systems, and unconventional weaponry not widely available on global arms markets.

Red Calf is structured as a modern corporation with clearly delineated divisions: executive leadership oversees contract negotiations and regulatory compliance, a financial division manages assets through offshore networks, a legal division exploits international legal loopholes, and an operations division under a former British SAS officer directs all field activity. Recruitment draws talent from a wide range of sources, including disbanded militaries, criminal networks, failed states, and notably, former supervillains and law enforcement officers with problematic service records.

docs.title: Legal Framework and Immunity
docs.text:
Private superheroes operating domestically generally benefit from the same legal immunity provisions as other LUMA holders, provided their actions fall within the scope of their license and the terms of their employment. However, this immunity is not absolute. When operatives exceed the boundaries of their authorization -- particularly in situations involving excessive force, collateral damage, or civil rights violations -- they and their employers may face both criminal and civil liability.

Internationally, the legal framework is far murkier. PMCs like Red Calf maintain legal compliance through skilled legal counsel that navigates and exploits loopholes in international law, particularly regarding war crimes and defense contracts. The absence of a unified international regulatory body for superhuman military activity means that oversight varies dramatically by jurisdiction, and accountability is often difficult to establish.

docs.title: History
docs.text:
The privatization of metahuman services emerged as a natural consequence of several converging factors: the growing population of individuals with superhuman abilities (approximately 500,000 in America alone), the limited capacity of government agencies like the NSRA to employ all metahumans who wished to use their abilities professionally, and the enormous commercial demand for superhuman security services in both the private and military sectors.

Domestically, firms like ZenithGuard Security Solutions established themselves by offering Licensed Vigilantes a middle path between independent vigilante work and full government employment as Registered Superhuman Entities. By providing corporate structure, legal protection, and professional benefits, these companies attracted metahumans who wanted stable careers without the constraints and obligations of direct government service.

On the international stage, private military contractors recognized early on that integrating superhumans into their operations would confer an enormous tactical advantage. Red Calf Incorporated, headquartered in Zurich, Switzerland, became one of the most prominent players in this space, building an elite roster of superhuman and conventional operatives and securing contracts with nation-states, corporations, and private clients worldwide. By September 2024, Red Calf had been linked to significant operations including the destabilization of the Kravchenko regime in Eastern Europe ("Operation Coldlight," March 2021) and involvement in a Sub-Saharan African conflict tied to agricultural resource control ("The Cassava Crisis," May 2024).

The October 2019 Vigil incident in Chicago marked a significant turning point in public discourse around domestic private superheroing. When ZenithGuard operative "Vigil" was deployed for crowd control during a peaceful protest and injured four bystanders -- two seriously enough to require hospitalization -- the resulting backlash prompted investigations by both ZenithGuard's internal review board and an independent civilian oversight body. The incident intensified debate about the accountability and regulation of private superhero firms and raised the prospect of stricter regulatory frameworks.

docs.title: Public Safety and Accountability
docs.text:
The privatization of superhero work introduces a fundamental tension between the efficiency of corporate superhuman deployment and the public's right to accountability. Unlike government-employed RSEs who are subject to mandatory psychological and ethical evaluations, private superheroes may face less rigorous ongoing oversight. When incidents occur, the question of who bears responsibility -- the individual operative, the employing corporation, or the contracting client -- remains legally and ethically complex.

The Vigil incident illustrated this tension in stark terms: local police distanced themselves from ZenithGuard's actions, the company placed the operative on administrative leave pending review, and legal scholars observed that the incident could set precedent for how private security firms employing metahumans are regulated. The dual-investigation model -- internal corporate review alongside independent civilian oversight -- represents one emerging approach to the accountability gap.

docs.title: Geopolitical Impact
docs.text:
Internationally, the deployment of superhuman PMC operatives has reshaped the calculus of armed conflict and regime stability. Organizations like Red Calf can project force at levels previously only available to nation-states, yet they operate with fewer constraints and less transparency. The CIA's Special Activities Division has assessed that while Red Calf is not officially designated a terrorist organization, its activities in destabilizing regions and undermining democratic institutions present a clear and growing threat to U.S. interests.

The high concentration of superhuman operatives in PMCs increases both the lethality of their operations and the difficulty of counteraction by conventional forces. This dynamic has prompted recommendations for enhanced counter-superhuman training and equipment for national military and intelligence forces, as well as calls for increased integration of superhumans into official government military units as a counterbalance.

docs.title: Labor and Career Dynamics
docs.text: For individual metahumans, private superheroing represents an alternative career path that may offer advantages over both independent vigilante work and government employment. Private firms provide competitive salaries, benefits packages, liability coverage, and professional development opportunities. However, metahumans who enter private employment may find themselves beholden to corporate interests, deployed in situations that conflict with their personal ethics, or exposed to legal jeopardy when their employers take on controversial contracts.

docs.text:

  • Red Calf's Director of Public Relations, Kevin Mahoney, is an American political strategist with ties to U.S. senators and major corporations, reflecting the organization's investment in maintaining a veneer of legitimacy.

docs.title: Psionics
docs.text: The broad category of metahuman abilities that involve the interaction between consciousness and physical reality, encompassing telekinesis, mind control, precognition, memory manipulation, and other anomalous cognitive phenomena whose underlying mechanisms remain one of the central unsolved problems in Dynology.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Psionics Also Known As Psionic abilities; psychic powers; cognitive powers; anomalous cognitive phenomena Category Science Discovered/Established 1980s (first theoretical framework proposed by Dr. Julian Feiner) Key Figures Dr. Julian Feiner (Psychron Theory); Dr. Lucia Solis (Dynological Institute of Madrid); Dr. Janine Klyne (Stanford University); Dr. Kamil Zarif (University of Prague); Dr. Alan Thorne (neurophysiologist) Governing Body N/A (no single governing body; research conducted across multiple institutions including the Institute for Advanced Dynology, Stanford University, the Dynological Institute of Madrid, and the University of Prague) First Appearance Worldbuilding article: "The Psychron Puzzle"

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Psionics refers to the class of metahuman abilities that operate through the interaction between consciousness and the physical world, bypassing conventional physical mechanisms. Unlike powers with clear physiological origins such as super strength or energy projection, psionic abilities appear to bridge the gap between mental intent and external effect without any detectable energy transfer in the form of heat, sound, or electromagnetism. This absence of observable intermediary force has made psionics one of the most intensely studied and least understood domains in Dynology.

The scope of psionic phenomena is broad. Documented abilities include telekinesis, mind control, thought transmission, memory reading and manipulation, emotion sensing, neural override, and precognition. These powers share a common thread: they involve the mind exerting influence on matter, other minds, or the flow of information in ways that defy the standard models of physics and neuroscience. Despite nearly five decades of research since superhuman abilities first began manifesting, no unified theory has emerged to explain how psionic powers function.

The field is further complicated by the Telepathy Problem, a well-documented limitation in which no known metahuman has ever demonstrated the ability to directly receive or read another person's active thoughts, even though the transmission of thoughts into another mind and the overriding of motor control are both established capabilities. This asymmetry has generated extensive scientific and philosophical debate about the fundamental nature of consciousness.

docs.title: Theoretical Frameworks
docs.text: Four major theories compete to explain the mechanisms underlying psionic abilities. None has achieved consensus, and the field remains in a state comparable to early twentieth-century quantum mechanics, where the phenomena are observable but the explanatory framework is incomplete.

docs.title: Psychron Particle Theory
docs.text: First proposed in the late 1980s by Dr. Julian Feiner, this theory posits the existence of a hypothetical subatomic particle called the psychron (also referred to as the psychronic particle). Psychrons would behave similarly to known quantum particles but interact specifically with consciousness. The theory holds that psionic abilities arise from the exchange of psychrons between the brain and external objects or organisms, mediating the transfer of mental intent into physical effect. If confirmed, the psychron would represent a fifth fundamental force alongside gravity, electromagnetism, and the strong and weak nuclear forces. Despite extensive attempts using high-energy particle accelerators, no direct experimental evidence for the psychron has been found. Advocates point to the behavior of telekinetics, who exert measurable force on objects without any detectable conventional energy transfer, as indirect support.

docs.title: Psionic Field Hypothesis
docs.text: This theory proposes that psionic phenomena are mediated not by particles but by a universal field, sometimes called the Psi Field or Consciousness Field, analogous to the Higgs Field. The mind would interact with this field to produce psychic effects, much as mass interacts with the Higgs Field to acquire inertia. The hypothesis is attractive for its explanatory breadth, potentially unifying telekinesis, precognition, and other disparate psionic abilities under a single framework. It also implies that consciousness is a fundamental property of the universe rather than an emergent property of brain activity. Critics consider the theory unfalsifiable, as no technology currently exists that can detect or interact with the proposed field. The implications for neuroscience are also contentious, as non-local consciousness challenges established models of individuality and subjective experience.

docs.title: Quantum Psychophysics
docs.text: This emerging field blends quantum mechanics with consciousness studies. It proposes that quantum processes occurring at the level of microtubules within neurons enable the brain to interact with quantum phenomena, producing psionic effects. Under this model, precognition could result from the brain accessing quantum superpositions in which multiple future outcomes exist simultaneously, then collapsing those probabilities to perceive likely futures. The theory draws support from the established field of quantum biology, where quantum effects have been observed in photosynthesis and avian navigation. Detractors argue that the warm, noisy environment of the human brain is inhospitable to the delicate quantum coherence required.

docs.title: Psionic Wave Theory
docs.text: This theory suggests that psionic phenomena are wave-based rather than particle- or field-based. Psionic waves would propagate through space-time and interact with the brain to produce psychic effects, behaving analogously to electromagnetic waves but subject to their own interference, resonance, and amplification patterns. Unlike the static Psi Field, psionic waves would be dynamic, which could explain observed environmental influences on power efficacy, such as areas of high electromagnetic activity enhancing or inhibiting abilities. Researchers have begun testing with high-sensitivity wave detectors, though results remain inconclusive.

docs.title: Consciousness-Centric Hypothesis (CCH)
docs.text: The most radical proposal holds that consciousness itself is the primary force in the universe and that physical reality is emergent from conscious thought. Under CCH, psionic abilities are not anomalies but natural expressions of individuals who have tapped into the fundamental nature of reality. This view has drawn significant criticism from physicists and philosophers for its proximity to metaphysics, but it has found support among metahumans with cognitive powers, who frequently describe their abilities as extensions of will or intent.

docs.title: The Telepathy Problem
docs.text: The Telepathy Problem is a well-documented limitation in the psionic domain: no known metahuman has ever demonstrated the ability to directly receive, interpret, or access the active thoughts of another person. While the mind can project outward through thought transmission, mind control, neural override, emotion sensing, and memory reading, the reception of another person's real-time conscious thoughts has proven impossible.

docs.title: What Is Possible
docs.text:
• Mind control -- The ability to override a target's voluntary motor functions or implant commands, effectively hijacking neural activity. The target typically retains full cognitive awareness while losing bodily autonomy.
  • Thought transmission -- One-way projection of thoughts, mental images, ideas, or emotions into another person's mind. The recipient cannot transmit back.
  • Memory reading and manipulation -- Access to and alteration of stored memories, which are encoded in relatively static neuronal networks and thus more accessible than the dynamic flow of active thought.
  • Neural override -- Direct control over a target's motor pathways, distinct from broader mind control in that it targets the neuromuscular system specifically while leaving cognition intact.
  • Emotion sensing -- The ability to detect or perceive the emotional states of others.

docs.title: What Is Impossible
docs.text:
• Direct thought reception
  • Real-time thought reading
  • Two-way mental communication
  • Access to active, in-progress thoughts
  • Live mental monitoring of another person's conscious experience

docs.title: Theories Explaining the Limitation
docs.text:
Four theories have been advanced to explain this asymmetry:

  • Cognitive Noise Theory -- The brain's constant processing of sensory input, bodily regulation, memory retrieval, and background cognitive operations generates too much interference for any external observer to isolate coherent thoughts from the surrounding noise.
  • Brain-to-Brain Mismatch Hypothesis -- Each brain possesses a unique neural architecture shaped by individual genetics, experience, and memory, effectively encoding thoughts in a private language with no universal translation key.
  • Quantum Mind Hypothesis -- If thoughts exist in quantum superposition until collapsed by the thinker, any external attempt to observe them would alter their state, making faithful reception fundamentally impossible.
  • Privacy of Consciousness Theory -- A philosophical position holding that conscious thoughts are inherently subjective first-person experiences that cannot, by their nature, be externally accessed, regardless of technological or biological capability.

docs.title: Physical Effects on Users
docs.text: Psionic abilities produce notable physical side effects on their users, a phenomenon linked to the Bracing Effect. Although cognitive powers do not involve visible physical force, users of psionic abilities experience symptoms consistent with the force distribution patterns observed in other extra-physiological powers, including spontaneous nosebleeds, migraines, and transient ischemic attacks (mini-strokes). This is considered paradoxical by researchers, as there is no apparent physical force being exerted in cognitive-only abilities. The connection between psionic power usage and physical strain remains an active area of research. Long-term use over ten to twenty years can produce symptoms resembling neurodegenerative disorders, along with chronic low-level nerve cell damage.

docs.title: History
docs.text:
Superhuman abilities began manifesting worldwide in the 1980s, and psionic powers were among the earliest to capture public and scientific attention. The prospect of telepathy, in particular, seized the popular imagination, though it quickly became apparent that the expected form of mind-reading did not exist among the emerging metahuman population.

In the late 1980s, Dr. Julian Feiner proposed the Psychron Particle Theory, the first formal scientific framework for explaining psionic phenomena. His hypothesis introduced the concept of the psychron as a mediating particle between consciousness and physical reality. While the psychron has never been detected experimentally, Feiner's work established the theoretical vocabulary and research agenda that continue to shape the field. Feiner, now Professor Emeritus at Stanford University, remains an active voice in the debate.

Subsequent decades saw the development of competing theoretical models. The Psionic Field Hypothesis gained traction for its explanatory breadth, while Quantum Psychophysics connected psionic research to the growing field of quantum biology. Psionic Wave Theory emerged more recently, offering a dynamic alternative to the static-field model. The Consciousness-Centric Hypothesis, though controversial, found adherents among practicing metahumans.

The Telepathy Problem was formally identified and named as researchers catalogued the consistent absence of thought-reception abilities across the global metahuman population. The legal system also grappled with psionics early on, as cases involving mind control and neural override raised unprecedented questions about criminal liability, consent, and autonomy. The 2009 trial of Damon "Marionette" Locke in the Superior Court of New York became a landmark case, centering on whether a mind-controlled victim retained agency and whether the controller bore full criminal responsibility for acts committed through others' bodies.

docs.title: Scientific
docs.text: The existence of psionic abilities challenges foundational assumptions in physics and neuroscience. The absence of detectable energy transfer during telekinetic events, the paradoxical physical strain experienced by cognitive-power users, and the hard boundary of the Telepathy Problem all suggest that current scientific models are incomplete. Psionic research is frequently compared to the state of quantum mechanics in the early twentieth century: the phenomena are observable and repeatable, but the underlying framework remains elusive. Resolution of the psychron question or confirmation of any competing theory would have revolutionary implications for the understanding of consciousness, force, and the relationship between mind and matter.

docs.title: Legal and Ethical
docs.text: Psionic abilities, particularly mind control and neural override, pose severe challenges to legal systems built on assumptions of individual agency. The Locke trial exposed the difficulty of prosecuting crimes committed through controlled intermediaries and raised questions about the culpability of victims whose bodies performed criminal acts while their minds remained aware but helpless. Memory manipulation introduces further complications around consent, evidence integrity, and mental privacy. The documented impossibility of direct thought reading provides a measure of reassurance regarding mental privacy, but the existence of memory access and emotional sensing continues to fuel ethical debate.

docs.title: Medical
docs.text: Users of psionic abilities face health risks consistent with the Bracing Effect, including vascular complications, migraines, nosebleeds, and transient ischemic attacks. Long-term practitioners risk neurodegenerative symptoms and chronic nerve damage. Specialized healthcare protocols exist for metahumans experiencing these effects, and the medication Capilastin-XR (brand name VeiloGuard) has been approved for related vascular complications. The paradox of physical strain from non-physical powers remains an unresolved research question.

docs.title: Societal
docs.text: The existence of mind control as a real and documented phenomenon has significant implications for public trust, interpersonal relationships, and institutional security. Certain applications of psionic powers are banned outright in regulated contexts, such as powered fighting leagues, where mind control and probability manipulation are prohibited. The Telepathy Problem, while a limitation, functions as a de facto safeguard for mental privacy in a world where many other forms of privacy have been eroded by metahuman capabilities.

Mind Control Override of a target's conscious decision-making and voluntary actions Outward (push) No -- overrides, does not read Neural Override Hijacking of motor control pathways while leaving cognition intact Outward (push) No -- controls body, not mind Thought Transmission Projection of thoughts, images, or emotions into another mind Outward (push) No -- inserts, does not extract Memory Reading Access to stored memories encoded in neuronal networks Outward (pull of stored data) No -- accesses static storage, not active thought Memory Manipulation Alteration or deletion of stored memories Outward (push) No -- modifies storage Emotion Sensing Detection of another person's emotional state Inward (passive reception) Indirect -- reads emotional state, not thoughts Precognition Perception of future events or probable outcomes Inward (reception) N/A Telekinesis Exertion of force on objects without physical contact Outward (push) N/A

docs.title: Related Concepts
docs.text:
• Dynology -- The scientific discipline encompassing the study of all superhuman abilities, of which psionics is a major subdomain.
  • The Bracing Effect -- The force distribution mechanism that causes physical strain in metahumans using extra-physiological powers. Paradoxically affects cognitive-power users despite the absence of visible physical force.
  • PERKS Assessment -- The classification system used by the NSRA to categorize metahuman powers. Psionic abilities fall under multiple PERKS categories depending on their specific function, including Brain (B) for cognitive and sensory powers and Adjust (A) or Employ (E) for abilities that modify or add to existing systems.
  • Psychrons -- The hypothetical subatomic particles proposed by Dr. Julian Feiner as the mediating mechanism behind psionic phenomena.
  • The Telepathy Problem -- The specific documented limitation within psionics in which direct reception of active thoughts is impossible.
  • VeiloGuard (Capilastin-XR) -- Medication approved for vascular complications resulting from metahuman power use, including those experienced by psionic-ability users.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• Telekinetics have been shown to exert measurable force on objects without any detectable energy transfer in the form of heat, sound, or electromagnetism, which is one of the strongest pieces of indirect evidence cited by Psychron Theory proponents.
  • The Telepathy Problem is sometimes informally summarized as "every brain has a transmitter but no receiver."
  • Mind control is among the powers explicitly banned in powered fighting leagues, alongside probability manipulation.
  • The 2009 trial of Damon "Marionette" Locke featured testimony from victims who described full cognitive awareness during periods of complete bodily control by Locke, with one witness comparing the sensation to the neurological condition alien hand syndrome extended across the entire body.
  • Dr. Julian Feiner, who first proposed Psychron Theory in the 1980s, remains active in the field as Professor Emeritus at Stanford University.
  • One of the open questions in Bracing Effect research is why cognitive-power users experience physical symptoms at all, given that their abilities do not involve any apparent physical force.

docs.title: Religion
docs.text: The evolving relationship between organized religion and the superhuman phenomenon, encompassing theological debate, institutional adaptation, and the integration of metahuman abilities into frameworks of faith.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Full Name Religion and Superhumans Also Known As Faith and Powers; Theology of the Superhuman Category Culture Discovered/Established Ongoing since the emergence of superhumans (post-1981) Key Figures Pope Leo XIV (Giovanni Battista Re); Saint Miriam of Lyon (Marie Dupont) Governing Body N/A (varies by denomination and faith tradition) First Appearance Worldbuilding article: "Religion"

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The emergence of superhumans in the early 1980s posed an immediate and profound challenge to the world's religious institutions. Individuals capable of healing the sick, defying physical laws, and performing feats previously attributed to divine intervention forced theologians, clergy, and lay believers alike to confront questions that had been purely hypothetical for millennia: What is the nature of a miracle when a human can replicate one at will? Are superhuman abilities a gift from God, a product of nature, or something else entirely?

Religious and spiritual groups across the globe have grappled with the superhuman phenomenon in markedly different ways. Some traditions have embraced powers as evidence of divine grace operating through human vessels, while others have drawn sharp distinctions between superhuman abilities and genuine miracles. In regions such as sub-Saharan Africa and parts of South and Southeast Asia, powers have been integrated into existing spiritual belief systems and are often viewed as communal gifts or blessings rather than individual endowments. The Western religious landscape, dominated by Christianity, has seen the most visible institutional responses, particularly from the Catholic Church under the leadership of Pope Leo XIV.

The broader cultural impact has been significant. Religious discourse now routinely engages with questions about the ethics of power use, the moral obligations of those who possess extraordinary abilities, and whether the existence of superhumans affirms or undermines traditional articles of faith. These debates remain unresolved and are likely to intensify as the metahuman population continues to grow.

docs.title: Theological Frameworks
docs.text:
Religious institutions have developed several broad approaches to incorporating superhuman abilities into their doctrinal frameworks:

  • Powers as Divine Grace -- The position most prominently associated with the Catholic Church under Pope Leo XIV. Under this view, superhuman abilities are understood as a form of divine grace acting through human will. The emphasis falls on the intention and moral character of the individual wielding the power rather than the power itself.
  • Powers as Distinct from Miracles -- A counter-position held by some theologians and denominational authorities who argue that superhuman abilities, while extraordinary, are fundamentally natural phenomena and should not be conflated with miracles of divine origin. This view maintains a strict boundary between the miraculous and the metahuman.
  • Powers as Communal Resources -- Prevalent in non-Western spiritual traditions, particularly in Africa, where superhuman abilities are viewed as gifts or blessings meant to benefit the community. This framework de-emphasizes the individual hero-villain dynamic common in the West and instead positions powered individuals as stewards of a collective resource.
  • Powers as Spiritual Phenomena -- Some faith traditions interpret superhuman abilities through the lens of existing spiritual cosmologies, integrating them into pre-existing frameworks of spiritual power, ancestral blessing, or karmic manifestation.

docs.title: The Miracles Question
docs.text: The central theological tension across nearly all faith traditions concerns the relationship between superhuman abilities and miracles. When a metahuman healer can cure the sick through touch, the traditional criteria for recognizing a miracle -- that the event be inexplicable by natural means and attributable to divine intervention -- become difficult to apply. The Catholic Church addressed this directly during the canonization of Saint Miriam of Lyon, ruling that her healings qualified as miracles not because of the mechanism (her superhuman ability) but because of the faith, intention, and selflessness with which she exercised them.

docs.title: Ethical Integration
docs.text: Across denominations and faith traditions, a common thread has emerged: an emphasis on the responsible and ethical use of superhuman abilities. Religious leaders have broadly advocated for frameworks that judge powered individuals by their moral conduct rather than by the nature or magnitude of their abilities. This position aligns with, and in some cases predates, the secular regulatory frameworks established by governments.

docs.title: Early Response (1981-2000s)
docs.text: The initial emergence of superhumans provoked a wide spectrum of religious reactions. Some communities interpreted the phenomenon as a sign of the end times or divine judgment; others saw it as evidence of ongoing creation. Formal institutional responses were slow to develop, as religious authorities struggled to assess a phenomenon that had no precedent in scripture or tradition. During this period, individual clergy and theologians published a range of speculative and scholarly works, but no major denomination issued definitive doctrinal statements.

docs.title: Election of Pope Leo XIV (2012)
docs.text: The election of Giovanni Battista Re as Pope Leo XIV on April 15, 2012 represented a turning point for the Catholic Church's engagement with the superhuman phenomenon. At 78, Leo XIV brought a scholarly background in the ethics of modern science and human rights, and was widely regarded as a reformist figure capable of bridging traditional doctrine with contemporary realities. His papacy was not defined solely by the superhuman question; he also prioritized social justice, poverty alleviation, environmental stewardship, and interfaith dialogue. However, his nuanced approach to metahuman issues -- advocating for ethical understanding of extraordinary abilities within the Christian moral framework -- set the tone for the Church's official stance.

docs.title: Canonization of Saint Miriam of Lyon (2023)
docs.text:
On June 18, 2023, the Catholic Church canonized its first superhuman saint: Saint Miriam of Lyon, born Marie Dupont in Lyon, France, in 1998. Miriam's superhuman healing ability activated following a near-fatal accident during her teenage years. She devoted her life to service, traveling to war-torn regions and areas struck by natural disasters to heal the sick and injured, often in locations where conventional medical assistance was unavailable.

Her canonization, led by Pope Leo XIV, followed years of theological scrutiny and debate. The Vatican ultimately ruled that her life embodied the Christian virtues of charity, compassion, and sacrifice, and that her healings -- verified by the Church as miracles -- were acts of divine grace channeled through her superhuman ability. Pope Leo XIV stated that sainthood concerns the intention and impact of one's actions as guided by faith, and that Miriam's life demonstrated the power of divine grace acting through human will.

The decision was not without controversy. Critics within the Church maintained that superhuman abilities should be categorically distinguished from traditional miracles. Nonetheless, the canonization was widely interpreted as a landmark moment in the integration of the superhuman phenomenon into established religious tradition.

docs.title: For Religious Institutions
docs.text: The superhuman phenomenon has compelled religious institutions to engage in some of the most significant theological revision since the scientific revolution. Denominations that have embraced integration -- positioning powers as compatible with or even evidence of divine activity -- have generally maintained or grown their congregations among metahuman communities. Those that have rejected or ignored the phenomenon risk alienating a growing segment of the global population.

docs.title: For Metahuman Individuals
docs.text: Religious frameworks provide many metahumans with a sense of moral purpose and ethical grounding that secular regulatory systems do not address. For individuals whose powers activate through traumatic events, faith communities can serve as critical support networks. Saint Miriam of Lyon's canonization, in particular, offered a powerful symbol for metahuman believers: that extraordinary abilities and devout faith are not mutually exclusive.

docs.title: For Global Culture
docs.text: The religious response to superhumans varies significantly by region. In the West, the debate is largely framed in terms of compatibility between powers and existing doctrine. In parts of Africa, South Asia, and Southeast Asia, where powers are more readily integrated into spiritual belief systems, the tension is less pronounced. These regional differences mirror broader cultural attitudes toward the superhero-villain dynamic, with non-Western cultures often favoring communal and spiritual interpretations over individualistic ones.

docs.title: For the Miracles Debate
docs.text: The existence of superhuman healers, reality-warpers, and other individuals whose abilities resemble historical accounts of miracles has introduced lasting uncertainty into the theological concept of the miraculous. This debate shows no sign of resolution and is likely to remain one of the defining theological questions of the era.

docs.text:

  • Saint Miriam of Lyon's birth name was Marie Dupont. Her religious name, Miriam, is the Hebrew form of Mary.
  • The Vatican's decision to canonize a superhuman required the Church to formally address whether abilities verifiable as metahuman in origin could simultaneously qualify as miracles -- a question with no prior precedent in canon law.
  • Some religious communities in Africa and Asia never experienced the same theological crisis as Western institutions, as their existing spiritual frameworks already accommodated the concept of individuals with extraordinary abilities.
  • The entertainment industry's shift toward superhuman-influenced productions has also affected religious media, with faith-based organizations producing content that engages directly with the theological implications of powers.
