Bush, James Grant, Laura Stewart, Samuel Rodriguez Governing Body N/A First Appearance Worldbuilding article: "Timelines: US and Philadelphia"

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The history of superhumans in the United States is defined by an accelerating cycle of emergence, crisis, and legislative response. What began in the early 1980s as a medical curiosity -- newborns manifesting inexplicable traits during difficult childbirths -- grew within a generation into a demographic and political phenomenon affecting every level of American society. By the 2020s, an estimated 500,000 individuals in the United States possess metahuman abilities, representing approximately 0.15% of the total population.

The trajectory from the Genesis Births through the establishment of the NSRA and the contentious politics of the Stewart and Rodriguez administrations reflects a nation repeatedly forced to adapt its institutions, laws, and cultural attitudes in response to a population it does not fully understand. Philadelphia, as one of America's major metropolitan centers, mirrors this national arc while producing its own distinct local history of superhuman engagement, from the formation of the Philadelphia Protectors to the election of the city's first superhuman council member.

docs.title: Mechanics
docs.text: N/A -- This page documents historical events rather than a system or phenomenon. For the classification and regulatory systems referenced throughout, see PERKS Assessment, LUMA, and the NSRA.

docs.title: Pre-1990s: Emergence
docs.text:
1982 -- Hospitals worldwide begin reporting newborns exhibiting extraordinary traits, predominantly during complicated childbirths where the infant's survival was in jeopardy. Dubbed the "Genesis Births," these cases attract immediate scientific and media attention. Dr. Alison Carter of UCLA is among the leading researchers. No common genetic marker is identified.

1985 -- The first major public demonstration of superhuman ability occurs in the Indian village of Badrika, where a toddler halts a flood by apparently manipulating elemental forces. The child is nicknamed "Krishna" by international media. Dr. Anita Kapoor and Dr. Randall Thompson are among the first experts to investigate.

1986 -- The first documented activation event on U.S. soil takes place in Virginia. A five-year-old child tears free from an overturned car, displaying extraordinary physical ability with no prior indication of such capabilities. The term "Activation Event" is coined by Dr. Rebecca Hartman to describe the sudden onset of latent metahuman abilities. Congressman Lawrence Baxter initiates early legislative discussions.

1989 -- A child in Cedar Mills, Iowa undergoes an uncontrolled activation event, generating a tornado that devastates nearly half the town. This marks the first large-scale disaster attributed to a superhuman activation. Property damage reaches tens of millions of dollars, and the incident prompts national calls for preparedness measures.

docs.title: 1990s: Growth and First Responses
docs.text:
1995 -- Data from the National Superhuman Registration Database reveals an 8.2% average annual growth rate in superhuman emergence over the preceding five years. The phenomenon is no longer confined to isolated incidents. Dr. Carol Yang of Stanford studies the sociological implications, while Senator Allison Greene publicly warns that legislative bodies are failing to keep pace.

1997 -- The U.S. government introduces the Pivot Protocols, a standardized set of emergency procedures for managing superhuman incidents. The protocols consist of three sections: Identification, Containment, and Response. Several European nations begin adapting these procedures for their own use. In Philadelphia, the police department establishes its first dedicated Superhuman Response Unit to implement the Pivot Protocols locally.

1998 -- Dr. Lillian Haversham publishes the first scientific framework for metahuman regeneration.

1999 -- The Geneva Summit on Superhuman Affairs convenes as the first international conference dedicated to the superhuman phenomenon. Representatives from across the globe participate in a three-day information-sharing event. Delegates from the United States and United Kingdom propose an international oversight body, sparking heated debate. Although no formal decisions are reached, the summit lays the groundwork for what will become the International Superhuman Coalition. In Philadelphia, the "Liberty Incident" -- a rogue superhuman battle that damages the Liberty Bell -- sours public sentiment toward superhumans in the city.

docs.title: 2000s: Institutionalization
docs.text:
2000 -- The Department of Defense establishes the Superhuman Study and Response Division (SSRD) to centralize the federal response to superhuman incidents. The SSRD operates under the DoD and coordinates with the FBI and CIA. Jason Alder (Democrat) becomes mayor of Philadelphia, initiating policies to mitigate superhuman-related damages and engage the superhuman community.

2001 -- The September 11 attacks occur. Superhumans participate significantly in rescue operations, lifting debris, evacuating the injured, and assisting firefighters. The crisis underscores both the value of metahuman responders and the inadequacy of existing institutional structures.

2002 -- Congress passes the National Superhuman Response Agency Establishment Act (Public Law 107-91), creating the NSRA as an independent agency within the Department of Defense. The SSRD is dissolved and all its functions, personnel, and assets are transferred to the new agency. The NSRA comprises four divisions: Intelligence, Operations, Science & Technology, and Public Affairs. President George W. Bush signs the act into law on May 22. In Philadelphia, City Council introduces the first Superhuman Intervention Ordinance, providing a legal framework for superhuman activities within city limits.

2003 -- Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago becomes the first hospital to integrate metahuman medical practitioners.

2004 -- Superhumans aid in disaster response during the Japanese earthquakes. In Philadelphia, local superhumans contain a major Center City fire, saving hundreds of lives and partially restoring public goodwill toward the metahuman community.

2005 -- The International Superhuman Coalition (ISC) is officially founded in Geneva, initially proposed by the U.S., UK, France, Japan, and Canada following a three-year deliberation period. The landmark case United States v. Davis establishes the legal framework for treating superhuman abilities as weapons when used criminally, creating the term "Felony-Enabled Superhuman Operatives" (FESO). Superhumans assist in Hurricane Katrina relief efforts; the team known as "The Saviors" (led by Valor, with members Momentum, Tempest, and Specter) gains national prominence.

2006 -- Daedalus Correctional Facility becomes operational as the first purpose-built superhuman prison. In Philadelphia, Sarah Westfield (Republican) becomes mayor and introduces stricter superhuman regulations citing public safety.

2007 -- In State of New York v. Sentry Insurance, the Supreme Court rules 5-4 that insurance companies cannot charge higher premiums based solely on superhuman status, citing the Equal Protection Clause.

2008 -- The Superhuman Registration Act (SRA) is passed under the Bush administration, mandating that all superhumans register with the NSRA regardless of whether they use their powers. The act ignites massive protests and civil liberties opposition. In Philadelphia, the Philadelphia Protectors are established as the city's first registered superhuman team.

2009 -- President James Grant (Democrat) takes office, promising a balanced approach to superhuman rights and signaling intent to challenge the SRA. The SRA is eventually struck down by the Supreme Court in a 6-3 decision as a violation of the Fourth and Fifth/Fourteenth Amendments. Dr. Emily Hargrove publishes her landmark paper on the Bracing Effect.

docs.title: 2010s: Crisis and Regulation
docs.text:
2010 -- The ISC's Crisis Response Unit deploys in the Balochistan Crisis. In Philadelphia, "Hero Riots" erupt following the controversial arrest of a popular superhuman, amplifying the national debate on superhuman rights.

2011 -- The Tesla Incident occurs on October 14 at the Tesla manufacturing plant in Sparks, Nevada. An industrial accident triggers the activation event of employee Alex Carter (magnetokinesis), and law enforcement's lethal response causes a cascading second activation in Sarah Chen (thermogenesis). Both superhumans lose control and die; 32 people are killed in total, including CEO Elon Musk. The incident exposes critical failures in law enforcement protocols for superhuman engagements and becomes a defining political event.

2012 -- Laura Stewart (Republican) wins the presidency, leveraging the Tesla Incident and running on a platform of superhuman security and pro-business deregulation. She defeats incumbent James Grant. Aurora Springs Residential Facility is established in Colorado as a non-punitive containment facility for non-criminal superhumans with uncontrolled abilities. In Philadelphia, Jeremy Owens (Democrat) becomes mayor, promising balanced superhuman regulation. The ISC's CRU responds to Typhoon Wukong.

2013 -- The LUMA Act is signed into law under the Stewart administration, creating the License to Utilize Metahuman Abilities system. The license is optional except for occupational use of powers, costing $40 for initial application and $20 for biennial renewal. A juvenile version (JLUMA) requires annual renewal.

2014 -- A major crackdown on superhuman crime in Philadelphia, conducted jointly by police and the Protectors, produces a significant drop in the city's crime rate. The ISC's CRU intervenes in the UAE Crisis. St. John's Hospital in New York City launches a metahuman healthcare pilot program.

2015 -- Riley v. California rules that warrantless search and seizure of a superhuman's personal data is unconstitutional under the Fourth Amendment. The Digital Privacy Act further strengthens digital privacy protections for superhumans.

2016 -- President Stewart wins re-election in a narrow contest, buoyed by campaign financing and her hardline stance on superhuman security. The UAE dissolves into its component Emirates. A superhuman-focused healthcare initiative launches in Philadelphia in partnership with Penn Medicine.

2017 -- The "Pink Mist" incident shakes the nation: an unregistered vigilante delivers the severed heads of major crime lords, gang leaders, and supervillains to the White House steps. The act provokes intense public debate about vigilante justice, systemic failure, and the limits of superhuman regulation. A manhunt is launched but the individual is never apprehended. United States v. Gibson establishes precedent regarding mind-control powers and criminal liability. The ISC's CRU deploys in a Ukrainian standoff.

2018 -- Lena Watkins (Republican) becomes mayor of Philadelphia, introducing policies to integrate superhumans into the city's emergency services. "The Big Raid" disrupts traditional criminal enterprises. The ISC assists in establishing the Amazonian Autonomous Zone.

docs.title: 2020s: The Present Era
docs.text:
2020 -- Samuel Rodriguez (Democrat) wins the presidency, defeating Joshua Bradshaw of the GOP's "New Hawks" faction with a platform of balanced regulation and civil liberties. The COVID-19 pandemic hits; controversy arises in Philadelphia and nationally over the use of superhuman abilities in pandemic response. The ISC's CRU facilitates the Syrian Detente.

2021 -- The Rodriguez administration passes the Superhuman Healthcare Act, a landmark law aimed at integrating superhumans into the healthcare system and preventing discrimination. The Transgender Health Protections Act is also passed. Justice Ginsburg is replaced by Justice Kethledge on the Supreme Court; Justice Thomas dies at age 73 and is replaced by Justice Goodwin Hon Liu.

2022 -- Philadelphia elects its first superhuman to City Council, marking a significant step in metahuman political integration. President Rodriguez declassifies the original Pivot Protocols documentation. The ISC deploys its CRU in the North Korean Crisis (details classified). Justice Kethledge dies in a car collision; Phoebe Byron is nominated from the Ninth Circuit at age 42.

2023 -- Key statistics reflect the state of superhuman America at the midpoint of the Rodriguez presidency: approximately 500,000 superhumans reside in the U.S.; 65% hold conventional employment while 35% work in "cape collar" occupations; 71% of active superheroes hold a LUMA, though only 38% of civilian superhumans do; 55% of the public supports the administration's balanced regulatory approach. The ISC, now comprising 73 member nations, responds to the Australian Wildfires.

docs.title: Implications
docs.text:
The timeline of superhuman emergence has fundamentally reshaped American governance, law, and culture. The recurring pattern -- catastrophic incident followed by reactive legislation -- has produced an institutional landscape that critics describe as perpetually behind the curve. The Pivot Protocols, the SSRD, the NSRA, the SRA, and LUMA each represent successive attempts to impose order on a phenomenon that defies easy categorization.

The political consequences have been equally significant. Superhuman policy has become a reliable wedge issue in American electoral politics, capable of swinging presidential elections as it did in 2012 when the Tesla Incident propelled Laura Stewart to victory. The emergence of factions like the New Hawks reflects an ongoing ideological struggle over how to balance security, liberty, and the integration of a population whose individual members can pose existential-scale threats.

At the local level, cities like Philadelphia have served as laboratories for superhuman policy, moving through cycles of hostility and acceptance. The arc from the Liberty Incident's souring of public opinion to the election of a superhuman council member in 2022 illustrates the uneven but broadly integrative trajectory of metahuman civic participation.

docs.title: Related Concepts
docs.text:
• PERKS Assessment -- The classification system used by the NSRA to categorize metahuman abilities; its development is closely tied to the institutional history documented here.
  • LUMA (License to Utilize Metahuman Abilities) -- The licensing framework introduced during the Stewart presidency in 2013, a direct product of the legislative trajectory following the SRA's invalidation.
  • NSRA (National Superhuman Response Agency) -- The federal agency established in 2002 that administers superhuman regulation; its creation is one of the most consequential events on this timeline.
  • Tesla Incident -- The 2011 disaster at the Tesla plant in Sparks, Nevada, which killed 32 people including Elon Musk and reshaped American superhuman policy and electoral politics.
  • Pivot Protocols -- The 1997 emergency response framework that marked the first federal standardization of superhuman crisis management.
  • International Superhuman Coalition -- The international body founded in 2005 following the 1999 Geneva Summit, now comprising 73 member nations.

  • Daedalus Correctional Facility -- The first purpose-built superhuman prison, operational since 2006.
  • Aurora Springs Residential Facility -- The non-punitive containment facility for non-criminal superhumans, established in 2012.

docs.title: Trivia
docs.text:
• The term "Activation Event" was coined by Dr. Rebecca Hartman, who had earlier gained prominence for her reporting on the Genesis Births for the LA Times in 1982.
  • September 11, 2001 occurred on its historical date in this timeline, with the notable addition of superhuman involvement in rescue operations.
  • The Superhuman Registration Act of 2008 was struck down as unconstitutional, but the political energy it generated contributed directly to the LUMA system that replaced it.
  • Over two-thirds of American metahumans choose not to participate in the superhero-supervillain dynamic at all, instead using their abilities in conventional employment or for personal use.
  • Philadelphia's Liberty Bell was damaged in the 1999 Liberty Incident, making it one of the earliest high-profile cases of superhuman collateral damage to a national landmark.
  • The Tesla Incident killed Elon Musk in this timeline, a significant point of divergence from real-world history.
  • The Pink Mist vigilante was never identified or apprehended despite a national manhunt.

docs.title: Book 1: Pup
docs.text: A fourteen-year-old girl with shark teeth and a blood compass learns that saving lives means risking your own — and that the world of heroes is far more dangerous than anyone told her.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Samantha "Sam" Small, a fourteen-year-old Jewish girl from Mayfair, Philadelphia, gains shark-based powers after a boating accident with her grandfather leaves her mangled by a propeller. The book opens with her PERKS assessment interview, where Officer Gold documents her abilities — shark teeth with enhanced bite force, a blood-sensing ability that functions as a new sense detecting nearby vascular systems, and a possible regenerative capacity she is not yet aware of. She is granted a provisional Juvenile License to Utilize Metahuman Abilities (JLUMA). During a Shabbat dinner at her grandfather Pop-Pop Moe's house in Ventnor, New Jersey, Moe encourages her to use her powers to save lives, planting the seed of heroism.

Sam's trajectory shifts when she encounters Liberty Belle, leader of the Delaware Valley Defenders, during a pickup basketball game. Her blood sense detects Belle's severe internal bleeding, and Belle later visits Sam's home to recruit her for the Young Defenders, a youth training division. During this visit, Belle privately reveals she is dying of metastasized stomach cancer with only a few years to live. Sam agrees to join on a trial basis. At DVD headquarters in Center City, she meets the team — Puppeteer, Blink, Crossroads, Gossamer, Playback, Rampart, and Gale — undergoes physical assessments, nearly collapses completing the obstacle course, and receives her costume and codename: Bloodhound.

On her first patrol with Gale, Sam detects a robbery at a Walgreens in Northern Liberties. She and Gale subdue a ground-liquefying criminal who names himself Mudslide. Immediately afterward, a space-warping figure called Safeguard appears, trapping Sam inside the store and compressing a bathroom around her before escaping. Over the following weeks, Sam trains with Puppeteer, patrols with Gale and Rampart, testifies in court against Mudslide, and begins high school at Tacony Academy Charter. She spots a student named Jordan wearing platform goth boots identical to Safeguard's. After school, Jordan freely confirms their identity and proposes a scheme: stage fake superhero-villain fights for mutual notoriety. Sam is disgusted but cannot bring herself to refuse outright.

Sam visits Jordan's hideout — an abandoned music hall in Tacony — where they choreograph a staged confrontation planned for the old Dobson Textile Factory. However, when they scout the factory at night, they witness Mudslide, now free and working for a criminal organization called the Kingdom of Keys, bury a captive man alive under orders from two suited operatives: Mr. Nothing and Mr. Polygraph. Jordan's friend Alex captures footage via drone before Mr. Nothing shoots it down. Sam is discovered, trapped, and interrogated at gunpoint before Jordan warps the space to let them escape. A brutal, desperate fight follows. Sam bites off metal from machinery to fashion improvised spears, Jordan stabs Mr. Nothing through the stomach, and both teenagers sustain severe injuries — Sam suffers two gunshot wounds, a broken nose, cracked ribs, and a broken ankle. Police sirens from Jordan's earlier 911 call force the criminals to retreat. In the hospital, doctors discover Sam's fractures have already consolidated and sharp teeth are growing from her bones, revealing an accelerated healing ability far beyond what her initial assessment suggested. Sam's parents confront her, terrified but ultimately supportive, with her mother insisting she stay with the Young Defenders but leave dangerous investigations to adults. The arc closes with Sam examining a vial of teeth extracted from her bones, determined to find answers about her evolving powers and the Kingdom of Keys.

docs.title: Themes
docs.text:
• Coming of age through violence — Sam is thrust from mundane adolescence into life-threatening situations, and each encounter strips away more of her childhood innocence while revealing her resilience.
  • Identity and self-worth — Sam repeatedly dismisses her own powers as "shitty" and "gross," yet discovers through action that her blood sense and tenacity make her formidable; the gap between self-perception and reality is a driving tension.
  • Moral compromise and ethical gray areas — Jordan's proposal to stage fights forces Sam to confront the distance between idealized heroism and the pragmatic shortcuts people take; her inability to refuse outright reveals her own moral flexibility.
  • Family as foundation — Pop-Pop Moe's Jewish wisdom, Ben's quiet protectiveness, and Rachel's practical love form the bedrock Sam returns to after every crisis; her greatest fear after being shot is not death but disappointing her parents.
  • Mentorship and its limits — Liberty Belle recruits Sam but is dying; Puppeteer trains her but cannot protect her from what she stumbles into; the adults in Sam's life provide guidance but cannot shield her from the consequences of her choices.

docs.title: Threads Planted
docs.text:
• Liberty Belle's terminal cancer — Belle reveals she has 3-4 years to live from metastasized stomach cancer; she is spending her remaining time recruiting young metahumans before criminal elements can (Ch. 4). Sam knows this secret and is keeping it from the rest of the team.
  • The villain who killed Professor Franklin — Marcus discovers that Liberty Belle's predecessor was killed six years ago by a villain whose identity has been suppressed from public records (Ch. 3). Belle cryptically dodges Sam's question about who "gave her" cancer (Ch. 4).
  • The Kingdom of Keys — A criminal organization with suited operatives using "Mr." honorifics. Mr. Nothing (power nullification via touch), Mr. Polygraph (lie detection), and a "Mr. B" (a lawyer, mentioned but unseen) are identified. They recruit Mudslide and murder a captive as a loyalty test (Ch. 12). They reference targeting Liberty Belle specifically, asking Mudslide if he's related to Diane Williams.
  • Mr. Nothing's power nullification — When Mr. Nothing touches bare skin, he cancels out the touched person's powers entirely; when he grabs Jordan, all spatial distortions instantly collapse (Ch. 13). This makes him an existential threat to any metahuman.
  • Sam's accelerating regeneration — Her PERKS assessment lists regeneration as "G?/S/P/U" (potential, unconfirmed). By the end of the arc, her fractures consolidate within hours, gunshot wounds scar over overnight, and sharp teeth grow from her bones during surgery (Ch. 14). Doctors and her parents are alarmed by the rate of healing.
  • Bone-teeth growth — A nurse delivers a container of pointed teeth that grew from Sam's bones during surgery. The surgeon describes them as "fully formed structures" growing right off her skeletal injuries (Ch. 14). This suggests Sam's shark biology is far more extensive than initially assessed.
  • Sam's evolving shark biology — Beyond teeth and blood sense, Sam demonstrates: the ability to bite through metal, drink saltwater without ill effect, potential super-kidneys for salt processing, enhanced durability, and accelerated healing. Her friend Tasha theorizes she may have developed alternate salt-excretion mechanisms (Ch. 3). The full scope is unknown.
  • Sam's blood sense as ESP — Gale raises the possibility that Sam's blood sense is not smell-based but a form of extrasensory perception, since it provides spatial information (location, distance, vascular system mapping) rather than olfactory data (Ch. 9). This is unresolved.
  • Sam's developing feelings for Gale — Sam experiences confusing attraction toward Gale during their patrols, denying it internally but showing clear signs of a crush (Ch. 9). Rampart awkwardly warns Sam not to hurt Gale's feelings.
  • Jordan's neglectful home life — Jordan reveals their mother doesn't buy food, doesn't come home, and essentially ignores them. They sleep in an abandoned building rather than go home (Ch. 11). Their motivation for the staged-fight scheme stems partly from seeking attention and recognition.
  • Jordan's space-warping mechanics — Objects duplicated by Jordan's powers eventually dissolve into ash. They can stretch space in any axis, create platforms, replicate machinery, and contract distances. Overexertion causes nosebleeds and loss of consciousness (Chs. 7-8, 11-13).
  • Alex and the drone footage — Jordan's friend Alex captured footage of the Kingdom murder on a memory card. The teens plan to deliver it to authorities as evidence (Ch. 14). Alex's identity as the drone operator is potentially traceable.
  • Mudslide's grudge — After being arrested by Sam and Gale, then recruited by the Kingdom, Mudslide now has a deep personal vendetta against both Sam and Jordan. He threatens revenge: "This ain't over, bitch. Both of you… you're going to pay" (Ch. 13).
  • Sam's secret identity is compromised — Mudslide identifies Sam as Bloodhound during the factory confrontation. Mr. Nothing and Mr. Polygraph have seen her face unmasked. Her mask is broken during the fight and she rips it off (Ch. 13). The Kingdom knows who she is.
  • The staged-fight plan — Sam and Jordan's original scheme to fake superhero-villain confrontations for notoriety is abandoned after the factory events, but the underlying dynamic of their partnership — and the moral questions it raises — remains unresolved (Chs. 10-12).
  • Marcus as "guy in the chair" — Sam's friend Marcus serves as her civilian research asset, discovering Safeguard named themselves after an antagonist from the manga BLAME!, tracking a hardware store sighting, and providing forum-sourced intelligence (Ch. 9). His role as information support is established.
  • Kate Smith's intensity — Kate is described as suggesting Sam target "loan sharks" and "slumlords" with unusual intensity, hinting at something personal beneath her tomboyish exterior. The wiki index notes she "later becomes Soot" (Ch. 3 introduction, wiki-index.md).
  • Tasha Reynolds as future Lighthouse — Tasha is introduced as an analytically brilliant friend. The wiki index identifies her future alias as "Lighthouse" with the Auditors (Ch. 3 introduction, wiki-index.md).
  • Pop-Pop Moe's connections — Moe mentions having personally met Stan Lee, Steve Ditko, and Mr. Chakravarti (Mr. Genesis), describing the latter as a true hero (Ch. 2). He also claims to "know some people on the force" (Ch. 2). His background and connections are unexplored.
  • Interlude 8.5 chat dynamics — Blink mentions seeing unfamiliar snake/worm graffiti during patrol, which Rampart flags as potentially connected to gang activity (Interlude 8.5). Playback jokes about weed from a dispensary in Camden run by someone his dad knows.
  • Sam's claustrophobia — When Safeguard compresses the bathroom around her, Sam experiences severe panic and a primal breakdown that surprises even Safeguard (Ch. 8). This traces back to her activation event of being trapped underwater beneath a boat.
  • JLUMA legal framework — Sam's license allows legal use of powers in self-defense or public interest but does not authorize her to seek out danger. The legal infrastructure around metahuman minors is established but its limits are untested (Ch. 1).
  • DVD organizational structure — Mr. Davis is the "de jure" leader of the DVD while Liberty Belle is the "de facto" leader. The organization has support staff including a nurse, dispatchers, computer specialist, forensic staff, investigators, and a lawyer named Mrs. Clara (Ch. 5). Professor Franklin's locker is still present.
  • Sam's self-image vs. reality — Sam consistently underestimates herself, calling her powers "shitty" and "weird," yet her blood sense proves tactically invaluable and her tenacity repeatedly saves her life. The tension between how she sees herself and what she actually accomplishes is a core character thread.

docs.title: Book 2: Keys
docs.text: A girl with shark teeth learns that the doors you kick open don't close behind you — and the people on the other side know where you live.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Fresh from the hospital after surviving the Dobson Mills factory fight, Sam delivers the drone footage of Mudslide's murder to the Delaware Valley Defenders. The adult heroes — Bulwark, Multiplex, Fury Forge, legal advisor Clara Parker, and Councilman Jamal Davis — recognize the criminal organization as the Kingdom of Keys, a group that has been filling voids in the drug trade for two years but whose operatives had never been identified by name. Despite Sam's protests and demonstration of her newly confirmed regenerative abilities, the adults exclude her from the investigation due to her age. Tensions simmer over Liberty Belle's conspicuous absence, with Playback questioning her missing leadership and Puppeteer defensively insisting Belle has her reasons.

Sam's life splits into parallel tracks. At home, she attends Rosh Hashanah dinner at Pop-Pop Moe's, where her grandfather subtly affirms her heroic path through Torah readings about suffering for future reward, Spider-Man's ethos of responsibility, and a direct quote from the Shulchan Arukh about the obligation to save others. She demonstrates her healing factor to her middle school friends at Kate's apartment, tells them she already has a costume and team, and begins intensive combat training with Rampart — Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu, bone conditioning, and striking fundamentals. A recreational outing with Gale leads to catching a purse-snatcher and deepening Sam's unspoken crush. Upon returning to headquarters, Puppeteer confronts Sam, accusing her of hiding information about Liberty Belle and questioning her worthiness. The confrontation turns physical when Puppeteer uses her strings to slam Sam against the lockers. Playback intervenes and reveals what he overheard — that Liberty Belle is seriously ill — defusing the crisis. Puppeteer, exhausted and ashamed, falls asleep on a bench.

Meanwhile, Sam and Jordan establish a vigilante partnership from an abandoned Tacony Music Hall, which Jordan has outfitted as a hideout. They confront the Coyotes, a local youth gang, discovering their leader Aaron possesses fire-ignition powers triggered by his gaze. The fight is brutal — Aaron sets Sam's costume ablaze, and Sam neutralizes him by biting his shoulder and spitting blood into his eyes. Jordan steals the gang's money and drugs, disposing of the hard substances in the Delaware River and splitting the cash. Over the following weeks, the pair conduct nightly raids across Northeast Philadelphia, targeting dog fighting rings, robberies, and drug operations. Sam's double life takes a toll: she falls asleep in class, maintains passing grades barely, and grows distant from her middle school friends. Marcus discovers her vigilante identity through an online video.

The investigation into the Kingdom of Keys accelerates when Crossroads — revealed as Lilly's second cousin Maxwell, and now acting leader of the Young Defenders during Puppeteer's psychiatric leave — recruits Sam and Jordan for an undercover mission at Crescent nightclub, a money-laundering front. Disguised with makeup and fake IDs, Sam and Jordan infiltrate the VIP section posing as waitstaff. They identify three Kingdom operatives: Dr. Xenograft (Mrs. X), who keeps a giant modified greyhound named Scylla; Mr. T-Rex (Mr. T), who can transform into a Tyrannosaurus Rex; and Mrs. Heartbeat (Mrs. H), who can slow or stop a person's heart through touch. When the woman in red notices their underage hand stamps, the cover is blown. Jordan bluffs with a prop gun, claiming it is a "Graviton Beam Emitter," and demonstrates by making a cigar box vanish with their space-warping powers. Sam escapes by attacking Mrs. Heartbeat and spitting blood on her ankle as a tracker, and the pair flee through the nightclub with Crossroads providing remote guidance. The mission is deemed a success — they gathered intelligence on three previously unknown Kingdom operatives.

The Kingdom retaliates. During Jordan's first visit to meet Sam's parents at their Mayfair rowhouse, Dr. Xenograft's mutant animal hybrids — raccoon-spider creatures, opossum-copperhead snakes, crow-basset hound chimeras — invade the house. Mr. T-Rex and a weather-controlling operative called Mrs. Z arrive outside. Sam's parents flee to Pop-Pop Moe's in New Jersey; Jordan escapes with Sam's Bloodhound mask and money to get help. Sam stays to fight. Mr. T-Rex transforms into a feathered Tyrannosaurus Rex and systematically destroys the Small family home while Sam clings to his back, biting and clawing. Her foot is crushed beneath his weight. Bulwark arrives and drives Mr. T-Rex off with improvised weapons and layered stone armor. Sam is hospitalized with a pulverized foot, where doctors confirm a 6x-8x healing factor that accelerates under active threat. Her father reveals he carried superhero insurance on their home. Unable to return to Mayfair, Sam moves in with Blink (Lily Chen) on Almond Street in Bridesburg, emails her teachers about her absence, and the arc closes with her determination unbroken despite losing her home.

docs.title: Themes
docs.text:
• Escalation and consequence — Every action Sam takes — delivering the drone footage, confronting the Coyotes, infiltrating the nightclub — triggers a proportionally larger response, culminating in the destruction of her home. The arc traces the causal chain from initiative to catastrophe.
  • The cost of secrecy — Sam's obligation to keep Liberty Belle's illness secret fractures the team, causing Puppeteer's breakdown and assault. Secrets protect individuals but corrode the trust that holds teams together.
  • Vigilantism vs. sanctioned heroism — Sam and Jordan's freelance operations produce results — disrupting the Coyotes, gathering intelligence — but their methods (stealing money, using violence against teenagers, infiltrating nightclubs underage) sit in uncomfortable ethical territory. The Young Defenders' by-the-book approach is slower but more sustainable.
  • Family as anchor and vulnerability — Pop-Pop Moe's religious wisdom grounds Sam morally, and her parents' love provides emotional stability, but the Kingdom weaponizes her family ties by attacking her home, transforming her greatest source of strength into her most dangerous liability.
  • The hunger in heroism — Sam notices a growing bloodlust in herself during the Coyotes fight, an appetite for violence that disturbs her even as it saves her life. Her shark biology and her moral compass pull in opposing directions.

docs.title: Threads Planted
docs.text:
• Sam's 6x-8x healing factor — Hospital staff confirm Sam heals six to eight times faster than a normal human, with the rate accelerating under active threat (Ch. 29). The mechanism behind threat-responsive acceleration is unexplained.
  • Teeth growing from bones — Sam keeps a vial of teeth extracted from her bones during surgery (Ch. 14-15, 17, 29). Doctors find additional teeth growing from bone fragments after the T-Rex fight. The full implications of Sam's skeletal shark biology are unknown.
  • Sam's growing bloodlust — During the Coyotes fight, Sam experiences disturbing pleasure from violence — biting Aaron, drawing blood, the "evil voice" urging counterviolence against the purse-snatcher (Ch. 19, 21). This appetite for violence troubles her internally.
  • The Wolfcave and vigilante identity — Sam and Jordan's abandoned music hall hideout, their system of dead drops, and their developing reputation as Bloodhound (with online fan sites) constitute an independent vigilante infrastructure outside the Young Defenders (Ch. 20, 22). This dual allegiance is unresolved.
  • Kingdom of Keys organizational structure — The Kingdom uses "Mr." and "Mrs." honorifics. Known operatives now include Mr. Nothing (power nullification), Mr. Polygraph (lie detection), Mr. T-Rex (dinosaur transformation), Dr. Xenograft (bioengineered creatures), Mrs. Heartbeat (cardiac manipulation), Mrs. Z (weather control), and Mudslide (earth liquefaction). A "code of conduct" forbids involving minors, though they violate it when provoked (Ch. 25-26). A lawyer called "Mr. B" was mentioned in Book 1 but remains unseen.
  • Mrs. Z's identity and powers — A weather-manipulating operative in an orange blouse, called "Mrs. Z" by Mr. T-Rex, creates the rainstorm during the home attack and then departs in a car (Ch. 28). Her full identity and role within the Kingdom are unestablished.
  • Crescent nightclub as a Kingdom hub — The nightclub is confirmed as a money-laundering front with unusually heavy armed security (Ch. 24-26). The Kingdom's broader financial operations remain unexplored.
  • Dr. Xenograft's bioengineered creatures — Scylla (an oversized greyhound), raccoon-spider hybrids, opossum-copperhead hybrids, crow-basset hound chimeras, a rottweiler-deer hybrid, and a turtle-crab lockpicker all appear wearing shock collars (Ch. 25, 27-28). The scope of her menagerie and the science behind it are unresolved.
  • Sam's compromised civilian identity — The Kingdom now knows Sam's real name, address, and face. They attacked her home directly (Ch. 27-28). Her anonymity is permanently destroyed among Kingdom operatives.
  • Aaron McKinley and the Coyotes — Aaron's fire-ignition power (triggered by gaze) and the gang's desire for revenge create an unresolved local threat (Ch. 20-21). Jordan creates a cover story about beating information out of Aaron to explain their Kingdom knowledge to the villains at Crescent (Ch. 26).
  • Jordan's cover story to the Kingdom — At Crescent, Jordan claims they beat information about the Kingdom out of Aaron McKinley (Ch. 26). This could lead the Kingdom back to the Coyotes or create blowback.
  • Puppeteer's psychiatric leave — After her breakdown and assault on Sam, Puppeteer takes leave for psychiatric treatment (Ch. 22-23). Her return and mental state are unresolved.
  • Sam's blood-tracking technique — Sam spits blood on Mrs. Heartbeat's ankle to create a tracker via her blood sense (Ch. 26). This tactical innovation — marking targets with her own blood — could become a signature ability.
  • Sam's inability to get drunk — At Lilly's party, Sam discovers her healing factor or metabolism prevents intoxication (Ch. 23). This detail about her physiology is noted but unexplored.
  • Crossroads as acting leader — Maxwell's assumption of leadership during Puppeteer's leave reveals his precognitive coin-flip method and his quiet competence (Ch. 23-26). The power dynamics when Puppeteer returns are unresolved.
  • The Small family's displacement — Ben and Rachel flee to Pop-Pop Moe's in New Jersey; Sam moves in with Blink in Bridesburg. Home reconstruction is estimated at 14-24 weeks depending on superhuman construction crews (Ch. 29). The family is scattered.
  • Superhero insurance — Ben Small carried superhero insurance on their home in addition to regular homeowner's insurance (Ch. 29). This worldbuilding detail has implications for how civilian families in this world protect themselves.
  • Marcus as information asset — Marcus discovers Sam's Bloodhound identity through online video and promises to keep her secret (Ch. 22). His role as a civilian intelligence resource continues to develop.
  • The Tacony Titans — Lilly mentions a local superhero team (Bubble, Compass, Weave, Sandman, Sundial) active in their neighborhood, with a rudimentary website (Ch. 17). They are referenced but never encountered.
  • Sam inadvertently reveals her real name — During the post-Crescent debrief call, Sam accidentally says her real name to the full Young Defenders team (Ch. 26). Her identity within the team is no longer secret.

docs.title: Threads Progressed
docs.text:
• Liberty Belle's terminal cancer — Belle remains absent throughout Book 2. Her illness becomes the catalyst for the Puppeteer confrontation when Playback reveals she is seriously ill (Ch. 19). The team now knows she is sick, though the full diagnosis (metastasized stomach cancer, 3-4 years to live) may not be known to all. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 4.
  • Sam's accelerating regeneration — Confirmed and quantified: doctors measure a 6x-8x healing factor that accelerates under active threat (Ch. 29). Her regeneration is now an established combat asset rather than a suspicion. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 14.
  • Sam's evolving shark biology — Additional teeth grow from bone fragments after the T-Rex fight (Ch. 29). She heals burns, stab wounds, and a crushed foot. She cannot get drunk. Her biology continues to develop beyond initial assessment. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 14.
  • The Kingdom of Keys — Dramatically expanded: three new operatives identified (Dr. Xenograft, Mrs. Heartbeat, Mr. T-Rex), plus Mrs. Z. Their organizational structure, code of conduct, and nightclub front are partially mapped. They have escalated from background threat to direct antagonists who destroy Sam's home. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 12.
  • Sam's secret identity is compromised — The Kingdom attacks Sam's home address directly, confirming they tracked her from the nightclub. Her civilian identity is now weaponized against her. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 13.
  • Sam's developing feelings for Gale — Deepens significantly: their recreational flight, music conversations, purse-snatcher teamwork, and Sam's intense internal monologue about her crush all advance this thread without resolution (Ch. 18-19). Planted in Book 1, Ch. 9.
  • Jordan's neglectful home life — Jordan mentions living near Magnolia Cemetery with their disabled mother when meeting Sam's parents (Ch. 27). Their motivation for the vigilante lifestyle and attachment to Sam as a surrogate family deepen. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 11.
  • Mudslide's grudge — Mudslide's crime is the catalyst for the investigation but he does not appear directly in Book 2. His status with the Kingdom and vendetta against Sam remain active. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 13.
  • Sam's self-image vs. reality — Puppeteer's verbal assault calls Sam's powers "shit" and her body "designed to take lives" (Ch. 19), echoing Sam's own insecurities from Book 1. Yet Sam's actual performance — combat training, purse-snatcher arrest, Coyotes fight, nightclub infiltration, surviving Mr. T-Rex — demonstrates increasing competence. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 1.
  • Kate Smith's intensity — Kate suggests Sam target "loan sharks" and "slumlords" with unusual emotional intensity at the friend gathering (Ch. 17), echoing the same hint from Book 1. The reason behind this remains unexplained. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 3.
  • DVD organizational structure — The adult Defenders (Bulwark, Multiplex, Fury Forge) and support staff (Clara, Davis) are now active participants in the story rather than background figures. The team's hierarchy — Davis as de jure leader, Belle as de facto, Puppeteer as Young Defenders leader, Crossroads as acting leader — is more clearly delineated. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 5.

docs.title: Threads Resolved
docs.text:
• Liberty Belle's secret is out — Playback reveals Liberty Belle's illness to the team during the Puppeteer confrontation (Ch. 19). Sam is no longer the sole keeper of this secret, though the full details (cancer diagnosis, timeline) may not be universally known. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 4.
  • The staged-fight plan — Sam and Jordan's original scheme to fake superhero-villain confrontations is fully abandoned, replaced by a genuine vigilante partnership and eventual collaboration with the Young Defenders (Ch. 20-23). Planted in Book 1, Ch. 10.
  • Alex and the drone footage — The memory card is delivered to the DVD, reviewed by both the Young Defenders and adult team, and assessed for legal admissibility by Clara (Ch. 15). The footage is now in the proper hands. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 14.

docs.text: A girl with shark teeth learns that the ghosts of dead mentors possess the living — and that the price of loyalty is watching someone you love choose to die.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
After losing her home to Mr. T-Rex and the Kingdom of Keys, Sam moves into Lily Chen's modest Bridesburg rowhouse, where she adjusts to a new family's rhythms, reconnects with Jordan by phone, and visits Akilah Washington (Puppeteer) at an inpatient psychiatric facility. Akilah reveals her Narcissistic Personality Disorder diagnosis and apologizes for assaulting Sam, accepting that her condition bars her from Registered Superhuman Entity status while still permitting licensed vigilante work. Leadership of the Young Defenders remains with Crossroads.

The team's first major operation comes when the Young Defenders are dispatched to South Street to confront the Philly Phreaks, a gang of visually-apparent metahuman teenagers whose behavior has grown uncharacteristically aggressive under Kingdom of Keys influence. The fight reveals the Phreaks' secret weapon: Daisy Zhen, codename Deathgirl, a twelve-year-old girl with anger-based power-copying abilities who was "gifted" to the Phreaks by the Kingdom. Deathgirl copies and amplifies the powers of every hero she faces — sound manipulation, wind control, telekinetic strings, regeneration, and insect physiology — before escaping through a storm drain. Spindle betrays his own team to help the Young Defenders capture Patches, and in custody he reveals the Kingdom's involvement, including that Mr. T-Rex and Mr. Nothing delivered Daisy. Meanwhile, Liberty Belle returns to the team gaunt and bald from chemotherapy, publicly revealing that her stomach cancer has spread to her lungs, liver, and bones, leaving her eight to twenty-four months.

Belle uses her remaining time to train Sam intensively in combat, tradecraft, surveillance, and deception — teaching her poker to hone her ability to conceal intentions, coaching her in legal and gray-area investigative methods, and drilling her in strategic fighting rather than brute-force instinct. Sam's personal life expands: she begins dating Jamila after an emotional confession during a makeup session in Jamila's Germantown bedroom, attends a Demon Core metal concert at The Lonesome Dove in Camden where she defends Jamila from a racist attacker, visits her childhood friend Kate's basketball scrimmage at underfunded Abraham Lincoln High School, and returns to Tacony Academy where classmates treat her as the "school badass" for surviving the dinosaur attack on her home. On Halloween night, Sam, Jordan, Jamila, and Spinelli infiltrate a Kingdom warehouse on Trenton Avenue, where they witness Mr. Polygraph execute a suspected informant and instruct approximately thirty recruits to convert stolen goods into twenty thousand dollars each as an initiation test. The team narrowly escapes when Mudslide confronts them at the back exit, with Spindle staying behind to create a diversion and returning battered but alive at dawn. They present the gathered evidence — including video footage and Jordan's extensive research into Kingdom shell companies like Orion Holdings, Cerulean Dynamics, and Lockhart & Greene — to Liberty Belle, Councilman Davis, and Clara Parker, who agree to pursue the intelligence through parallel construction.

In the arc's final movement, Sam secretly follows Liberty Belle across Philadelphia over several nights, using her blood sense to track Belle's bleeding ulcers. She discovers Belle setting up surveillance equipment at the abandoned PES refinery in Southwest Philadelphia — the location where Professor Franklin was killed and where Belle herself nearly died. When Belle confronts Sam at an abandoned pier, she reveals the refinery is where she expects Chernobyl to return and forbids Sam from getting involved. On the first night of Hanukkah, emergency pagers signal Chernobyl's arrival. Sam disobeys orders to assist with evacuation and follows Belle to the refinery, where she records a confrontation in which Chernobyl reveals he has an arrangement with the federal government to provide energy in exchange for freedom. Chernobyl accuses Belle of being haunted by a "dybbuk" — the possessing spirit of Professor Franklin driving her to suicidal vengeance. Despite Belle's ferocity, Chernobyl's mechanized suit proves overwhelming. Sam intervenes with a makeshift spear fashioned by chewing a pipe to a point, managing to puncture the suit and draw Chernobyl's unusual white blood, but she cannot change the outcome. Chernobyl drives a spike through Belle's chest, killing her, then tells Sam to tend to her mentor and warns her not to follow. Sam cradles Belle as she dies, thanking her and apologizing. The arc closes with heroes gathering at DVD headquarters to mourn, the Young Defenders joining Sam in silent grief and solidarity.

docs.title: Themes
docs.text:
• The dybbuk — inherited grief as possession — The arc's title invokes the Jewish folklore of a possessing spirit. Chernobyl explicitly accuses Belle of being haunted by Franklin's ghost, driven to suicidal vengeance rather than rational heroism. The parallel structure — Franklin dies, Belle pursues his killer and dies, Sam will pursue Belle's killer — frames mentorship's dark side: the dead impose their unfinished missions on the living.
  • The cost of loyalty — Sam's defining trait is her refusal to abandon people she cares about, even when ordered to stand down. She follows Belle despite explicit prohibition. She stays at the refinery when fleeing would save her life. Loyalty here is not a virtue rewarded but a compulsion that places her at the epicenter of trauma.
  • Coming of age under fire — Sam juggles first love, school reintegration, family displacement, and intensifying hero work. The arc traces her transition from reactive street fighter to trained investigator, but each new skill comes freighted with the knowledge that Belle is teaching it because she is dying.
  • Institutional violence against the marginal — The Philly Phreaks are visually-apparent metahuman teenagers from disadvantaged backgrounds, weaponized by the Kingdom and sent against other teenagers for optics reasons. Chernobyl is a trapped man used as a government energy source. Pop-Pop Moe regrets building Daedalus, a prison for people with powers. The systems designed to manage superhumans consistently exploit the most vulnerable.
  • Normalcy as illusion — Sam's attempts to maintain ordinary life — Thanksgiving dinner, school friendships, basketball games, a first date — are repeatedly interrupted by emergencies, violence, and death. The arc asks whether a powered teenager can inhabit both worlds or must choose.

docs.title: Threads Planted
docs.text:
• Chernobyl's government energy deal — During the refinery confrontation, Chernobyl reveals he has an arrangement with the federal government to provide energy to power substations in exchange for freedom. Sam records this confession on her phone (Ch. 44).
  • Sam's recording of Belle's death — Sam films the entire refinery confrontation on her phone, including Chernobyl's admissions and Belle's final battle. Belle notices the camera and silently encourages Sam to keep recording. This footage becomes critical evidence (Chs. 44–45).
  • The dybbuk cycle — Chernobyl accuses Belle of being possessed by Franklin's spirit, suggesting her suicide mission is inherited vengeance rather than justice. Sam, now inheriting Belle's legacy, is positioned to continue the cycle (Ch. 44).
  • Chernobyl's white blood — Sam observes through her blood sense that Chernobyl's blood appears white rather than red, suggesting fundamental physiological alteration at the cellular level (Ch. 45).
  • Chernobyl's piledrive weapon system — His suit contains retractable metal spikes fired with enormous force from the palms, plus steam-venting capability that creates scalding then icy conditions. The number of spikes he can fire is unknown (Ch. 45).
  • Deathgirl's escape and origin — Daisy Zhen, a power-copying child weapon "gifted" to the Phreaks by the Kingdom, escapes through a storm drain after the South Street battle. Her origin, the facility that created her, and her future trajectory are all unresolved (Chs. 32–33).
  • Playback and Patches' pre-powers history — Playback calls Patches by her real name Amira during the South Street fight, revealing they know each other from before either had powers. After capture, Patches demands Playback specifically during interrogation (Chs. 32, 34).
  • Kingdom shell companies — Jordan's investigation reveals Orion Holdings, Cerulean Dynamics, and Lockhart & Greene as Kingdom financial fronts, evidence passed to Clara Parker for parallel construction (Ch. 41).
  • Kingdom recruitment pipeline — Mr. Polygraph's warehouse meeting shows a formalized initiation system: approximately thirty recruits must convert stolen goods into $20,000 cash by mid-December, with execution as the penalty for informants (Chs. 40–41).
  • Chernobyl-Kingdom connection question — Secondary thefts follow Chernobyl's attacks, suggesting the Kingdom is scavenging in his wake. Councilman Davis suspects a deeper connection, though Sam argues the Kingdom appears to be following rather than collaborating (Ch. 37).
  • Sam's accelerating regeneration — Nurse Sylvia notes Sam's healing factor may be increasing from 8x to 12–15x normal, with the rate possibly accelerating under active threat (Ch. 34).
  • Puppeteer's NPD and RSE restriction — Akilah's Narcissistic Personality Disorder diagnosis permanently bars her from Registered Superhuman Entity status, though she can still work as a licensed vigilante (Ch. 31).
  • Kate's growing distance and hidden intensity — Sam visits Kate's basketball game and feels the strain of keeping secrets from her oldest friend. Kate notices Sam's physical changes and asks about her "afterschool activities" (Ch. 38).
  • Jamila's father's untranslated comment — When he learns Sam is Jewish, Jamila's father makes a remark in Arabic that angers Jamila, who refuses to translate it, introducing cultural and religious tension (Ch. 35).
  • Aurora Springs as containment option — Belle mentions Aurora Springs as a facility Chernobyl rejected in favor of freedom; she promises to explain it to Sam later but dies before she can (Ch. 37).
  • Spindle's defection and integration — Connor betrays the Phreaks, cooperates with authorities, enters witness protection, escapes from Sam's backpack, and asks to join Sam's team, beginning his transformation from gang member to hero (Chs. 33–34, 39).
  • Mr. Mudslide as Kingdom enforcer — Mudslide confronts the team during their warehouse escape, now wearing professional attire with his paper bag mask, confirming his rise within the Kingdom hierarchy (Ch. 41).
  • Pop-Pop Moe's Daedalus regret — The Morris Small interview reveals that Pop-Pop Moe co-founded Horvath-Small Ltd. and deeply regrets his firm's role in building Daedalus Correctional Facility, worrying about what his grandchildren will think (interlude).
  • Belle's letter and detective bequest — Belle's will leaves Sam all her detective equipment and investigative files, including a notebook on Chernobyl, positioning Sam as her investigative successor (set up by Belle's intensive training throughout the arc, paid off in Book 4).
  • Emergency pager system — Fury Forge distributes "forever battery" pagers to all Young Defenders, establishing a rapid-response communication infrastructure (Ch. 37).

docs.title: Threads Progressed
docs.text:
• Liberty Belle's terminal cancer — Belle returns to the team gaunt and bald, publicly revealing the cancer has spread to lungs, liver, and bones with 8–24 months to live. She spends the arc training Sam and preparing for her final mission. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 4.
  • Sam's evolving shark biology — Sam's regeneration accelerates beyond initial measurements. Her physical appearance continues changing — increased muscle tone, tiny scars, heightened combat readiness that classmates notice. She fashions a weapon by chewing a metal pipe to a point during the refinery battle. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 14.
  • The Kingdom of Keys — The Kingdom's operations expand significantly: they "gifted" Deathgirl to the Philly Phreaks, run a formalized recruitment pipeline through warehouse meetings, maintain shell companies for money laundering, and are scavenging industrial materials in Chernobyl's wake. Mr. Polygraph and Mrs. Heartstopper are seen leading operations directly. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 12.
  • Sam's compromised civilian identity — Students at Tacony Academy know her house was destroyed by "a dinosaur" and treat her as the "school badass." She wears tooth caps to hide her shark teeth and becomes the school's unofficial bully-hunter. The gap between her civilian and hero identities widens. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 13.
  • Sam's developing feelings for Gale — Progresses from unspoken crush to open relationship. Sam confesses her feelings during a makeup session; they share their first kiss; Sam defends Jamila at a concert; Jamila publicly announces the relationship to the team. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 9.
  • Jordan's neglectful home life — Jordan now lives at the abandoned Tacony Music Hall full-time, avoiding their mother both for safety and because the relationship is toxic. They mention their mother "probably hasn't even noticed" they're gone. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 11.
  • The villain who killed Professor Franklin — Identified as Chernobyl / Illya Myronovych Fedorov, a Ukrainian national whose body emits ionizing radiation. Belle reveals he killed Franklin six years ago and nearly killed her two years ago, giving her the cancer that is now killing her. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 3.
  • DVD organizational structure — The adult Defenders (Multiplex, Bulwark, Fury Forge), support staff (Clara Parker, Councilman Davis), and medical personnel (Nurse Sylvia) operate as an increasingly visible institutional framework around the Young Defenders. Davis and Clara actively manage intelligence from the Halloween warehouse operation. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 5.
  • Sam's self-image vs. reality — Sam continues underestimating herself while demonstrating escalating competence: she completes intensive combat and tradecraft training under Belle, leads a warehouse infiltration, and intervenes against Chernobyl with improvised weapons. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 1.
  • Mudslide's grudge and Kingdom career — Mudslide appears at the warehouse exit wearing professional attire, confirming he has risen within the Kingdom. His confrontation with the team is hostile but they escape. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 13.
  • The Wolfcave / vigilante identity — The Tacony Music Hall evolves from Jordan's personal hideout into a shared team base where Sam, Jordan, Jamila, and Spinelli plan operations. Jordan's extensive corkboard of Kingdom intelligence shows they have been conducting solo investigations for weeks. Planted in Book 2, Ch. 20.
  • Crossroads as acting leader — Maxwell continues leading the Young Defenders through the South Street operation, the Chernobyl emergency response, and ongoing team coordination, demonstrating quiet competence and tactical acuity. Planted in Book 2, Ch. 23.
  • The Small family's displacement — Sam lives with the Chens, her parents stay at Pop-Pop Moe's in Ventnor. She video calls family on Thanksgiving and receives mailed personal items. The house reconstruction is ongoing but not complete. Planted in Book 2, Ch. 29.

docs.title: Threads Resolved
docs.text:
• Liberty Belle's terminal cancer — Belle's cancer arc reaches its endpoint: she reveals the full extent of her diagnosis publicly, trains Sam as her successor, and dies fighting Chernobyl at the PES refinery on the first night of Hanukkah. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 4; resolved in Ch. 45.
  • The villain who killed Professor Franklin — Chernobyl is fully identified and confronted. The mystery of who "gave" Belle her cancer and who killed her predecessor is answered: Illya Myronovych Fedorov, codename Chernobyl, whose ionizing radiation exposure caused Belle's cancer during a fight two years prior and who killed Franklin at the same refinery six years before that. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 3; resolved in Chs. 37, 44–45.
  • Puppeteer's psychiatric leave — Akilah completes inpatient treatment at Elysium Behavioral Health, receives her NPD diagnosis, and returns to active duty with the Young Defenders for the South Street operation. Planted in Book 2, Ch. 22; resolved in Ch. 31.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
In the aftermath of Liberty Belle's death at Chernobyl's hands, Sam attends the reading of her mentor's will and discovers that Belle has bequeathed her entire collection of detective equipment, investigative files, and case notes — including a notebook on Illya Myronovych Fedorov. A personal letter explains that Belle chose Sam as her investigative successor because Sam questioned her like a true detective rather than worshipping her as a legend. At Belle's funeral at Laurel Hill East Cemetery, Sam is shaken by the appearance of Mrs. Z, a Kingdom of Keys operative, among the mourners. Over winter break, Sam studies the notebook and discovers Belle's final cryptic note — the word "Porcelain?" underlined in red. When NSRA agents arrive at Lily Chen's house to confiscate the materials, Miasma intervenes, exposing their false claims. Sam plays a recording from Belle's final battle in which Chernobyl admits to a government arrangement, and she confronts Councilman Davis, who proposes forming an off-the-books covert team to investigate the NSRA's protection of Chernobyl.

Sam's investigation is brutally interrupted when Aaron McKinley — given a kill order by Mr. Polygraph after his earlier humiliation — ambushes her with a crowbar after a routine day of power testing with Dr. Leonard Harris. Joined by Pumice, Daisy/Deathgirl, and Chrysalis, the former Philly Phreaks capture and torture Sam: Aaron removes her fingernails with a claw hammer, and Daisy breaks her left hand. Through psychological manipulation and sheer will, Sam provokes Daisy into a chaotic transformation, discovers she can grow teeth from her wrists and knuckles, saws through her restraints, and escapes after puncturing Aaron's throat and face. She staggers into a residential neighborhood where strangers named Marge and Bill call an ambulance. At a New Year's Eve party at DVD headquarters, Sam reveals her ordeal and her new power to her teammates, struggling to balance her trauma with the celebration and her strained relationship with Jamila.

The newly formed Auditors — Sam, Jordan, and Spindle, with Miasma as a volatile adult advisor — establish their headquarters at the Tacony Music Hall. They analyze shell companies linking the NSRA to the Kingdom, conduct surveillance on a suspected covert facility, and discover a listening device in their base. Jordan's abusive mother tracks them down twice: the first time Sam punches her to protect Jordan, the second time Mrs. Westwood calls the police and NSRA agents Torres and Jennings, resulting in Jordan permanently severing ties with their mother. When Miasma is framed for killing four NSRA security guards at the Hatboro-Horsham office, the Auditors investigate the crime scene posing as student journalists and encounter Mr. Polygraph and Mr. ESP impersonating NSRA agents, confirming Kingdom involvement in the frame-up. Agent Torres later visits the Auditors off-record, sharing files on Chernobyl's location in the abandoned Arch Street Subway tunnels and warning them to stay away.

The Auditors defy Torres's orders and enter the tunnels, where they are ambushed by Mr. ESP (whose psychic power that day is "remote listening," allowing him to have overheard their conversation with Torres) and Mr. Mudslide. In a desperate battle in total darkness, Sam uses her blood as a sensory mapping tool while Jordan and Spindle fight from the shadows. Chernobyl arrives and violently rejects the Kingdom's recruitment offer, hurling Mr. ESP into a concrete pillar. Sam sends Jordan and Spindle to safety and confronts Chernobyl alone despite two gunshot wounds to her abdomen. Their battle is as much philosophical debate as physical combat: Chernobyl invokes the Maccabees and self-defense, Sam counters with her grandfather's Torah teachings and the obligation not to stand idly by. She systematically dismantles his armor, exposing herself to lethal radiation, and when Chernobyl emerges from his suit, she embraces him rather than killing him, asking him to pretend she is his daughter Yulia. Chernobyl shoves her away, weeping, and retreats into his damaged suit. Sam collapses from radiation poisoning. She is admitted to Thomas Jefferson University Hospital as a "Jane Doe" with radiation exposure exceeding ten Grays — a normally lethal dose — and spends two weeks in a coma while her regeneration fights to save her. On February 23rd, she awakens to learn that Chernobyl has turned himself in to authorities. Her grandfather confirms: she got to him.

docs.title: Themes
docs.text:
• Exorcism and inherited haunting — The arc's title answers Book 3's "Dybbuk." Chernobyl accused Belle of being possessed by Franklin's ghost; now Sam must determine whether she is possessed by Belle's ghost or acting from her own convictions. Her choice to embrace Chernobyl rather than kill him is the exorcism — a deliberate break from the cycle of inherited vengeance.
  • Compassion as weapon and weakness — Sam's defining moment is not defeating Chernobyl through violence but through vulnerability: she asks him to pretend she is his daughter. This radical compassion achieves what Belle's brute force could not — Chernobyl turns himself in. Yet it nearly kills Sam in the process, interrogating whether mercy and survival can coexist.
  • Institutional betrayal and justified disobedience — The NSRA protects Chernobyl, frames Miasma, attempts to confiscate evidence, and sends agents to intimidate a fourteen-year-old. The Kingdom impersonates federal agents. Sam's investigation reveals that the line between government agency and criminal organization is thinner than anyone acknowledged, justifying the Auditors' extralegal existence.
  • The body as battleground — Sam's evolving shark biology is both her greatest asset and her most intimate horror. Growing teeth from her knuckles saves her life during torture, but the uncontrollable tooth growth during her hospital stay and the skin she sheds by the pound make her body an alien landscape she cannot fully control.
  • Found family versus blood family — Jordan's story crystallizes the arc's family theme: their biological mother is abusive and neglectful, but the Auditors provide genuine love and acceptance. Sam's biological family remains loving but increasingly distant from her reality. The Auditors, formed from necessity, become a family forged in shared danger and mutual sacrifice.

docs.title: Threads Planted
docs.text:
• "Porcelain?" in red ink — Belle's final cryptic note in the Chernobyl notebook is the single word "Porcelain?" underlined in red. Its meaning is unexplained. Porcelain is the alias of Chezki Espinosa, leader of Red Calf, per the wiki index (Ch. 48).
  • The Auditors as a team — Sam, Jordan, Spindle, and Miasma formally adopt the name "The Auditors" as their independent investigative unit, operating outside both the DVD and NSRA structures. Their future trajectory, membership, and legal standing are unresolved (Ch. 54).
  • Miasma framed for murder — Miasma is accused of killing four NSRA security guards at Hatboro-Horsham. The Auditors believe the Kingdom framed him, but he remains a fugitive. His location and legal situation are unresolved (Chs. 56–57).
  • Mr. ESP's rotating powers — Mr. ESP possesses psychic abilities that change daily, making him unpredictable. His power on the day of the tunnel battle is "remote listening." The full scope and mechanics of this power rotation are unexplored (Chs. 57, 59–60).
  • Kingdom recruiting Chernobyl — The Kingdom of Keys attempted to recruit Chernobyl with money and documents for his family. Chernobyl violently rejected the offer, but the Kingdom's knowledge of his family creates leverage for future attempts (Chs. 59–60).
  • Chernobyl's surrender and fate — Chernobyl turns himself in to authorities on or around February 23, 2024, after his encounter with Sam. Whether he faces trial, is sent to Daedalus or Aurora Springs, or what happens to his family in Ukraine is entirely unresolved (Ch. 62).
  • Sam's radiation exposure aftermath — Sam survived over 10 Grays of ionizing radiation through her regeneration. The long-term effects on her body, powers, and health are unknown. During her coma she shed approximately five pounds of skin. Her regeneration may have been permanently altered (Ch. 62).
  • Sam's PERKS threat level at 6/10 — The updated assessment classifies Sam as "a superhuman of national interest" with tooth growth at G5 and regeneration at G6 (25-35x under severe injury). This classification attracts government scrutiny (SS.1).
  • Rachel Small's bipolar concern — During Sam's coma, her mother Rachel reveals concerns about possible inherited bipolar disorder, suggesting a family mental health history that has not been previously disclosed (Ch. 62).
  • Aaron McKinley's blue flame — Aaron develops a new toxic blue fire that produces poisonous fumes, damaging his own lungs in the process. He leaves Philadelphia on the vet's advice, positioning himself for a potential return as a more dangerous threat (AMK.2).
  • Aaron knows Sam's civilian identity — Aaron identified Sam at Tacony Academy Charter High School and committed her face to memory. This knowledge persists even after his departure from Philadelphia (AMK.1).
  • Daisy Zhen's facility origin — Daisy was kidnapped in Los Angeles at age eight and subjected to four years of experimentation by unnamed parties in a facility with barbed wire and locked doors. The identity of the organization, its location, and what they did to other children remain unknown (DZ.1).
  • Mrs. Z as Daisy's transfer agent — Mrs. Z is the Kingdom operative who physically delivered Daisy from the facility to the Philly Phreaks in Philadelphia, connecting her weather-manipulation powers to the trafficking operation (DZ.1).
  • Agent Torres as sympathetic insider — Torres evolves from an antagonistic NSRA agent to a whistleblower who provides classified information off-record and expresses doubts about his own agency. His future relationship with the Auditors and his professional fate are unresolved (Chs. 58–59).
  • NSRA contesting Belle's will — The NSRA is legally contesting Diane Williams's bequest of investigative materials to Sam. Laura Zhang is fighting the challenge, promising to tie them up in paperwork (Ch. 58).
  • Sam's dreaming of Diane — During her coma, Sam experiences visions of Diane Williams in a flower-filled place. Whether these are meaningful visions or fever dreams is left ambiguous (Ch. 62).
  • "A nice man in a suit" — Mrs. Westwood mentions that a "nice man in a suit" told her about "freaks coming and going" at the Music Hall, suggesting either Kingdom or NSRA surveillance directed someone to Jordan's mother to use her as a weapon against the Auditors (Ch. 54).
  • The Tacony Music Hall's legal status — The Auditors cannot find the building's legal owner. Jordan has approximately $13,000 in savings. The question of whether they can legally secure their headquarters remains open (Ch. 59).

docs.title: Threads Progressed
docs.text:
• Sam's evolving shark biology — Sam's powers advance dramatically. She discovers tooth growth from her knuckles and wrists during torture (Ch. 52), and her regeneration is measured at 25-35x under severe injury (SS.1). Teeth grow passively from internal organs. Her body's "bite response" to penetrating trauma adds passive defenses. The PERKS reclassifies her tooth growth from a subcategory of "Shark-Like Biology" to a standalone G5 ability. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 14.
  • Sam's accelerating regeneration — Now confirmed to scale proportionally with injury severity: 4x baseline for minor injuries up to 25-35x for severe injuries. She survives over 10 Grays of radiation — a dose that has killed stronger superhumans. During her coma, her body sheds skin at an alarming rate. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 14; quantified in Book 3, Ch. 34.
  • Chernobyl's government energy deal — The recording Sam made in Book 3 becomes the catalyst for the entire arc. She plays it for Miasma (Ch. 48) and Councilman Davis (Ch. 49), uses it to form the Auditors, and it drives the investigation into the NSRA. Planted in Book 3, Ch. 44.
  • The Kingdom of Keys — The Kingdom expands its operations: Mr. Polygraph dispatches Aaron to kill Sam, the organization impersonates NSRA agents, frames Miasma for murder, attempts to recruit Chernobyl, and monitors the Auditors through surveillance devices and Mr. ESP's powers. New operatives identified: Mr. ESP (rotating psychic powers). Planted in Book 1, Ch. 12.
  • Sam's compromised civilian identity — Aaron identifies Sam at her school (AMK.1) and uses this knowledge to ambush her. The Kingdom also knows where the Auditors operate from a listening device and Mrs. Westwood's information. Sam's civilian identity is now compromised to multiple threat vectors simultaneously. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 13.
  • Jordan's neglectful home life — Escalates to its breaking point. Jordan's mother tracks them to the Music Hall, verbally abuses them, reveals their birth name "Avery," mocks their gender identity, and calls the police. Jordan permanently severs ties, with Mrs. Westwood declaring them "not her child anymore." Jordan reveals they gained their powers after being accidentally locked in a car trunk. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 11.
  • The dybbuk cycle — Chernobyl accused Belle of being haunted by Franklin's ghost in Book 3. Sam now carries Belle's unfinished investigation, her detective equipment, and her letter. The arc asks whether Sam is continuing the dybbuk cycle or breaking it. Her choice to embrace rather than kill Chernobyl suggests an exorcism — a break from inherited vengeance. Planted in Book 3, Ch. 44.
  • Deathgirl's trajectory — Daisy participates in torturing Sam alongside Aaron (Chs. 51–52), showing her continued weaponization. Her origin interlude (DZ.1) reveals her as a victim of kidnapping and systematic experimentation, complicating any simple villain reading. The Phreaks abandon Aaron after the failed attack (AMK.2), suggesting fractures in their alliance. Planted in Book 3, Chs. 32–33.
  • Spindle's integration — Connor has a new costume, trains with Playback, is a provisional Young Defenders member, and is dating Jordan. He co-founds the Auditors and fights in the subway tunnel battle. His transformation from Philly Phreaks defector to hero is well underway. Planted in Book 3, Chs. 33–34, 39.
  • Belle's detective bequest — The training and mentorship Belle provided in Book 3 pays off directly: Sam inherits the physical equipment, files, and investigative legacy. The bequest drives the entire arc's plot. Set up in Book 3 throughout; executed in Ch. 46.
  • Sam's blood-tracking technique — Evolves from a simple combat trick into a sophisticated sensory mapping system. In the tunnel battle, Sam smears her blood across walls and floors to create a three-dimensional blood-sense map of her surroundings, coordinating her team's movements in total darkness (Ch. 60). Planted in Book 2, Ch. 26.
  • Mudslide's Kingdom career — Mudslide appears as a full Kingdom operative in the subway tunnel ambush, trapping the Auditors in liquefied concrete. He retreats to help injured Mr. ESP rather than press the attack when Chernobyl arrives (Chs. 59–60). Planted in Book 1, Ch. 13.
  • The Wolfcave / vigilante identity — The Tacony Music Hall evolves from Jordan's personal hideout into the Auditors' formal headquarters, now equipped with Faraday cage, surveillance countermeasures, and government surplus equipment from Councilman Davis. Planted in Book 2, Ch. 20.
  • Kingdom shell companies — Jordan's Book 3 research into Orion Holdings, Cerulean Dynamics, and Lockhart & Greene continues as the Auditors discover additional patterns linking shell companies to both the NSRA and the Kingdom, suggesting possible institutional overlap (Ch. 55). Planted in Book 3, Ch. 41.
  • Chernobyl's white blood — Sam's blood sense detects Chernobyl's "white-hot" blood signature in the subway tunnels, confirming the unusual physiology she first observed in Book 3 (Chs. 59–61). Planted in Book 3, Ch. 45.

docs.title: Threads Resolved
docs.text:
• Chernobyl as an active threat — Illya Myronovych Fedorov, who killed Professor Franklin and Liberty Belle, turns himself in to authorities after Sam's encounter with him in the subway tunnels. The immediate threat he posed to Philadelphia is neutralized, though his legal fate remains open. Planted in Book 1, Ch. 3 (Professor Franklin's killer identified in Book 3, Ch. 37); resolved in Ch. 62.
  • Sam's growing bloodlust — Sam's internal struggle with her appetite for violence reaches its thematic resolution when she chooses compassion over killing. Given the opportunity to destroy Chernobyl with her teeth, she embraces him instead. The "evil voice" from Book 2 is answered by a conscious moral choice. Planted in Book 2, Ch. 21; resolved in Ch. 61.
  • Aaron McKinley and the Coyotes — Aaron's arc as a local threat to Sam reaches its climax and resolution: he ambushes and tortures her but is mauled during her escape, abandoned by the Phreaks, and forced to leave Philadelphia with damaged lungs and a toxic new power. The Coyotes are confirmed dead as a gang; Aaron operates solo. Planted in Book 2, Chs. 20–21; resolved in AMK.2.
  • The Philly Phreaks as a faction — The remnant Phreaks (Pumice, Chrysalis, Deathgirl) ally with Aaron to attack Sam but abandon him afterward. Chrysalis tells Aaron he is "not worth the bullet." The Phreaks as a coherent group are effectively dissolved, with members scattering. Planted in Book 3, Chs. 32–33; resolved in AMK.2.
