docs.title: Book 5: Mayfly
docs.text: A powerless girl wages her own war on crime while a recovering hero discovers that the people she left behind refused to stay behind.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Act 1 Book Number 5 Title Mayfly Chapters 69–85 Interludes MM.1, IF.3, BM.1, MM.2 Timeline Late March–Early June 2024 (Passover through end of school year) POV Samantha "Sam" Small (Chs. 69–85); Kate Smith / Miss Mayfly (MM.1, MM.2); Illya Fedorov / Chernobyl (IF.3); Blake Matthews / Mr. Tyrannosaur (BM.1) Preceded By Intermission 4.5: Amnion Followed By Book 6

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Sam returns to active patrolling after months of hospitalization and recovery from radiation poisoning, operating out of the newly renovated Tacony Music Hall with Jordan. Their first night back, they encounter two members of the Tacony Titans — Sundial and Bubble — breaking up a drunken brawl in Wissinoming Park, establishing the existence of a parallel hero team operating in the Northeast. Sam adopts the "Big Bad Wolf" persona, complete with a wolf mask and cloak, and the pair rebrand themselves as "the Auditors" with a new operational philosophy of stealth over force. She celebrates Passover with her family and Jamila, briefly reflecting on the forbidden maternal grandfather and her newly discovered Hispanic heritage, before settling into an uneasy routine of patrols, school, and recovery that leaves her barely passing her classes by the end of the year.

When the Young Defenders respond to a villain incident involving Ricochet, Sam defies orders to observe from the sidelines and witnesses the Tacony Titans in full action — Sundial, Moonshot, Bubble, and Compass coordinating alongside the Defenders. Sam's blood sense detects that Ricochet's blood is "orange and carbonated," the first indication of the Jump and Fly drug crisis that will dominate the arc. After being told to stand down, Sam channels her frustration into community first aid, walking through neighborhoods and treating minor injuries with skills learned from Gossamer. At the Young Defenders' headquarters, Crossroads briefs Sam on two forms of power drugs: Jump (temporary green pills granting three hours of powers) and Fly (permanent injectable transformation with psychoactive side effects). Shortly after, Derek Taylor — a confrontational member of Sam's support group who secretly knows her identity — reveals that his friend Elias Franklin took Fly and transformed into a chimeric creature called Chimera. Sam and Derek confront Elias at an Independence Blue Cross office he is trashing; Elias provides the first physical description of a Fly distributor (bald, white, electrical powers) before escaping through a seventh-story window in deer form.

The Auditors expand to include Derek (as "Fenrir") and Spindle, and they launch a methodical investigation into the drug trade. Jordan identifies the mid-level dealer Squeal (Steven Praznik, sonic scream powers), and the team plans a sting at the Dobson Mills warehouse. Sam visits the Tacony Titans' garage headquarters and proposes a formal alliance, integrating the Titans into the operation. The sting is disrupted when Miss Mayfly — a masked non-powered vigilante Sam does not yet recognize — detonates stink bombs and smoke grenades inside the warehouse, blowing the surveillance. In the ensuing chaos, Squeal escapes and Sparkplug's enforcer nearly kills Jordan before Sam intervenes. Sam discovers that Miss Mayfly is Kate Smith, her childhood best friend, who has been secretly operating as a vigilante with a support team of their mutual school friends: Tasha Reynolds (Wasp, comms), Lilly Rodriguez (Moth, medical/chemical), Marcus Johnson (Mite, drones/engineering), and Jenna Nguyen (Ant, programming/surveillance). Sam grounds Kate from field operations and restricts Team Mayfly to reconnaissance and tech support, then convenes a tri-team meeting at the Music Hall to plan the takedown of Sparkplug.

The combined teams execute a multi-phase infiltration of Sparkplug's penthouse at the Dorchester high-rise. Jordan pickpockets and clones a key fob, Derek uses his enhanced scent to locate the unit, and the full alliance breaches while the Tacony Titans — with Sandman riding the werewolf Fenrir — handle the lobby and exits. Sam subdues Sparkplug with a Ketamine/Xylazine injector glove and he is turned over to authorities. During interrogation, Sparkplug reveals his connection to "Rogue Wave," an organization manufacturing and distributing Jump and Fly. In the aftermath, Kate steals a dose of Jump from the sting evidence, takes it, and confronts Sam at their childhood basketball court with temporary metal-skin powers. The fight exposes deep fractures: Kate accuses Sam of abandoning their friendship after gaining powers, of class betrayal for attending a charter school, and of hypocritically gatekeeping heroism while opposing the drugs that could equalize powerless people. Sam's teeth and claws shatter against Kate's metal exterior. Both collapse from exhaustion, reaching a fragile truce — Kate promises to stop vigilantism, but crosses her fingers behind her back.

docs.title: Locations
docs.text:
• Tacony Music Hall — The Auditors' renovated headquarters; now features functional electricity, security locks, a makeshift medical clinic, a Faraday cage room (wire mesh for ESP protection), TV, and mismatched furniture; serves as the tri-team meeting site (Chs. 70, 72, 77–78, 83)
  • Wissinoming Park — Site of the Auditors' first encounter with Sundial and Bubble during a drunken brawl (Ch. 70)
  • Small Family Home (rebuilt) — The Smalls' newly renovated house after earthquake damage; site of Passover Seder (Ch. 71)
  • Tacony and Mayfair neighborhoods — Patrol routes for the Auditors; setting for community first aid scenes (Chs. 70, 73)
  • Young Defenders Headquarters — Locker room briefings and the Jump/Fly intelligence drop (Chs. 74, 85)
  • Independence Blue Cross Office — Where Elias/Chimera rampages in revenge for denied healthcare claims; site of the Sam/Derek fight with Chimera (Chs. 75–76)
  • Dobson Mills Warehouse, East Falls — Returning location from Book 4; site of the Squeal sting operation that Miss Mayfly disrupts (Chs. 79, 81)
  • Tacony Titans Garage HQ — The Titans' nondescript garage headquarters with corkboard investigation wall, gadgets, and workbenches (Ch. 80)
  • The Dorchester — Upscale high-rise building where Sparkplug operates from penthouse unit 3028; metal studs embedded in walls to enhance his electrical attacks (Ch. 84)
  • Kingdom of Keys HQ, South Philadelphia — Disguised as an accounting firm; features a reception desk, fish tank, and luxurious break room with a chandelier (BM.1)
  • Federal Courthouse — Site of Chernobyl's arraignment; marble and wood courtroom with lead smocks for spectators near Illya (IF.3)
  • Mayfair Basketball Court — Sam and Kate's childhood hangout; site of their climactic confrontation after Kate takes Jump (Ch. 85)

docs.title: Themes
docs.text:
• Power inequality and the ethics of gatekeeping — Kate's argument that Sam hypocritically opposes power drugs while telling unpowered people they cannot be heroes strikes at the heart of the arc. The question of who "deserves" powers and whether the superhero community is a meritocracy built on accident rather than merit is never fully answered.
  • The cost of being left behind — Multiple characters (Kate, Team Mayfly, Jordan, the Titans) built their own structures of resistance and purpose while Sam was hospitalized. The arc examines what happens to the people surrounding a hero when the hero is absent — they do not wait; they adapt, sometimes dangerously.
  • Coalition and trust — The arc tracks the formation of a three-team alliance (Auditors, Titans, Mayfly) and the frictions inherent in multi-group coordination: differing philosophies, overlapping jurisdictions, communication failures, and the fundamental challenge of trusting strangers with your life.
  • Recovery as identity crisis — Sam's return from near-death forces her to reconcile her weakened body with her reputation. She adopts a new persona (Big Bad Wolf), discovers her friends built lives without her, and faces the dissonance between who she was before Chernobyl and who she is becoming.
  • Class and economic inequality — Kate's accusations about charter school attendance, college anxiety, and economic disparity between their families expose the material conditions underlying superheroism. The power-drug debate mirrors real debates about access and equity.

docs.title: Threads Planted
docs.text:
• Rogue Wave organization — Sparkplug names the organization behind Jump and Fly distribution during interrogation; their ideology (anarcho-capitalist, "leveling the playing field") and membership remain largely unknown (Ch. 85)
  • Elias Franklin / Chimera at large — Derek's Fly-transformed friend escapes by shifting to deer form; his whereabouts are unknown; he described Sparkplug before fleeing; Derek's long-term mission to track him is established (Chs. 75–76)
  • Kate crosses her fingers — Kate promises Sam she will stop vigilantism but crosses her fingers behind her back, signaling she has no intention of quitting (Ch. 85)
  • Kate's class resentment — Kate's philosophical challenge about power inequality and who gets to be a hero is never answered by Sam; the argument exposes fractures that a single conversation cannot repair (Ch. 85)
  • Chernobyl's trial timeline — Trial is set for August 15, 2024, creating a ticking clock; the necessity defense strategy and whether Sam will be called as a witness are unresolved (IF.3)
  • Mrs. Xenograft's interest in Fly — At the Kingdom leadership meeting, Mrs. Xenograft displays scientific curiosity about Fly's mechanism, planting seeds for later Kingdom drug development (BM.1)

docs.title: Threads Progressed
docs.text:
• Sam's recovery and return to action (planted Book 4, Ch. 62) — Sam returns to patrols but remains physically weakened from radiation; her muscles ache, she tires quickly, and she is not at peak performance; her regeneration works better under acute stress, creating a cruel incentive toward danger.
  • The Auditors team formation (planted Book 4, Ch. 54) — The team expands from Sam-Jordan-Spindle to include Derek/Fenrir, and ultimately coordinates with two allied teams (Titans and Mayfly); the name "Auditors" is formally adopted on their first patrol.
  • Sam's mental health and medication (planted Intermission 4.5, Ch. 64) — Sam continues on lithium; the emotional flatness it produces contrasts with the aliveness she feels during combat; the tension between medication stability and danger-seeking behavior persists throughout.
  • Sam and Jamila's relationship strain (planted Intermission 4.5, Ch. 65) — Jamila participates in Passover, gives Sam a wind pendant for her birthday, but increasing distance is evident; the Hajj conversation in Chapter 85 signals physical separation ahead.
  • Sam's maternal grandfather mystery (planted Intermission 4.5, Ch. 65) — Sam "briefly reflects" on the forbidden figure during Passover but gains no new information; the secrecy persists.
  • Sam's Hispanic heritage (planted Intermission 4.5, Ch. 65) — Acknowledged through Passover context and Camilla's continued presence but not deeply explored this arc.
  • Kingdom of Keys operations (planted Book 2) — The Kingdom discusses the Fly crisis at their South Philadelphia HQ; Mr. Polygraph was personally attacked by Fly users; Mrs. Zenith orders intelligence gathering, signaling the Kingdom's entry into the drug conflict.
  • Miasma's false charges (planted Book 4, Ch. 56) — Sam continues following Joshua Pleasants' legal case; she previously asked the Young Defenders for help and has video evidence; no resolution this arc.
  • The Tacony Music Hall as base (planted Intermission 4.5, Ch. 67) — The base receives significant upgrades (electricity, Faraday cage, medical clinic) and hosts the tri-team meeting; it transitions from a temporary hideout to a semi-permanent headquarters.
  • Jordan's surveillance tendencies (planted Book 4, Ch. 55) — Jordan investigates Derek's home without authorization, finding cages in the basement; Sam expresses discomfort, continuing the ethical tension about Jordan doing morally gray work so Sam does not have to.
  • Sam's community first aid practice (planted Intermission 4.5) — After being dismissed from the Ricochet fight, Sam walks home treating neighbors' minor injuries, applying Gossamer's training and developing a softer approach to heroism that foreshadows the later mentorship program.
  • The Dobson Mills warehouse (planted Book 4) — The warehouse from Sam's first major battle returns as the site of the Squeal sting; Sam and Jordan reflect on previous trauma associated with the location; evidence of Mudslide's earlier presence remains.
  • Sam's "Big Bad Wolf" persona (planted this arc, building on Bloodhound identity from Book 1) — Sam adopts a wolf mask and cloak, rebranding from Bloodhound to a more intimidating identity; her old gear is repurposed by Derek as "Fenrir."

docs.title: Book 6: Sideshow
docs.text: A city on trial tears itself apart while a teenage hero discovers that the courtroom can be as brutal as any battlefield.

docs.text: Field Value Act 2 Book Number 6 Title Sideshow Chapters 86–100 Interludes LTN.1, BA.1, IF.4, DH.1 Timeline June–September 2024 (Summer before sophomore year through first day of school) POV Samantha "Sam" Small (Chs. 86–100); Dr. Lena Trinh-Norwood / Mrs. Xenograft (LTN.1); Bianca Agnelli / Fury Forge (BA.1); Illya Fedorov / Chernobyl (IF.4); Devonte Harris / Playback (DH.1) Preceded By Book 5: Mayfly Followed By Book 7

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
The arc opens with the end of Sam's freshman year and a summer defined by legal preparation and personal upheaval. Federal prosecutor Anne-Marie Gibson recruits Sam as the key witness in the upcoming trial of Illya Fedorov (Chernobyl), revealing that the NSRA deliberately obstructed contact between them for three months. Sam undergoes weeks of deposition preparation and a grueling mock cross-examination with defense attorney Jerry Caldwell, who probes her testimony for weaknesses. Meanwhile, Jamila breaks up with Sam, revealing that she may be asexual and cannot reconcile herself with the violence inherent in superhero life. Sam spirals into depression, showing up at Fury Forge's apartment at 1 AM and throwing herself into increasingly reckless late-night sparring sessions with Rampart.

The Jump crisis escalates dramatically when Sam and Rampart discover a man undergoing a horrific mutagenic transformation in Love Park, his body erupting with uncontrollable metal shrapnel. Pumice of the Philly Phreaks attacks during the rescue, and Sam fights him in a brutal hand-to-hand engagement using her knuckle-spike teeth. Multiplex arrives with reinforcements and Pumice retreats on the back of Chimera, confirming the Phreaks' connection to the tainted Jump distribution. A full DVD briefing reveals four Jump incidents in eighteen hours across Philadelphia, and Sam shares intelligence linking the Phreaks to the drug crisis. Councilman Jamal Davis hints at Young Defenders graduations to the senior team, triggering a fraught meeting where Gale announces her desire to step back from active duty and Puppeteer discloses a psychological condition (NPD) that may disqualify her from advancement — leaving Crossroads as the only viable candidate for promotion.

The trial of Illya Fedorov begins August 15 and consumes nine days. Sam testifies on Day 4, presenting her video footage of Liberty Belle's final confrontation with Chernobyl. Under cross-examination, Caldwell introduces a handwritten note allegedly penned by Liberty Belle inviting Fedorov to the refinery where she died, which Sam reluctantly acknowledges resembles Belle's handwriting. A news article format covers Days 4 through 9, tracking the prosecution's case through forensic pathology, Professor Franklin's murder, hazardous materials charges, and the bombshell testimony of NSRA Agent Evelyn Shaw, who is exposed as having maintained a quid pro quo arrangement with Fedorov — providing him resources in exchange for his radioactive abilities powering the Eastern Seaboard. The revelation ignites massive protests outside the courthouse.

The Philly Phreaks exploit the chaos, launching a terrorist attack on the courthouse crowd by force-feeding protesters tainted Jump, causing mass mutagenic transformations. The DVD and Young Defenders split over whether to follow NSRA orders to suppress the protests, with Sam and Playback refusing while Rampart and Gossamer side with Multiplex. Sam undergoes a rage-fueled physical transformation — denticle plates, bone blades from her elbows and shins, and recurved barbs lining her throat — and fights Deathgirl in a savage one-on-one battle on the courthouse steps while Playback and Spindle, aided by Gale returning in disguise as a biker-helmeted stranger, take on Pumice. Inside the courthouse, Crossroads warns Illya that if Deathgirl copies his nuclear powers without a containment suit, she will kill everyone in Philadelphia; Illya stays put, praying in Hebrew for the safety of his daughter and Sam. Sam pins and restrains Deathgirl, who dissolves into sobbing and incoherent apologies. The heroes capture three of four Phreaks — Deathgirl, Pumice, and Chrysalis — while Chimera escapes. In the aftermath, Sam helps with search and rescue using her blood sense, receives a phone call from her father expressing pride in her for the first time, and attends a debriefing where the Phreaks are sent to Daedalus under chemical sedation.

The arc concludes with multi-week recovery, during which the jury finds Fedorov guilty of manslaughter rather than murder. Crossroads graduates to the Delaware Valley Defenders, Rampart is named leader of the Young Defenders, and Captain Plasma relocates from Los Angeles to bolster the DVD's depleted ranks. Puppeteer and Playback resign — Puppeteer to train as a paramedic, Playback to return to college, though Sam senses something deeper and bitter behind Playback's decision. Jamila moves away from Philadelphia entirely. Sam is invited to speak at a congressional legislative session. The Young Defenders are reduced to five members: Rampart, Gossamer, Blink, Spindle, and Bloodhound. Sam begins sophomore year on September 5, 2024, walking through metal detectors and past riot police into a city holding its breath.

docs.title: Themes
docs.text:
• The theater of justice — The trial is as much spectacle as legal proceeding. Sam is simultaneously witness, symbol, and pawn; the courtroom demands performance while claiming to seek truth. The arc interrogates whether institutional justice can address harms that institutions themselves enabled.
  • Attrition and isolation — Sam loses Jamila (breakup), Gale (withdrawal), Puppeteer (resignation), Playback (resignation), and Crossroads (promotion) across a single arc. Each departure is rational and individual; collectively, they hollow out Sam's support network and push her toward the independent team she will eventually build.
  • Complicity and moral compromise — The NSRA-Fedorov arrangement reveals that the system protecting the public was also protecting a murderer for its own benefit. The DVD's willingness to suppress protesters at NSRA orders mirrors the same institutional rot. Sam and Playback's refusal is principled but costly.
  • The body as battleground — Sam's physical transformation during the courthouse fight (denticles, bone blades, throat barbs) represents rage made literal. Her injuries throughout the arc — shrapnel wounds, broken ribs, a thigh puncture that takes weeks to close — accumulate alongside emotional wounds that her regeneration cannot heal.
  • Sympathy for the condemned — Sam's testimony is complicated by her genuine compassion for Illya, a man she hugged on a frozen battlefield. The manslaughter verdict (not murder) reflects the moral ambiguity she introduced to the narrative. Deathgirl's sobbing collapse after the fight briefly humanizes another "monster." The arc refuses to let its villains be simple.

docs.title: Threads Planted
docs.text:
• Liberty Belle's handwritten note — Caldwell introduces a note allegedly written by Belle inviting Fedorov to meet at the PES Refinery on the night of their final confrontation; Sam acknowledges the handwriting appears authentic; forensic confirmation is not established; if genuine, it reframes Belle's death as something she deliberately initiated (Ch. 95)
  • NSRA institutional corruption — Agent Shaw's testimony exposes the NSRA's arrangement with Fedorov, sparking public outrage and protests; whistleblowers begin coming forward; congressional hearings and potential legislation are foreshadowed (Chs. 96, 100)
  • Sam's congressional invitation — Sam is invited to speak at a legislative session in mid-October about superhuman regulation, establishing her as a political voice at the national level (Ch. 100)
  • Sam's evolving transformation — Under extreme stress, Sam manifests denticle plates, inch-long bone blades from her elbows and shins, and recurved barbs lining her throat, representing a new and more extreme expression of her powers beyond the usual knuckle-spike teeth (Ch. 97)
  • Deathgirl's emotional breakdown — Deathgirl dissolves into incoherent apologies and cries for her parents after being pinned, suggesting trauma and possible manipulation rather than pure villainy; her power to copy others' abilities makes her one of the most dangerous characters in the setting (Chs. 97–98)
  • Deathgirl near Chernobyl — Crossroads warns Illya that if Deathgirl copies his nuclear powers without a containment suit, she will cause a nuclear meltdown killing everyone in Philadelphia; the two must never come into contact (IF.4)
  • Illya Fedorov's daughter — During the courthouse crisis, Illya prays for the protection of "our daughter," the first mention of him having a child; her identity, location, and caretaker are unknown (IF.4)
  • Crossroads and Illya's bond — Crossroads and Illya share a moment of mutual understanding in the besieged courtroom, with Crossroads flipping a coin as a gesture of trust; this establishes an unusual hero-defendant connection (IF.4)
  • Gale's disguised return — Jamila returns to fight Pumice disguised in biker leather and a motorcycle helmet, using her wind manipulation while pretending to be an unknown "telekinetic"; she leaves before Sam can identify her, contradicting her stated departure from heroism (DH.1)
  • Playback's hidden bitterness — Playback's resignation is framed as a return to college, but Sam detects something deeper and unresolved; his whispered "Don't trust these bitches" to Sam before leaving suggests disillusionment with the DVD institutional structure (Ch. 100)
  • Chemical sedation of the Phreaks — The captured Phreaks are chemically sedated and sent to Daedalus; Sam expresses discomfort with this, raising ethical questions about the treatment of metahuman prisoners (Ch. 99)
  • Chimera still at large — Three of four Phreaks are captured, but Chimera (Elias Franklin) escapes; a news broadcast mentions a manhunt; he continues distributing tainted Jump (Chs. 99–100)
  • Philadelphia crime wave and reinforcements — The Jump crisis stretches Philadelphia's heroes to the breaking point; reinforcements arrive from New York, Wilmington, Baltimore, and D.C.; Captain Plasma relocates from Los Angeles; the city is described as a "powder keg" (Chs. 94, 100)
  • Kate Green as reporter — A reporter named Kate Green covers the courthouse aftermath; this may be Kate Smith operating under a new identity after being declared officially dead (Ch. 99)
  • Young Defenders reduced to five — With Crossroads promoted, Gale departed, and Puppeteer and Playback resigned, the YD is reduced to Rampart (leader), Gossamer, Blink, Spindle, and Bloodhound, with new recruitment a stated priority (Ch. 100)
  • Puppeteer's NPD and institutional discrimination — Puppeteer's self-disclosure that her NPD diagnosis may bar her from advancement raises questions about ableism within superhero institutional structures; the disqualification is presented as systemic rather than individual (Ch. 92)
  • DVD leadership's recruitment discussion — Fury Forge-led discussion identifies Crossroads, Rampart, Puppeteer, Playback, and others as graduation candidates; Multiplex proposes graduating Martinez and Reynolds with Harris, Li, and Chen close behind, establishing the pipeline for future team composition (BA.1)
  • Mrs. Xenograft's Kingdom recruitment — The December 2021 flashback shows how Mrs. Zenith used coercion and unlimited research funding to recruit Dr. Trinh-Norwood, who later creates chimeric creatures and will eventually develop Hypeman (reverse-engineered Jump) and Vysera (a power suppressant); her acceptance marks the Kingdom's acquisition of a critical scientific asset (LTN.1)

docs.title: Threads Progressed
docs.text:
• Chernobyl's trial (planted IF.3, Book 5) — The trial proceeds across nine days; Sam testifies; the prosecution presents forensic evidence, expert witnesses, and video footage; Fedorov testifies in his own defense; the NSRA arrangement is exposed; the jury convicts on manslaughter rather than murder; sentencing is scheduled for September 28.
  • Sam and Jamila's relationship strain (planted Intermission 4.5, Ch. 65) — The strain culminates in Jamila breaking up with Sam, citing possible asexuality and inability to handle the violence of hero life; Sam spirals into depression; by the arc's end Jamila has moved away entirely.
  • The Jump/Fly drug crisis (planted Book 5, Ch. 73) — The crisis escalates dramatically with mutagenic Jump variants causing horrific transformations; four incidents occur in eighteen hours; the Phreaks weaponize tainted Jump as a tool of terrorism at the courthouse; the DEA emergency-schedules Jump as Schedule I.
  • The Philly Phreaks (planted Book 3) — The Phreaks escalate from street-level crime to domestic terrorism, force-feeding tainted Jump to courthouse protesters; Deathgirl, Pumice, and Chrysalis are captured and sent to Daedalus; Chimera remains at large.
  • Sam's mental health and medication (planted Intermission 4.5, Ch. 64) — Sam continues on lithium for bipolar disorder; Dr. Desai checks on her medication response; therapy sessions reveal her grief processing style (bottling followed by explosive release); she describes wanting to "rip skin off" in anger, suggesting the medication's emotional flattening effect is in tension with her raw emotional states.
  • Sam's recovery patterns and physical limits (planted Book 4) — Sam takes injuries from Pumice (shrapnel, broken ribs, deep lacerations) that require weeks to heal even with regeneration; the thigh wound from Deathgirl takes weeks to close and is prone to infection; Dr. Abara notes Sam's tendency to reject and spit out sutures.
  • Kingdom of Keys operations (planted Book 2) — The LTN.1 flashback shows the Kingdom's 2021 recruitment of a genetic engineer, expanding their scientific capabilities; this connects to later Kingdom drug development and the broader power struggle.
  • Young Defenders team composition (planted Book 1) — The team undergoes dramatic restructuring: Gale steps back, Puppeteer and Playback resign, Crossroads graduates to the DVD, Rampart takes leadership, and the roster is reduced to five members with recruitment urgently needed.
  • Elias Franklin / Chimera at large (planted Book 5, Ch. 75) — Chimera reappears carrying Pumice during the Love Park escape, confirming his alliance with the Phreaks; he remains free after the courthouse attack while three other Phreaks are captured.
  • Sam's unacknowledged role in Chernobyl's capture (planted Intermission 4.5) — Sam's testimony makes her the public face of the prosecution's case, but her personal role in Illya's surrender remains largely unacknowledged; her conflicted feelings about condemning a man she showed compassion to complicate her testimony.
  • Spindle's Phreaks connections (planted Book 5, Ch. 77) — Spindle corroborates intelligence on Deathgirl's instability during the DVD briefing, drawing on his prior relationship with the Phreaks; his knowledge continues to serve as a bridge between the heroes and their understanding of the Phreaks' internal dynamics.
  • Gale's departure from heroism (planted this arc, Ch. 88/92) — Jamila announces her desire to leave the team and breaks up with Sam, but her disguised return to fight Pumice at the courthouse contradicts her stated withdrawal, suggesting she cannot fully abandon the life.
  • Ben Small's stance on Sam's heroism (planted Book 1) — Ben calls Sam after the courthouse battle and expresses pride in her superhero work for the first time, marking a significant shift in the family dynamic around Sam's double life.

docs.title: Threads Resolved
docs.text:
• Sam's role as trial witness — The question of whether Sam would testify, planted during Chernobyl's arraignment in IF.3 (Book 5), is resolved: she takes the stand on Day 4, presents her video evidence, survives cross-examination, and is excused (planted IF.3, resolved Chs. 94–95)
  • Chernobyl trial verdict — The trial concludes with a guilty verdict on manslaughter (not murder), theft, property damage, and illegal hazardous materials generation; the necessity/self-defense argument partially succeeds; sentencing hearing set for September 28 (planted IF.3, resolved Ch. 100)
  • Sam and Jamila's romantic relationship — The relationship ends with Jamila breaking up with Sam; by arc's end Jamila has moved away from Philadelphia (planted Intermission 4.5, resolved Chs. 88, 100)
  • Young Defenders graduation question — The question of who would graduate to the senior team is resolved: Crossroads is the sole promotion; Rampart takes YD leadership; Puppeteer and Playback resign voluntarily (planted Ch. 91, resolved Ch. 100)
  • NSRA-Fedorov secret arrangement — The long-suspected government complicity with Chernobyl is publicly exposed through Agent Shaw's testimony, confirming the NSRA provided Fedorov resources in exchange for his radioactive abilities powering the Eastern Seaboard (planted Book 4, resolved Ch. 96)

docs.title: Book 7: Security
docs.text: A city's demand for safety becomes the weapon used against it, as a teenage hero discovers that the most dangerous threats wear badges and wrap themselves in flags.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Act 2 Book Number 7 Title Security Chapters 101–118 Interludes EF.1, MR.1, RJ.1, IF.5 Timeline September 5 – October 31, 2024 POV Samantha "Sam" Small (Chs. 101–118); Mayor Watkins (EF.1, press release format); Maya Richardson / Mrs. Zenith (MR.1); Richard Johnson / Patriot (RJ.1); Illya Fedorov / Chernobyl (IF.5) Preceded By Book 6: Sideshow Followed By Book 8

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Book 7 opens on Sam Small's first day of sophomore year at Tacony Charter Academy, where heightened post-Chernobyl security measures have transformed the school into a pressure cooker. Racist security guard Officer Ridley assaults a Black freshman named James over a hat violation; Sam intervenes with an Aikido throw, earning a week of detention and the silent respect of many students. Sam and Jordan Westwood investigate the connection between the school's security guards and local law enforcement, trailing Officer Ridley to Patty's Bar, a cop hangout where they discover Patriot and Egalitarian among the regulars. The encounter crystallizes the arc's central conflict: the institutional alliance between police, private security, and Pattinson's Pals operating under the banner of public safety.

Sam, Jordan, Derek Taylor, and Connor Spindle launch an anonymous whistleblower website exposing misconduct by the school's security guards, which goes viral and attracts both legal support and DDOS attacks. Sam continues mentoring Maggie O'Brien (Flashpoint), training her repulsion field abilities in an abandoned Tacony lot. The training session is interrupted by Zero, a power-negating member of Pattinson's Pals, who stalks and chases Sam and Maggie through the streets of Tacony with his followers. The pair escape to the Tacony Music Hall, Jordan's secret base, where they find Jordan, Spindle, and Tasha Reynolds already present. This crisis galvanizes the group into an organized resistance cell that will become the Auditors. Meanwhile, Sam's family gathers for Rosh Hashanah dinner, where Uncle Shelly drunkenly reveals that Pop-Pop Moe helped build the Daedalus Correctional Facility. During the Tashlich ceremony afterward, Abigail deduces that Sam is Bloodhound through investigative journalism and circumstantial evidence. Illya Fedorov is sentenced to fifty years at Aurora Springs Residential Facility.

The team spends weeks conducting surveillance on Patriot and his associates, gathering embarrassing and incriminating evidence through dumpster diving, directional microphone recordings, and Sam's blood-tracking abilities. Sam records Patriot discussing plans to push anti-superhuman legislation and create a private security empire. Jordan schedules the evidence dump to coincide with the homecoming dance, providing the team an alibi. The plan backfires spectacularly: Patriot, Egalitarian, and a squad of police officers storm the dance to arrest Jordan on cyberterrorism charges. Egalitarian deploys her vertigo-inducing power, incapacitating nearly everyone in the gymnasium except those with superpowers. Sam steps between Patriot and Jordan; Patriot beats her savagely in front of the entire school. A "Spartacus" moment erupts as students and teachers, led by Mr. Weston and Mike Giannopoulos, stagger to their feet and form a human shield. Jordan escapes. Sam is hospitalized.

Sam returns to school battered but unbroken. The whistleblower website is taken down via legal injunction. Mike Giannopoulos invites Sam to an upcoming protest. At a full Delaware Valley Defenders meeting, Sam announces her congressional testimony, scheduled since August. She travels to Washington, D.C. with her parents and federal escorts, donning her Bloodhound costume to testify before a Senate oversight committee on superhuman regulation. She observes testimony from NSRA Director Margaret Huang, Special Agent Evelyn Shaw, Commissioner Faraday, a DEA agent, Mayor Watkins, DA Carla Alvarez, and Dr. Emily Nakamura. Sam's own testimony focuses on the personal cost of being a teenage hero, the systemic failures that enable abuse, and the need for independent oversight. After her return, Devonte Harris and Akilah Washington visit with intelligence on Project Titan, a classified military program that attempted to create enhanced soldiers, identifying Patriot as an original test subject and war criminal. They also provide physical evidence of Egalitarian's Fly drug use. Sam confronts Patriot at a protest at Dilworth Park, engaging him in a philosophical exchange about power and ideology before arranging a private meeting.

The arc culminates on Halloween night in an abandoned warehouse at Penn Treaty Park. Sam arrives prepared with tripwires, a light killswitch (operated remotely by Tasha), pig blood spray, pepper spray, and a gauntlet rigged with syringes. The fight is brutal and sustained: Patriot breaks Sam's wrist, dislocates her shoulder, and cracks her ribs, while Sam breaks his nose twice via headbutts and bites his collarbone with her teeth. When Sam's helmet shatters, Patriot recognizes her as Sam Small. Sam injects him with what she claims is a slow-acting poison (actually saline) and negotiates a mutual non-aggression pact: Patriot stands down, leaves Jordan alone, and confines his operations to South Philadelphia, or Sam releases the evidence and Egalitarian's Fly use is exposed to DA Alvarez. Patriot reluctantly agrees. Sam leaves a first aid kit as a final gesture of mercy.

docs.title: Locations
docs.text:
• Tacony Charter Academy High School — Sam's school; site of Officer Ridley's assault, the whistleblower QR code campaign, heightened security, and the homecoming dance attack (Chs. 101–106, 111–113)
  • Patty's Bar — Police hangout where all school security guards are regulars; Sam and Jordan infiltrate it and encounter Patriot and Egalitarian (Chs. 103–104)
  • Tacony Music Hall — Jordan's secret base of operations; converted dressing rooms serve as sleeping quarters, storage, and workspace; becomes the proto-Auditors' headquarters (Chs. 110–111, 116)
  • Pop-Pop Moe's House, Ventnor — Site of Rosh Hashanah dinner and Yom Kippur fast; the pier nearby is used for the Tashlich ceremony; Pop-Pop Moe's boat is docked here (Chs. 108, 110)
  • Abandoned Lot, Tacony — Training ground where Sam mentors Maggie in martial arts and power use; where Zero and his followers first confront them (Chs. 106, 109)
  • DVD Headquarters — Site of the post-homecoming meeting where Sam announces her congressional testimony (Ch. 113)
  • Dilworth Park, Philadelphia — Site of the protest where Sam confronts Patriot in costume and they arrange the warehouse meeting (Ch. 117)
  • Penn Treaty Park Warehouse — Abandoned warehouse on the Delaware River where Sam and Patriot fight on Halloween night; Sam arrives early to prepare the environment with traps (Ch. 118)
  • U.S. Capitol, Washington, D.C. — Site of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee hearing on superhuman regulation where Sam testifies as Bloodhound (Chs. 114–115)
  • Aurora Springs Residential Facility — Federal containment facility for non-criminal dangerous superhumans where Illya Fedorov begins his fifty-year sentence; features radiation-absorbing walls, specialized medical staff, and visiting areas with lead glass (Chs. 107, IF.5)
  • Kingdom of Keys Safehouse, 12th and Pine — Where Maya Richardson and Mr. Mudslide lay low after being pursued; site of the debriefing call with Mr. Nothing (MR.1)

docs.title: Themes
docs.text:
• Security as oppression — The title operates on multiple levels: the "security" measures at Tacony Charter suppress students rather than protect them; Pattinson's Pals use "public safety" to justify harassment and intimidation; Patriot's private security ambitions are a vehicle for power rather than protection. The arc asks who is made secure and at whose expense.
  • Civilian activism vs. institutional power — Sam and her friends fight back not with superpowers but with journalism, whistleblower websites, legal action, and congressional testimony. The arc positions information and truth-telling as more threatening to the power structure than any physical confrontation.
  • The making and unmaking of heroes — Patriot's interlude reveals a man forged by abuse and institutional violence into a weapon who calls himself a hero. Sam's trajectory mirrors his in some respects (physical suffering, determination, a desperate need to prove worth), making the warehouse confrontation a battle between two people shaped by the same forces who chose different paths.
  • Family legacies and complicity — Pop-Pop Moe's Daedalus involvement, Great-Grandpa Elijah's HUAC investigation, and Patriot's father's abuse all demonstrate how family history shapes present action. Sam inherits both the guilt of complicity and the imperative to resist.
  • Bluffing as survival — Sam's victories in Book 7 come not through superior force but through deception: the saline "poison," the bluff about knowing DA Alvarez, the reverse-pickpocketing of Patriot. The arc frames cunning and psychological warfare as legitimate tools for the outmatched.

docs.title: Threads Planted
docs.text:
• Project Titan — Devonte and Akilah reveal the existence of a classified military program that attempted to create enhanced soldiers through artificial power induction; Patriot is identified as an original test subject; the full scope, other participants, and who authorized it remain unknown (Ch. 116)
  • Egalitarian's Fly use — Physical evidence (dried blood containing Fly traces) proves Egalitarian is using the superpower-granting drug; this information is used as leverage against Patriot but has not been publicly released; its wider implications for Pattinson's Pals' credibility are unexplored (Chs. 116–118)
  • The Auditors' formation — The proto-team assembles at the Tacony Music Hall: Sam, Jordan, Tasha, Spindle, Derek, and Maggie; Jordan names them "Auditors" and establishes the team dynamic; this represents the nucleus of the independent team that Sam has been gravitating toward since Book 6 (Chs. 110–111)
  • Zero's power-negation at range — Zero can suppress metahuman abilities from a distance without physical contact, unlike Mr. Nothing who requires touch; his range, limitations, identity, and origin are unexplored; he remains active with Pattinson's Pals (Chs. 109–110, 117)
  • Sam's identity exposed to Patriot — When her helmet breaks during the warehouse fight, Patriot recognizes Sam Small as Bloodhound; this knowledge is contained only by the threat of mutual assured destruction (the truce), not by secrecy (Ch. 118)
  • Abigail knows Sam's identity — Sam's journalist cousin Abigail independently deduces that Sam is Bloodhound through investigative reasoning and promises to keep the secret; her knowledge as a journalist creates both protection and risk (Ch. 108)
  • The truce's fragility — The Halloween truce rests on multiple bluffs: the "poison" is saline, Sam does not actually know DA Alvarez, and the evidence leverage is mutual rather than one-sided; Sam herself acknowledges that future conflicts with Patriot are inevitable (Ch. 118)
  • Pattinson's Pals expanding nationally — Patriot mentions that "San Diego is already interested in our services" during a recorded conversation, indicating the organization is seeking to expand beyond Philadelphia into a national private security operation (Ch. 111)
  • Rogue Wave mind control — Maya Richardson encounters people who become violent automatons when the phrase "Rogue Wave" is mentioned, suggesting a form of targeted psychic compulsion; the Kingdom is investigating but has no answers; the mechanism, scope, and controller are unknown (MR.1)
  • Kingdom's NSRA infiltration plan — Maya proposes that the Kingdom offer its services to the NSRA as independent security consultants to gain an inside track on government operations; this has not yet been executed (MR.1)
  • Pop-Pop Moe's Daedalus involvement — Moe's construction firm helped build the Daedalus Correctional Facility; he describes it as a different time and a mistake he's spent years trying to atone for; this creates a family legacy of complicity that parallels the institutional corruption Sam fights (Ch. 108)
  • Sam's activation event details — Pop-Pop Moe reveals that Sam's powers first manifested on his boat, where she became a "snarling thing of the water" and tore the engine apart; Sam has no memory of this (Ch. 108)
  • Whistleblower website legal battle — The site is taken down via injunction on cyberterrorism grounds; Jordan has backups and legal support but the site's future is uncertain; the active warrant for Jordan's arrest remains unresolved (Chs. 112–113)
  • Jordan's active warrant — Patriot secures a warrant for Jordan's arrest on charges of cybercrimes, domestic terrorism, unlicensed use of superpowers, and petty theft; the warrant is technically still active even after Patriot's public disgrace (Chs. 112–113)
  • Illya's engineering work — Fedorov designs portable radiation shielding at Aurora Springs, potentially creating technology with applications beyond his own containment (IF.5)
  • Egalitarian's power mechanics — Egalitarian's vertigo power only affects non-powered individuals; powered individuals (Sam, Jordan) remain standing while everyone else is incapacitated; this suggests her ability targets a biological mechanism absent in metahumans (Ch. 112)
  • Congressional hearing outcomes — Sam testifies alongside NSRA, PPD, DEA, and city officials; the hearing may lead to new legislation on superhuman oversight, but the political maneuvering suggests outcomes are uncertain; Sam advocates for independent oversight boards (Chs. 114–115)
  • Evelyn Shaw's confident smirk — During her congressional testimony, Shaw develops an unexplained smug satisfaction despite being scapegoated, suggesting she knows something that will protect or advantage her (Ch. 114)

docs.title: Threads Progressed
docs.text:
• Sam's congressional testimony (planted Book 6, Ch. 100) — The invitation from Book 6 is fulfilled as Sam travels to D.C. and testifies before the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee about her experiences, the NSRA's failures, and the need for superhuman oversight reform (Chs. 113–115)
  • Illya Fedorov's sentencing and incarceration (planted Book 6, Ch. 100) — Fedorov is sentenced to fifty years at Aurora Springs (not Daedalus); in his interlude, he settles into the facility, reconnects with his wife Olena and daughter Yulia, and finds purpose in engineering work (Chs. 107, IF.5)
  • Illya's family (planted Book 6, IF.4) — The thread of Illya's daughter is expanded: she is named Yulia, lives in Kyiv with her mother Olena; they visit Illya through lead glass at Aurora Springs; the family is reconnecting (IF.5)
  • Pattinson's Pals and Patriot as threats (planted Book 6, Ch. 100) — The Pals escalate from background menace to the arc's primary antagonist, conducting "neighborhood safety patrols," deputizing civilians, and ultimately storming a school dance with police support; Sam confronts and neutralizes Patriot through intelligence and combat (Chs. 101–118)
  • Sam's whistleblower activism (planted this arc, Ch. 105) — The website goes viral, attracts legal support and DDOS attacks, triggers Patriot's homecoming assault, is taken down via legal injunction, and becomes the catalyst for the full confrontation with Patriot's organization (Chs. 105–113)
  • Jump/Fly drug crisis (planted Book 5, Ch. 73) — The crisis continues in the background; DEA Agent Turner testifies about its national scope; Egalitarian is revealed to be a Fly user herself, making the anti-superhuman crusaders hypocrites; Sam describes Fly blood as "fizzy" and "fluorescent orange" during her testimony (Chs. 114–116)
  • Kingdom of Keys operations (planted Book 2) — Maya Richardson investigates Rogue Wave while managing Kingdom business; she encounters the mind-control trigger; Mr. Nothing and Mr. Mudslide are active; Mr. Camcorder provides CCTV surveillance; the Kingdom is positioning itself to exploit the chaos of the Chernobyl trial aftermath (MR.1)
  • Young Defenders team status (planted Book 6, Ch. 100) — The reduced team (Rampart, Gossamer, Blink, Spindle, Bloodhound) continues operating under Rampart's cautious leadership; Rampart orders stand-down regarding the Pals; Sam grows increasingly frustrated with the institutional approach, pushing her further toward the independent Auditors (Chs. 106, 109, 113)
  • Playback and Puppeteer post-resignation (planted Book 6, Ch. 100) — Devonte and Akilah resurface working as private investigators at Chambers & Woo Investigations; Devonte is also in college; they deliver critical intelligence on Project Titan and Egalitarian, maintaining their connection to Sam's operations outside official channels (Ch. 116)
  • Ben Small and Rachel Small's awareness (planted Book 1) — Sam's parents are increasingly aware of and engaged with her superhero life; they accompany her to the congressional hearing; Rachel intervenes to reduce school security after the homecoming beating; Ben continues expressing pride (Chs. 113–115)
  • NSRA institutional corruption (planted Book 6, Ch. 96) — The NSRA's failures are further exposed during the congressional hearing; Director Huang deflects; Shaw is scapegoated; the hearing aims to establish new oversight mechanisms; Sam advocates for independent review (Chs. 114–115)
  • Daedalus Correctional Facility legacy (planted Book 1) — Pop-Pop Moe's personal connection to Daedalus is revealed, adding a family dimension to the facility's thematic role; Dr. Nakamura testifies about Daedalus and Aurora Springs at the hearing (Chs. 108, 115)
  • Sam's identity management (planted Book 1) — Sam's secret identity becomes increasingly precarious: Abigail deduces it independently (Ch. 108), Patriot discovers it when her helmet breaks (Ch. 118), and the congressional testimony requires federal agents to have her file on record (Ch. 114)
  • Sam's physical and psychological limits (planted Book 4) — Sam sustains severe injuries from Patriot at homecoming (broken nose, cracked ribs, throat damage) and again at the warehouse (broken wrist, dislocated shoulder, cracked ribs); her old Deathgirl wound resurfaces without regeneration in Zero's field; she experiences a panic attack during congressional testimony (Chs. 109, 112, 115, 118)

docs.title: Threads Resolved
docs.text:
• Fedorov's sentencing — The question of where Illya would be incarcerated, raised during Book 6's verdict, is resolved: he receives fifty years at Aurora Springs Residential Facility, not Daedalus (planted Book 6 Ch. 100, resolved Ch. 107)
  • Pattinson's Pals' direct confrontation — The simmering tension between Sam and Patriot's organization, building since Book 6, reaches resolution through two direct confrontations and a negotiated truce: Patriot stands down, leaves Jordan alone, and confines operations to South Philly in exchange for Sam withholding evidence (planted Book 6 Ch. 100, resolved Chs. 117–118)
  • Sam's congressional testimony — The invitation from Book 6 is fulfilled: Sam travels to D.C. and testifies as Bloodhound before the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee (planted Book 6 Ch. 100, resolved Chs. 114–115)
  • Playback's hidden bitterness — Devonte's whispered "Don't trust these bitches" and his resignation in Book 6 are contextualized: he and Akilah have been conducting independent intelligence work at Chambers & Woo Investigations, uncovering Project Titan and Egalitarian's Fly use, exactly the kind of work the official institutions failed to do (planted Book 6 Ch. 100, resolved Ch. 116)

docs.title: Book 8: Big
docs.text: When the villain wins the election and the dinosaur is just the distraction, a teenage hero learns that the biggest threats hide behind legitimacy and that looking past the obvious is the only way to survive.

docs.title: Infobox
docs.text: Field Value Act 2 Book Number 8 Title Big Chapters 119–135 Interludes DT.1, RS.1, DH.2, MR.2, MR.3 Timeline November 1 – early December 2024 POV Samantha "Sam" Small (Chs. 119–135); Finn Taylor (DT.1); Rachel Small (RS.1); Devonte Harris / Playback (DH.2); Maya Richardson / Mrs. Zenith (MR.2, MR.3) Preceded By Book 7: Security Followed By Book 9: Sheol

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Book 8 opens the morning after Sam's Halloween warehouse fight with Patriot, as she learns that Maya Richardson is projected to win the City Council special election. Sam and Jordan scramble to expose Richardson's connections to the Kingdom of Keys before the vote, meeting with Republican candidate Richard Duvall (who dismisses their concerns while revealing his own racist politics) and Councilman Jamal Davis (who advises patience and intelligence-gathering). Despite frantic investigation — dumpster diving, undercover interviews, stakeouts, and a rally for third-party candidate Frank Martinez — they find no actionable evidence, and Richardson wins with 81% of the vote. Sam and Jordan process the defeat on the Music Hall roof, watching the sunrise as President Rodriguez wins re-election nationally.

The arc shifts into espionage as Sam infiltrates the Crescent, a Kingdom-connected nightclub, disguised as "Jessie" with a fake ID and costume from Gossamer. She plants surveillance devices and discovers a map of marked locations across Philadelphia, but her cover is blown first by Nina (a barback who recognizes her from the viral Patriot video) and then by Mudslide, who confronts her in the back hallways. Sam escapes after being shot in the arm, fleeing to the Music Hall where Tasha treats the wound. The team analyzes the marked locations — City Hall, high schools, the Philadelphia Zoo — and debates their significance. Meanwhile, Sam mentors Maggie in combat training and patrols with Rampart, encountering a new Jump gang in Olney where a dealer named Jackie has a violent, involuntary reaction when "Rogue Wave" is mentioned, confirming the mind-control trigger discovered in Book 7's MR.1 interlude.

The crisis escalates when Devonte (Playback) arrives at the Music Hall severely injured after investigating Kingdom operations at the docks near 5245 Bleigh Avenue. His interlude (DH.2) reveals he overheard plans for "Operation Ivory" — the Kingdom's scheme to steal elephants and rhinos for illegal ivory trade, with a mysterious "second phase" involving Maya Richardson's political cover. Devonte is hospitalized after being shot during his escape, rescued by Akilah (Marionette). The Delaware Valley Defenders formally forbid the younger heroes from involvement, but Sam spends the following weeks conducting solo surveillance at the zoo, building a relationship with a zookeeper named Mack while watching for signs of the Kingdom's move.

The arc's parallel interludes deepen the world: DT.1 flashes back to 2002 Boston, where Derek Taylor's father Finn — an Irish mobster — witnesses the emergence of superheroes (Windstorm in Chicago) and decides to leave the criminal life, fleeing to Philadelphia with young Derek after a confrontation with Russian mobsters is interrupted by a masked vigilante. RS.1 shows Rachel and Ben Small hosting Pop-Pop Moe for dinner, exploring the parents' perspective on Sam's dangerous life — Rachel's fear that Sam might turn out like her estranged father, and the family's attempt to find normalcy in their reconstructed home. MR.2 reveals the Kingdom's leadership meeting at Nobu Fifty Seven in Manhattan, where Maya reports to Mr. A alongside Ophelia (Blue Velvet), Wesley (ESP), Jacob (Keys), and Nolan (Yellowjacket); they discuss Rogue Wave, the Windy City Wreckers in Chicago, and decide to implement a psychological pressure campaign to burn out young superheroes. Ophelia references "Project Hollywood," a child-soldier program connected to Deathgirl that is "out in Afghanistan, uncontactable." MR.3 is the arc's darkest chapter: Richard Duvall confronts Maya at City Hall with evidence of her Kingdom connections, attempting blackmail; Maya pickpockets his recording device, takes him for a drive to Checkers, reveals her true power is pressure control (not weather manipulation), and kills him by creating a vacuum inside the car, staging his death as natural causes.

The climax arrives when the Kingdom launches Operation Ivory at the Philadelphia Zoo on a snowy December day. Mr. T-Rex transforms into dinosaur form, destroying the rhino enclosure and creating mass chaos while Kingdom operatives take hostages. Sam, already on-site from her surveillance, suits up and fights back alongside Mack. Multiplex saves her from a surprise attacker, and the full Delaware Valley Defenders arrive — Captain Plasma hitting T-Rex at supersonic speed, Fury Forge and Crossroads on an ATV. But Sam realizes the dinosaur rampage is a distraction: the real heist is happening in the Reptile House, where Mr. Nothing, Mrs. Heartbeat, and Mudslide are stealing specific poison dart frogs (wild-caught specimens whose toxins are critical for drug synthesis). Sam confronts them alone in the Reptile House. Mr. Nothing neutralizes her powers through touch and threatens to shoot her knee, but Maggie arrives unexpectedly — wearing Sam's stolen bulletproof vest — and hits Nothing with a power-propelled baseball. In the ensuing fight, Maggie is shot multiple times (the vest saves her life but leaves her with broken ribs and internal bruising), while Sam engages in a brutal hand-to-hand battle with Mr. Nothing. Sam overpowers and zip-ties Nothing; Maggie fights Mudslide with her repulsion fields until Sam intervenes to prevent lethal force. Both villains are captured, but Mrs. Heartbeat escapes with some of the frogs, and Mr. T-Rex flees with followers. The arc ends with a partial victory: two Kingdom leaders captured, but the real prize — the poison dart frogs — is partially lost.

docs.text: # File Summary 119 119.txt Sam recovers from the Patriot fight; learns Maya Richardson is projected to win the City Council election; her family reacts to Richardson's Kingdom connections; Sam and Maggie go on Maggie's first official patrol through Mayfair as Bloodhound and Flashpoint. 120 120.txt Sam and Jordan visit Richard Duvall's campaign office to share evidence of Richardson's Kingdom ties; Duvall dismisses their concerns and reveals racist views about crime in Kensington and Tioga; Sam meets with Councilman Davis at DVD HQ, who advises patience and democratic process. 121 121.txt Two days of frantic investigation into Richardson — dumpster diving (finding a suspicious cash deposit receipt), an undercover interview attempt, attending a Frank Martinez rally; on election night, Richardson wins 81-20 and President Rodriguez is re-elected; Sam and Jordan smoke weed on the Music Hall roof and watch the sunrise. DT.1 dt-1.txt INTERLUDE — Finn Taylor POV, 2002 Boston. Irish mobster Finn witnesses the emergence of superheroes (Windstorm in Chicago) and grows fearful for his son Derek's future. After a secret meeting with younger mobsters is interrupted by Russian gangsters and a masked vigilante, Finn decides to leave the criminal life. He flees Boston for Philadelphia with four-year-old Derek, spotting another costumed figure swinging between buildings as they cross the bridge. 122 122.txt Sam plans and executes an undercover mission at the Crescent nightclub disguised as "Jessie" (with fake ID from Jordan and costume from Gossamer). She plants surveillance devices, talks to bartender Pete, and discovers a map of marked locations across Philadelphia in an office. Nina, a barback from a civilian superhuman support group, recognizes her despite the disguise. 123 123.txt Continuation of the Crescent mission. Sam debates the plan with the Young Defenders; Captain Plasma shares a cautionary tale. At the club, Nina nearly blows Sam's cover from the viral Patriot video. Sam creates a fight distraction to access employee-only areas, discovers the marked-locations map, hides in a filing cabinet to overhear Kingdom operatives discussing accelerated schedules, plants a bug, and runs into Mudslide. 124 124.txt Sam escapes from Mudslide at the Crescent after being threatened with a gun; uses mace and a taser; is shot in the arm during the escape. Flees to the Music Hall where Tasha treats the gunshot wound. The team analyzes the map's marked locations (City Hall, schools, the zoo). They decide to inform the DVDs. Tasha walks Sam home; Sam breaks down crying when she sees her mother. 125 125.txt Sam briefs the Delaware Valley Defenders on the Crescent intel and her encounter with Mudslide. Crossroads informs her that Connor is meeting potential foster parents. Sam calls Akilah, who reveals she's considering the name "Marionette" instead of Puppeteer. Training session with Maggie and Tasha focusing on judo techniques and power integration. 126 126.txt Sam and Tasha investigate the Philadelphia Zoo (one of the map's marked locations). They notice increased police presence and explore exhibits. They unexpectedly encounter Dr. Trinh-Norwood (Mrs. Xenograft), who engages in a civil conversation about animals, reveals she's wearing a wire, and warns Sam to be careful. Sam and Tasha discuss the moral complexities of heroism and villainy on the way home. RS.1 rs-1.txt INTERLUDE — Rachel Small POV. Rachel and Ben host Pop-Pop Moe for dinner in their reconstructed home. Rachel expresses fears about Sam's dangerous activities, Moe shares a bridge-building metaphor for parenting, and they discuss the zoo incident with "evil dolphins." Rachel reveals her deeper fear that Sam might turn out like her estranged father. Sam and Maggie arrive home, providing momentary peace. 127 127.txt Sam trains with Rampart at DVDs' HQ (bone conditioning with gravel). They go on an unofficial patrol in Olney with Captain Plasma's tacit approval ("bring me a hoagie"). They encounter a new Jump gang; Sam's blood sense detects an injured person (Mike); they find gang members on 9th Street, with one (Slims) unknowingly teleporting from Jump use. Sam challenges the gang. 128 128.txt Sam and Rampart fight the gang at the construction site. Jackie (Phillies Cap) has a violent, involuntary reaction when "Rogue Wave" is mentioned — confirming the mind-control trigger from MR.1. They report to Captain Plasma and Fury Forge, who express concern about possible mind control. The Young Defenders are grounded pending reevaluation. 129 129.txt CPS agent Anna Katz visits the Tacony Music Hall to assess Connor's living situation for his adoption process. The group scrambles to hide evidence of superhero activities. Ms. Katz reveals she already knows about their affiliations, conducts private interviews with Jordan and Sam, and assures them Connor's support system won't be disrupted. Jordan reveals they lied about being emancipated to hide their homelessness. 130 130.txt Snowy Saturday at the Music Hall. The team discusses Richardson's election (District 7, covering Mayfair and Tacony), her past as superheroine Stormrise, and the kingdom's potential surveillance via Mr. ESP. Sam recounts the Xenograft encounter and the Rogue Wave mind-control trigger. Connor shares good news about his adoption. Sam's blood sense alerts her to someone at the door — Devonte (Playback), severely injured. DH.2 dh-2.txt INTERLUDE — Devonte (Playback) POV. He investigates Kingdom operations at the docks near 5245 Bleigh Ave in a snowstorm, using his sound-stealing powers to evade guards. Overhears plans for "Operation Ivory" (elephant and rhino trafficking to Johannesburg), a "second phase," and Richardson's involvement as political cover. Mrs. Heartbeat arrives to check progress. Mr. Nothing catches Devonte; Akilah (Marionette) rescues him; he's shot during the escape and they flee to the Music Hall, where Devonte loses consciousness. 131 131.txt The group treats Devonte's injuries; he's taken to the hospital by ambulance. At the hospital, Devonte shares intelligence about Operation Ivory and the Kingdom's plan to steal rhinos. The DVDs forbid younger heroes from getting involved. Fury Forge promises to help Devonte with hearing implants (his sound-stealing powers have damaged his hearing). Sam stays to comfort Devonte in a heart-to-heart conversation. MR.2 mr-2.txt INTERLUDE — Maya Richardson (Zenith) POV. Kingdom leadership meets at Nobu Fifty Seven in Manhattan: Maya, Ophelia (Blue Velvet), Wesley (ESP), Jacob (Keys), Nolan (Yellowjacket), with Mr. A joining virtually. Maya reports on her City Council position. They discuss Rogue Wave, the Windy City Wreckers in Chicago, and Ophelia's mention of "Project Hollywood" (a child-soldier program connected to Deathgirl, currently "in Afghanistan, uncontactable"). They decide to implement psychological pressure to burn out young superheroes. Maya and Nolan discuss utilitarian justifications for removing child heroes from the equation. 132 132.txt Sam spends a week preparing for Operation Ivory: meets Bulldozer at a coffee shop, gets a new winterized costume fitted by Amelia and Jordan (noting a missing bulletproof vest), meets Razor and Sandman in an alley, briefs the Auditors (who oppose her going alone), meets Sundial and Manta Rei at a UPenn café. Nobody explicitly agrees to help watch the zoo. Thanksgiving dinner at the Golden Panda Buffet with friends. MR.3 mr-3.txt INTERLUDE — Maya Richardson (Zenith) POV. Richard Duvall confronts Maya at City Hall with evidence of her Kingdom connections and attempts to blackmail her. Maya pickpockets his recording device during a hug, takes him for a drive to Checkers (charming the drive-through worker), reveals her true power is pressure control (not weather manipulation), and kills him by lowering the air pressure inside the car to create a vacuum. She stages his body at his house to look like natural causes and returns to City Hall. Mr. Nothing texts acknowledgment of the death. 133 133.txt After a week of solo surveillance at the zoo, Sam senses something different about a snowy December day. Mr. T-Rex appears in dinosaur form, destroying the rhino enclosure; Kingdom operatives take hostages; chaos erupts. Sam suits up and fights back alongside zookeeper Mack. An unseen attacker nearly takes her from behind, but Multiplex saves her. Captain Plasma arrives and hits T-Rex at supersonic speed. Fury Forge and Crossroads arrive on an ATV. The full DVDs finally arrive in force. 134 134.txt Sam realizes the main battle is a distraction and investigates the suspiciously empty Reptile House. She discovers Mr. Nothing, Mrs. Heartbeat, and Mudslide stealing specific poison dart frogs (wild-caught specimens; Mrs. Heartbeat sedates them while a captive zookeeper identifies which are wild-caught). Mr. Nothing catches Sam when her phone vibrates, neutralizes her powers, and threatens to shoot her knee. Maggie arrives unexpectedly, hitting Nothing with a power-propelled baseball. Mrs. Heartbeat escapes with frog containers; Mudslide traps Sam in liquefied floor. A gunshot ends the chapter. 135 135.txt Maggie is shot multiple times but protected by Sam's bulletproof vest (which she secretly took). Sam fights Mr. Nothing in brutal hand-to-hand combat — he stabs her shoulder with a switchblade, trying to reach exposed skin to negate her powers; she overpowers him with knuckle-teeth and zip-ties him. Maggie fights Mudslide despite broken ribs and internal injuries; Sam stops her from using lethal force with her repulsion fields. Both villains are subdued. Multiplex and Crossroads acknowledge Sam was right about the true heist. Mr. T-Rex escapes with followers. Mrs. Heartbeat escapes with some frogs. Partial victory as Arc 8 concludes.

docs.title: Themes
docs.text:
• Institutional impotence vs. individual action — Every institution Sam appeals to fails her: Duvall dismisses her evidence, Davis counsels patience, the DVDs forbid involvement, the democratic process elects a supervillain. The arc systematically strips away institutional support to force Sam into independent action, culminating in her solo zoo surveillance while the adults debate procedure.
  • The distraction and the real threat — The title "Big" operates on multiple levels: the big, obvious dinosaur rampaging through the zoo is literally a distraction from the real heist happening in the Reptile House. Richardson's public philanthropy distracts from her criminal empire. Duvall's racism distracts from the fact that he's actually right about Richardson. The arc teaches Sam (and the reader) to look past the spectacle to find the truth.
  • Parenthood as counterpoint — Three interludes explore parenthood: Finn Taylor leaves crime to protect young Derek (DT.1), Rachel Small grapples with her daughter's dangerous life (RS.1), and Maya Richardson justifies harming children through utilitarian calculus (MR.2). These parallel perspectives — protective father, terrified mother, calculating predator — frame the arc's central question of what adults owe to children.
  • The cost of mentorship — Maggie's arc across Book 8 moves from trainee to combat partner, climaxing with her secretly taking Sam's bulletproof vest and arriving at the Reptile House to save her mentor. The student protecting the teacher inverts the mentorship dynamic, but at a brutal physical cost — broken ribs, internal bleeding, gunshot impacts. The arc asks whether Sam's mentorship has empowered or endangered Maggie.
  • Legitimacy as weapon — Maya Richardson's election gives the Kingdom a foothold in legitimate government, allowing her to provide political cover for Operation Ivory and eliminate threats (Duvall) from within the system. The arc positions democratic legitimacy itself as a tool of criminal power, making the enemy harder to fight because they now wear the armor of public office.

docs.title: Threads Planted
docs.text:
• Operation Ivory and the poison dart frogs — The Kingdom's true objective was not rhinos or elephants but specific wild-caught poison dart frogs whose toxins are needed for drug synthesis; Mrs. Heartbeat escaped with some specimens; the full implications of what they plan to create are unknown (Chs. 133–135)
  • Project Hollywood — Ophelia references a child-soldier program that created Deathgirl, currently "out in Afghanistan, uncontactable"; this connects to the Kingdom's broader network and suggests a military or intelligence operation beyond their direct control (MR.2)
  • Kingdom's anti-youth-hero campaign — The leadership decides to implement a psychological pressure campaign to burn out young superheroes rather than fight them directly; the methods and targets are unspecified (MR.2)
  • Rogue Wave mind-control confirmation — Jackie's violent involuntary reaction to the phrase "Rogue Wave" in Philadelphia confirms the trigger first observed by Maya in MR.1, establishing it as a widespread phenomenon affecting street-level drug dealers; the mechanism remains unknown (Ch. 128)
  • Maya Richardson's true power revealed — Maya kills Duvall using pressure control (creating a vacuum inside a car), confirming her actual ability is barokinesis, not weather manipulation; she stages the death as natural causes; Mr. Nothing texts acknowledgment, suggesting institutional awareness within the Kingdom (MR.3)
  • Richard Duvall's murder — Duvall's death is staged as natural causes; he had compiled evidence of Richardson's Kingdom connections (including digital evidence in his emails); this evidence may still exist and could surface later (MR.3)
  • Derek Taylor's criminal heritage — Finn Taylor was a Boston Irish mobster who fled to Philadelphia in 2002; Derek's origin as the son of a criminal who chose to go straight adds depth to his character and may inform future plotlines (DT.1)
  • Maggie's bulletproof vest theft — Maggie secretly took Sam's vest from old costumes at the Music Hall, demonstrating both her initiative and her willingness to put herself in danger without telling Sam; this pattern of protective secrecy could escalate (Ch. 135)
  • Rachel Small's estranged father — Rachel reveals a deeper fear that Sam might turn out like her estranged father, implying a family history of violence or instability on Rachel's side that has not been explored (RS.1)
  • Connor Spindle's adoption — Connor is meeting with potential adoptive parents and undergoing CPS evaluation; his transition from the team's quasi-ward to someone with a formal family structure may change group dynamics (Chs. 125, 129)
  • Devonte's hearing damage — Devonte's sound-stealing powers have damaged his hearing; Fury Forge promises hearing implants, establishing a physical cost to his abilities (Ch. 131)
  • Dr. Trinh-Norwood's warning — Mrs. Xenograft warns Sam to "be careful" at the zoo while wearing a wire, suggesting she may be hedging her bets between loyalty to the Kingdom and some form of self-preservation or conscience (Ch. 126)
  • The Crescent surveillance devices — Sam planted bugs at the Kingdom nightclub; their continued operation and the intelligence they may yield remain unexplored (Chs. 122–124)

docs.title: Book 9: Sheol
docs.text: A stalker's fire burns through Philadelphia, and a teenage hero learns that the line between justice and cruelty is thinner than she thought.

docs.text: Field Value Act 2 Book Number 9 Title Sheol Chapters 136–148 Interludes LTN.2, VB.1, MM.3, RS.2 Timeline Early February – late February 2025 POV Samantha "Sam" Small (Chs. 136–148); Dr. Lena Trinh-Norwood / Mrs. Xenograft (LTN.2); Victor Blanc (VB.1); Kate Smith / Miss Mayfly medical report (MM.3); Rachel Small (RS.2) Preceded By Book 8: Big Followed By Book 10: Plume

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Book 9 opens weeks after the zoo heist, with Sam increasingly isolated as her friends advance toward conventional futures — Jordan accepts a full MIT scholarship, Connor's adoption proceeds, Maggie recovers from her zoo injuries. Two interludes bracket the transition: LTN.2 shows Dr. Trinh-Norwood (Mrs. Xenograft) presenting her new drug "Hypeman" (Compound J-237) to Mr. Antithesis at his sterile Manhattan office, revealing that it's derived from Jump chemistry, requires poison dart frog compounds for stability, uses cultured cells from Daisy Zhen, and is fatally incompatible with Jump when mixed. VB.1 introduces Victor Blanc — Sam's paternal grandfather, whose existence she is unaware of — in a 1960s childhood flashback at the Philadelphia Zoo and a school disciplinary meeting, establishing his pattern-oriented thinking, his WWII-veteran father's philosophy of finishing fights, and his capacity for violence.

The main arc ignites when a bright red fire with a metallic smell appears in a garbage can outside Sam's school, triggering an intense panic attack centered in her right hand — where Aaron McKinley previously removed her fingernails. Sam flees to the library, where Jordan finds her. Attempts to cope through normal activities fail; Sam sneaks out at 2 AM to patrol, and Jordan confronts her with the question she can't answer: who is she without the mask? The team conducts controlled fire experiments, discovering Sam's reactions are strongest in familiar territory near the school. During testing, they respond to a real fire at Amy's Coffee Shop — sprinkler system sabotaged, accelerants placed methodically — where Sam rescues an unconscious woman. Jordan maps the fires and discovers they form a circle around Tacony Charter Academy. The Auditors identify Aaron McKinley as the perpetrator, confirmed by Sundial's psychometric investigation at the burned coffee shop.

Aaron's psychological warfare escalates: he places a nail salon gift card with a hammer sticker in Sam's locker, delivered through a chain of unwitting intermediaries (from dealer to John to Melissa Marshall to Sam's locker), demonstrating his ability to reach her without direct contact. Community response splits between constructive and problematic: Parabellum and Egalitarian organize civilian defense walks (with Parabellum expressing concerning surveillance-state views), while Sandman maintains covert watch over Sam's neighborhood. The Delaware Valley Defenders are absent, occupied with a three-day hostage crisis in West Philadelphia. Sam teams up with Derek Taylor, using his enhanced werewolf sense of smell to track Aaron's scent from the gift card envelope through Tacony-Mayfair — discovering Aaron has been systematically surveilling her school entrances, the Music Hall, and her regular locations. They track him to a red Camry under the Tacony-Palmyra Bridge, where he's been living. The confrontation goes badly: Aaron attacks with evolved fire powers (red flames hotter than before, thick white smoke), injures both Sam and Derek, and escapes in a smokescreen. Aaron then breaks into the Music Hall, fights through Jordan (baseball bat) and Tasha (fire extinguisher), and during the chase demonstrates a new white fire ability that surprises even him. The crisis peaks when Sam's sleeve bursts into red flames during a school evacuation, injuring her and six other students.

Hospitalized with second-degree burns, Sam escapes Jefferson-Frankford Hospital at midnight, navigates a chaotic Philadelphia full of copycat arsons and civilian patrols, and discovers Kate Smith's house ablaze. The fire's circumstances are ambiguous — Aaron is the presumed perpetrator, but Kate is found with what appear to be self-inflicted wounds on her forearms. Sam rescues Kate through a second-story window, performs CPR when Kate's airway swells shut, and demands that Crossroads use his precognitive abilities to locate Aaron. After slapping Crossroads in frustration, he agrees and directs her to an abandoned house near Vogt Park. The final confrontation is the arc's brutal climax: Aaron has prepared the house (soaked walls, gasoline, Duraflame starters), and the fight progresses through multiple phases — verbal sparring, Sam crashing through the floor with an elbow drop, close-quarters combat with pipe and hammer, a gasoline explosion, fire suppressant foam blinding Aaron, and a final beating where Sam methodically dislocates his shoulder and damages his elbow. Aaron is arrested. Sam emerges severely injured — burns, smoke inhalation, broken bones, concussion.

The aftermath is explored in two interludes: MM.3 is Kate's hospital admission report at Jefferson-Frankford, documenting her injuries (respiratory distress, carbon monoxide exposure, forearm lacerations described as "consistent with sharp object injury," Lichtenberg scarring from a prior lightning strike). RS.2 follows Rachel Small's POV as the families — Smalls, Kate's father Liam, all the kids — take a healing trip to Kalahari water park in the Poconos. Sam confesses to Rachel that she permanently disabled Aaron's arm after he was already cornered, grappling with the satisfaction she felt in the moment and the guilt that followed. Rachel internally connects Sam's capacity for violence to her own estranged father Victor Blanc, wondering if the cycle of violence can be broken. The interlude ends with parents bonding over the impossibility of raising these particular children.
