docs.title: Themes
docs.text:
• The violence you choose — The arc's moral center is Sam's deliberate decision to disable Aaron's arm after he's already cornered. Her confession to Rachel in RS.2 — "It felt satisfying in this gross, animal way. Like what a cat probably feels when they catch a bird" — forces a reckoning with the pleasure of righteous violence. Rachel's internal connection to Victor Blanc frames this as potentially hereditary, questioning whether the capacity for cruelty is a family inheritance.
  • Identity beyond the mask — Jordan's 5 AM question ("Who are you without the mask?") haunts the arc. Sam's inability to answer drives her compulsive patrolling, her trash-collecting, her need to always be doing something heroic. The arc suggests that Sam has so thoroughly fused her identity with Bloodhound that she may not survive losing the role.
  • The stalker's pattern — Aaron's campaign mirrors domestic abuse: escalating from distant threats (fire pattern around the school) to personal violation (the locker gift card) to physical attack (setting her on fire) to attacking her loved ones (Kate's house). The fires forming a literal circle around Sam's school visualize the tightening noose of obsession.
  • Institutional absence — The DVDs are occupied with a three-day hostage situation, leaving Sam to face Aaron with minimal adult support. This vacuum allows both the crisis and the problematic community response (Parabellum's surveillance patrols) to escalate. The arc continues Book 8's theme of institutional impotence forcing individual action.
  • Ambiguity and self-harm — Kate's house fire introduces deliberate ambiguity: Aaron is presumed responsible, but Kate is found with forearm lacerations that the medical report describes as "consistent with sharp object injury." The MM.3 hospital report carefully avoids attributing the cuts, and Sam's emotional distance from Kate in RS.2 suggests she may suspect the truth.

docs.title: Threads Planted
docs.text:
• Hypeman (Compound J-237) — Xenograft's new drug derived from Jump chemistry using poison dart frog compounds and cultured Daisy Zhen cells; fatally incompatible with Jump when mixed; approved by Mr. Antithesis for development and distribution (LTN.2)
  • Mr. Antithesis's power — His ability negatively affects superpower-created things (Scylla can't enter his presence); the exact nature and scope of this anti-power effect are unexplored (LTN.2)
  • Victor Blanc — Sam's paternal grandfather, whose existence she is unaware of; Rachel's estranged father with a capacity for violence; 1960s Philadelphia childhood with a "finish fights" philosophy; Rachel internally fears Sam may have inherited his violent tendencies (VB.1, RS.2)
  • Aaron McKinley's evolved fire powers — His abilities have progressed from yellow to blue to red to white fire, with the white fire surprising even him; the mechanism of this evolution (natural progression, drug-related, or something else) is unexplained (Chs. 143–144)
  • Kate Smith's forearm lacerations — The MM.3 medical report notes "linear lacerations consistent with sharp object injury" on Kate's forearms, separate from fire burns; whether these are self-inflicted or caused by Aaron remains deliberately ambiguous (MM.3, Ch. 147)
  • Sam and Kate's emotional distance — After the fire, Sam and Kate are "distant" and "stilted" in ways Rachel notices but can't explain; Sam watches Kate out of the corner of her eye at Kalahari; the rift's cause is unresolved (RS.2)
  • Sam's capacity for excessive violence — She permanently disabled Aaron's arm after he was already cornered, feeling animal satisfaction in the moment; Rachel connects this to Victor Blanc; whether Sam can reconcile this with her self-image as a hero is the arc's lingering question (Ch. 148, RS.2)
  • Aaron's permanent disability — Surgery didn't go well; he'll never use his arm the same way; the consequences of this for future encounters or legal proceedings are unexplored (RS.2)
  • Scylla (Xenograft's chimeric pet) — A greyhound chimerized with a dead lobster, giving it an iridescent carapace shell; not created with powers (born normally, then modified); loyal to Xenograft; its capabilities and role are unexplored (LTN.2)
  • Hypeman-Jump fatal interaction — Mixing the two drugs is lethal; this could become a weapon or an accidental mass-casualty event; the interaction's mechanism is unexplained (LTN.2)
  • Daisy Zhen's cultured cells — Xenograft has cultured cells from Daisy Zhen (Deathgirl) to create Compound B for Hypeman; the source of these cells and their connection to Project Hollywood are unexplored (LTN.2)
  • Copycat arsons across Philadelphia — Aaron's fires inspire imitators with orange-green flames, making it difficult to track the real threat; the broader social phenomenon of copycat powered crime is noted (Chs. 146, RS.2)
  • Liam Smith's insurance battle — Payout frozen pending determination of whether the fire was a "supervillain attack" or "ordinary arson"; highlights the legal and financial infrastructure struggling to adapt to superhuman reality (RS.2)
  • Tacony Coyotes deceased — Aaron's former gang members are dead, supposedly in a drive-by shooting; whether Aaron killed them or someone else did is unresolved (Ch. 140)
  • Jordan's MIT departure looming — Full scholarship accepted; Jordan's eventual departure from Philadelphia will remove one of Sam's most critical support pillars (Ch. 136)

  • Crossroads as ally (planted Book 6) — Crossroads uses his precognitive "cheating" to extract information about Aaron at the hospital, then reluctantly uses his coin to locate Aaron after Sam slaps him; his power has practical limits (he gives Sam one hour before backup) (Chs. 145, 147–148)
  • Sundial and the Tacony Titans (planted Book 5) — Sundial uses psychometry to investigate the arson, providing critical evidence identifying Aaron; offers Sandman for neighborhood surveillance; Moonshot and Compass provide additional support (Ch. 140)
  • Pattinson's Pals in the community (planted Book 7) — Parabellum and Egalitarian organize civilian defense patrols in response to the fires, positioning themselves as community protectors while expressing concerning surveillance-state views that blur the line between safety and authoritarianism (Ch. 141)
  • Derek Taylor's dual nature (planted Book 2) — Derek's werewolf condition creates a hard time constraint (he must get home before transformation) during the bridge fight with Aaron; his enhanced daytime senses make him a critical tracker; his father's criminal background (revealed in DT.1) adds context to his willingness to operate outside the law (Ch. 143)
  • Sam's identity management (planted Book 1) — Sam's secret identity becomes further compromised when she's set on fire at school (connecting Bloodhound's fire-related trauma to civilian Sam's incident); she uses cover stories with her father and hospital staff (Chs. 144–146)

docs.title: Threads Resolved
docs.text:
• Aaron McKinley's fire campaign — Aaron's escalating psychological warfare and arson attacks are ended when Sam tracks him to the Vogt Park house and defeats him in brutal hand-to-hand combat; he is arrested and taken into custody with permanent arm damage (planted Chs. 136–144, resolved Ch. 148)
  • Connor Spindle's adoption — Connor is officially adopted during this arc, completing the CPS evaluation process established in Book 8 (planted Book 8 Ch. 129, resolved Ch. 136)

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Book 10 opens in the aftermath of Aaron McKinley's arrest, with Sam still bandaged from burns as she gives deposition testimony about the confrontation. During the deposition she overhears that Aaron's defense is being funded by mysterious "concerned citizens for due process" through the high-powered law firm Tremont & Fairfax — a thread the Auditors will pull for the rest of the arc. At home, Sam's relationship with Kate Smith is tense but functional: they attend physical therapy together, compete on an obstacle course, and maintain a cold détente in which neither acknowledges the growing evidence that Kate is the chemical-smoke vigilante Soot. Meanwhile, Jordan introduces a police scanner and the team investigates a scene of pepper-sprayed drug dealers — their first hint that someone else is waging a street-level war on the Jump trade.

The arc's first major crisis arrives when the Kingdom of Keys ambushes the prison transport of Mr. Nothing and Mudslide. Interlude RG.1 follows Captain Plasma's POV as the elaborate convoy — multiple decoys, anti-ESP shielding, aerial surveillance — is systematically dismantled by Kingdom operatives: Mr. Tyrannosaur emerges on the turnpike, Mrs. Fulcrum flips vehicles with her power, Mr. Yellowjacket conducts precision attacks with pressurized air bursts, and Mrs. Jellyjam ultimately suffocates Plasma with a gelatinous substance. Interlude BM.2 then follows Mr. Tyrannosaur and the rescue team to a Kingdom-owned steakhouse in Lancaster, revealing organizational dynamics through banter — Yellowjacket runs the Baltimore branch, Jellyjam shows leadership instincts, Mudslide explains the symbolism of his paper-bag mask, and the Kingdom's money-laundering infrastructure is laid bare. Back in Sam's timeline, she monitors the transport's collapse via scanner, then publicly confronts Maya Richardson at a school assembly about Richard Duvall's death and Kingdom connections, going viral on NetSphere.

The political landscape shifts dramatically when Councilman Ward and Richardson introduce the Superhuman Activity Regulation Act, banning vigilante activities for individuals under 18 regardless of LUMA status. The legislation passes 12-5, and the Young Defenders are formally dissolved — Gossamer leaves superhero work, Connor departs for civilian life, Rampart joins the DVDs officially, while Sam and Blink refuse to quit. The team reorganizes as "The Auditors," with Amelia and Lily formally joining, operating from the Tacony Music Hall. Interlude So.1 provides Soot's POV for the first time: a calculated vigilante who infiltrates dealer gatherings, trades stolen drugs for Jump, processes chemicals in an abandoned warehouse, and reveals a motivation centered on helping their father — before Bloodhound tracks them down and they surrender the Jump pills. The two vigilantes develop a tentative, wary alliance. Sam's 16th birthday party (Ch. 154) gives way to a midnight patrol where she and Maggie witness Bash using a mysterious autoinjector to dramatically enhance his powers during a gang fight — something different from Jump or Fly — before being arrested again for obstruction.

Interlude MR.4 reveals Richardson's two-front maneuvering: she recruits Patriot, Turbo Jett, Miasma, and Captain Devil to form a government-sanctioned team, appealing to each one's need for redemption or legitimacy. That same night, Porcelain — a high-ranking operative from the global mercenary group Red Calf — arrives to demand Maya's help extracting someone (heavily implied to be Deathgirl) from Daedalus Correctional Facility, and casually purchases Hypeman for Red Calf's use, revealing how far Maya's web of obligations has spread. The Auditors infiltrate Rogue Wave's Jump distribution event at a Pennsport marina (Chs. 156–157), where Monkey Business reveals his supernatural contract-binding power — signing means total loyalty, with a quarter of the crowd already under his control. The operation explodes into a multi-sided brawl involving mind-controlled dealers, Patriot and Turbo Jett (who escalate the violence), and Soot deploying chemical smoke. Rogue Wave then hijacks NBC10 and the emergency alert system (Ch. 158) to broadcast their manifesto, claiming 30,000 contracted individuals in Philadelphia and declaring open war on the Kingdom. Jordan's reckless test at school (Ch. 159) — deliberately claiming Kingdom allegiance to provoke sleeper agents — exposes Officer Ridley as Rogue Wave-contracted, resulting in both Sam and Jordan being suspended.

The arc's climax unfolds across four chapters (161–164). From house arrest, the Auditors trace Tremont & Fairfax's corporate filings to Stheno Pharmaceuticals, a suspicious biomedical front company registered by T&F junior partner Martin Calloway near a known Kingdom location. Amelia provides new stealth costumes and gear, and the team infiltrates the Stheno warehouse on Trenton Avenue. The operation goes loud when Soot appears fighting Kingdom enforcers Bash and Lenny (forcefield generator), filling the warehouse with smoke. Argus Corps arrives for an off-the-books operation — Captain Devil tracks through smoke, Turbo Jett attacks with super-speed and heat, Miasma floods the space with toxic gas, and Patriot orders mass detention. Soot announces intent to release 80 cubic feet of stored chlorine gas to create a chemical chain reaction that will destroy the facility. Sam prioritizes rescuing a zip-tied security guard from the office upstairs; Patriot pursues her, crushing her ankle on the staircase before Jordan severs the stairs with spatial compression. Sam cuts the guard free, breaks the window, and jumps — landing on a cloak held by Jordan and Blink. The warehouse explodes behind them as the chemical chain reaction destroys the entire facility. The Auditors escape via taxi to South Street, laughing hysterically, as Sam glimpses what might be Soot watching from a nearby rooftop. The chapter — and Act One of the story — ends with emergency services rushing toward the explosion site.

Suicide bombers hold NBC10 hostage. Cafeteria erupts into chaos. 159 159.txt Jordan deliberately provokes Rogue Wave sleeper agents in the school cafeteria by climbing on a lunch table, demonstrating space manipulation powers, and claiming Kingdom allegiance. Officer Ridley reveals himself as contracted — attacks Jordan with taser and baton in zombie mode. Sam puts Ridley in a chokehold. Both Sam and Jordan suspended for one week. At home, Sam and Kate's roommate dynamic evolves — Kate reveals her "anonymous benefactors," Sam shares the suspension story. 160 160.txt Under house arrest, Sam watches Richardson announce Argus Corps on livestream: Patriot ("under short leash"), Turbo Jett, Miasma, and Captain Devil (dramatic appearance). Richardson declares "preemptive deterrence" strategy. Sam attempts to surveil Kate — pencil lead in door hinge fails, laptop camera eventually records Kate returning at 3 AM correlating with Soot sightings. Meaningful conversation with Ben Small about self-destructive tendencies: "live long enough to see it through." Team tracks Soot sightings via group chat. MR.5 mr-5.txt INTERLUDE — Document format. Confidential internal proposal for Argus Corps authored by Maya Richardson with legal review by Katherine Huang. Establishes Argus Corps as a Registered Superhuman Entity Organization under NSRA Special Directive 14-B. Details include: detention (but not arrest) powers, civilian oversight board, mandatory body cameras, proactive threat neutralization mandate. Cites 54% increase in metahuman crimes. Projects 50% gang activity reduction. Reveals broader operational scope than publicly acknowledged. 161 161.txt Auditors hold virtual meeting from house arrest. Discover Katherine Huang (Aaron's defense attorney) on Argus Corps paperwork. Jordan accesses Pennsylvania Department of State records, narrows 14,982 new LLCs to 74 suspicious matches. Key finding: Stheno Pharmaceuticals, registered by Tremont & Fairfax junior partner Martin Calloway near a known Kingdom location, claims to develop "novel analgesics" through "lab-grown bioreactors." Team decides to investigate the warehouse. Sam acknowledged as de facto Auditors leader. 162 162.txt Mission preparation: Amelia delivers new stealth costumes — Bloodhound suit with advanced helmet and gauntlet (blood spray + pepper spray), new helmets for Jordan, black stealth costume for Lily. Infiltration of Stheno Pharmaceuticals warehouse on Trenton Avenue: Jordan uses a cardboard box and space manipulation to get inside hours early, clones a security keycard. Team discovers chemical storage and processing equipment. Jordan steals USB drives. Mission compromised when Bash appears and smoke fills the warehouse — Soot is there. 163 163.txt Three-way warehouse battle. Soot fights Kingdom enforcers Bash and Lenny (forcefield generator with cyan-blue barriers). Sam tags enemies with pig's blood spray for tracking through smoke. Combat escalates — Lenny's forcefields trap Soot's smoke, Bash shows unusual restraint around chemical containers. Warehouse security responds. Jordan warns of limited time. Argus Corps arrives: Turbo Jett forces open the shutter, Patriot orders "detain the capes," Captain Devil clears smoke in his path and creates instinctual fear in Sam, Miasma floods the space with toxic gas. 164 164.txt Chaos reaches its peak. Soot encounters Captain Devil; Turbo Jett attacks Bash; Jordan creates spatial compressions for escape routes. Miasma intentionally avoids confronting Sam. Soot announces intent to release 80 cubic feet of chlorine gas to trigger a chemical chain reaction. Sam prioritizes rescuing a zip-tied security guard from the upstairs office. Patriot pursues Sam up the staircase and crushes her ankle; Jordan severs the stairs, dropping Patriot. Sam cuts the guard free with tooth-claws, breaks the window. Team escapes via taxi and moped as the warehouse explodes. Sam glimpses Soot on a nearby rooftop. End of Arc 10, Year Two, and Act One of the overall narrative.

docs.title: Themes
docs.text:
• The three-body problem — Philadelphia's conflict expands from a two-sided struggle into a chaotic three-way war between the Kingdom of Keys, Rogue Wave, and the state (via Argus Corps). The Auditors are caught between all three forces, hunted by criminals and government alike, unable to ally fully with any faction. The warehouse climax literalizes this: Kingdom enforcers, Argus Corps, and Soot all fight simultaneously while the Auditors try to escape with evidence.

  • Contracts, control, and consent — Monkey Business's binding contracts serve as the arc's central metaphor: people surrender autonomy in exchange for something they want (drugs, money, power). This mirrors Richardson's legislation (surrendering freedom for safety), the Kingdom's hierarchy (loyalty enforced through threat), and even Sam's implicit contract with heroism (sacrificing normalcy for responsibility). Everyone in Book 10 is bound by something they didn't fully understand when they agreed to it.

  • The outsider's burden — Official institutions consistently fail: the prison transport is ambushed, SARA bans the teenagers who are actually fighting crime, Argus Corps is staffed with morally compromised adults on an off-the-books leash. The Auditors — a group of high schoolers operating from a music hall — produce better intelligence than the DVDs and more meaningful disruption than the police, yet they're the ones getting arrested and suspended.

  • Investigation as weapon — Book 10 marks the Auditors' evolution from street-level vigilantes to intelligence operatives. Their most significant victories come not from fights but from following paper trails: Tremont & Fairfax's statistical anomalies, Stheno Pharmaceuticals' corporate filings, the USB drives stolen from the warehouse. The pen proves mightier than the fist — though the arc ends with an explosion, the real prize is data.

  • End of innocence / End of Act One — The arc closes Year Two and what the author calls "Act One (of Three)." The landscape has transformed completely from Book 1: organized crime operates at a national and international scale (Red Calf), the government fields its own cape team, the drug crisis has spawned supernatural mind-control networks, and Sam's teenage team is wanted by every faction. The warehouse explosion serves as both a literal and figurative detonation of the status quo — everything that comes next will be different.

docs.title: Threads Planted
docs.text:
• Monkey Business's contract-binding power — Rogue Wave's leader possesses a supernatural ability to create binding contracts with physiological and psychological compulsion; the mechanism, limits, and origin of this power are unexplored; contracts appear unbreakable (Chs. 156–158)
  • Rogue Wave's organizational structure and declaration of war — Rogue Wave reveals its full leadership (Monkey Business, Birthday Suit, Rush Order, Dr. Snake Oil, Dead Drop, Jackpot), claims 30,000+ contracted individuals in Philadelphia and 60,000 along the eastern seaboard (Jordan identifies both as likely inflated), hijacks NBC10 to broadcast a manifesto declaring war on the Kingdom (Ch. 158)
  • Soot as independent vigilante — A chemical-smoke-powered vigilante emerges who absorbs and releases gases, demonstrates martial arts proficiency, processes chemicals in abandoned warehouses, and claims motivation of helping their father; mounting evidence (build, schedule, regional focus, chemical knowledge, Kate's 3 AM returns, access to Sam's team chat) suggests Soot is Kate Smith, but neither confirms it openly (Chs. 150, 153, So.1, 159–160)
  • Argus Corps — Richardson's government-sanctioned superhero team (Patriot, Turbo Jett, Miasma, Captain Devil) operates under NSRA Special Directive 14-B with detention powers and mandatory body cameras, but its first field appearance is an off-the-books warehouse operation; the team's true scope exceeds public announcement (Chs. 160, MR.5, 163–164)
  • Porcelain and Red Calf — A global mercenary organization enters the story through Porcelain, who demands Maya help extract someone (heavily implied to be Deathgirl) from Daedalus Correctional Facility and purchases Hypeman for Red Calf's use; escalates the conflict to international scale (MR.4)
  • Stheno Pharmaceuticals and the Auditors' USB evidence — Kingdom front company registered by T&F junior partner Martin Calloway; warehouse destroyed by Soot's chemical chain reaction, but Jordan stole USB drives containing unknown evidence about Kingdom drug operations; the contents and their implications are unexplored (Chs. 161–162, 164)
  • Tremont & Fairfax connections — Major law firm handles a statistically outsized number of superhuman defense cases; connected to Aaron McKinley's funded defense, Stheno Pharmaceuticals' incorporation, and Argus Corps' legal paperwork via Katherine Huang; the full scope of the firm's role in Philadelphia's superhuman ecosystem is unexplored (Chs. 149, 151, 161)
  • Aaron McKinley's mysterious defense funding — "Concerned citizens for due process" financing Aaron's expensive defense through Tremont & Fairfax; source and motivation unknown (Ch. 149)
  • Bash's autoinjector enhancement — Kingdom enforcer uses a mysterious autoinjector substance (distinct from Jump or Fly) to dramatically enhance his existing powers, then appears at the Stheno warehouse showing similar enhancement; suggests Hypeman is being deployed at the street level (Chs. 154, 162–163)
  • Captain Devil's abilities — Argus Corps member can track through Soot's smoke and creates an instinctual fear response in Sam; the nature and full extent of his powers are unexplored (Chs. 163–164)
  • Miasma's selective behavior — During the warehouse battle, Miasma intentionally avoids confronting Sam, suggesting a hidden agenda or allegiance beyond Argus Corps' stated mission (Ch. 164)
  • Kate's anonymous benefactors — Kate Smith's father's debts are mysteriously paid off by anonymous donors, enabling their planned move; the source is unknown and Sam is skeptical (Ch. 154)
  • Officer Ridley and institutional infiltration — School security officer exposed as a Rogue Wave sleeper agent through Jordan's deliberate provocation; demonstrates how deeply contracted individuals have penetrated civilian institutions (Ch. 159)

docs.title: Threads Progressed
docs.text:
• Kingdom of Keys operations (planted Book 2) — The Kingdom rescues Mr. Nothing and Mudslide via an elaborate highway ambush, regaining key operatives lost in Book 8; operates Stheno Pharmaceuticals as a drug production front; deploys Bash with autoinjector enhancement at street level; loses the Stheno warehouse to Soot's chemical chain reaction but retains organizational infrastructure including the Lancaster steakhouse and Baltimore branch (RG.1, BM.2, Chs. 152, 154, 162–164)
  • Maya Richardson's political rise (planted Book 7, MR.1) — Richardson introduces the Superhuman Activity Regulation Act, successfully banning minor vigilantism (12-5 vote); forms Argus Corps as a government-sanctioned superhero team; meets with Red Calf's Porcelain, revealing her entanglement extends to international criminal interests; her approval rating takes a hit after Sam's public confrontation but she consolidates institutional power (Chs. 151–152, 160, MR.4, MR.5)
  • Rogue Wave mind control (planted Book 7, MR.1) — Expands from isolated trigger reactions to a fully revealed mass contract system; Monkey Business's supernatural binding power compels thousands of signatories; Officer Ridley exposed as a sleeper agent embedded in a school; Rogue Wave openly declares war on the Kingdom via broadcast manifesto (Chs. 156–159)
  • Jump/Fly drug crisis (planted Book 5, Ch. 73) — Jump distribution continues expanding with Rogue Wave using it as a recruitment tool; dealers sign binding contracts for distribution rights; the Kensington streets show worsening conditions; community defense groups ("neighbors with baseball bats") emerge as civilian response (Chs. 150, 154–157)

docs.title: Threads Resolved
docs.text:
• Mr. Nothing and Mudslide's imprisonment — The Kingdom successfully liberates both operatives from the prison transport through an elaborate highway ambush, resolving the question of whether and how the Kingdom would attempt a rescue; Captain Plasma is incapacitated, and the convoy is overwhelmed despite extensive precautions (planted Book 8 Ch. 135, resolved RG.1)
  • Young Defenders dissolution — The Superhuman Activity Regulation Act passes 12-5, formally banning minor vigilantism; the Young Defenders are dissolved as a team — Gossamer leaves superhero work, Connor departs for civilian life, Rampart joins the DVDs officially — while Sam and Blink refuse to quit and reconstitute as the Auditors (planted Book 6-7, resolved Chs. 151, 153)

docs.title: Book 11: Alarm Will Sound
docs.text: A teenage hero takes three bullets and jumps into a river to kill someone who was never real — and the person she's protecting is the one who broke her heart.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Book 11 opens in the early hours of April 27, with the Auditors eating at a South Street McDonald's, bloodied and elated after the Stheno warehouse explosion. Jordan reveals they stole USB drives and recommends a week of radio silence to avoid Kingdom ESP monitoring. Sam returns home to face her parents — confesses to the warehouse raid and receives new ground rules (school first, mandatory check-ins, grounded for the month) — then confronts Kate with the full weight of circumstantial evidence that she is Soot. Kate denies everything but Sam discovers her team chat left open on the laptop; she quietly changes protocols and waits. At DVD headquarters for her ankle, Sam receives an unexpected offer from Multiplex: combat training, no strings attached. Jordan reports the USB files are encrypted with military-grade RSA keys containing dense biochemical data beyond their ability to decipher.

Three weeks pass. Surveillance escalates around Sam — dark sedans, men in suits, new security officer at school. She enlists former teammates Akilah (Puppeteer) and Devonte (Playback), now apprenticing at Chambers & Woo Investigations, to decode the Kingdom data. They confirm the Tremont & Fairfax to Stheno Pharmaceuticals pipeline and agree to work pro bono. Meanwhile, Interlude MR.6 reveals Maya Richardson organizing the Kingdom's response: Boston branch dispatches Mr. Retribution and Mrs. Quiet — elite enforcers — to identify and punish whoever destroyed the Stheno warehouse. Maya authorizes "whatever means necessary," including against minors, with a two-week investigation timeline. Sam begins training with Multiplex, developing a jaw-clenching technique to absorb punches and later creating "Instant Armor" — overlapping tooth plates grown over her skin that shatter on impact but absorb blows, at the cost of severe dehydration and fatigue.

The arc's tension peaks across Chapters 170-174 in a sequence of escalating stakes. Kingdom enforcers Mr. Retribution and Mrs. Quiet intercept Sam on the street, offering up to $3 million for Soot's identity. After Mrs. Quiet fires a silenced gunshot to demonstrate her sound-nullifying power, Sam negotiates a counteroffer: she'll provide Soot's identity in exchange for a meeting with "Upper Management" and two Hypeman autoinjectors. She feeds them deliberately misleading physical descriptions (male, pink nail polish, wears a cup) and endures a blood oath via knife cut. That night, Sam warns Kate — who finally confirms she is Soot. Kate leads Sam to her safehouse (booby-trapped, full of chemical weapons manufacturing), confesses that she was clinically dead for 3 minutes and 42 seconds during the house fire, experienced visions she interprets as hell, believes her Catholic faith condemns her as a lesbian, and admits she's been in love with Sam for years. Sam theorizes the "hell vision" was actually Kate's power manifesting, gently explains she doesn't reciprocate romantically, and proposes they work together rather than Kate operating alone. Sam is then driven to Manhattan to meet Mr. Antithesis — the Kingdom's leader, who operates from a sterile office with obsessive cleanliness and sees everything as business transactions. Sam provides a mix of truth (Kate is Soot) and strategic falsehoods, obtains two Hypeman autoinjectors, and gives up Kate's former safehouse location as planned.

The climax — "Phase Two" — is the arc's centerpiece. Interlude So.2, narrated from Sam's perspective while impersonating Soot, follows an elaborate deception: the Auditors create a fake villain team called "The Washes" (Brainwash/Amelia, Powerwash/Lily, Mouthwash/Kate) who chase "Soot" (Sam) to Lardner's Point Park. Kingdom operatives arrive — including the unexpected Mr. Polygraph (lie detector) and Mr. Nothing alongside Retribution and Quiet. The plan survives: Akilah controls bodies from the Tacony-Palmyra Bridge with invisible telekinetic strings (faking Brainwash's mind-control), Devonte plays recorded Kate audio through Soot's mask (defeating Polygraph's powers since Sam isn't speaking), Crossroads calls real police on a 15-minute delay, and Jordan keeps the Bridge team hidden with space manipulation. When Polygraph demands to see "Soot's" face, Devonte triggers fake police sirens. In the chaos, Mrs. Quiet shoots Sam three times. The Washes throw her into the Delaware River. Underwater, dying, Sam injects the Hypeman autoinjector and loses consciousness.

Sam wakes clinging to a dock at the Wissinoming Yacht Club, teeth growing all over her body from the Hypeman, blood sense expanded to detect from vastly greater distances. The team recovers her, Tasha provides emergency medical care, and the Kingdom is confirmed to believe Soot is dead. Kate and Sam meet with Kate's father Liam, Sam's parents offer financial help, and Kate agrees to relocate to Center City as "Kay Smith." Before leaving, Sam challenges Kate to a final fight at their old basketball court — an extended, violent, emotionally cathartic sparring match at 3 AM that functions as goodbye, closure, and sublimated tension. Jordan departs for MIT's summer program by Greyhound bus, transferring Auditors leadership to Sam. She delivers the Stheno data and a Hypeman sample to the DVDs, where she discovers Kingdom tracking devices on the vials. The arc closes with anti-vigilante legislation spreading to five states and the federal level, Sam experiencing lingering Hypeman side effects (shaking hands, buzzing, headaches), and the realization that everything after this will be different.

docs.title: Themes
docs.text:
• Deception as survival — The arc's central operation is a nested series of lies: Sam lies to the Kingdom about Soot's identity, then lies while impersonating Soot, then her team fakes an entire villain group. Kate lied about being Soot for months. Sam withholds details of Kate's confession from her team. Even the "truth" Sam tells Mr. Antithesis is strategically curated. Survival in this world demands constant performance, and the cost is measured in bullets and river water.

  • Strategic evolution — Sam transforms from a punch-first vigilante to a strategic operative who negotiates with criminal enforcers, engineers multi-phase deceptions, meets with crime lords in Manhattan offices, and runs coordinated team operations requiring precise choreography. Multiplex's training embodies this shift: "powers fail, skills don't." The arc's victories come not from fighting harder but from thinking better.

  • The cost of protection — Every protective act exacts a devastating physical toll: Sam takes three bullets and nearly drowns to protect Kate's identity; Hypeman causes teeth to grow across her entire body; her hands shake and her head buzzes for days afterward. Protecting Kate requires Sam to betray her to the Kingdom with measured truths. Protecting the team requires Kate to abandon her identity entirely. Love, in this arc, is measured by what you're willing to lose.

  • Identity and transformation — Kate becomes "Kay Smith" with dyed hair and glasses. Soot "dies." Sam becomes Auditors leader. Jordan becomes an MIT student. Even Monkey Business is revealed as Lawrence Sullivan, Esq. — a lawyer drafting contracts with a fountain pen. Everyone is shedding one identity for another, and the arc asks whether you can ever truly kill the person you used to be (Kate acknowledges she'll keep fighting under a new name).

  • Enemies as mirrors — The three organizations evolve in parallel: Mr. Antithesis runs the Kingdom like a corporation (quarterly reports, cleanup operations, cost-benefit analyses); Sullivan runs Rogue Wave like a law firm (contract revision, retention metrics, power extraction as product development); Sam runs the Auditors like an intelligence agency (multi-phase operations, informants, disinformation campaigns). All three are becoming more sophisticated versions of themselves, and the sophistication makes them harder to tell apart.

docs.title: Threads Planted
docs.text:
• Mr. Antithesis revealed — The Kingdom's leader appears in person: clinical, obsessively clean (hand sanitizer, destroyed stress balls), sees everything as business transactions, spares Sam only because her powers don't cause "significant collateral damage"; his anti-power effect (from LTN.2 in Book 9) is confirmed but unexplored in the meeting context; his motivations and background remain opaque (Ch. 173–174)
  • Sam's Hypeman side effects — After injecting Hypeman to survive being shot, Sam experiences teeth growing across her entire body, dramatically expanded blood sensing, and lingering symptoms (shaking hands, buzzing sensation, headaches) that persist weeks later; whether these effects are permanent or escalating is unknown (So.2, Chs. 175, 177)
  • Sam's Instant Armor — New defensive technique: overlapping tooth plates grown over skin that shatter on impact but absorb blows; causes severe dehydration and fatigue; Multiplex recommends bloodwork to identify resource depletion; combat applications are still being developed (Chs. 169–170)
  • Kate / "Kay Smith" — Kate relocates to Center City under a new identity with dyed hair and glasses, but explicitly acknowledges she'll continue vigilante work under a new persona; her relationship with Sam is unresolved — love confessed but not reciprocated (Chs. 172, 176–177)
  • Kate's hell vision and power origin — Kate was clinically dead for 3:42 during the house fire and experienced visions of fire and smoke she interprets as divine damnation; Sam suggests it was actually her power manifesting; whether Kate's interpretation or Sam's is correct remains deliberately ambiguous (Ch. 172)
  • Department of Applied Anomalous Sciences — Government think tank near MIT that "slams people with weird superpowers together and see what science shakes out"; Jordan's internship implies they were given their scholarship because of their powers; the department's agenda and relationship to NSRA are unexplored (Ch. 168)
  • Rogue Wave contract revision — Sullivan drafts multi-stage response hierarchy replacing the violent compulsion clause Jordan exploited; new contracts include false information delivery and non-violent exit protocols; improved contracts will make Rogue Wave harder to detect and expose (LS.1)
  • Jackpot's power extraction and Jump variants — Jackpot's probability assessment power is painfully crystallized by Snake Oil, yielding 60 standard doses for new Jump drug variants; the extraction process and its implications for mass-producing custom powers are unexplored (LS.1)
  • Kingdom rebuilding Hypeman in Camden — Mr. Polygraph and Mr. Nothing assigned to coordinate with Xenograft on rebuilding production in Camden, New Jersey; the shift across state lines may complicate law enforcement jurisdiction (MR.7)
  • Anti-vigilante legislation expanding nationally — SARA spreading to state legislatures in Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan, Illinois, and New York; Representative Martin introduces federal Juvenile Superhuman Safety Act; Richardson orchestrating coordinated campaign (Chs. 177, MR.7)
  • Mr. Retribution and Mrs. Quiet remaining in Philadelphia — Boston enforcers ordered to stay and monitor Bloodhound; Maya doubts Soot's death was too "clean"; potential threat to Sam if the deception unravels (MR.7)
  • Sam's blood oath with the Kingdom — Mrs. Quiet cut Sam's palm and forced a handshake as a "blood oath"; given Monkey Business's contract-binding powers, the implications of any "agreement" in this world are potentially supernatural (Ch. 171)
  • Elias Franklin's disappearance — Derek mentions Elias's continued absence at the farewell party; no further context provided (Ch. 177)
  • Kingdom tracking devices on Hypeman — Sam discovers tracking devices embedded in the Hypeman vials Antithesis gave her; she crushes them, but the fact that they were planted suggests the Kingdom expected her to share the samples (Ch. 177)
  • Connor and Jordan's relationship — Connor arrives at the farewell party, revealing he and Jordan never actually broke up; Jordan's departure for MIT adds long-distance dimension (Ch. 177)

docs.title: Threads Progressed
docs.text:
• Kate Smith as Soot (planted Book 10, Ch. 153) — After months of denial, Kate finally confirms her identity during a 2 AM safehouse visit, confessing her motivations (religious guilt, love for Sam, "sin eating" philosophy), her near-death experience, and her chemical vapor powers. The Auditors engineer an elaborate fake death operation to remove Soot from the Kingdom's target list. Kate relocates as "Kay Smith" (Chs. 165, 172, So.2, 175–177)
  • Kingdom of Keys operations (planted Book 2) — Kingdom dispatches Boston enforcers to investigate the warehouse destruction, offers $3 million for Soot's identity, arranges Sam's meeting with Mr. Antithesis, confirms Soot's "death," and begins rebuilding Hypeman production in Camden; the organization demonstrates both reach (surveillance photos, family details) and vulnerability (buying information from a teenager) (MR.6, Chs. 170–174, MR.7)
  • Stheno Pharmaceuticals USB evidence (planted Book 10, Chs. 161–162) — Files confirmed encrypted with military-grade RSA keys containing dense biochemical data; Chambers & Woo identifies a technolect who could help but requires a federal warrant; data eventually delivered to the DVDs along with a Hypeman sample; Jordan mentions the files may relate to the autoinjectors (Chs. 165–168, 177)
  • Hypeman drug (planted Book 9, LTN.2) — Sam obtains two samples from Mr. Antithesis; uses one to survive gunshot wounds, experiencing dramatic side effects (teeth growth, enhanced blood sense); discovers Kingdom tracking devices in the vials; Maya assigns Camden production rebuilding; Porcelain's Red Calf purchase (from MR.4) has already expanded international demand (Chs. 171, 174, So.2, 175, 177, MR.7)
  • Sam's combat training and power development (planted various) — Multiplex training introduces jaw-clenching absorption and Instant Armor techniques; team researches shark adaptations; blood sensing experiments with Tasha; Multiplex challenges creative power use ("why only shark teeth?"); training interrupted by Kingdom confrontation (Chs. 169–170)
  • Maya Richardson's political rise (planted Book 7, MR.1) — Richardson expands anti-vigilante legislation from Philadelphia to five states plus federal level; manages Kingdom's response to warehouse and Soot's elimination; privately reflects on moral compromise ("They took something from me once"); Davis attempts to hold her accountable for Argus Corps' off-the-books operations (MR.6, MR.7, Ch. 177)
  • Rogue Wave operations (planted Book 10) — Sullivan revises contracts after Jordan's exposure, implementing multi-stage response hierarchy; Rush Order reports 22% distribution increase with 92% retention; Dead Drop monitors Kingdom's reduced operations; Jackpot's power extracted for new Jump variants; Sullivan views setbacks as "evolutionary pressure" (LS.1)
  • Jordan's MIT departure (planted Book 9, Ch. 136) — Jordan works on USB decryption remotely, mentions Department of Applied Anomalous Sciences internship, formally transfers all Auditors leadership and Music Hall admin to Sam, leaves for MIT summer program by Greyhound bus; revealed to still be dating Connor (Chs. 165–168, 177)
  • Sam's identity management (planted Book 1) — Kingdom enforcers show Sam surveillance photos proving they know she's Bloodhound; she meets Mr. Antithesis face-to-face in Manhattan; her civilian and cape identities are now fully known to the Kingdom's leadership (Chs. 170–174)
  • Ben Small and Rachel Small's awareness (planted Book 1) — Parents set ground rules after warehouse confession, accompany Sam to Chambers & Woo meeting, offer financial help for Smiths' relocation; increasingly integrated partners in Sam's hero life rather than oblivious bystanders (Chs. 165, 167–168, 175, 177)
  • The Auditors' operations (planted Book 7, Chs. 110–111) — Team executes their most complex operation: multi-phase plan with fake villains, coordinated deception, and five-person Bridge team. Music Hall lease secured under Sam's name. Sam formally becomes leader. Team demonstrates intelligence-agency-level operational sophistication (Chs. 165–177, So.2)
  • Playback and Marionette's PI work (planted Book 6, Ch. 100) — Akilah and Devonte take the Kingdom data investigation pro bono at Chambers & Woo; actively participate in the fake death operation from the Bridge; Akilah's telekinetic strings and Devonte's sound-stealing are essential to the deception's success (Chs. 167–168, 175)
  • Sam's self-destructive tendencies (planted Intermission 4.5) — Sam volunteers to be shot three times and thrown into a river to protect Kate; Ben confronted this pattern in Book 10; Nurse Sylvia warns about sustainability; the pattern deepens rather than resolves (So.2, Chs. 175–176)

docs.title: Threads Resolved
docs.text:
• Kate's identity as Soot — After months of mounting evidence (Books 10–11) and direct denial, Kate confirms she is Soot during a late-night safehouse visit, providing full motivation (religious guilt, love for Sam, near-death experience, "sin eating" philosophy) and operational details (chemical manufacturing, multiple dojos, booby-trapped safehouse) (planted Book 10 Ch. 153, resolved Ch. 172)
  • Soot as Kingdom target — The Kingdom's multi-million-dollar hunt for Soot is concluded through the elaborate Phase Two fake death operation: Sam impersonates Soot, is shot by Mrs. Quiet, and thrown into the Delaware River. Maya's team confirms the kill, though she privately suspects the operation was too "clean" (planted MR.6, resolved So.2/MR.7)
  • Jordan's MIT departure — Jordan physically leaves for MIT summer program by Greyhound bus, transferring all Auditors leadership, Music Hall administration, and operational responsibilities to Sam; their departure marks the end of the original partnership that founded the team (planted Book 9 Ch. 136, resolved Ch. 177)

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Book 12 opens three weeks after Kate's departure, with Sam adjusting to sole leadership of the Auditors. She's training with Multiplex at DVD headquarters — landing a hit on the electromagnetic Captain Plasma through strategic misdirection — and teaching boxing to her remaining team at the Music Hall, but Hypeman withdrawal episodes (headaches, tremors, alleviated only by cigarettes) are worsening. Amelia presents a new self-repairing costume with designated weak points for Sam's teeth, and the team transitions to intelligence-driven operations: civilian reconnaissance patrols, informant recruitment, and methodical evidence gathering.

The arc's first major thread follows the Auditors' investigation of a Jump distribution point at an abandoned Sunoco station on Longshore Avenue. A new informant named Darius tips them off; the team discovers active utilities and security cameras behind a shell company ("Horizon Development Group LLC"); and Sundial's psychometry confirms drug transactions. A night infiltration goes wrong when Marathon and his crew return, trapping Sam. She's captured by Dead Drop — a ferrokinetic enforcer who suspends her with metal chains — but the team extracts her through coordinated action: Blink's slingshot covering fire, Gossamer's secretly trained bullwhip, and Flashpoint's force fields. Rush Order arrives on motorcycle to extract Dead Drop, abandoning Marathon's crew. The team escapes with evidence before police arrive. That same morning, Rogue Wave hijacks a news broadcast to recruit a "mad scientist's assistant" for Snake Oil.

Interlude LS.2 reveals the recruitment process from the inside: Monkey Business and Snake Oil interview seventeen scavenger-hunt survivors at a Toyota dealership back office, rejecting institutionalized thinkers and mercenaries. Two candidates stand out — Pyrausta (Aurora Reyes, a self-taught fire chemist with a flame tulpa named Espada who has reverse-engineered Jump) and Chimera (Elias Franklin, a wheelchair-using biochemist and Fly user from the Philly Phreaks). Snake Oil also floats a potential collaboration with Dr. Necrosis, a German bioterrorist hiding in Chicago.

The political front escalates when Sundial warns Sam about Patriot's "Safer Streets Initiative" — a $500 bounty for reporting powered youth, announced on Fox News. Sam meets Bulldozer (Sean McNulty, the new leader of Pattinson's Pals) at Patty's Bar in South Philly to present evidence of Richardson's Kingdom connections. Bulldozer agrees to investigate independently. Meanwhile, Richardson visits Rachel Small at the library with thinly veiled threats about "extracurricular activities" and budget cuts. Rachel stands her ground and decides to testify against the anti-vigilante legislation in Harrisburg. Interlude RJ.1 shows Patriot receiving Bulldozer's intelligence, confronting Richardson at City Hall (where she provides plausible denials but triggers his suspicions through behavioral inconsistencies), and briefing his Argus Corps team — where Miasma privately warns him to be careful.

The arc's climax arrives when Rogue Wave hijacks the emergency alert system for a citywide Jump "scavenger hunt," throwing Philadelphia into chaos. Sam tracks Elias Franklin through the streets using Derek Taylor's blood sample, discovering a research station where Elias is testing Jump formulations in the field for Rogue Wave. Elias transforms into a snow leopard/vulture hybrid and escapes. Rush Order then ambushes Sam in a deliberately staged public fight designed as propaganda — crowds record as he systematically outmatches her. Sam's father Ben arrives, having tracked her via family sharing app, and confronts Rush Order with a handgun. Both men are wounded in the exchange of gunfire. "Gun Dad" goes viral.

Sam recovers at Jefferson Hospital with three cracked ribs and a sprained wrist while Ben undergoes surgery. Rachel extracts a promise from Sam to suspend Bloodhound activities during recovery. Interlude RS/DC/JF provides three perspectives: Rachel organizing a parents' support group and installing motion sensors on Sam's windows; Rush Order recovering in a Camden safehouse and confirming the fight was staged propaganda; and Jamila Fayad in Chicago, now operating as "Zephyr" in the Powered Youth Initiative, obsessively watching Sam's beating and debating whether to reach out. Gun sales spike 300%. Rush Order then releases a video declaring "Gun Dad" under Rogue Wave's protection — effectively painting a Kingdom target on Ben.

Sam breaks her promise and infiltrates Richardson's town hall at City Hall, confronting her in full Bloodhound costume with accusations about Richard Duvall's death and the T-Rex attack on the Small home. Richardson counters with a planted expert and sympathetic rhetoric, turning the crowd against Sam — until Rachel stands, identifies herself as "Gun Dad's wife," and reveals dozens of organized parents throughout the audience with protest signs reading "PROTECT POWERED YOUTH." The parent coalition catches Richardson off guard as it trends nationally with 20,000 signatures within hours. Captain Devil of Argus Corps intercepts Sam — revealing invisible talons, acidic blood, and four distinct powers — but she escapes via Flashpoint's force fields, a second-story window jump, and Blink's scooter extraction. At home, Sam's parents accept they cannot stop her from being Bloodhound but impose new boundaries: a tracker, library volunteering, and mandatory mission notifications.

Intermission VB.2 introduces Victor Blanc, Sam's estranged 72-year-old maternal grandfather, a long-haul trucker on I-81 in Virginia who receives mysterious texts about a granddaughter he didn't know existed. He decides to visit Philadelphia out of clinical curiosity rather than sentiment — someone with significant resources is deliberately bringing him into Sam's life.

docs.text: # File Summary 178 178.txt Three weeks after Kate's departure. Sam spars with Captain Plasma at DVD HQ — exploits his electromagnetic field by feigning a gunshot wound bleed, forcing him to drop his shield, then lands a tooth-knuckle punch. Plasma departs for New York (Kingdom-related, classified). Sam teaches boxing to Maggie and Tasha at the Music Hall, assuming leadership role. Withdrawal symptoms: headaches, hand tremors. Aaron McKinley sentenced to 38 years at Daedalus. 179 179.txt Late Monday, July 7. Amelia presents new self-repairing costume with designated tooth emergence points, hidden arm pocket, and air-circulating fabric. Sam, Maggie, and Tasha conduct civilian reconnaissance through Tacony. Encounter Tacony Community Patrol (red windbreakers, baseball bats); patrol recognizes Sam from Richardson confrontation. Severe Hypeman withdrawal episode — Tasha suggests cigarette, which partially alleviates symptoms (supporting stimulant withdrawal theory). Confront patrol harassing Darius over marijuana; Sam recruits Darius as informant about suspicious Sunoco station activity. Tasha objects to reckless recruitment of strangers. 180 180.txt Early July. Methodical investigation of abandoned Sunoco on Longshore Ave. Sam establishes three-confirmation verification process. Library research: station purchased by shell company "Horizon Development Group LLC," active utilities despite vacant status. Amelia's polaroid surveillance confirms security cameras and "Yellow Jacket Guy" (Marathon). Sam and Lily stake out from laundromat; observe Marathon arguing with man in red bomber jacket. Meet Darius, Ty, and Costello at Campbell Square Park — confirm activity, mention "orange glasses" person. Plan to use Sundial's psychometry for definitive confirmation. Sam bumps into surly goth girl on a bus. 181 181.txt Thursday, July 10, ~1 AM. Night infiltration of Sunoco with Sundial, Maggie, and Lily. Sundial's psychometry confirms drug transactions, identifies "Marathon," observes argument about territory. Marathon and three henchmen return — silent alarm triggered. Sam recognized as "the Big Bad Wolf of Tacony." Fight breaks out; Marathon shows Jump-enhanced resilience. Sam captured by Dead Drop — female enforcer suspending her with ferrokinetic metal chains. Tells Maggie and Sundial to run. Drop and Marathon debate killing Sam; Sam bluffs about DVD backup. Blink's slingshot strikes Drop's hand. 182 182.txt Continuation of Sunoco confrontation. Mysterious cracking sounds — Gossamer reveals hidden bullwhip expertise. Blink provides covering fire from rooftop. Rush Order arrives on motorcycle to extract Dead Drop, abandoning Marathon's crew. Sam released when Drop chooses escape. Team retrieves Jump evidence and escapes before police arrive. Regroup at Wawa in civilian clothes. Tasha identifies Rush Order and Dead Drop from the May broadcast as core Rogue Wave. Rogue Wave hijacks news: "Who wants to be a mad scientist's assistant?" 183 183.txt Same day, morning to late afternoon. Team watches Rogue Wave's recruitment broadcast — three meeting locations, candidates must carry Milton Friedman or Ayn Rand books. Sam sleeps nine hours, dreams of Liberty Belle and unfamiliar grandfather figure in endless concrete hallway with filing cabinets. Tasha tracks recruitment through HIRC and forums. Blink gathers intel from her family's police-frequented restaurant. Five finalists disappeared at One Liberty Place, likely bound by supernatural contracts. Team debates next moves: Kingdom, Argus Corps, Rogue Wave, regular crime. LS.2 ls-2.txt INTERLUDE — Monkey Business and Snake Oil POV. Seventeen candidates at Toyota dealership back office. Reject Melvin Broderick (too institutionalized), Jennifer Walsh/Blackout (mercenary), David Kim (suspicious military background), Dr. Rebecca Foster (ethics questions). Promising: Aurora Reyes/Pyrausta — self-taught fire chemist, reverse-engineered Jump, controls flame tulpa "Espada," discovers crystals do strange things to fire when burned. Discuss potential Dr. Necrosis collaboration (German bioterrorist in Chicago). Final: Elias Franklin/Chimera — wheelchair user, PhD biochemistry from Penn (incomplete), Fly consumer, Philly Phreaks member. Interview interrupted at cliffhanger. 184 184.txt Saturday, July 19. Sam teaches boxing behind Music Hall; neighborhood watches (Mrs. Miller brings lemonade). Lucy/Sundial arrives with warning: Bubble caught by police, Patriot's "Safer Streets Initiative" offers $500 bounties for reporting powered youth (announced on Fox News). Compass considering going underground; Sandman suggests standing down. Lucy proposes inter-team coordination and reaching out to Pattinson's Pals. Sam takes subway to South Philly, hyperaware of surveillance. 185 185.txt Same Saturday afternoon. Sam arrives at Patty's Bar on Wolf and 11th Street — entire bar falls silent "spaghetti western style." Bulldozer (Sean McNulty) gives her thirty seconds. Private back room: Sam accuses Richardson of Kingdom connections, cites Mrs. Z accompanying Mr. T-Rex in attack on Small house, legal connections via Tremont & Fairfax. Veiled threats about "extracurricular activities," budget cuts, "bad influences." Rachel stands her ground ("I think you're scared"), implies Richardson looks old. Camilla supports the plan. Sam arrives as family discusses. RJ.1 rj-1.txt INTERLUDE — Richard Johnson Jr./Patriot POV. Backstory: failed ASVAB three times, military career built on physical strength. Morning workout at Argus Corps HQ (350-lb barbell, 100 reps). Call from Bulldozer/McNulty — relays Bloodhound's accusation that Richardson is Kingdom. Evidence: Tremont & Fairfax representing both Argus Corps and Aaron McKinley, suspicious weather during T-Rex attack, Richard Duvall's death. Patriot confronts Richardson at City Hall — she laughs off allegations with plausible explanations but never addresses the weather. Briefs Argus Corps: Jett dismisses, Devil quiet, Miasma privately warns. Plans to confront Bloodhound publicly. 186 186.txt Friday, July 25, ~6–7:30 PM. Patriot confronts Sam at Mayfair basketball court in civilian clothes; neighborhood kids Malik and DeShawn provide public accountability. Sam notices Patriot may harbor doubts. At home: Camilla's Lexus in driveway. Parents and grandmother reveal Richardson's library visit. Rachel announces plan to testify; Camilla offers financial support. Pop-pop Moe arrives with dessert. Derek texts urgently — stabbed Elias to get blood for Sam's tracking ("you're the second-best tracker in Philadelphia"). Rachel drives Sam to South Philly. Rogue Wave hijacks emergency alert system: citywide Jump "scavenger hunt" with "contractors" ordered to interfere with police and Argus Corps. Chaos erupts. Derek must cage himself before sunset (8:20 PM werewolf transformation). 187 187.txt Same evening, ~8–10 PM. Sam changes into Bloodhound costume; sends reassuring lies to parents. Tracks Elias's distinctive orange-tinged blood through South Philly — methodical, purposeful path. Intervenes in Jump chaos: bodega fight, glowing-blue-hands woman, injured teenagers. Encounters Bulldozer and Parabellum. Follows trail to five-story storage facility: maps, notebooks with scientific data, surveillance equipment. Confronts Elias — he's testing Jump formulations for Rogue Wave, motivated by anarchist philosophy and medical trauma, promised lifetime Fly supply. "Genesis Births should've been greatest paradigm shift in human history." Elias transforms (snow leopard, vulture, other animals) and escapes across rooftops. Rush Order tackles Sam — "backup's here." 188 188.txt Same evening, ~9–10:30 PM. Rush Order ambushes Sam on South Street — theatrical, drawing crowd with recording devices and drones. Deliberate propaganda spectacle. Sam analyzes movement patterns via Multiplex training, identifies "tell" (must plant feet before accelerating). Systematically outmatched. Rush Order reveals ideology: "The system's broken, and we're tearing it down." Tells Sam to "stay in Tacony." Herds her back when she tries to flee. Ben Small arrives via family sharing app with handgun. Standoff, exchange of gunfire — both men wounded. Rush Order retreats with mangled shoulder. Bystanders (nurse, Mike in Eagles cap) provide first aid. Mike drives Sam and Ben to Jefferson Hospital. Emergency department overwhelmed with Jump casualties. Sam calls Rachel. "She's going to kill us both, isn't she?" 189 189.txt Night of July 25 through morning July 26. Jefferson Hospital. Sam: three cracked ribs, sprained wrist, reveals accelerated healing to medical staff. Ben in surgery for gunshot wound. Rachel arrives — reporters gathering, video trending, social media dubs Ben "Gun DILF." Pop-pop Moe escorted by police after speeding to hospital. Ben regains consciousness briefly. Rush Order spotted at Camden underground clinic. Both admitted overnight. Rachel extracts promise from Sam to suspend Bloodhound activities until Ben recovers. Lily waiting to visit. RS/DC/JF rs-dc-jf.txt INTERLUDE — Three POVs. §1 RACHEL: Organizes parents' support group at South Philly Library, fourteen attendees; creates secure communication network; installs motion sensors on Sam's windows; gun sales spiked 300% post-"Gun Dad"; debates implications with Camilla. §2 RUSH ORDER: Recovers in Camden safehouse; describes Sam's "teeth from knuckles" (compares to Wolverine); Snake Oil, Elias, and Monkey Business tend injuries; confirms fight was staged propaganda; team debates targeting Bloodhound again. §3 JAMILA: Now in Chicago, enrolled at university, operating as "Zephyr" in Powered Youth Initiative; assists Navy Pier storm barrier with wind powers; meets professional hero Whiteout; friend Sana reveals Jump has reached Chicago; brother Ahmed urges her to contact Sam; Jamila struggles with guilt over leaving but can't bring herself to call. 190 190.txt ~August 8–15. Two weeks of recovery under Rachel's watch. Tasha transforms Sam's bedroom into command center. Team continues limited surveillance: Rogue Wave expanding, Kingdom enforcers in suits, Argus Corps guarding armored transports. Bulldozer gone silent. Rush Order releases video declaring "Gun Dad" under Rogue Wave protection — Sam and Tasha recognize this paints Kingdom target on Ben. Sam resumes limited training with Multiplex (60% capacity). Amelia reinforces suit for healing ribs. Team scouts City Hall for Richardson's upcoming town hall. Rachel forbids Sam from attending. Sam triggers motion sensor deliberately, meets Lily with scooter at predetermined location. Captain Devil spotted on City Hall roof. 191 191.txt Evening, August 15. Sam enters town hall in Bloodhound costume through center aisle. Accuses Richardson of connection to Duvall's death (Checkers cashier testimony) and T-Rex attack on Small house (eyewitness). Richardson counters: planted Dr. Chambers cites neurological development against youth vigilantism; crowd turns against Sam. Security ordered to remove her. Rachel stands — identifies herself as "Gun Dad's wife," announces she is "the parent of a powered teen." Dozens of parents rise with protest signs: "PROTECT POWERED YOUTH," "MY CHILD IS NOT A WEAPON." Rachel announces September state hearing testimony. Richardson orders room cleared. Captain Devil intercepts Sam — invisible extendable talons, acidic blood, four distinct powers. Sam sprays diluted pig's blood to track invisible talons; cannot use teeth due to acid blood. Signals Lily for extraction. Slides under Captain Devil's attack, slips free of boot caught by talons. 192 192.txt Same evening, continuing. Sam flees through City Hall corridors one-booted. Cornered in stairwell — Captain Devil's invisible talons gouge marble floors. Maggie arrives with force fields, knocks Devil off balance. Sam jumps from second-story window onto awning; Maggie follows using force fields. Devil chooses not to pursue in public. Lily extracts on Amelia's scooter. Music Hall debrief: town hall footage trending nationally; Rachel's "Parents of Powered Kids" coalition launched website, 20,000 signatures in hours, chapters across Pennsylvania spreading to neighboring states. Councilman Davis texts: "Nice work tonight. -JD." Family confrontation: Rachel confirms she knew Sam would break promise (motion sensors tracked departure, not prevented it). Punishment: library volunteering five days/week, Ben's physical therapy help, tracker at all times, mission notification required. Parents express grudging pride. Coalition gaining national momentum. VB.2 vb-2.txt INTERMISSION — Victor Blanc POV. 3:17 AM, I-81 in Virginia. 72-year-old long-haul trucker with cats Box and Coal. Reflects on 1989 dock-worker violence, revealing calculating nature. Mysterious texts (3:20–4:22 AM): unknown person mentions "family in Philadelphia," granddaughter Samantha — Victor learns she exists for the first time. Struggles to remember Ben Small's name. Decides to visit out of clinical curiosity, not sentiment. Recalls Rachel's wedding (felt "nothing," got into a fistfight, drank at the edges). Contacts dispatcher Maeve — mysterious person already arranged time off. Delivers to Harrisonburg depot. Feels unusual anticipation, acknowledges this as "very weird." Someone with significant resources is engineering this reunion.

docs.title: Themes
docs.text:
• Leadership without a safety net — Sam loses every person who previously shared the weight: Jordan at MIT, Kate in hiding, Captain Plasma departing for New York. What remains is a team of teenagers who look to her for training, strategy, and courage she doesn't fully possess. She teaches boxing techniques she learned weeks ago. She runs intelligence operations modeled on spy movies and TV cop procedurals. She builds an informant network out of a stranger in a park. The arc's central question is whether competence born from desperation can substitute for experience — and the answer, terrifyingly, is "sometimes."

  • The family as political unit — The Small family transforms from bystanders to active combatants on multiple fronts: Sam fights in costume, Ben fights with a gun, Rachel fights with a coalition and testimony. Richardson's mistake is threatening Rachel at her library — the intimidation that was meant to isolate instead galvanizes. When Rachel stands in the town hall audience and identifies herself as "the parent of a powered teen," she weaponizes the one thing Richardson's legislation cannot account for: a mother willing to go public. The arc argues that families are not collateral damage but infrastructure.

  • Propaganda and spectacle — Every faction now fights on camera. Rush Order stages his fight with Sam for drones and phones, calculating media impact. Rogue Wave's recruitment is performance art. Richardson hosts town halls that double as legislative theater. The parent coalition launches a website that goes viral. "Gun Dad" becomes a cultural symbol overnight. Even Sam's town hall entrance — walking down the center aisle in full Bloodhound costume — is calculated spectacle. The war for Philadelphia is increasingly a war for narrative.

  • Institutional mirroring — Each faction builds parallel infrastructure: Sam runs an intelligence operation with informants, surveillance, and psychometric confirmation; Monkey Business conducts formal job interviews with technical assessments and cultural-fit evaluations; Richardson deploys bounty systems, planted experts, and coordinated town halls; Patriot maintains a paramilitary hierarchy with research assignments and team briefings. All four organizations are becoming more sophisticated versions of the same thing — institutions competing to define legitimate power.

  • The cost of curiosity — Elias Franklin became a Rogue Wave operative because he asked "what if Genesis Births could be democratized?" Rush Order stages fights because he believes "the system's broken and we're tearing it down." Even Victor Blanc's decision to visit Philadelphia stems from clinical curiosity about inherited temperament. The arc's villains are not stupid or evil but dangerously curious — people who followed interesting questions to monstrous conclusions. Sam's own curiosity drives her to investigate, infiltrate, and confront, and the bill comes due in cracked ribs and a father in surgery.

docs.text: A teenager discovers that the dead hero she inherited has enemies who are still alive — and one of them just broke out of prison with a grudge, a swastika carved into his own chest, and a very specific idea about what "finishing Belle's work" means when the successor is Jewish.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Book 13 opens with Sam adjusting to her new restrictions: library volunteering, tracker, and mission notifications. Her punishment yields an unexpected discovery when she begins digitizing the Morrison Collection — 73 boxes of superhuman history in Philadelphia dating back decades, containing documentation of early vigilante teams, government regulation attempts, and cyclical patterns of powered-youth suppression. Sam proposes adding Liberty Belle's notebooks to the collection and discovers Belle was investigating Daedalus Correctional Facility, where Pop-pop Moe's engineering firm Horvath-Small Ltd. designed concerning isolation features. Belle's notes reference a consultant named "Espinosa" — later identified as Porcelain.

The political storyline culminates at the Harrisburg state senate hearings. Rachel's "Parents of Powered Kids" coalition organizes coordinated protests across 14 northeastern cities. Rachel delivers powerful testimony; Senator Martin tries to leverage the crisis when explosions hit the Boston protest (actually an Activation incident triggered by police kettling). At 3:13 AM on September 10, an emergency alert announces a breach at Daedalus Correctional Facility. Interlude MR.8 reveals the backstory: Porcelain — "the strongest superhuman on Earth" and leader of Red Calf — forced the Kingdom to assist in extracting Daisy Zhen / Deathgirl, a 13-year-old with power-copying abilities. The operation was deliberately timed during the hearings. Interlude BM.3 shows Blake Matthews / Mr. Tyrannosaur attending the planning session at a Staten Island restaurant, where Kingdom operatives express deep unease about being forced into collaboration with Red Calf. Interlude EW.1 follows the extraction team underground: Mr. Mudslide tunnels beneath Daedalus, they reach Deathgirl's cell, but she wakes prematurely and copies multiple powers simultaneously — Mudslide's liquefaction, Vector's telekinesis, Mrs. Synapse's nerve manipulation — escaping into lower tunnels. Tarbaby reveals he planted a tracker on her.

Interludes DZ.2 and DZ.3 follow Daisy's journey from the flooded tunnels to Albany, where she reunites with her parents. Legal battles ensue: her attorney Patricia Gilly secures a compromise — placement at the Whitford Institute in Chicago (the only specialized facility for powered youth) rather than return to Daedalus. A mysterious man with a braided beard watches from the courtroom (Porcelain). Back in Harrisburg, the anti-vigilante legislation fails 11-9 after Senator Cho casts the deciding vote, a political victory for the coalition.

The family storyline detonates when Sam and Rachel return home to find Victor Blanc's truck parked outside. Sam's first meeting with her grandfather reveals a calculating, emotionally flat man who immediately identifies her scars as fighting marks and recommends autism/ASPD testing, sending Rachel into a protective fury. Sam defies her mother's explicit prohibition to visit Victor at his hotel, where he reveals his 1983 stroke fundamentally altered his personality (volatile before, emotionless after), admits to hitting Rachel, shows mysterious Kingdom-arranged texts, and reveals Rachel has a brother named David de Leon. Victor has seven other children and twelve grandchildren he rarely contacts. Sam hugs him on the way out.

The arc's final threat escalates methodically. Dead birds appear throughout northeast Philadelphia with precise puncture wounds — expanding neighborhood by neighborhood in a systematic search pattern. The kills progress from birds to patterns to a bloodhound dog impaled on a streetlight with "WHERE ARE YOU?" painted beneath it. Sam identifies the killer as Niles Nolan / Shrike, one of Liberty Belle's first captures, a Daedalus escapee with spike-creation powers and explicitly anti-Semitic motivations. His elaborate hostage operation — seventeen mannequins at an abandoned church, a homeless man trapped in a barbed-wire-wrapped dumpster, dozens of false leads on gemstone-named streets — is designed to identify Bloodhound rather than maximize harm. Shrike invades the Small home at 3:17 AM, threatens to prevent Sam's parents from having more children, reveals he's "seeded" the house with delayed-activation spikes, and demands Sam leave an "invitation" at the Metropolitan Opera House for their final confrontation. The family evacuates.
